lead_paragraph: “Parker: The Score,” an adaptation of a Richard Stark novel by the cartoonist Darwyn Cooke, is new to the graphic books hardcover best-seller list this week at No. 7. The story centers on Parker, a coldhearted thief who is planning his biggest heist yet: stealing everything of value from an isolated small town in North Dakota. As in past stories, Parker doesn’t suffer fools, is brutally efficient and doesn’t let any emotional ties get in his way. All of which makes reading “The Score” completely delectable. It’s a perfect companion to “The Hunter” and “The Outfit.” Parker may be tough and icy, but he still somehow has charms, à la George Clooney in “Ocean’s Eleven.” The fourth Parker adaptation is due next year.

abstract: “In Paris,” a stage adaptation of a short story by the Nobel Prize-winning writer Ivan Bunin, stars Mikhail Baryshnikov as a former general in the White Russian Army.

The most mundane tasks — the morning shave, or hanging up your hat and coat in a cafe — become drawn-out rituals that fill out the hours lying heavy in your hands. headline: C.D.C. Reports Outbreak of Swine Flu
abstract: Federal health officials reported a new outbreak of swine flu on Friday, mostly among children who appeared to have picked up the virus at county fairs.
lead_paragraph: Federal health officials reported a new outbreak of swine flu on Friday, mostly among children who appeared to have picked up the virus at county fairs. Sixteen people have become infected with the H3N2 swine flu virus over the past three weeks, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said. There were 12 cases in 2011. The new flu has a gene from the 2009 pandemic strain that officials are monitoring because it could make the illness more contagious. So far it has only been picked up from pigs and has not been passed from person to person, said Joseph Bresee, a doctor in the influenza division at the agency.

headline: Pakistan: Contempt Law Rejected
abstract: Chief Justice Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry called the law, which provided greater protection to the prime minister and other senior government officials against such charges, unconstitutional and contrary to the independence of the judiciary.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Friday struck down a controversial law that the governing party had hoped would help fend off contempt charges against Prime Minister Raja Pervez Ashraf. Chief Justice Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry called the law, which provided greater protection to the prime minister and other senior government officials against such charges, unconstitutional and contrary to the independence of the judiciary. In June, the court ousted Yousaf Raza Gilani, then the prime minister, after he refused to support the reopening of a corruption investigation against President Asif Ali Zardari in Switzerland. The law struck down on Friday was introduced by the Pakistan Peoples Party in July to shield Mr. Gilani’s successor, Mr. Ashraf, from a similar fate. The court gave Mr. Ashraf until Wednesday to ask Swiss authorities to reopen the case against Mr. Zardari. He has given no indication that he plans to do so.

headline: China: Muslim Fasting Discouraged

lead_paragraph: Several local governments in the western region of Xinjiang have ordered Muslim restaurants to stay open during the holy month of Ramadan and are telling civil servants and students to continue to eat and drink during daylight hours, when Muslims generally fast. Ramadan began on July 20. A notice on the Web site of the health bureau of Urumqi, the regional capital, said local officials had discussed “increasing eating and drinking during Ramadan” and were urged “to increase the monitoring of collective eating with supplied food at work units.” The goal was to “guarantee the health of the masses,” the posting said. Local governments have been putting in place such policies for several years. Southern Xinjiang and Urumqi have a large number of Uighurs, Muslims who often express discontent with ethnic Han, who dominate China.

headline: Panama: President Ends Blockade at Newspaper

lead_paragraph: It took the intervention of President Ricardo Martinelli and a chief of the national police to end a blockade of the newspaper La Prensa on Friday by scores of workers from one of Panama’s largest construction companies. The workers from the Transcaribe Trading Company used 30 trucks to surround the offices of the newspaper, which has published investigative articles about the company, reporting that it had received millions of dollars in favorable government contracts. La Prensa has a long history of reporting on corruption and has clashed with the president, although his office released a statement condemning the workers’ action. A representative of the company did not respond to a request for comment, but its Web site includes videos of workers denouncing La Prensa. Lourdes de Obaldía, the editor of the newspaper, said the protest did not prevent the publication of the newspaper, but she called the blockade, which lasted several hours, part of a rising number of actions aimed at intimidating the news media in Panama.

headline: Where South Beach Meets Inwood
abstract: Eight friends gathered at La Marina on Dyckman Street in time for happy hour; they lingered through the sunset and a meal.
lead_paragraph: A misty, not-quite-full moon hung over the railroad tracks on Tuesday and peered quizzically onto an expansive new waterfront spot in Upper Manhattan, featuring candlelit cocktail tables, twinkling lights, a beach bar with beds and a covered 200-seat restaurant. La Marina in Inwood, open for a month, seems to be trying for a Miami-on-the-Hudson vibe, but it’s still closer to the South Bronx than South Beach. The incongruity of such a sprawling paradise at the end of Dyckman Street, several blocks from the A train, past broken glass and bingo players, never quite disappears. On weekends, the deck and beach bars are jammed, but this weeknight, the atmosphere was just comfortably buzzing. Patrons smoked hookah pipes in the patio lounge while a modest band played. Diners watched the sun set behind the Palisades, summoning still-learning wait staff. Firefighters, police officers, bankers, romantics, families and old friends converged for the scene and the company. Jet Skis whined on the river, kayakers glided in the moonlight and the George Washington Bridge burst into crystals of light, making the spectacular setting worth the trip.

abstract: With the planet, and particularly cities, becoming ever more crowded, there’s nowhere to grow but up.
lead_paragraph: In the sizzling summer heat I’ve been thinking about igloos. To chill out in, of course, but also because I admire their elemental simplicity. Inuits traditionally used bone knives to carve bricks from quarries of hardened snow. A short, low tunnel led to the front door, trapping heat in and keeping out fierce cold and critters. Mortar wasn’t needed, because the snow bricks were shaved to fit, and at night the dome ossified into a glistening ice fort. The human warmth inside melted the ice just enough to seal the seams.

headline: ‘Total Recall’ Remake Struggles at Box Office

But moviegoers weren’t feeling it: “Total Recall” took in about $26 million at North American theaters over the weekend, a distant second behind “The Dark Knight Rises,” which was No. 1 for the third weekend in a row, with about $36.4 million in ticket sales ($354.6 million total over three weeks).

headline: If This Dancer’s Amigas Could See Her Now

lead_paragraph: The 1966 musical (and 1969 movie) “Sweet Charity” gets a Latin makeover in the director Julio Agustin’s production at the New Haarlem Arts Theater, and it’s called for. The original could use some salsa. With its picaresque and coincidence-filled narrative; somewhat flighty title character (a lovelorn floozy, if not a prostitute, with a heart of gold); and principal setting (a dime-dance joint, already an anachronism in mid-’60s New York), the musical, originally staged by Bob Fosse, is itself a watered-down version of Fellini’s “Nights of Cabiria,” which actually did concern a prostitute and gritty issues like physical and emotional abuse and an existential take on religion. “Sweet Charity” was never one of Fosse’s more provocative shows, and Neil Simon’s quip-packed book seems sitcom-ready in retrospect.

abstract: The Supreme Court should hear a Maryland case that raises important questions about whether the collection of DNA samples from people arrested but not yet convicted violates the Fourth Amendment.

The Supreme Court should take up this case, but there was no good reason for the chief justice to allow the police to continue collecting DNA while the case is on appeal.

headline: Vote of Confidence
abstract: The romantic clothes of Mimi Plange have obvious first-lady appeal.
lead_paragraph: “I kept asking myself, ‘Is that really my skirt?’ ” Mimi Plange recalls of the time she saw Michelle Obama wearing a periwinkle gabardine skirt from her spring collection during an appearance on “The View” in May. “And it was. And it looked great. And I felt really, really blessed.” In her fifth season, the 34-year-old Plange, who was born in Ghana and grew up in California, has joined the ranks of White House-approved designers, including Thakoon Panichgul, Jason Wu and Carly Cushnie and Michelle Ochs of Cushnie et Ochs, with clothes that have obvious first-lady appeal: they are romantic (corseted organza dresses in an hourglass silhouette, top left, $2,900; Esti’s, 718-645-2600), mature (Victorian silk blouses with velvet trim) and practical (lots of A-line skirts). “I am catering to every woman’s body from a female perspective,” Plange says. “It’s not about me or what I want to wear; it’s about wearable, real fantasy for real women.” And although Plange admits that she had never really watched “The View” — “I’m still not sure what the episode was all about because I couldn’t pay attention,” she says — she’s now a fan of the show and its star guest for life.

headline: A Provençal Reunion, With Vegetables at the Center of the Plate
abstract: The south of France lures a group of friends back again and again, but dishes celebrating the region’s summer produce can be replicated almost anywhere. Today: a grain salad with tomatoes, broad green beans and a tangy dressing.
lead_paragraph: Last month I had a reunion in Provence with friends who discovered this magical region of France with me more than 30 years ago. It was a true southern French vacation – we relaxed, we went to the market, we cooked. Market stalls were piled high with summer squash, tomatoes and eggplant, green beans — both regular ones and the flat ones that we call romano beans and that my Provençal market labeled cocos — onions of all kinds, braids of plump pink garlic, and leeks. Even the supermarket produce sections were inspiring. We bought short-grain rice from the Camargue, southwest of our area of Provence, for our risottos, and a local wheat berry called petit épeautre for chewy pilafs and grain salads. We ate peaches, apricots, amazing strawberries and melons for dessert and for breakfast.

headline: American Ballet Theater Announces Apprentice Program
abstract: The company has announced the creation of a program for six dancers to work as apprentice members of Ballet Theater’s corps de ballet.
lead_paragraph: Developing young dancers will be a new focus at American Ballet Theater. The company has announced the creation of a program for six dancers to work as apprentice members of Ballet Theater’s corps de ballet, Kevin McKenzie, the artistic director, said on Monday. The selected dancers will train under Kate Lydon, ABT Studio Company’s artistic associate, and Clinton Luckett, ABT’s Ballet master, for 10 weeks beginning in September, and they will then advance to apprentice level with American Ballet Theater during the company’s performances of “The Nutcracker” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. According to the announcement, training will provide full immersion into the ballets in ABT’s repertory, including tutorials in ballet story lines, history, style and mime. In addition, dancers will attend seminars in hair and makeup and company etiquette in preparation for entering the main company. The dancers will be selected first from among the students at the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis School, second from among Summer Intensive students and by audition. Their apprenticeship will continue throughout ABT’s performance season ending July 2013.

headline: Between the Devil and the Deep Blue Sea
abstract: A new book and exhibit recount the proud history and sad fate of the S.S. United States, which for a time was the fastest and most advanced ocean liner ever built.
lead_paragraph: There’s some sadness in the story of the S.S. United States, which for a time in the 1950s and 1960s was the fastest and most advanced ocean liner ever built. It was the lifelong project of William Francis Gibbs, America’s preeminent naval architect, a self-taught engineer who, among his many other achievements, was instrumental in transforming a German liner captured during World War I into the Leviathan, the pride of America’s postwar passenger fleet. Then, during World War II, he pioneered a revolutionary process to construct the so-called Liberty Ships, which became symbols of America’s industrial might. All along, Gibbs nursed plans to build a revolutionary superliner. But his designs, hatched in his parents’ Philadelphia attic as early 1916, were not realized until 1952. Ten years after its christening, his transatlantic ship would prowl the icy North Atlantic as a kind of floating anachronism, jet planes having turned its record three-day, 10-hour crossing time into a sorry joke. Such is the sweep of “A Man and His Ship” (Simon & Schuster, $30) an absorbing, transporting new history by Steven Ujifusa, which coincides with a show about the S.S. United States now on view at the Forbes Gallery (through Oct. 20).

lead_paragraph: Sharon Osbourne, below, has repeated her threat to leave the hit NBC summer series “America’s Got Talent,” though the network continues to treat her comments as less-than-official positioning for the future. Ms. Osbourne told The New York Post that she was quitting the show over a dispute involving her son, Jack, who was in discussions to appear in another NBC reality competition, “Stars Earn Stripes,” before he was found to have multiple sclerosis earlier this year. The show involves strenuous physical activity and requires that contestants pass a physical exam. An NBC spokeswoman said there had never been a contract with Jack Osbourne for “Stars Earn Stripes.” Ms. Osbourne told The Post there had been an oral commitment for him to take part in the show. The network is taking no public position about Ms. Osbourne’s future participation on “America’s Got Talent,” except to restate that she has a contract with the show, one she renegotiated last year.

headline: Zambia: Chinese Supervisor Dies During Protest at Mine

lead_paragraph: Workers striking at a Chinese-owned coal mine killed a Chinese supervisor when they hit him with a coal trolley, officials of the mine workers’ union said Monday. Employees at the Collum Coal Mine staged a protest over the weekend, demanding that their pay be raised to match Zambia’s new minimum wage for laborers of about $230 a month, which was announced last month. China has invested heavily in Zambia, a major producer of copper, coal and other minerals. Chinese companies in Zambia have long been accused of mistreating and underpaying their workers, and violence has broken out at the Collum mine during labor disputes in the past. President Michael Sata was elected last year on a largely anti-China platform, but has softened his position since taking office.

headline: Russia: Suicide Bombers Strike at Military Unit in Chechnya
abstract: Suicide attacks against a military vehicle left four people dead and wounded three on Monday on the outskirts of Grozny, the capital of Chechnya, in Russia’s volatile North Caucasus region.
lead_paragraph: Suicide attacks against a military vehicle left four people dead and wounded three on Monday on the outskirts of Grozny, the capital of Chechnya, in Russia’s volatile North Caucasus region. A spokesman for the Russian Interior Ministry said two suicide bombers ambushed an armored military van near a police checkpoint outside of the city. The dual explosions killed three members of a military unit and wounded three others. A fourth body, presumed to be that of one of the bombers, was also found at the scene. The bombing is the first suicide attack in Grozny in nearly a year. Moscow has been battling separatists in Chechnya since the 1990s, but a leader backed by the Kremlin has cracked down on the insurgency.

headline: ‘Thus,’ Just So
abstract: “Thus,” meaning “in this way” or “therefore,” is an adverb. “-Ly” is a suffix that turns an adjective into an adverb. Since “thus” is already an adverb, it has no need for “-ly.” So “thusly” is unnecessary — colloquial at best, illiterate in the view of many readers. Yet we’ve used “thusly” 10 times in the last year, including two days in a row last week. Let’s be careful.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Sikh Temple Shooter’s Hate-Filled Music, and the Apple-Google Chill

Kovaleski report. In an interview posted on the Web site of the record company Label56 (and since taken down), Mr. Page mentioned going to Hammerfest, an annual white-supremacist festival; he also said he played in various neo-Nazi bands, including Blue Eyed Devils, whose song “White Victory” includes the lines: “Now I’ll fight for my race and nation/Sieg Heil!”

abstract: Designer Markus Lupfer and Asos.com have collaborated on a 10-piece, all leather, kaleidoscope-patterned collection.
lead_paragraph: For years the London-based designer Markus Lupfer and the British retailer Asos.com have made cool and quirky clothes for women — at very different price points (Lupfer, high; Asos, low). Now they’ve gone into business together and are meeting in the middle, offering a 10-piece, all leather, kaleidoscope-patterned collection for the Asos Black label (available in October). “I love the cutout skater dress,” Lupfer says. “It is so cute and fun.” Along the lines of Lupfer’s own ready-to-wear brand — which features glitter-bombed cocktail dresses and loudmouthed graphic tops — Asos Black includes tailored track pants, boxy shell tops, hot-shorts and pencil skirts, as well as pouchettes and utilitarian heels to complete the look. The collaboration hits what Lupfer calls the “nonintimidating” (read: cost-effective) side of high fashion, which is probably why he can comfortably add, “The girls in my office want it all.”

headline: Elizabeth’s Braised Leeks With Parmesan
abstract: The sophisticated flavors and textures that this dish offers may convert those who think they don’t like leeks.
lead_paragraph: My friend Elizabeth tells me that even people who think they don’t like leeks like this dish. The leeks are braised in wine and water or stock until soft and golden, then topped with Parmesan and run under a broiler, so you get a crunchy layer on top of soft cooked leeks. One of the tricks here is to discard the outer layers that become papery when you cook them, so that the whole leek will be soft and easy to cut through.

The checks are rebates from insurers that did not spend at least 80 percent of the premiums they collected from small group plans on either actual health care expenses or improving the quality of health care, a provision known as the medical loss ratio rule.

headline: Alongside Rudolph’s Ilk, Yoiking in Lapland
abstract: In America, the reindeer is more akin to a mythical creature, like a unicorn. In Inari, the capital, of the Finnish Sami, it is a ubiquitous presence, sometimes found wandering even in the middle of town.
lead_paragraph: Nils-Heikki Paltto is far from the only reindeer herder who hates wolverines, loves the solitude of tracking his herd on snowmobile during the dim Arctic winter, and knows how to yoik, a form of singing that falls somewhere between a chant and a yodel. Yoiking is the unique tradition of his Sami people, the indigenous group that populates (minimally) the northern stretches of Norway, Sweden and Finland that we call Lapland.

headline: The Quotable Robert Hughes

headline: One on One: Steve Mann, Wearable Computing Pioneer

lead_paragraph: Philip Marlowe is making another comeback. Henry Holt & Company said on Tuesday that Raymond Chandler’s creation, one of the world’s most famous private eyes, will star in a novel written by John Banville to be published in 2013.

headline: Vain Glorious | The Seaweed Secret
abstract: Repêchage has introduced its first hair treatment, perfect for Montauk-loving mermaids whose hair needs some help after a beachy weekend.
lead_paragraph: Who: Repêchage Beauty From the Sea.

headline: Capturing the Winter Songs of Rare Whales
abstract: Recording their screeches and whistles, researchers form theories on where the Spitsbergen bowheads breed in the Arctic winter blackness.
lead_paragraph: Between Greenland and the northern island of Spitsbergen, Norway, in the blackness of the Arctic winter, a group of rare whales sing in ghostly screeches and drawn-out creaks, eerie whistles and hollow screams, day in, day out, in the ice-laden water.

headline: How ‘Mildred Pierce’ Explains the World
abstract: In “How to Be Gay,” David M. Halperin argues that when it comes to defining what it means to be a homosexual man, sex is overrated.
lead_paragraph: The four most overrated things in life, Christopher Hitchens once said, are “Champagne, lobsters, anal sex and picnics.” This remark was repeated at his memorial service this past April in New York City. The next speaker was the British comic Stephen Fry, who is out and proud. “Well,” he commented, “three out of four isn’t bad.”

headline: On Its Centenary, Celebrating a Ride That Advanced Physics
abstract: On the 100th anniversary of the discovery of cosmic radiation by the physicist Victor F. Hess, he is remembered by his grandson.
lead_paragraph: BAD SAAROW-PIESKOW, Germany — Precisely where Victor Hess, his electroscopes and his hot-air balloon touched down is a mystery.

headline: What Influences Consumers to Buy or Rent Their Homes
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Eight-five percent of people say that owning makes more sense than renting. Why would they feel that way after the housing crisis?
lead_paragraph: Even the deepest housing crisis since the Great Depression wasn’t enough to dampen Americans’ desire to own their homes.

headline: British Brothers Dominate Triathlon
abstract: Alistair Brownlee was first and his brother Jonny finished third, giving Britain its first medals in the event.
lead_paragraph: Alistair Brownlee was first and his brother Jonny finished third, giving Britain its first medals in the event.

headline: Six-Second Goalkeeper Rule Proves Baffling to Many
abstract: A referee’s call during the Canada-United States semifinal in women’s soccer prompted debate as to the cited rule’s usefulness.
lead_paragraph: The critical, controversial call that helped the United States women’s soccer team score the tying goal in its overtime victory over Canada may not have been wrong, but that does not mean it was right, either.

headline: Sipping on a Sunset, Italy in Mind
abstract: A slightly bitter, go-down-easy Italian aperitif has found its way into bartenders’ flutes and highball glasses from Los Angeles to London.
lead_paragraph: JUST as the culinary cognoscenti press us into embracing certain food trends (“You will eat pork belly! Love cupcakes now! Hate cupcakes now!”) so, too, do they dictate our drinks.

headline: The Caucus Click: A Hug for Caray
abstract: Mitt Romney gave a hug to Dutchie Caray, wife of the Chicago Cubs announcer Harry Caray at a campaign event at Harry Caray’s restaurant in Chicago.

headline: Painted Black, Nissan NV200 Taxi Is Poised for London Duty
abstract: The van is based on the same model selected earlier this year as the official taxi vehicle of New York City.
lead_paragraph: The Nissan NV200 van, the same model chosen to be New York’s Taxi of Tomorrow, was announced on Monday for service in London.

headline: Marvin Hamlisch, the Pro’s Pro
abstract: The composer was often overlooked because he put solid work ahead of personal self-expression.
lead_paragraph: 3:52 p.m. | Updated How fitting that Marvin Hamlisch, a one-time rehearsal pianist for countless singers and dancers, should have created the vamp of all Broadway musical vamps for “A Chorus Line.” That vamp, set to words by Edward Kleban as the song “One,” is the thematic thread and engine of a show whose score would not have cohered without it. This motif, so elemental that it seems to have existed forever, is the catapult behind everything else in the show.

headline: Calling Jack Horner
abstract: You probably won’t find these plum varieties in the supermarket.
lead_paragraph: Greenmarkets normally win plaudits for selling produce that’s locally grown and often organic, but they also sell items that are simply not available anywhere else.

headline: Marvin Hamlisch, Whose Notes Struck Gold, Dies at 68
abstract: Mr. Hamlisch, the singularly productive composer of musicals like “A Chorus Line” and songs like “The Way We Were,” won Oscars, Grammys, Emmys, a Tony and a Pulitzer Prize.
lead_paragraph: Marvin Hamlisch, the Pulitzer Prize-winning composer who imbued his movie and Broadway scores with pizazz and panache and often found his songs in the upper reaches of the pop charts, died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 68 and lived in New York.

headline: Weight Training May Lower Diabetes Risk
abstract: In a study, doing at least two and a half hours a week of either aerobic exercise or weight training substantially lowered the risk of Type 2 diabetes — but doing both may offer the greatest benefit.
lead_paragraph: Doctors routinely recommend regular aerobic exercise to reduce the risk of Type 2 diabetes. But for those who prefer resistance training to running on a treadmill, a new study shows that weight training can protect against diabetes as well.

headline: Federal Judge Grudgingly Approves Morgan Stanley Price-Fixing Case
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: A federal judge on Tuesday approved a $4.8 million settlement between the Justice Department and Morgan Stanley over accusations of price fixing in the electricity market, even as he said that the settlement amount was too low.
lead_paragraph: Over objections from consumer groups and New York officials, a federal judge on Tuesday approved a $4.8 million settlement between the Justice Department and Morgan Stanley over accusations of price fixing in the electricity market.

headline: A Kitchen Rainbow
abstract: Bialetti, an Italian cookware company, is now offering its five-quart oval pasta pot in red, charcoal gray, purple, turquoise and orange.
lead_paragraph: Bialetti, an Italian cookware company, introduced its five-quart oval pasta pot more than 10 years ago. I loved its shape, which neatly accommodated a pound or two of long pasta like spaghetti, and its colanderlike lid, which locked in place for easy draining. I even put up with the color, metallic blue. Now Bialetti has introduced an array of hues: red, charcoal gray, purple, turquoise and orange. Meanwhile, I have discovered some uses besides preparing pasta: It will hold six ears of corn on the cob, and is ideal for steaming or boiling two 1 ¼-pound lobsters.

headline: Filipinos Turn to Twitter as a Lifeline After Severe Flooding
abstract: As rescue workers raced to help after the worst flooding in Manila since 2009, residents turned to social media to pinpoint the locations of those trapped.
lead_paragraph: The worst flooding since 2009 has swamped major streets in Manila and nine provincial areas around the city, as rescue workers used rafts and boats to try to rescue people trapped on rooftops or in buildings. As my colleague Floyd Whaley writes, more than 50 people have been killed and at least 250,000 have been evacuated in the last week in the flooding, which was set off by a series of storms and monsoon rains

headline: Thick Crust or Thin: What’s Your Slice?
abstract: Debate the virtues of a thicker, sturdier crust, which has fallen out of style in Neapolitan-mad New York in recent years.
lead_paragraph: This week Pete Wells reviews Nicoletta, the East Village pizzeria where the chef Michael White had hoped, he said, to conjure the Wisconsin pizza of his youth, a pie with a crust that’s not too thick or too thin, cut into squares. What he is serving instead has a crust that, while not deep-dish, approaches that heft, sliced into the usual triangles.

headline: Sunglasses From Oliver Peoples and Parabellum

lead_paragraph: Oliver Peoples has paired up with Parabellum, the leather goods company, for a limited line of two unisex sunglasses, resulting in a curious intersection of rugged and polish.

headline: Top Two Finishers in Beijing Trade Places
abstract: Sally Pearson of Australia, the 100-meter hurdles silver medalist in 2008, won gold. The Americans Dawn Harper, Kellie Wells and Lolo Jones swept the next three places.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As Australia’s Sally Pearson sailed over hurdle after hurdle Tuesday, a crowd of 80,000 at Olympic Stadium erupted in a roar, but she said she could not hear a thing.

keywords: ['Sikhs and Sikhism', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Oak Creek, Wis, Shooting (2012)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']

lead_paragraph: THE Stockton Gurdwara in California — the first Sikh temple in the United States — is celebrating its 100th anniversary this year. Immigrants from Punjab, India, purchased the lot on Grant Street in early 1912.

headline: Get Comfy With Your Sofa Before It’s Delivered

headline: The Folly of Attacking Outsourcing
keywords: ['Protectionism (Trade)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Outsourcing']
abstract: Politicians on the left and right continue to attack the loss of American jobs, but have yet to develop policies to deal with globalization’s challenge to American workers.
lead_paragraph: The middle class, I’m sure you’ve heard, is under threat by cheap foreign labor. We must be having an election soon. President Obama’s assault on Mitt Romney for sending jobs overseas draws from a playbook used repeatedly by politicians of the right and left over the last two decades.

headline: George Romney’s Extra, Extra-Value Meals
abstract: At a fund-raiser in Chicago on Tuesday, Mitt Romney shared a vivid tale of food, frugality and fatherhood.
lead_paragraph: On the campaign trail, Mitt Romney rarely tells detailed personal stories from his life, an omission that has left some voters grasping for a flesh-and-blood narrative to latch onto.

headline: Come See Our Play. But Watch the Movie First.
abstract: Audiences can watch a prequel to the play “Men to Be Feared” before it comes to this year’s Fringe Festival.
lead_paragraph: They’re somewhat rare, but theater prequels and sequels are out there. There are two prequels actually running now on Broadway: “Wicked,” an origin story about the witches from “The Wizard of Oz,” and “Peter and the Starcatcher,” about the life of a young Peter Pan.

headline: A Note to My Readers
abstract: A note about my recent blog post.
lead_paragraph: In a recent blog post, I used an inappropriate phrase to refer to the late VP of PR for Chick-fil-A. My choice of words did not rise to either my own standards or to The Times’s, and the phrase has been removed from the post. I regret this lapse.

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bankruptcies', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Knight Capital debacle follows a long list of Wall Street failures, but in this capitalist system, weak players are discarded so stronger players can survive.
lead_paragraph: The near implosion of the Knight Capital Group on an accidental $440 million trading loss may make many feel that Wall Street firms are on automatic self-destruct with the timer set to go off fairly soon.

headline: Anna Piaggi, Fashion Editor With a Keen Eye for Trends, Dies at 81
abstract: Ms. Piaggi was known for her wildly colorful style of dress and a collection of clothes spanning more than 200 years.
lead_paragraph: ANNA PIAGGI, an oracular Italian fashion editor known for an endless array of eye-popping, wildly colorful outfits of the most peculiar combinations, ranging from vintage Patou to thermal mountain rescue coats to a uniform vest from late-period McDonald’s, died Tuesday at her home in Milan. She was 81.

headline: Obama to Make Three-Day Campaign Swing Through Iowa
abstract: Iowa has long held a special place in the Obama creation story as the state whose caucuses propelled him on his way to the Democratic nomination in 2008.
lead_paragraph: At a time when he usually races from state to state seeking votes, President Obama has decided to invest much of next week in a single place, Iowa, the one where it all began for him.

headline: Black Keys, Foo Fighters and Neil Young to Headline Benefit Concert in Central Park
abstract: The Sept. 29 show is intended to motivate people to do something to alleviate extreme poverty around the world.
lead_paragraph: The Black Keys, Foo Fighters and Neil Young and Crazy Horse will be on the bill for a charity concert in Central Park next month intended to motivate people to do something to alleviate extreme poverty around the world, organizers announced on Tuesday.

abstract: Pin collecting at the Olympics is a sport in itself. All you need to do is show up to the Olympics, find some pins and start trading.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – For Olympic athletes, glory comes wrapped in gold, silver and bronze. For some of the rest of us, it comes in the form of an enamel pin.

headline: Footnotes
abstract: The Public Theater said that its production of “Into the Woods” at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park would run through Sept. 1.
lead_paragraph: The Public Theater said that its production of “Into the Woods” at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park would run through Sept. 1, a week longer than originally scheduled. The Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical began previews on July 24 and officially opens Thursday. ... In other fairy tale news, “Rodgers & Hammerstein’s Cinderella,” already announced for Broadway with Laura Osnes as Cinderella and Santino Fontana as the Prince, has a theater and an opening date. The musical will start previews at the Broadway Theater on Jan. 21 with an official opening night of Feb. 21, according to a release.

headline: Highlighting Contrasts and Not Holding Back
abstract: The Chamber Orchestra of Europe, led by Yannick Nézet-Séguin, gave a vibrant performance on Sunday in the Mostly Mozart Festival at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: When the Chamber Orchestra of Europe took its first steps into the spotlight, it left a mixed impression. This was an ensemble of young musicians, mostly alumni of the European Union Youth Orchestra, who wanted to continue working together as a professional group, and you wanted to root for them. They gave you plenty to work with: on their early recordings and tours the playing was energetic and trim, but it could also be cautious and prim, as if only the most finely polished performances were acceptable.

headline: Our Extinction, via the Internet
abstract: The online series “H+” imagines an Internet glitch that kills nearly all of humanity.
lead_paragraph: The future according to Tom Hanks: post-apocalyptic, with electricity rationed and rebels communicating via antique radios. The future according to the “CSI” creator Anthony Zuiker: tenuous, with the world about to fall victim to a vast online fraud.

headline: Gutting Welfare
abstract: Mitt Romney’s new welfare attack ad is–surprise surprise–dishonest.
lead_paragraph: In 2005, 29 Republican Governors requested more flexibility in implementing welfare work requirements. They asked Congress for “increased waiver authority, allowable work activities, availability of partial work credit” in order to “effectively serve low-income” Americans according to their states’ needs. One of these governors was, as the mayor of London once put it, a guy called Mitt Romney.

headline: Gulping the Heady, Thin Air of Creativity
abstract: Vail International Dance Festival commissions works, and Monday’s program in Colorado featured world premieres by Brian Brooks, Matthew Neenan, Doug Varone and Christopher Wheeldon.
lead_paragraph: VAIL, Colo. — Even on a rainy evening here, the walk from the center of this town to the Gerald R. Ford Amphitheater, where most performances of the Vail International Dance Festival take place, is a thrill for the senses: you pass through pine trees beside a rushing mountain stream amid the Rockies. And after several performances, the walk home features a sky full of unusually bright stars.

headline: The Family Breakfast
abstract: To get every member of my family sitting down in one place and looking at each other every day, I compromised on dinner and created the ‘Family Breakfast’.
lead_paragraph: As a mother, I daydream about the ideal family dinner, a sort of mini-Thanksgiving with a Norman Rockwell haze to it. I love the idea of a family seated around the table, talking over the events of the day, learning table manners, conversational skills and good nutritional habits.

headline: Woman Prepares to Officiate and Make N.F.L. History
abstract: Shannon Eastin will become the first woman to officiate an N.F.L. game when the San Diego Chargers host the Green Bay Packers on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: Shannon Eastin, who was overruled by her mother when she wanted to play youth football, will make it to the N.F.L. on Thursday night. Eastin will become the first woman to officiate an N.F.L. game when the San Diego Chargers host the Green Bay Packers in a preseason game.

headline: Lots of Sand at P.G.A., but No Bunkers
abstract: A ruling on bunkers will prevent the situation that cost Dustin Johnson two strokes, and a spot in a playoff, at the 2010 P.G.A. Championship at Whistling Straits, another course with abundant sand.
lead_paragraph: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C. — There are more than 30 acres of waste area at the Ocean Course, host to this week’s P.G.A. Championship, and although much of those areas is made of sand, none of it will be considered a bunker.

headline: TimesCast Politics

lead_paragraph: Jodi Kantor reports on the push for a female debate moderator.

headline: Defending Champs Advance to an All-U.S. Final
abstract: Misty May-Treanor and Kerri Walsh Jennings reasserted their dominance in women’s beach volleyball by defeating China, clinching a gold or a silver medal for the United States.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Misty May-Treanor and Kerri Walsh Jennings reasserted their dominance in women’s beach volleyball Tuesday, defeating China in two sets in their semifinal match. They will face their United States teammates, April Ross and Jennifer Kessy, for the gold medal Wednesday.

headline: Twin Prostitutes, Growing Old Plying Their Trade in Amsterdam
abstract: “Meet the Fokkens” is a documentary about 69-year-old identical twins who have lived and worked as prostitutes in Amsterdam’s red-light district for over 50 years.
lead_paragraph: When Martine Fokkens bustles into the small grocery store early in “Meet the Fokkens,” a 2011 documentary portrait of identical twin prostitutes, she calls out a cheery hello to the man behind the counter. She has a purple hat and orange scarf framing her plump white face and a Chihuahua tucked under an arm, and what she needs, she announces, is a box of condoms. She was 69 when the movie was shot and still plying her trade from one of the picture windows in Amsterdam’s red-light district. Two years earlier her sister, Louise, had hung up her own riding crop because, as the second twin explains in this insistently upbeat movie, “I couldn’t get one leg over the other.”

headline: Craigslist’s Challenger Could Be an App, or Several
abstract: Despite its outdated interface, Craigslist has not had a real contender to knock it from its throne. But could that change as more people adopt powerful smartphones that let them connect to others nearby about buying a sofa or renting an apartment?
lead_paragraph: A few days ago an incoming alert caught my eye. Someone had posted a public message through Highlight, an iPhone app that shows people who else is nearby whom they might want to meet.

headline: Cuomo to Attend Only Last  Day of Democratic National Convention
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said he would not attend the entire convention because his duties were in New York.
lead_paragraph: Despite his growing stature within the Democratic Party, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is skipping most of the Democratic National Convention next month because, he said, he is too busy with his day job in New York.

headline: Artistry Fades as Gymnasts Push Boundaries
abstract: In 1972, Olga Korbut displayed balletic moves for 20 seconds of her floor routine. Today’s female gymnasts have no time to waste on dancing around.
lead_paragraph: The American gymnast Aly Raisman won an Olympic gold medal in the floor exercise Tuesday with a score of 15.6, well above the silver medalist Catalina Ponor’s 15.2 (a huge margin in the fractional point differences of gymnastics) and the bronze medalist Aliya Mustafina’s14.9. The difference in the scores reflects the difficulty of these women’s routines.

headline: An Irish Revolutionary Checks Out the Sights 90 Years After His Death
abstract: Escorted by summer visitors from Ireland, a cardboard cutout of Michael Collins has been touring New York and other American cities.
lead_paragraph: The other day, Richard Teahan was strolling down Fifth Avenue with Michael Collins under his arm when a woman covered fully by a burqa approached him near 65th Street and asked for directions to the Port Authority Bus Terminal.

headline: Lifting 545 Pounds Over His Head for Olympic Gold

lead_paragraph: The Iranian weight lifter Behdad Salimikordasiabi won gold with a 545-pound lift. Mark Cannella, a former United States coach, explains how he did it.

headline: Take Part in Live Op-Ed Video Discussions
abstract: It’s your chance to participate in a political conversation with our columnists during the Republican and Democratic conventions.
lead_paragraph: This year at the Republican and Democratic conventions, we will be training our eyes and ears as far outside the bubble as we can. In a series of four live videos, New York Times Op-Ed columnists, including Frank Bruni and Gail Collins, will be talking to you and, we hope, with you about four key issues in the campaign. Since Campaign Stops began on Nov. 6 last year, you have contributed more than 60,000 comments. Now we’re giving you another chance to speak up.

lead_paragraph: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C. — Tiger Woods was speaking, but the boom of thunder overhead would not let him be heard. Then he was trying to listen, but the drumbeat of rain pounding on the roof would not let him hear.

Feeney sits in an armchair and explains how he will get rid of his last $1.5 billion, give or take, by 2016.

headline: Another Jets Dust-Up Is One Too Many for Ryan

lead_paragraph: CORTLAND, N.Y. — On a crisp, cloudless morning, midway through the Jets’ second straight contentious practice, Rex Ryan finally showed Tuesday that he actually has a boiling point, abruptly stopping a drill and angrily ordering the Jets to line up.

headline: Risking Life, Limb and Dignity With Stupid Human Tricks
abstract: In “Nitro Circus: The Movie 3D,” a troupe performing crazy daredevil stunts burnishes its escapades in preparation for a Las Vegas stage show.
lead_paragraph: When something that was originally slapdash and spontaneous becomes big business, part of the fun always seems to go out of it, a phenomenon that you can feel throughout “Nitro Circus: The Movie 3D.” Hurtling skyward off a rickety ramp to do a crazy flip on a tricycle, once the kind of nutty daredevilry that gave the Nitro Circus stunt troupe its signature attitude, feels like work here more than it does play.

The State Fire Marshal’s Office said it had issued a temporary certificate of occupancy for 30 days to the Islamic Center of Murfreesboro. For two years, the center’s expansion has faced legal challenges and threats of violence. Vandals painted “not welcome” on construction signs at the mosque and set fire to construction equipment. A Texas man was indicted in June on charges that he left messages threatening to detonate a bomb at the center on Sept. 11. In May, a county judge ruled that the construction plans had not received sufficient comment from the public and that an occupancy permit could not be granted. Federal prosecutors filed a discrimination lawsuit, and a federal judge ruled in the mosque’s favor last month.

headline: What’s So Bad About a Boy Who Wants to Wear a Dress?
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Hormones', 'Men and Boys', 'Parenting', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Transgender and Transsexual', 'Homosexuality', 'Children and Childhood', 'Gender']
abstract: A new approach to parenting gender-fluid children.
lead_paragraph: The night before Susan and Rob allowed their son to go to preschool in a dress, they sent an e-mail to parents of his classmates. Alex, they wrote, “has been gender-fluid for as long as we can remember, and at the moment he is equally passionate about and identified with soccer players and princesses, superheroes and ballerinas (not to mention lava and unicorns, dinosaurs and glitter rainbows).” They explained that Alex had recently become inconsolable about his parents’ ban on wearing dresses beyond dress-up time. After consulting their pediatrician, a psychologist and parents of other gender-nonconforming children, they concluded that “the important thing was to teach him not to be ashamed of who he feels he is.” Thus, the purple-pink-and-yellow-striped dress he would be wearing that next morning. For good measure, their e-mail included a link to information on gender-variant children.

headline: Feasting After Fasts in the Streets of Old Delhi

A majority of the families prepare traditional delicacies in their homes and head out to the Jama Masjid, the principal mosque of the area, to eat in its gigantic courtyard. Many others throng the narrow lanes to feast after their fast.

headline: Blockbusters Yield to Magic
abstract: Heroic blockbusters like “Marvel’s the Avengers” and “The Dark Knight Rises” are draws this summer, but so are smaller films like “Moonrise Kingdom” and “Magic Mike.”
lead_paragraph: WHEN “Jaws” landed in June 1975, it thrilled so many moviegoers week after hot sticky week that within months it had made box office history. As the critic Tom Shone put it in his book “Blockbuster,” “That’s what America did in the summer of 1975: It watched ‘Jaws.’ ” These days, though, Americans are rarely unified by one must-see movie for long, even when school’s out. When “Marvel’s The Avengers” opened in May, it topped the box office for three weeks until it was toppled by “Men in Black 3,” which held the top spot for two, until it was bested by “Snow White and the Huntsman,” which held on for one. And so it goes as each studio behemoth is bumped by the next in what has become a faster cycle of planned obsolescence.

headline: Taliban Gun Locker: The Frankengun of Wardak Province
abstract: Whenever analysts and arms researchers scrutinize infantry weapons circulating through a conflict they encounter predictable finds. But sometimes there are surprises.
lead_paragraph: Almost no matter the place or the year, whenever analysts and arms researchers scrutinize infantry weapons circulating through a conflict, they encounter predictable finds. Time and again, the same items turn up: AK assault rifles, PK machine guns, RPG-7 shoulder-fired anti-armor weapons, and, depending on the region, a smattering of M-16 variants, Fabrique Nationale and Heckler & Koch weapons, and bolt-action or lever-action rifles from yesteryear. There are oddities, including homemade jobs. Often there are also stray vestigial arms from previous wars in the same region or from particular arms transfers to a government on the same soil. But most of these are outliers. Usually a researcher can write up a list of likely candidates, then check them off while working the beat.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Obama on the News Media, and Madonna Speaks Out in Russia
abstract: Also, the judge in the Google-Oracle case wants to know about payments to journalists, bloggers and commentators for favorable coverage; and Hollywood is building bridges to China.
lead_paragraph: Barack Obama has more than a spectator’s interest in how the news media does its job, Amy Chozick notes as she describes the president’s typical news diet. Press coverage helped propel him to the national stage when he was a state legislator, and three and a half years into his presidential term he sees news coverage as frustrating his ambitions to change the tone of political debate. His most persistent complaint is what he calls the news media’s belief in a “false balance,” in which two opposing sides are given equal weight regardless of the facts. (A note of caution from Tom Rosenstiel, director of the Project for Excellence in Journalism: “I think we’ve learned through history to beware of presidents playing press critic. They’re not press critics — they’re people trying to advance a political agenda.”)

lead_paragraph: THERE are some things one invariably wonders when waiting for a plane to take off. Is the air vent above my head blowing someone’s flu into my face? If I neglect to turn off my cellphone, will I really endanger the plane? If I knock back a cocktail at 30,000 feet, will it knock me out? Plagued by these and other aviation questions at the height of the summer vacation season, I called government officials and medical doctors for answers. Here’s what the experts had to say about five common travel bugaboos.

abstract: Officials had reported earlier that Wade M. Page, who the police say killed six people at a Sikh temple, was fatally shot by the police.

In mid-July, he suddenly stopped showing up to his job as a machine operator. About two weeks later, he bought a 9-millimeter handgun, testing it by firing 50 rounds at a target in the gun shop’s basement.

headline: Too Conservative, or Just Extremely Conservative?

lead_paragraph: Ahead of Tuesday’s G.O.P. primary in Missouri, Senator Claire McCaskill and her Democratic supporters spent around $2 million on ads describing one candidate, Representative Todd Akin, as too conservative for the state. Ms. McCaskill’s hope was that Missouri Republicans would think “too conservative, sounds good!” and support Mr. Akin—in her estimation a relatively weak challenger. That strategy seems to have worked: Mr. Akin won last night’s race with 36 percent of the vote.

headline: Natural Selection’s Evolution: Rebecca Stott Talks About ‘Darwin’s Ghosts’
abstract: Ms. Stott’s new book traces the roots of evolutionary theory, from Aristotle to Alfred Russel Wallace.
lead_paragraph: Soon after he published “On the Origin of Species,” Charles Darwin was accused of neglecting to mention the thinkers who had helped to shape evolutionary theory before him. He scrambled to put together a list of predecessors that would be added to future editions of his book. In “Darwin’s Ghosts,” Rebecca Stott tells the story of those predecessors’ work, from the empirical research of Aristotle to the studies of Alfred Russel Wallace, who was piecing together the science around the same time as Darwin. In The New York Times Book Review, Hugh Raffles called the book an “absorbing account” with a narrative that “flows easily across continents and centuries.” In a recent e-mail interview, Ms. Stott discussed the roots of her interest in Darwin, the reasons Wallace played second fiddle without complaint and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: New Fossils Indicate Early Branching of Human Family Tree
abstract: Three specimens unearthed in Kenya are the most compelling evidence yet for multiple lines of evolution in our own genus, Homo, scientists said.
lead_paragraph: Fossil by fossil, scientists over the last 40 years have suspected that their models for the more immediate human family tree — the single trunk, straight as a Ponderosa pine, up from Homo habilis to Homo erectus to Homo sapiens — were oversimplified. The day for that serious revision may be at hand.

headline: The Breadbasket of the Union

Fort Henry, Fort Donelson, Nashville and Memphis had all fallen, leaving Union forces largely in control of Kentucky, middle and western Tennessee, northern Mississippi and northern Alabama.

headline: Long-Lost Le Mans Corvette, Found at Last?
abstract: A Corvette racecar that eluded collectors for decades may have been rediscovered inside a warehouse in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Chip Miller, a noted collector of Chevrolet Corvettes who died in 2004 at age 61, spent much of his later life searching for a Corvette fielded by Briggs Cunningham — the driver, automotive manufacturer, yachtsman and race-team privateer — at Le Mans in 1960. Though he was unsuccessful in his search, before his death Miller passed along a valuable clue he had kept closely guarded.

headline: Competitive Armchair Olympics: Rocket Man
abstract: Usain Bolt can run. But can he jump?
lead_paragraph: POWER

headline: Pole-Vaulter Bends but Doesn’t Break
abstract: Steve Hooker, the defending Olympic champion, made the pole-vaulting finals after a knee injury robbed him of his confidence over the past year.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Steve Hooker of Australia is the defending Olympic pole vault champion, but he has had a problem with the yips that would bring sympathy from any golfer.

headline: Scene City: Liza Minnelli and Alan Cumming Bring Cabaret to Fire Island
abstract: A night of cabaret in Cherry Grove with the one and only.
lead_paragraph: A night of cabaret in Cherry Grove with the one and only.

headline: Fire Island’s Got Talent
abstract: Alan Cumming hosts one of the biggest cultural events on Fire Island this season.
lead_paragraph: THE Ice Palace nightclub in Cherry Grove on Fire Island is not a place ordinarily associated with great theater. On Friday night, Alan Cumming was there at an underwear party, dancing around in a jock strap and doing something with a gummy bear that cannot be described in this newspaper.

headline: Stone Links: The Drone Wars
abstract: In this week’s links: the ethics of drones, Facebook philosophy, Amartya Sen on the idea of Europe, and more.
lead_paragraph: A new chapter in the ongoing debate about the morality of drones opened last week, with a profile in The Guardian of the philosopher Bradley Strawser. Strawser’s perspective on just war theory and the ethics of drones, which was also featured in a recent news analysis in the Sunday Review, is all the more interesting because, as a professor at the U.S. Naval Postgraduate School, he is employed by an institution which is uniquely positioned to act on his views.

headline: U.F.O. Home
abstract: Roberto Sanchez Rivera built his home in Puerto Rico to look like a spaceship, with lights and audio effects.
lead_paragraph: Roberto Sanchez Rivera built his home in Puerto Rico to look like a spaceship, with lights and audio effects.

headline: The Flat
abstract: Since opening in March, the bar has been a haven for affordable drinks and edgy music in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: AROUND midnight on a sweltering Friday, the Flat was no place to cool off. In the swarmed bar, young women danced with condensation-slick bottles of Dos Equis held aloft. Heems, a rapper from the group Das Racist, slouched on a zebra-print bench under a portrait of an old woman.

headline: Norbert Leo Butz Will Join Katie Holmes in ‘Dead Accounts’
abstract: Theresa Rebeck’s play is scheduled to open on Broadway in November.
lead_paragraph: This fall on Broadway, Norbert Leo Butz will play the ne’er-do-well brother of Katie Holmes’s character, whose return to their childhood Ohio home sets off the action in Theresa Rebeck’s “Dead Accounts,” representatives for the play announced on Wednesday. “Dead Accounts” will begin previews at the Music Box Theater on Nov. 3, with a scheduled opening on Nov. 28.

headline: Teenagers’ Petition on Female Moderators Draws Support
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Television', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: A petition to have a female debate moderator gathers more than 100,000 signatures.
lead_paragraph: Quick, name the last woman who moderated a presidential debate. If you are having trouble, there is a reason: No woman has done the job in 20 years, since Carole Simpson in 1992.

headline: The U.S. Bounces Back, and Over
abstract: Aries Merritt won the 110-meter hurdles, Brittney Reese won the long jump, and Allyson Felix won the 200 meters as all three overcame disappointments from 2008.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The three Americans who won gold medals in Olympic Stadium on Wednesday were competing in different ways. Aries Merritt had to clear 10 hurdles. Brittney Reese had to leave the takeoff board at full speed before treading on the Plasticine strip that marks a foul. Allyson Felix had to sprint the curve and find something new within herself and her famously smooth stride.

headline: New Google Tools to Make the Search Engine More All-Knowing
abstract: At an event for reporters Wednesday, Google showed tools that make the search engine more omniscient, including some that are bound to raise red flags on privacy. They include incorporating personal Gmail messages into search results, and updates that make voice search for the iPhone more impressive.
lead_paragraph: When Google imagines the future of Web search, it sees a search engine that understands human meaning and not just words, that can have a spoken conversation with computer users and that gives users results not just from the Web but also from their personal lives.

headline: A Grounded Flying Saucer in Puerto Rico
abstract: On a hill overlooking a highway, the colored lights of what appears to be a flying saucer are visible. A closer examination reveals a spaceship-inspired house.
lead_paragraph: On a hill overlooking a highway, the colored lights of what appears to be a flying saucer are visible. A closer examination reveals a spaceship-inspired house.

headline: Money, Mentoring and a Claim on the Payoff
abstract: Plenty of entrepreneurial students graduate with so much debt that they leave their dreams behind for a corporate paycheck. Now, a former Google executive has a way for young entrepreneurs to get money and mentoring to start their projects. In return, he and his investors get a claim on their future earnings.
lead_paragraph: If you believe someone has a great future as an entrepreneur, maybe you should own a piece of it.

headline: Destination | Makepeace Island
abstract: Sweet-smelling eucalyptus trees, bouncing marsupials and laughing kookaburras. Just another day on Richard Branson’s island in Australia.
lead_paragraph: Makepeace Island, Richard Branson’s island in Australia, is a 10-minute ride on a private launch from Noosa, on Queensland’s Sunshine Coast. The name is reason enough for any couple (quibbling or not, let’s make peace!) to visit, plus the island is heart shaped — though not quite as much as it appears to be on its namesake Web site — a forgivably cheeky exaggeration.

lead_paragraph: A police evidence unit brought out several large paper bags on Wednesday from the basement in SoHo where the man charged in the Etan Patz case says he killed the boy who disappeared in 1979.

abstract: Photos from Egypt, Syria, Democratic Republic of Congo and Manila.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Egypt, Syria, Democratic Republic of Congo and Manila.

headline: What’s Next in the Standard Chartered Case
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Iranian-Americans', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: In the wake of the New York State regulator’s allegations that Standard Chartered of Britain helped Iran launder $250 billion, the Federal Reserve and the Justice Department are now in the uncomfortable position of deciding what to do with their investigations.
lead_paragraph: The  order issued to Standard Chartered by Benjamin M. Lawsky, the superintendent of the New York State Department of Financial Services, creates a problem for the federal government in its own investigations of the bank. Mr. Lawsky accused the bank of operating “as a rogue institution” in its dealings with Iranian customers in violation of federal law, and seeks to revoke its license to do business in New York.

headline: The Starbucks-Square Deal: Visionary or Risky?
abstract: The mobile wallet just became more hip with the news that Starbucks has teamed up with Square, the mobile payments start-up. Competitors, analysts and others weighed in on the news of the deal.
lead_paragraph: The mobile wallet just became more hip with the news that Starbucks has teamed up with Square, the mobile payment start-up. Beginning this fall, you’ll be able to pay for a cup of joe at Starbucks by showing a Square barcode on your smartphone to a cashier.

headline: A Sneakers-Only Runway
abstract: Fashion is in the midst of a serious affair with tennis, as editors, designers and models hit the courts to play or cheer. Now serving and rooting: Anna Wintour.
lead_paragraph: WANT to rub shoulders with a high-powered fashion editor? How about a designer? Arguably the best place these days isn’t the Top of the Standard hotel or even Amy Sacco’s new boîte, No. 8, but a nondescript slab of a building at 27th Street and Eighth Avenue, a neighbor to Chelsea housing projects and a Gristede’s grocery store, and the home of the misleadingly titled Midtown Tennis Club. (It’s not in Midtown, and membership isn’t required to play there.)

headline: Felix Wins Gold
abstract: Allyson Felix of the United States won the women’s 200 meters at the London Games in 21.88 seconds on Wednesday, upgrading her previous two Olympic silver medals to gold.
lead_paragraph: Allyson Felix of the United States won the women’s 200 meters at the London Games in 21.88 seconds on Wednesday, upgrading her previous two Olympic silver medals to gold.

headline: A Flock of Keyboards, Gathered in the Round
abstract: Grand Band, a group of six new-music pianists who first played together at the Bang on the Can Marathon in June, gave its second performance Tuesday night at Le Poisson Rouge.
lead_paragraph: When people refer to piano quartets or piano trios, they generally mean a piano and some other stuff — a violin and a cello, say. But the new ensemble Grand Band is a piano sextet in the purest sense: six pianos, and only six pianos.

headline: Weymouth Journal: Beer in Sausage, Rather Than Beer and Sausage
abstract: Dennis Spurr, owner of the Fantastic Sausage Factory in Weymouth, England, likes to mix unusual ingredients in his products.
lead_paragraph: Periodically throughout the Olympics we will check in with Dennis Spurr, owner of the Fantastic Sausage Factory in Weymouth, a pretty town on the English coast where the sailing events are taking place. Mr. Spurr’s sausage business was a target of the Olympic branding authorities in 2007 after he put up a sign featuring the Olympic five-ring logo fashioned out of sausage links. He took it down on their demands, but replaced it with a sign featuring five squares made out of sausage links.

headline: All the Trimmings Are the Main Course
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Handbags and Purses', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Hats and Caps', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Sunglasses']
abstract: As apparel sales lag, accessories — footwear, handbags, glasses and hats — are booming. Fashion students are interested.
lead_paragraph: A YEAR before Paula Cheng graduated from Parsons the New School for Design with an M.F.A. in fashion design in May, she won a contest organized by the Metropolitan Museum of Art to create designs inspired by the Alexander McQueen exhibition at the museum. Ms. Cheng focused not on bumster pants nor showstopper gowns, but on black platform-heeled shoes and sandals with winged tiers of fur that have already been pictured on Italian Vogue’s Web site.

headline: And the Olympic Gold for Whining Goes to ...
abstract: Any moment not shrouded in gold, silver or bronze has the potential to draw complaints, insults and general disgruntlement from fans and the news media.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For the handful of countries sitting at the top of the medal count, the Olympics have been a source of joy and a cause for celebration.

headline: R. Peter Straus, Radio Pioneer, Dies at 89
abstract: Under Mr. Straus’s leadership, WMCA in New York broadcast what were regarded as the first radio editorials and political endorsements.
lead_paragraph: R. Peter Straus, who took over WMCA in New York in the late 1950s and turned it into one of the nation’s most innovative radio stations, broadcasting what are regarded as the first radio editorials and political endorsements and helping to popularize rock ’n’ roll, died on Monday at his home in Midtown Manhattan. He was 89.

lead_paragraph: “Coming soon, from the creator of the Macarena!”... “New, from the founders of Myspace!”... “He has the same agent as Steven Seagal!”

lead_paragraph: BRANDY CASWELL, 28, turns to Facebook to keep up with her friends. But in the last year or so, she found that her newsfeed was being overrun with baby photos, documenting everything from nap times to diaper changes.

headline: The Riot Girls’ Style
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Bright tights, boots and those haunting balaclavas. The Russian punk collective Pussy Riot is known for its political performance art — and its flashy aesthetic.
lead_paragraph: It has been a shock to see the bravely smiling faces of three girls from the Russian punk collective Pussy Riot locked in a glass cage in a Moscow courtroom these past two weeks. Ordinarily they are dressed in shots of clashing colors, their faces hidden behind bright balaclavas. Stripped of their costumes and dressed in plain clothes (graphic tee, button-down shirt, day dress), they are unrecognizable. Hearing their names and seeing Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, 22, Maria Alyokhina, 24, and Yekaterina Samutsevich, 29, exposed and vulnerable on national television seems only to emphasize the band’s slogan: “We Are All Pussy Riot.” After all, if women who look like Tolokonnikova, Alyokhina and Samutsevich are Pussy Riot, why can’t I be, too?

headline: In a Factory’s Shadow, Fears About Health
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Global Warming', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Birth Defects']
abstract: Residents of Nathkuva, next to the hulking coolant gas factory, complain of rashes and birth defects, which they say are the result of pollution from the plant.
lead_paragraph: NATHKUVA, India — By issuing carbon credits to companies for reducing emissions in the developing world, the United Nations aimed to inject cash into poor communities supporting the growth of sustainable industry. But in this remote village adjacent to Gujarat Fluorochemicals Limited’s coolant gas plant, environmental groups and residents have been at loggerheads with the company over pollution since it opened in 1989.

headline: The Agents Who Fooled the Nazis About D-Day
abstract: Ben Macintyre’s “Double Cross” and Stephen Talty’s “Agent Garbo” both tell the histories of the double agents who were able to trick their German contacts about the Allied invasion.
lead_paragraph: Ben Macintyre is the reigning champ when it comes to attention-grabbing World War II spy stories that are stranger than fiction. Each of his two most recent books, “Agent Zigzag” and “Operation Mincemeat,” has been suspensefully written and studded with exotic details. And each has been narrowly particular. “Agent Zigzag” focused on Eddie Chapman, the onetime thief who turned his duplicity toward deceiving Germany on behalf of the Allied war effort. The more amazing “Operation Mincemeat” outlined the elaborate use of a floating corpse to spread disinformation.

headline: Kitty Cam Shows Not All Cats Are Killers
abstract: Video cameras attached to 60 suburban cats revealed that only 44 percent of them stalked or killed wildlife. And of those who did hunt down prey, birds were not the top favorite.
lead_paragraph: No owner would likely deny that cats are creatures with personality. Some spend all day stalking squirrels, some spend all day snoozing in the sun. Some like to cuddle, and some are loners.

headline: Angry Romans Occupy Ludlow Street
abstract: “Coriolanus” is this summer’s second offering by the Drilling Company in its Shakespeare in the Park(ing) Lot series.
lead_paragraph: The new production of “Coriolanus,” Shakespeare’s drama about an election that pits disdainful elites against the 99 percent, would seem to be a perfect fit for both our time and the inherently populist theater series to which it belongs, Shakespeare in the Park(ing) Lot. (Yes, this Elizabethan tragedy is performed gratis on the pavement of a functioning municipal parking lot, amid cars, trucks and pedestrians ferrying home Chinese takeout.)

abstract: Unlike R-rated movies or a learner’s permit, there are no clear rules that dictate when a child can or should have a phone.
lead_paragraph: Wendy Sue Swanson, a pediatrician in Seattle, knows that a 9-month-old baby can perform some basic acts of imitation. You might expect smiling, blinking and some other facial expressions and gestures. But you know what she’s seeing a lot of?

headline: Uncertainty of Operatic Proportions
abstract: The Seattle Opera’s financial situation is among the most acute among American opera companies, although problems affect almost all of them.
lead_paragraph: “The new normal?” Speight Jenkins, the general director of the Seattle Opera, repeated the question I had just asked him over the telephone. He paused for a moment.

headline: Suburban Taxpayers Vote to Support Detroit Museum
abstract: Voters in three counties approved a property tax that is expected to raise $23 million a year for the Detroit Institute of Arts, which receives no financial support from either the city or the state.
lead_paragraph: The Detroit Institute of Arts was saved from devastating budget cuts Tuesday night after voters in three Michigan counties agreed to institute a property tax increase earmarked specifically for the museum.

headline: Editor Fired Following Harassment Accusation
abstract: Marc Smirnoff, the editor of the Oxford American, a Southern literary magazine, has been fired after accusations of sexual harassment and has started an aggressive public counteroffensive.
lead_paragraph: CONWAY, Ark. — The gathering, Marc Smirnoff said, was intended as a morale-boosting retreat for his staff at The Oxford American magazine, a July 4 overnight party at a mountain cabin that would fuel the creative intellect.

headline: They ‘Tessellate,’ and Dabble in Both the Sinister and the Naughty
abstract: Alt-J played selections from its first album on Tuesday at Glasslands Gallery in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: At the stroke of midnight on Tuesday night Alt-J was at Glasslands Gallery in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, playing “Handmade,” the secret track from “An Awesome Wave,” its new full-length debut. A simmering hymn of one-way infatuation, it boiled down to a duologue between Joe Newman, the band’s frontman, and Gus Unger-Hamilton, its keyboardist. “Legions upon legions of craftsmen handmade my feelings,” they harmonized with studied imprecision, before reaching a moony refrain: “For yoooouuu.”

headline: With School Gym as Olympic Stadium, Autistic Students Chase Goals
abstract: The Rebecca School in Manhattan, which serves developmentally disabled children, incorporated the London Olympics into its summer curriculum as a way to engage its older students.
lead_paragraph: In London, thousands gathered on Wednesday to watch as two Jamaican track stars, Usain Bolt and Johan Blake, limbered up for the 200-meter sprint. At the Rebecca School for developmentally disabled children in Manhattan, however, Sam Wilkinson had eyes for only one race: the one between his team, East Side Story, and its rival, the Subway Stars.

headline: A Puzzle of a Carpet to Add or Subtract
abstract: A modular wool carpet made from 14 pieces and patterns.
lead_paragraph: For home dwellers who stress over finding the perfect size and shape for an area rug, the Dutch design company Droog has an answer: All in One, a reconfigurable wool carpet made from 14 different pieces covering about 388 square feet. “If you have a big room, you can use them all together as one piece,” said Renny Ramakers, director of Droog. Or you can split them up for different rooms.

headline: Cool Pieces for Hot August Dinners
abstract: The handmade resin dining pieces come in refreshing hues that are layered to look sculptural.
lead_paragraph: Dinosaur Designs may not have anticipated a blistering hot summer, but it had the wisdom to introduce a collection called Sorbet that coincides with it. The handmade resin pieces include soy sauce dishes, gelato spoons (right), vases and salad servers, in refreshing hues that are layered to look sculptural.

headline: Romney Makes a Surprise Stop at a New Jersey Wedding
abstract: Mitt Romney’s arrival at a New Jersey fund-raiser capped a breakneck drive along New Jersey’s highways followed by a surreal pursuit by an Orthodox wedding party, according to a pool report.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney’s arrival at a New Jersey fund-raiser on Wednesday capped a breakneck drive along New Jersey’s highways followed by a surreal pursuit by an Orthodox Jewish wedding party, according to a reporter on the trip.

headline: Classic Seating in a New Wardrobe
abstract: Madeline Weinrib reimagines midcentury furniture classics with her signature prints.
lead_paragraph: Midcentury furniture classics reimagined: that’s the angle behind the designer Madeline Weinrib’s treatment of a score of notable pieces, which she upholstered in her signature prints. Displayed from Saturday to Sept. 3 at Sebastian & Barquet’s Southampton gallery, the collection includes Vladimir Kagan’s Erica chaise in lavender jacquard ($18,500), Osvaldo Borsani’s P32 lounge chair in dove-gray striped ikat on the back and dove-gray ikat on the front ($7,000) and a three-seat sofa by Ico and Luisa Parisi in brown-striped ikat (above, $45,000). “I wanted to pay tribute to the original designs,” Ms. Weinrib said, “while simultaneously introducing them to the viewer in a way they’ve never experienced the pieces before.” The exhibition is open Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m., 67 Jobs Lane, Southampton, N.Y.; information: (631) 283-0456 or sebastianbarquet.com.

headline: Like a Sprinter, Bursts of Power
abstract: Designed to clean every household surface and texture, the Dyson DC44 Digital Slim cordless vacuum cleaner is a stocky little machine with interchangeable attachments — a Mr. Potato Head for neatniks.
lead_paragraph: A reporter sprinkled cocoa powder onto light gray carpet, then ground in cheese-flavored tortilla chips with her heel. She picked up the new Dyson DC44 Digital Slim cordless vacuum cleaner with its sapphire-blue good looks. Would it inhale the mess?

lead_paragraph: Unlike many in his profession, Mathieu Lehanneur, 38, is not driven by the desire to create the next great chair, but he would like to improve the world around him.

headline: Rembering Ballesteros, the Competitor Who Never Quit
abstract: José María Olazábal recalls a 1991 Ryder Cup Match at the Ocean Course in which Seve Ballesteros refused to concede.
lead_paragraph: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C. — As the lone returning competitor from the 1991 Ryder Cup match at Kiawah Island Resort’s Ocean Course to play here this week in the P.G.A. Championship, José María Olazábal couldn’t help but reminisce. Olazábal paired with Seve Ballesteros to form “the Spanish Armada,” one of the most formidable teams in Ryder Cup history. In 1991, they went 3-0-1 in their four matches together.

headline: Time Wasters, Pointless but Fun
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Smartphones', 'Mobile Applications', 'Computer and Video Games']
abstract: There are many apps made just for people who want to fill a few minutes of downtime.
lead_paragraph: Times have changed since the best way to pass an idle 10 minutes was Nokia’s famous Snake, or whatever flavor of game was built into your old, dumb cellphone. These basic games were simple entertainment and they were fun — to an extent. But with smartphones, we have thousands of app-enabled ways to pass the time waiting in line at the post office or even when struck with insomnia.

headline: North Korea: Is That a Dior, Comrade?

lead_paragraph: In a country that still has trouble feeding all its people, Ri Sol-ju, the wife of the country’s young leader, was pictured this week with what appears to be a luxury many North Korean women have probably never heard of, much less owned: a Christian Dior handbag. If it is not a knockoff, the bag’s going price in Seoul is the equivalent of $1,600, about 16 times the monthly wage of some of North Korea’s best-paid workers. The family of Ms. Ri’s husband, Kim Jong-un, has long been said to live in style. A former Russian presidential envoy who traveled with his father on a private train in 2001 reported that it was stocked with cases of French wine and that live lobsters were delivered. But it has been unusual for Pyongyang’s elite to show wealth so publicly. In a recent speech to party leaders, Mr. Kim lovingly remembered how his father insisted on wearing a threadbare gray parka to remind himself of the famine of the 1990s.

There were no reports of deaths, but many businesses were closed and Shanghai’s two major airports delayed or canceled hundreds of flights. Shanghai’s ports, among the world’s busiest by container volume, were also closed Wednesday, according to Reuters. Local governments in the region were on high alert following flooding in Beijing in late July that caused the deaths of at least 77 people and led to a public outcry over the city’s poor preparedness.

Satya Dev Tripuraneni, an American who worked for Infosys for five years in California, says the company billed fraudulently for workers brought from India on short-term visitor visas and also evaded taxes. After he reported his concerns, he was threatened and demoted, Mr. Tripuraneni claims in the lawsuit filed in federal court for the Northern District of California.
