headline: Reviewing the BMW 528i
abstract: With a potent 4-cylinder engine, the German automaker’s midsize sedan achieves greater efficiency than the 2011 model, but at a price.
lead_paragraph: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Csaba Csere reviews the 2012 BMW 528i, a vehicle born of the German automaker’s conviction that American consumers will pay $60,000 for a premium midsize sedan powered by a 4-cylinder engine.

headline: ‘Bye, Bye, Honey, Don’t Forget to Vacuum’
abstract: Elli Hakami discusses “The Week the Women Went,” a reality series on Lifetime about a week when the women of a South Carolina town left and let the men take care of their families.
lead_paragraph: Rare is the overworked mother or exasperated wife who hasn’t wished to turn on her heel and close the door behind her. Perhaps even more unusual is the woman who has left, even for a few days, without reeling from guilt. But for one week last summer, more than 100 women 18 to 82 from Yemassee, S.C. (population 1,000, give or take), were granted a hall pass from their everyday routines and hustled out of town while the men stayed behind.

abstract: Subjects include the annual Lucy Fest in Jamestown, N.Y.; the closing of a bowling alley in Harlem; and the greenest block in Brooklyn.

headline: Romances of Various Sweetness
abstract: At the Ailey Citigroup Theater, Ballet NY mixes performances new and old, including excerpts from works both bittersweet and sugary.
lead_paragraph: The stage fog rolled in during intermission at Ballet NY’s program at the Ailey Citigroup Theater on Thursday night. What followed was “The Garden of Souls,” a work-in-progress duet by the company’s artistic director Medhi Bahiri. To the taped Middle Eastern singing of Azam Ali, Jennifer Goodman and Jason Jordan emerged to undulate, together and apart, in red-and-black leggings under half-skirts.

headline: Ethiopian Reclaims 5,000-Meter Title From a Rival Countrywoman
abstract: Meseret Defar won the 5,000 meters, defeating Tirunesh Dibaba, a fellow Ethiopian who was fatigued from her gold-medal effort in the 10,000 as well as an undisclosed pre-Olympics illness.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For almost a decade, the Ethiopians Tirunesh Dibaba and Meseret Defar have been locked in a heated custody battle over the 5,000 meters. They have traded world championships, world records and Olympic crowns, with Dibaba exhibiting a protective ferocity for the event for much of the last four years.

headline: Making the Trip From the Vine to the Shelf
abstract: Companies are churning out a variety of products showcasing what is arguably New Jersey’s most famous crop.
lead_paragraph: ROCKY HILL, N.J. — First Field ketchup is found at barbecues where “the burgers are Kobe beef,” according to Theresa Viggiano, a founder of the company with her husband, Patrick Leger. When the couple were testing recipes as the company was getting started in 2008, however, the ketchup was more likely to be in their relatives’ refrigerators.

headline: A Vibrant Performance, Though Neither Mozart Nor Even Baroque
abstract: The Freiburg Baroque Orchestra performed music by Schubert, Schumann and Mendelssohn at Alice Tully Hall as part of the Mostly Mozart Festival.
lead_paragraph: The Freiburg Baroque Orchestra, a leading period-instrument ensemble entering its 25th season, came to the Mostly Mozart Festival on Thursday night but played no Mozart, nor any of the Baroque repertory it specializes in.

abstract: The president of the Mars Society bemoans cuts in the space budget.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Bridge Deal at the World Youth Teams Games
abstract: A look at a board from the 14th World Youth Teams Championships in Taicang, China.
lead_paragraph: LILLE, France — While the Second World Mind Sports Games get under way here, with the first three rounds played on Friday, let’s look at one more board from the 14th World Youth Teams Championships in Taicang, China.

headline: Favorite Fitness Apps: Beijing Edition
abstract: Whether you’ve spent the last two weeks watching the Olympics or lounging at the beach, chances are you’ve thought about how to improve your own fitness. There’s an app for that.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Whether you spent the last two weeks watching records get crushed at the Olympics, or lounging half naked at the beach, chances are you’ve also been thinking about your own fitness and how to improve it. It may come as no surprise: There’s an app for that.

headline: Good for Barbecues
abstract: A number of red wines from Long Island are good matches for steak, burgers and other foods and can be found for less than $20.
lead_paragraph: When a crowd gathers for a backyard barbecue and the menu features steak, lamb, burgers, grilled vegetables and the like, red wines are called for. If the guest list is large, you’ll want each bottle to cost less than $20. (And clear plastic glasses are fine.)

headline: A Summery Menu, With a Hamptons Feel
abstract: At First and South in Greenport, the New American menu of salads and local fish is typical Hamptons-style fare, but with twists like crispy duck tongues.
lead_paragraph: LIKE it or not, the gradual gentrification of the North Fork continues. Its newer restaurants are a departure from the rough-and-ready fish houses of yesteryear. A case in point is First and South in Greenport, which opened in May and has the summery East End look down pat.

headline: The British Lawmaker Nipping at Tabloids’ Heels

abstract: For years Tom Watson has led the push to investigate Britain’s freewheeling tabloids, especially Rupert Murdoch’s papers, and now the scrutiny is yielding prosecutions.
lead_paragraph: LONDON

headline: Racing Where They Could, Running What They Had
abstract: In the early 1950s, California prohibited racing on public roads, and purpose-built racetracks were a rarity. So races were held on airport courses or on winding private roads.
lead_paragraph: THE golf course fairway where judging for the Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance will be held next Sunday is a short sprint from winding private roads that once hosted sports car races. The proximity is not a coincidence: the concours and the race were held in tandem in 1950-56.

headline: Raced, Rescued, Restored
abstract: After holding its own against the sophisticated European models of the early 1950s, the Glasspar G2 racecar disappeared. Recently restored, it will be on display at the Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance.
lead_paragraph: After holding its own against the sophisticated European models of the early 1950s, the Glasspar G2 racecar disappeared. Recently restored, it will be on display at the Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance.

headline: After a Brilliant Debut, a Case of Lost and Found
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Restoration and Renovation', "Pebble Beach Concours D'Elegance (Car Show)", 'Automobile Racing', 'Collectors and Collections', 'Antique and Classic Cars']
abstract: Having dropped out of sight for years, the Glasspar G2 factory racecar that once ran with Jaguars and Ferraris has been rediscovered, and will appear at this year’s Pebble Beach concours.
lead_paragraph: VISITORS to the Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance on the Monterey Peninsula of California next Sunday will see vehicles of unfathomable value, many bearing revered nameplates. But few parked on the neatly manicured fairway will have a more captivating back story than a blue-and-white 1953 Glasspar G2, a shapely and powerful sports car that raced as the Mameco-Ardun entry before dropping out of sight almost 60 years ago.

headline: Even the Look Is an Adventure
abstract: Even among provocative designs, three concepts stand out.
lead_paragraph: LIKE futuristic dream cars at auto shows, concept designs for travel trailers are created to be provocative. Among the many ideas that have been recently floated — in one case, literally — three stand out.

headline: Heeding Call of the Wild, Travel Trailers Shape Up
abstract: Boxy designs still grab a large share of the travel-trailer market, but in recent years manufacturers have introduced models that show a little more daring.
lead_paragraph: FOR a long time, travel trailers came in two basic varieties: the big white shoebox or the Chiclet-shape pop-up; Airstream’s iconic aluminum bubble was a notable exception.

headline: Beyond the Box
abstract: With sales of travel trailers growing, some manufacturers have found success with more adventurous designs.
lead_paragraph: With sales of travel trailers growing, some manufacturers have found success with more adventurous designs.

headline: Richard Cragun, Stuttgart Ballet Dancer, Dies at 67
abstract: Mr. Cragun was the partner of Marcia Haydée, the prima ballerina, in an acclaimed series of classical dance dramas in the 1960s and 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Richard Cragun, a former star dancer with the Stuttgart Ballet and the partner of the prima ballerina Marcia Haydée in a series of classical dance dramas acclaimed internationally in the 1960s and ’70s, including “Romeo and Juliet,” “Eugene Onegin” and “The Taming of the Shrew,” died on Monday in Rio de Janeiro, where he had lived since 1999. He was 67. The Stuttgart Ballet, which announced his death, did not give the cause.

headline: Thousands Gather to Mourn Six Dead in Shooting at Temple
keywords: ['Sikhs and Sikhism', 'Oak Creek, Wis, Shooting (2012)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: People from around the world attended a group memorial service and wake at a school in Oak Creek, Wis., for Sikh worshipers who were killed on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: OAK CREEK, Wis. — One by one, six coffins were rolled into a high school gymnasium here Friday and were surrounded by Sikh men and women singing traditional Punjabi hymns. As they sang, thousands of people from around the world streamed into the gym to mourn the six worshipers who were shot and killed on Sunday at the Sikh Temple of Wisconsin here.

headline: Bulldozers Join Tourists as Fixtures in Capital
abstract: Visitors to the National Mall have been confronted with an empty Reflecting Pool and a closed Washington Monument as construction crews make repairs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation’s capital is under construction.

headline: Alone in the Zone
abstract: For high-level athletes, it’s a perennial struggle to balance focus and family.
lead_paragraph: I have been trying to imagine how I would have felt if, after having performed at a level that made me the best in the world, I only then learned from my parents that my grandparents were dead and my mother had cancer. The news last week that the multiple gold medals of the Chinese diver Wu Minxia had, in a way, come at a price made me think about the tug of war between the hyper-focus required to excel and the yearning for connection. That tension often makes athletes feel as if these forces are mutually exclusive or, at the very least, that they linger in the realm of the imbalanced and unhealthy. Death, it would appear, is inconvenient.

headline: Cold, Creamy and Locally Made
abstract: Culinary pilgrims are drawn to several places in southwestern Connecticut for a freshly made summer staple.
lead_paragraph: MORE than 60 cars were parked in the unpaved lot at Rich Farm on a recent Sunday afternoon, as an orange-vested attendant directed drivers toward vacant spots. With scores of people lined up in front of its wood-sided shop, the farm seemed poised to host a revival meeting.

headline: After Sinai Killings, Cairo Tightens Grip on a Neglected Region
abstract: The northern Sinai Peninsula has seen a buildup of troops and military hardware since a fatal attack Sunday on Egyptian soldiers who were about to break their Ramadan fast.
lead_paragraph: EL-ARISH, Egypt — The new police chief peered through the black grill of a holding cell and asked a baby-faced prisoner inside when he had gotten there. The young man — he might have been a teenager — had been detained in the previous day or two as Egypt’s military swept through the Sinai in pursuit this week of the killers of 16 of its soldiers.

headline: Carlo Rambaldi Dies at 86; Maestro of Special Effects in Movies
abstract: Mr. Rambaldi was a special-effects virtuoso who won two Academy Awards for his work on Steven Spielberg’s “E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial” and Ridley Scott’s “Alien.”
lead_paragraph: Carlo Rambaldi, a special-effects virtuoso who won two Academy Awards for his work on Steven Spielberg’s “E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial” and Ridley Scott’s “Alien” and a special achievement award from the Motion Picture Academy for John Guillermin’s 1976 remake of “King Kong,” died Friday in southern Italy. He was 86.

headline: After a Struggle, Mosque Opens in Tennessee
abstract: The congregation overcame years of threats, attacks and legal opposition, and opened without the protests or violence some feared.
lead_paragraph: MURFREESBORO, Tenn. — The worshipers bowed low, their heads touching the freshly laid carpet, as the new mosque filled with echoes of exultation.

headline: When Soriano’s Emotions Overflow, Mark the Date
abstract: Rafael Soriano recorded his 27th save in the Yankees’ victory over Detroit on Thursday, pitching in honor of his son, who was celebrating his 13th birthday.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Rafael Soriano pounded his glove with extra vigor after Thursday’s 4-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers. Soriano had just delivered only his second four-out save of the season, and the game was already emotionally charged after Manager Joe Girardi had been ejected for arguing a call in the fifth inning.

headline: Grass-Roots Mobilization, by Corporate America
keywords: ['Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Corporations', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The use (or co-optation) of grass-roots politics is a remarkable facet of the new politics of the contemporary corporation.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles

headline: Tithing, Dues, Pledges and Your House of Worship
abstract: Bucks readers swap tales of how their religious communities collect money.
lead_paragraph: No matter which God you worship, your religious community is probably always just a little bit hurting for funds — and constantly in search of a better way to collect a little bit more a bit more often.

headline: U.S. Goldman Disclosure a Rare Break in Secrecy
abstract: After deciding not to prosecute Goldman Sachs for its conduct during the financial crisis, the Justice Department did something rare: it publicly announced that the investigation was closed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After deciding not to prosecute Goldman Sachs for its conduct during the financial crisis, the Justice Department did something rare: it publicly announced that the investigation was closed.

headline: Card Swipes in Church Make Giving Easier
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Philanthropy', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Religion and Belief', 'Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: Most religious institutions are better at collecting money than they used to be, by accepting donations via credit card or electronically pulling money from people’s bank accounts.
lead_paragraph: For anyone who spends time pondering the cost of keeping the lights on and the staff paid at their houses of worship, the Mormon tithing slip has a sort of utilitarian beauty.

headline: An Improvised Trap for a Burglar Who Made Himself at Home
abstract: Twice, the police said, a man let himself into an apartment with a key while the tenant was away — the second time, the victim had set up a webcam.
lead_paragraph: In a city of millions of keys, this is a story of two of them. Two keys carried by two strangers that opened the same apartment door. Twice, the police said, one man let himself inside while the other was away. The first time, the victim was just that — a victim. The second time, he was ready.

headline: Vibrant Postcards From an Inner World
abstract: “Marc Chagall,” an exhibition running through Nov. 4 at the Nassau County Museum of Art, celebrates the work of a reluctant mystic and an anomaly in the modern-art canon.
lead_paragraph: “If we had nothing of Chagall but his Bible, he would be for us a great modern artist,” the art historian Meyer Schapiro once wrote. Those words, taken from an essay published in 1956, along with Chagall’s Bible etchings, are quoted in the press materials accompanying the exhibition “Marc Chagall” at the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn Harbor, N.Y. The second part of Mr. Schapiro’s statement isn’t included, however. He added that Chagall was “also a surprising anomaly in the art of an age which otherwise seems so remote from the content and attitude of his work.”

headline: Standard Chartered Case Casts a Chill Over Banks
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Money Laundering', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Global banks are worried that their New York operations could make them public targets for processing transactions already deemed legal by federal regulators, federal authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Money laundering accusations leveled against a British bank by New York’s top banking regulator are causing global banks to worry that their New York operations could make them public targets for processing transactions already deemed legal by federal regulators, according to federal authorities with knowledge of the concerns.

headline: Mark Brinker, Automotive Surgeon
abstract: Mark Brinker, whose Mameco-Ardun sports car is featured in the Autos section this week, has taken a circuitous route through the collector-car hobby, gravitating toward rare cars that need a lot of work.
lead_paragraph: The Glasspar G2 Mameco-Ardun sports car featured in Sunday’s Automobile section has a story to tell. That tale, however, might not have ended particularly well were it not for Mark Brinker, who purchased the long-lost car and financed an exacting restoration.

headline: Letting Companies Settle While Denying Guilt Reconsidered by F.T.C.
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission said it would review a rule after one commissioner wrote a blistering dissent to a settlement with Facebook.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Trade Commission finished a settlement with Facebook on Friday over allegations that the company had violated its privacy policy, and in the process said it would re-examine its own practice of allowing companies to settle charges of wrongdoing while denying that they had done anything wrong.

headline: Painting Bryant Park, While Adding to Its Charm
abstract: The corporation that operates the oasis behind the New York Public Library’s main branch hired four artists in residence this summer to paint scenes of park life.
lead_paragraph: Bryant Park’s pristine lawn, lush hydrangeas and movable bistro tables have been well documented in photographs and videos, but not so much in paint. This summer, to correct that situation, the Bryant Park Management Corporation, which operates the park, chose four artists to be painters in residence: each is being paid $2,000, in addition to the cost of materials, to spend two weeks depicting life in the park.

headline: A Galloping City Captured in Slow Motion
abstract: In James Nares’s “STREET,” at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art in Hartford, silent Manhattan vignettes unfold to the sound of a jangling, droning acoustic guitar soundtrack.
lead_paragraph: THERE are moments in history when everything interesting seems to take place indoors: clandestine meetings, documents being signed, objects and discoveries being made in private studios and ateliers. The past year, however, saw a different moment, in which plazas were occupied and protests and revolutions unfolded in the streets. Public space was activated — which might partially explain why James Nares’s “STREET,” at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art in Hartford, feels particularly relevant at this moment.

headline: Sami Rohr, Jewish Philanthropist Remembered by a Writing Prize, Dies at 86
keywords: ['Philanthropy', 'Rohr, Sami, Prize for Jewish Literature', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Books and Literature', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: Mr. Rohr, who made a fortune in real estate after fleeing the Nazis, was honored by his children in 2006 with the creation of the Sami Rohr Prize for Jewish Literature.
lead_paragraph: Sami Rohr, a Jewish philanthropist whose children presented him with an unusual gift six years ago when they created the Sami Rohr Prize for Jewish Literature, a $100,000 annual award intended to foster the careers of young, unknown writers, died on Sunday in Miami. He was 86 and lived in Bal Harbour, Fla.

headline: Water Damage
abstract: Why do so few black children know how to swim?
lead_paragraph: CULLEN JONES and Lia Neal were among the many swimmers to win medals for the United States in this year’s Olympic Games. But their inspiring performances obscure a disturbing truth. Not only are they, as African-Americans, anomalies in the elite levels of their sport, but enormous numbers of African-Americans do not have even rudimentary swimming skills, a lack that costs lives.

headline: Lakers Again Land a Large Piece of the Puzzle
abstract: Los Angeles acquired the best big man of the era — for the second time since signing Shaquille O’Neal in 1996 — and with Steve Nash, can also claim the N.B.A.’s top starting backcourt.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A.’s premier center — a towering, talented mass of muscle, shot-blocking and bravado — was fitted for a Los Angeles Lakers jersey Friday, leaving fans of 29 other teams a small range of emotional options.

headline: Report Looks at Hospital in Outbreak of Hepatitis
abstract: Thousands of patients in New Hampshire are being tested after a medical technician, who had worked in eight states since 2007, is linked to syringes left unattended on carts.
lead_paragraph: STRATHAM, N.H. — Edgar Barnes was relieved, almost buoyant, on Friday for the first time in many weeks. He had just emerged from a state-sponsored health clinic here where he was tested for hepatitis C. His test came back negative.

headline: U.S. Superstar Relay Riddles Argentina With Scoring Barrage
abstract: The United States, which won 109-83, will play Spain in the gold medal game Sunday, a rematch of the 2008 final in Beijing that the Americans won.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — They took turns on Friday night, four American superstars who passed the scoring torch as if competing in an Olympic basketball relay, as if auditioning for the title of best local foursome since the Beatles last played here.

headline: Ex-CNN Anchor Joins Debate vs. Unions Over Teacher Misconduct
abstract: Campbell Brown has become a vocal participant in the debate over the role of unions in disciplinary actions against teachers accused of sexual misconduct.
lead_paragraph: In late July, a Twitter user began to post a flurry of messages on what happens to be one of the Bloomberg administration’s newest education campaigns.

headline: Down With Shareholder Value
keywords: ['Corporations', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: How a company’s stock price became the be-all-end-all in the modern-day corporate culture.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been known to say that I was present at the creation of “shareholder value.”

headline: Officer Charged With Aiding Drug Ring
keywords: ['Police Brutality and Misconduct', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Devon Daniels, 30, was indicted on four counts of accessing a computer database without authorization and four counts of making false statements to federal agents.
lead_paragraph: A New York City police officer accused of providing protected law enforcement information to the head of a drug-dealing organization in Jamaica, Queens, was indicted on Friday by a grand jury in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

headline: Aug. 10: Iowa, the Forgotten Swing State
abstract: We know much less about what’s going on in Iowa than in the other swing states, but there was a new poll there on Friday, and it had pretty good news for Mitt Romney.

lead_paragraph: New York City’s commissioner of correction, Dora B. Schriro, developed a template to reform the nation’s immigrant detention system while working at the United States Department of Homeland Security; she has also headed the Corrections Departments of Missouri and Arizona. Ms. Schriro, 62, began her career in New York in 1984 and was appointed to her current job by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in 2009. Born on Staten Island, she focuses on Rikers Island these days, with a goal of making jails safer for those who work in them and for those who are incarcerated. A widow, she lives in a 99-year-old Dutch colonial on City Island in the Bronx with her calico cat, Annie Annie. Sundays at this time of year find Ms. Schriro in her garden, where she recently planted eight new rosebushes.

It’s surely one of the longer journeys you can take for a single MetroCard swipe: a little over 20 miles from Manhattan, 5 of them over water and 16 on the Staten Island Railway. Named for a family of landowners and shipyard founders, Tottenville is a colonial-era relic amid energetic recent development. Several of the oldest buildings sit within Conference House Park, whose wild, beautiful woods are crisscrossed with paths leading to the shore.

But few people today recall that poetry, just like the 100 meters, was an official Olympic competition from 1912 to 1948. Sadly, the names of the medal winners are not listed on the International Olympic Committee’s rosters. And many of the winning poems in the so-called Pentathlon of the Muses — which had to be “inspired by the idea of sport” — have mysteriously vanished as well, perhaps, as critics have suggested, because of their dubious literary quality.

On that particular occasion I put to him a question that embarrassed me: what if one is deeply in love with a young woman — which was my case — and with age her beauty fades. Will her attraction fatally diminish? Might it be displaced by a sort of repulsion? For instance, when her skin withers and wrinkles, will I still want to kiss the crook of her arms, those arms that I so admire, and, if gallantry pushes me to do so, will I have to avert my eyes?

The Realest MC,” loosely based on the story of Pinocchio and an autobiographical look at coming out in a hip-hop world.

headline: London 2012: A Gold Medal, or An Also-Ran?
abstract: Drugs and drama, world records, an eccentric opening, historic breakthroughs, women boxers, a man with no legs. Quite an Olympics. What thrilled you? Made you weepy? What was rubbish? Let us know.
lead_paragraph: There were drugs, of course there were — a slew of positive tests and expulsions, in weight lifting and race walking, in gymnastics and judo.

headline: Cleveland Browns, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
abstract: The Browns are easily the least-talented team in the A.F.C. North. The endless rebuilding continues in Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: It’s Year 14 of the Cleveland Browns’ rebuilding project. Or Year 3 of their third or fourth rebuilding project – however you want to look at it (averting your gaze would be understandable). The Browns finished 4-12 last season, the third straight year, and ninth time since their reinstatement in 1999, that they have lost at least 11 games. They did it primarily with bad offense (13.6 points per game, ranked third worst), though their defense was nowhere near as good as its No. 5 scoring ranking suggested.

headline: Silver and Bronze Are Not Equal
abstract: Equality in the sports arena means an equal opportunity and a level playing field. But ultimately, sports are competitive and the pecking order should be reflected on the podium.
lead_paragraph: Watching the Olympics over the past two weeks, I noticed something odd about the heights of the podiums during the awards ceremonies. While the podium on which the gold medal winner stands is — as expected — the highest, the heights of the silver and bronze podiums are the same.

headline: How Not to Be a Helicopter Parent: Volunteer
abstract: What happened after I convinced myself that staying home to badger my child 24/7 would improve his chances in life: I realized my energies could be better spent in not driving him nuts.
lead_paragraph: Years ago, when one of my children was partying too much in high school, and college applications were looming, I quit my job teaching at a university and began working full time at home. In truth, I had been teaching college students on and off for 25 years, and I was at the end of my pedagogical rope. But I also convinced myself that staying home to badger my child 24/7 would improve his chances in life.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition

lead_paragraph: Open magazine ran an Independence Day special on “Radical Indians” this week. Particularly interesting is a dissection of the work of Arundhati Roy, the writer and activist, whom the magazine labels “the Queen of Exaggeration.”

headline: A Young Ugandan Surprises the Field and Himself
abstract: Stephen Kiprotich’s victory in the marathon gave Uganda its first gold medal at the London Games and its second ever. Abel Kirui of Kenya won silver and his countryman Wilson Kipsang took bronze.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The East Africans were heavily favored to win the Olympic marathon Sunday, but they happened to be Kenyans and Ethiopians, not a Ugandan named Stephen Kiprotich.

headline: Ryan Brings the Tea Party to the Ticket

lead_paragraph: For two years, Tea Party lawmakers in the House have been the stubborn barbarians at the gate, strong-arming their often reluctant Republican colleagues by refusing to compromise on spending, taxes, debt or social policy.

headline: Racial Profiling Charges Renew Questions About Counterterrorism Program
abstract: Sunday’s story about a T.S.A. program that some say has degenerated into racial and ethnic profiling raises the question: Is all of the bulked-up counterterrorism machinery built after the Sept. 11, 2001 attacks still critical to protect Americans from Al Qaeda and other violent extremists, or is it time to rethink and scale back?
lead_paragraph: My Washington bureau colleagues Mike Schmidt and Eric Lichtblau wrote a revealing story Sunday on the accusations by more than 30 Transportation Security Administration officers at Boston’s Logan International Airport that a program intended to detect terrorists has instead degenerated into racial and ethnic profiling.

abstract: The pianist Jean-Efflam Bavouzet played Bartok’s Third Piano Concerto and the pianist Shai Wosner played an all-Schubert program as part of the Mostly Mozart Music Festival.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to attend Mostly Mozart Festival concerts these days without getting birds on the brain. Birds and bird song are a pervasive element of this year’s festival, which is exploring the “avian theme inside and outside the concert hall,” as Lincoln Center’s artistic director, Jane Moss, explains in a program note.

headline: Digital Diary: How GIFs Became the Perfect Medium for the Olympics
abstract: The Olympics have highlighted the GIF as a particularly compelling storytelling format, an amalgamation of video and photo that despite its inherent succinctness is able to convey a compelling narrative.
lead_paragraph: This year’s Olympic Games have been the most compelling I can remember watching: the elaborate blinged-out accessories worn by Ryan Lochte, the staggering physical feats of Usain Bolt, Gabby Douglas’s heartwarming win.

headline: Tough Love in a Tough Job Market
abstract: “Get to Work,” a Sundance Channel reality series, looks at the service organization Second Chance, which uses a job-placement program to help unemployed workers find jobs.
lead_paragraph: “Get to Work,” an eight-episode reality series that begins Monday on the Sundance Channel, sounds from the title as if it might help the mainstream unemployed — the middle-income victim of downsizing, the blue-collar laborer whose factory has closed — find employment. It won’t.

headline: Yanks’ Rally Falls Short as Hughes Loses Grip
abstract: The journeyman Rajai Davis drove in five runs for Toronto and prevented a certain two-run home run with a leaping catch in left field.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — At the moment that virtually every pitch is thrown by every pitcher at every level of baseball, the throwing hand pronates. When the hand releases the ball, the thumb tends to twist underneath the hand in a circular motion, followed by the index and middle fingers.

headline: A Royal Power Player Who Sprints to the Throne
abstract: The Public Theater’s Mobile Shakespeare Unit is back home with its abbreviated production of “Richard III,” with a nine-person cast that stars Ron Cephas Jones.
lead_paragraph: No character in Shakespeare is as hungry for power as Richard III. And it’s hard to think of an actor with a naturally hungrier look than Ron Cephas Jones, the tall, beanpole-thin, snakelike actor who portrays the title character in the production of “Richard III” from the Public Theater’s new Mobile Shakespeare Unit. This scaled-down staging has been presented at prisons, homeless shelters and other sites in underserved neighborhoods before returning to the company’s home base on Astor Place.

headline: Pick a Topic, Any Topic. He Did.
abstract: In “The Way the World Works,” a collection of essays from the last 15 years, Nicholson Baker caroms among topics as diverse as video games and World War II pacifism.
lead_paragraph: In the final essay of this hodge-podgy collection, Nicholson Baker — best known for his microscopically detailed accounts of daily life, his love of the minute, the specific, the Seinfeld-ian small — notes that he’d like to write a book for children and adults called “The Way the World Works,” a book that would explain “everything about history, beauty, wickedness, invention, the meaning of life,” the “whole unseemly, bulging ball of wax.”

Titled “Myth & Transformation,” the two-night program will feature Graham’s interpretation of Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring”; the world premiere of a work choreographed by Nacho Duato with music by Arvo Pärt; and performances by the guest artist Wendy Whelan, a principal dancer for the New York City Ballet. headline: Beneath the Dappled Light, There’s Safety and Charm in Numbers
abstract: The Downtown Dance Festival began on Saturday with six troupes from the city, upstate and abroad performing amid the shade in Battery Park.
lead_paragraph: In perhaps the most famous aria in all of Handel’s operas, “Ombra mai fu,” King Xerxes of Persia states that no shade was ever so dear as that of his beloved plane tree. Though I’ve observed plane trees all my life and have known that aria for decades, only on Saturday did Handel’s sublime melody come to mind — when I spent over two hours in the shade of plane trees in Battery Park, watching the opening event of the 31st annual Downtown Dance Festival. The charm of those trees’ shade on a warm afternoon, the ravishing way they filtered the brightness of the light, and the dappled look of the leaves from beneath: all brought back Xerxes’ words as set to music by Handel.

headline: Glow With the Flow
abstract: The latest detox craze, External Counter Pulsation therapy, is being offered as a multipurpose remedy for everything from fatigue to weight gain.
lead_paragraph: First there was the raw food movement. Then came macrobiotics, followed by the all-mighty juice cleanse. The latest detox craze isn’t something you can ingest, but it has plenty of people drinking the proverbial Kool-Aid. A cardiovascular procedure called External Counter Pulsation therapy, cleared by the F.D.A. in 1987 for the treatment of angina, claims to stimulate and clear collaterals (small blood vessels) to bypass narrow or clogged arteries. During the procedure, a patient’s legs are strapped to an adjustable bed using pressurized cuffs hooked up to a heart monitor. The cuffs inflate and deflate in sync with the heartbeat, pumping blood upward, so it can oxygenate more rapidly and distribute with greater ease. Now rebranded as Pure Flow Pulsation at New York’s PureFlow, E.C.P. is being offered, under the guidance of the cardiologist Dr. Samir Shah, as a multipurpose remedy for everything from fatigue to weight gain. (Andrew Barile, PureFlow’s co-founder, says that a 45-minute session is the aerobic equivalent of a seven-and-a-half-mile walk.) Some New Yorkers are swearing by it. “At first I wasn’t convinced, but by the third session I noticed that, for the first time in 20 years, I was able to enjoy a full night’s sleep without interruption,” says Celeste Fierro, a restaurant and nightclub consultant. Her tolerance for alcohol is lower, too. “I used to be able to drink a bottle of wine at dinner, and now I can only take a glass.” And for the Tom Ford stylist Sabrina Baldieri, the results are outwardly apparent, too. “I have more control over my weight,” she says. “It also gives me immediate relief from jet lag and an overall glow.”

headline: What Paul Ryan Doesn’t Offer
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: Mitt Romney’s running mate lacks experience in foreign policy, and in the private sector.

Anyone who’s ventured below the fold probably also knows that he’s a social conservative: He opposes same-sex marriage and has said that he’s “as pro-life as a person gets,” which seems accurate since he’s the co-sponsor of a bill that would grant fetuses “all the legal and constitutional attributes and privileges of personhood.”

headline: The Sound of New York’s Skaters
abstract: The self-invented, devil-may-care attitude that’s characterized the irreverent sound of so many New York bands has had a big influence on Skaters.
lead_paragraph: “None of us can skateboard. We just don’t have the coordination, I guess,” says Michael Ian Cummings, the lead singer for a band called, of all things, Skaters. “The name just reminds me of my youth and the way I felt listening to music and hanging out with my friends running around the city being a hooligan.” The self-invented, devil-may-care attitude that’s characterized both skate culture and the irreverent sound of so many New York bands (the Ramones and Suicide come to mind) has had a big influence on Skaters, who released their debut EP, “Schemers,” for free on the Web earlier this year. A rose-colored, wistful affection for the city is shared by the group’s three members — Cummings, Noah Rubin (drums) and Joshua Hubbard (guitar) — and can be heard loud and clear in songs like “Good Weird Woman,” with its subway-station-sounding saxophone, and “Are We Just Doomed?” a bittersweet account of leaving home and hardly sleeping, something any New York band worth its salt knows intimately. “I couldn’t imagine making or listening to this music in any other environment,” Cummings says. And even without the skateboards or skills, Skaters do look the part. Dressed in the British men’s-wear label Folk, as they were for their T photo shoot, there’s no covering up their romantically ragged edges.

lead_paragraph: By picking Paul Ryan, Mitt Romney got someone who could shore up his conservative credentials. He got someone Catholic. And he made himself look like a political daredevil, which no one had previously mistaken him for.

headline: Palestinian Seeks Diplomatic Allies
abstract: Hanan Ashrawi, a member of the Palestine Liberation Organization’s executive committee, asked diplomats on Monday to support a renewed bid for observer-state status at the United Nations.
lead_paragraph: Hanan Ashrawi, a member of the Palestine Liberation Organization’s executive committee, asked diplomats from two dozen countries on Monday to support the Palestinian Authority’s renewed bid for observer-state status at the United Nations, calling it “a test of the whole rule of law.” Speaking in East Jerusalem to envoys from countries in Europe, Latin America, Asia and the Middle East, Ms. Ashrawi asked them not only to vote for the future United Nations resolution on observer-state status, possibly this fall, but to provide the Palestinian Authority with a financial “safety net” when, she predicted, “Americans decide to cut off aid” because of the bid. The Palestinians’ plan is to petition the United Nations General Assembly, where passage is all but assured. That would give the Palestinians access to organizations like the International Criminal Court, where they hope to pursue claims against Israel on matters like settlements.

headline: Let the Real Debate Begin
abstract: With Paul Ryan on the Republican ticket, Americans can have a much needed discussion about the size and role of the federal government.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney’s choice of Paul Ryan to be his running mate is — do I dare say this? — good news for lots of people. Conservative Republicans will mobilize around a deeply conservative Tea Party hero, who will help ease their essential discomfort with their presumptive presidential nominee. Democrats will try to make political hay over the shrink-the-government budget proposals that Ryan, a congressman from Wisconsin, has rolled out in the House, starting with his plan to “save” Medicare by essentially creating a voucher program that would inevitably cause seniors to pay for more of their own health care.

headline: Where Do Sentences Come From?
abstract: How to find good writing in that dark, cavernous place called the mind.
lead_paragraph: Sift the debris of a young writer’s education, and you find dreadful things — strictures, prohibitions, dos, don’ts, an unnatural and nearly neurotic obsession with style, argument and transition. Yet in that debris you find no traces of a fundamental question: where do sentences come from? This is a philosophical question, as valuable in the asking as in the answering. But it’s a practical question, too. Think about it long enough, and you begin to realize that many, if not most, of the things we believe about writing are false.

headline: Summer Hideaways
abstract: A chance for some mid-summer traveling with Ian Livengood.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — The epitaph that Thomas Jefferson wrote for himself lists precisely three accomplishments: that he authored the Declaration of Independence and the Virginia Statute of Religious Freedom and that he founded the University of Virginia. (Not one to pad a résumé, Jefferson refrained from mentioning, you know, his presidency.) If you knew this, you probably had no trouble filling in 46 Across, which referred to the establishment of UVA. It’s just one of many clues in today’s Ian Livengood-constructed puzzle that seems perfectly suited for mid-August: tossed in alongside vacation destinations in the theme, there are a couple of nagging reminders of school.

headline: Mexico: Suspect Linked to Veracruz Killings, Officials Say
abstract: The Mexican Navy announced Monday that a suspected member of a drug gang was captured while carrying the identification cards of a recently slain newspaper employee in the state of Veracruz.
lead_paragraph: The Mexican Navy announced Monday that a man suspected of being a member of a drug gang had been captured while carrying the identification cards of a recently slain newspaper employee in the state of Veracruz. The authorities link the suspect, Juan Carlos Hernández Pulido, whom they captured Friday, to the killing of the newspaper employee, Irasema Becerra. Her dismembered remains were found in May along with those of three photojournalists. Six journalists have been killed in Mexico so far this year; five of them in Veracruz. None of the crimes have been solved yet.

headline: Baltimore Ravens, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
abstract: The Ravens’ defense is not quite as good as it was a year ago. Baltimore will need the offense to step forward.
lead_paragraph: There are 27 seconds left in the A.F.C championship game. The visiting Baltimore Ravens trail the New England Patriots by 3. It’s second-and-1. Quarterback Joe Flacco is dropping back to pass. He has completed five of his last seven throws on what’s turning out to be a brilliant 56-yard drive. Flacco calmly pump-fakes and then slings a laser between two defenders in the front corner of the end zone. The ball lands in the hands of wide receiver Lee Evans. It’s an incredible throw – the type of throw that exhibits why the Ravens took Flacco in the first round, the type of throw that makes fans forget about Flacco’s middling 57.6 percent accuracy in the  regular season or his four-year reputation as the young quarterback who isn’t ready to push a great Ravens club over the top.

lead_paragraph: Perhaps we should thank Chad Johnson for officially welcoming us to football season. Because the N.F.L. cannot really begin until some nonsense involving a past-his-prime receiver reminds us there is no I in team, but there is in “oh geez, not another reality show.” This is possibly now in the N.F.L. rule book. So, Johnson merely stepped up to perform his duty as past-his-prime receiver with the celebrity ego gone off the rails. That he got arrested on domestic violence charges against the woman he just married on reality TV and well, you have the proper absurdity points for a full-fledged fiasco.

headline: Timely | Camera Sly
abstract: Aïda Ruilova’s compact, psychologically charged videos, which have been shown everywhere from the Venice Biennale to a Jumbotron in Times Square, don’t so much draw you in as snare you in a relentless loop with no hope of climax or resolution.
lead_paragraph: Aïda Ruilova’s compact, psychologically charged videos, which have been shown everywhere from the Venice Biennale to a Jumbotron in Times Square, don’t so much draw you in as snare you in a relentless loop with no hope of climax or resolution. Her latest, a collaboration with the director Abel Ferrara, begins with a conversation about Pier Paolo Pasolini’s death and veers into a wholly tangential discourse on love, hustlers, desire, drugs, conspiracy, film scripts and the actress Zoë Lund. It will be shown at the New Museum in New York this fall and at Kayne Griffin Corcoran in Los Angeles next spring. And then there is Ruilova’s continuing collaboration with her husband, the artist Raymond Pettibon. “Having a baby is the ultimate ready-made,” she says of their infant son. “We make videos with him every day.”

headline: Will Indian Women Ever Have the Freedom Not to Marry?
abstract: Behind the Bollywood dream of the Great Indian Wedding, complete with white horse and brass bands, the reality for many Indian women is stark: there isn’t much alternative to marriage. Does it have to be this way for the next generation?
lead_paragraph: Behind the Bollywood dream of the Great Indian Wedding, complete with white horse and brass bands, the reality for many Indian women is stark: there isn’t much alternative to marriage. Does it have to be this way for the next generation? How long can tradition be used to justify marrying off women before they’re old enough to make good choices — or to pressure women into marriage, because being single is not a culturally acceptable choice?

headline: The Art of Reef Conservation
abstract: An artist installs sculptures in tropical shallows with an eye to saving reefs.
lead_paragraph: What’s not to like about the work of Jason deCaires Taylor? The 37-year-old sculptor, raised in England, Spain and Malaysia, has found a way to blend a love of diving and coral reefs with his art — which he crafts on dry land and then lowers into the seas, where, he says, it diverts divers who might otherwise spend too much time poking at fragile reefs. The sculptures themselves, with time, end up as homes for corals, sponges and other marine life.

headline: Good Enough to Make Farm-Stand Peaches Blush
abstract: Big, handsome peaches in perfect condition, unblemished and ready to savor, are available for order.
lead_paragraph: Farm stands are piled high with the perfect argument for not buying most supermarket peaches. So why even consider the organic fruit from Frog Hollow Farm in Brentwood, Calif.? Because the farm ships its big, handsome peaches unblemished and ready to savor, dripping with rich juice. Unlike many farm-stand peaches, these have their skins brushed to be less fuzzy. And they include unusual varieties. Cal Reds, weighing 6 to 7 ounces each, are ready now. The skin deepens to burgundy, and within, the golden, fairly firm, satiny flesh is sweet but trimmed with tartness. They are excellent to halve and grill, to slice atop a tart or to serve plain with a glass of prosecco. The Cal Reds will be finished in about 10 days, but the harvest continues into mid-September with giant Summersets and juicy Autumn Flames.

headline: The Making of Rear Admiral Farragut
abstract: How a has-been officer became a Civil War naval hero.
lead_paragraph: “Yesterday I hoisted my flag at the main, and the whole fleet cheered, which I returned with a most dignified salute,” wrote David Glasgow Farragut, commander of the Union’s Western Gulf Blockading Squadron, to his family on Aug. 12, 1862. “I called all hands, and read the act of Congress complimentary of their achievements. I got under way, and stood down the river, leaving a general order to be read to the fleet. I stopped at the forts, to let the men see what they had done to deserve the resolutions.”

The United States poet laureate Natasha Trethewey, the Pulitzer Prize winner C. K. Williams, the former New Jersey poet laureate Amiri Baraka and dozens of others will gather in Newark on Oct. 11-14 for the 14th Geraldine R. Dodge Poetry Festival, a biennial event that bills itself as North America’s largest poetry event. And Oct. 18-20, the American Academy of Poets will present its sixth annual Poets Forum, which will feature readings and discussions on issues like poetry and social media (the subject of a lecture by Jorie Graham), and poetry-themed walking tours of Harlem, the West Village, the Museum of Modern Art and SoHo.

headline: A Historical Benchmark for Religion and Race
abstract: With the choice of Paul D. Ryan to be the Republican vice- presidential nominee, not one person in a group of top political jobs — the presidential and vice-presidential nominees of both parties, the Supreme Court justices, the speaker of the House or the Senate majority leader — is a white Protestant.
lead_paragraph: With the choice of Paul D. Ryan to be the Republican vice- presidential nominee, not one person in a group of top political jobs — the presidential and vice-presidential nominees of both parties, the Supreme Court justices, the speaker of the House or the Senate majority leader — is a white Protestant. That group instead comprises nine Catholics (six justices, Mr. Ryan, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Speaker John A. Boehner), three Jews (on the court), two Mormons (Mitt Romney and Senator Harry Reid) and one African-American Protestant (President Obama). For much of American history, white Protestants dominated the top rungs of American government.

abstract: The joy of Shakespeare in the Park is a summer ritual that can be connected to milestones in a New Yorker’s life.
lead_paragraph: “Into the woods, each time you go,/There’s more to learn of what you know.” It was hard not to be reminded of those Sondheim lyrics last week when I went to Central Park, which is as close as many New Yorkers get to the woods, for the latest Shakespeare in the Park production. Dodging bikers and runners, walking up the gentle slope and through one of the wooden pathways to arrive at the Delacorte Theater, I was reminded of my first visit years ago.

headline: Can a Banker Think Like an Entrepreneur?
abstract: The Alberleen Group provides seasoned investment bankers with the infrastructure and working capital to start their own firms.
lead_paragraph: In a just-published New York Times article, I write about Jolyne Caruso, a Wall Street veteran who founded the Alberleen Group, a company that applies the incubator concept — ubiquitous in the world of tech start-ups — to investment banking. The Alberleen Group provides seasoned investment bankers with the infrastructure and working capital to start their own firms. In exchange, it takes a revenue share.

headline: The Dolphin Lover’s Conundrum
abstract: Feeding or petting a dolphin is illegal, but many who love them seem blissfully unaware.
lead_paragraph: People who express the greatest concern about protecting Florida’s wild dolphins are often the same ones who break laws about feeding, petting or swimming with the charismatic species, according to a new study commissioned by the National Marine Fisheries Service. headline: Profile in Style | Hannelore Knuts
abstract: A Renaissance woman, this model — who designs bikes, acts in feature films and dances on prime-time T.V. — is well-diversified.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the worst thing you could call Hannelore Knuts  is a model-turned-fill-in-the-blank. Fortunately, the title doesn’t really apply. After 14 years in the business, the 34-year-old Belgian is still modeling — and does five hours of boxing workouts a week to keep it that way. She is also taking photographs: she shot her first campaign, for the French men’s brand Arnys. She acts: she’s in the first feature by her boyfriend, the artist Nicolas Provost, and she will play David Bowie in a Radio Soulwax video. She designs bags for Delvaux and just put the finishing touches on a bike for Marniek Kint, which she describes as having a slightly off-white frame, a fluorescent pink brake cable, classic racing handlebars and a hot pink basket. “Yep! The perfect man race bike for women,” she says. And not least, this fall she will appear on the Belgian version of “Dancing With the Stars.” So what do you call Knuts? Busy comes to mind.

abstract: Ole-Martin Hansen moved from Norway to London 10 years ago to study sound art, but he soon found a very different calling: smoking salmon, the Norwegian way.
lead_paragraph: Ole-Martin Hansen moved from Norway to London 10 years ago to study sound art, but he soon found a very different calling: smoking salmon, the Norwegian way. At his North London shop, Hansen & Lydersen, he recreated his grandfather’s special smoking chamber in a 1950s boiler room, where he flavors fresh salmon from Denmark’s Faroe Islands with beechwood and juniper, and uses small fans to blow air on the fish. “The salmon needs to move,” he explains. After curing the fish with salt from Guérande, France, Hansen sends it to some of London’s finest restaurants and markets. Lest there be any doubt about his dedication to the fish, Hansen adds that the chamber is equipped with a piano, on which he plays them Edvard Grieg’s “In the Hall of the Mountain King.”

headline: The Dirt on Clean | Laundering Fashion’s Most Elaborate Creations
abstract: However does Lady Mary Crawley upkeep her baroque costumes?
lead_paragraph: Though “Downton Abbey” is currently between seasons — Season 3, which will take the fictional Crawley family into the Jazz Age, will have its debut next month in Britain but not until January on this side of the Atlantic — its sumptuous costumes remain firmly planted in our imaginations; for many, they’re reason enough to tune in. So while watching the the Balmain fall 2012 collection unfurl it was easy to embroider a line between the elaborate, mosaic-style beading that the designer Olivier Rousteing dreamed up and the exquisitely embellished clothes worn by Lady Mary and company. The obvious parallels, of course, lie in the richness of the workmanship. But there are less evident similarities between the “Downton” costumes and Rousteing’s clothes, as well as those of Erdem Moralioglu, who embroidered lace onto rubber; Marios Schwab, who layered sequined gowns with chiffon; and Gucci, where the designer Frida Giannini sent out a cocktail dress dripping with coq feathers. These creations (and many others, every season) beg the inevitable question: How are they to be cleaned? Once these individual testaments to the skills of seamstresses, embroiderers, featherers and beaders have been worn, perspired in and spilled on, what’s the wearer to do?

headline: Japan: Cabinet Member Visits Tokyo War Shrine

lead_paragraph: A Japanese cabinet member visited a Tokyo war shrine on Wednesday for the first time in three years, a move that could add to already heated exchanges with neighboring South Korea over history. The visit by Jin Matsubara, the National Public Safety Commission chairman, was the first by a cabinet member to the Yasukuni Shrine since the Democratic Party came to power in 2009 with vows to build closer ties with Asia. Mr. Matsubara, an outspoken conservative, told Kyodo News that he visited the shrine to Japan’s war dead as a private citizen, ignoring a request from Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda not to go. abstract: Changing a strongly held belief has little to do with actual facts.
lead_paragraph: Forget for a minute everything you know about politics. Barack Obama now openly supports gay marriage. Mitt Romney now opposes roughly the same kind of health care reform he fought for as governor of Massachusetts. What if they weren’t two politicians calculating how to win an election but instead just two guys who changed their minds? They didn’t “flip-flop”; they experienced, as social scientists say, an attitude change, the way any of us do when we become a vegetarian or befriend a neighbor we used to hate or even just choose to buy a new brand of toothpaste.

headline: Pockets of City See Higher Use of Force During Police Stops
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Search and Seizure', 'Police Brutality and Misconduct', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Minorities', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Police']
abstract: The New York police have come under scrutiny over racial disparities in their stop-and-frisk practice. But the frequency of officers’ use of force in those encounters is often overlooked.
lead_paragraph: The crowded neighborhoods of the West Bronx come alive at night. Residents, young and old, cluster around door stoops. Teenagers fill playground basketball courts. Police officers from the nearby 44th and 46th Precincts patrol the streets, from time to time stopping and frisking young men, mostly black and Latino. And when they do, statistics show, they use physical force far more often than the police do anywhere else in the city.

abstract: Claressa Shields pays homage to the coach that got her to the Olympics.
lead_paragraph: Two months ago, Claressa Shields packed a strapless purple dress to wear in London if she became one of the first women boxers to win an Olympic medal. When the 17-year-old boxer from Flint, Mich. (who was included in our multimedia feature on America’s boxing women aiming for the Olympics this past winter), finally got to wear that dress, she had more than one historical achievement to celebrate: the first woman middleweight gold medalist, the youngest since 1924, the only American boxer to stand on top of the podium this year and the second-most-trending name on Yahoo! on the day of her victory.

lead_paragraph: It was an unlovely place and its customers had many complaints: a chronic damp and musty smell, a poor selection unless one harbored a passion for Campbell’s soups, exorbitant prices, a fresh deli that could be anything but and bored workers with little interest in helping shoppers.

lead_paragraph: My fiancé and I are planning a small wedding for family and close friends. It is important to us that the sanctity and beauty of the ceremony be respected. Several of our guests have babies and young children. We are happy to have them at our wedding under their parents’ supervision, but are concerned that this might lead to disruptions during the religious ceremony, which will be about 30 to 45 minutes.

headline: Leaning Toward the Light: Molly Ringwald Talks About Her New Novel
abstract: Ms. Ringwald’s “When It Happens to You” follows the troubles of a married couple.
lead_paragraph: Molly Ringwald became a star for her roles in a beloved triumvirate of mid-’80s teenage movies: “Sixteen Candles,” “The Breakfast Club” and “Pretty in Pink.” Now 44, she continues to act and is also focused on a career as an author. In 2010, she published “Getting the Pretty Back.” She called that effort “a kind of entertaining, anecdotal style guide.” Her new book is “When It Happens to You,” a novel told in stories centered around Phillip and Greta, a couple whose marriage is foundering. In a recent e-mail interview, Ms. Ringwald discussed the appeal of flawed characters, advice she got from Bret Easton Ellis and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: A Battle Plan for Jet Lag
abstract: Tired of being tired when you travel across time zones? Here’s some advice for fighting jet lag, straight from a team at NASA.
lead_paragraph: THERE are more so-called remedies for jet lag than there are time zones, from long-standing antidotes like No-Jet-Lag’s homeopathic tablets to new innovations like the Valkee Brain Stimulation Headset, which was tested earlier this year by Finnair and purports to alleviate jet lag by channeling bright light into the brain through the ear canal.

headline: Just Red Sox Being Red Sox
abstract: After Yahoo reported on the Red Sox players’ revolt, there was some backtracking in Boston but little sympathy for Bobby Valentine.
lead_paragraph: With everything that changes each season in baseball, it is nice to have a constant, a touchstone that reminds you what era one is in. To that end, the Red Sox are performing a public service, their dysfunction so consistent that it is almost comforting. Only the details change, from booing Nomar Garciaparra out of town to Manny being Manny to fried chicken and beer to whatever has popped out of Bobby Valentine’s mouth today.

headline: Abby Elliott Not Returning to ‘Saturday Night Live’
abstract: In her four seasons at “Saturday Night Live,” Abby Elliott provided impersonations of famous figures like Angelina Jolie, Meryl Streep, Zooey Deschanel and Rachel Maddow.
lead_paragraph: Abby Elliott has joined the ranks of performers like Kristen Wiig and Andy Samberg who are leaving the cast of “Saturday Night Live.” Ms. Elliott, who joined “SNL” as a featured performer during its 2008-9 season, told the Web site Splitsider.com that she would not be returning to that long-running late-night comedy series. NBC declined to comment on Wednesday but a person with direct knowledge of plans at the show confirmed the report.

headline: A Rare Mother Goose, Indeed
abstract: A new collection includes established favorites like “Little Miss Muffett” along with less celebrated nursery folk.
lead_paragraph: The renowned children’s book editor Margaret McElderry died last year, but the imprint bearing her name carries on, as does the publisher’s “McElderry Book of...” series of anthologies. “The McElderry Book of Mother Goose,” the fourth volume (earlier collections were of Greek myths, Aesop’s fables and Grimms’ fairy tales) does much to continue her storied tradition — and give it a fresh little tweak, especially for those who’ve had enough of Little Jack Horner and his over-recited ilk.

headline: Ann Romney Refuses to Release More Tax Returns
keywords: ['Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Presidential Election of 2012']

headline: Introducing Maggie Koerth-Baker
abstract: The science editor of Boing Boing kicks off her new column for the magazine, called “Eureka.”
lead_paragraph: Readers of Boing Boing will know what I mean when I say that very few people can write about science like Maggie Koerth-Baker. She is the site’s longtime science editor and also the author of the excellent book Before the Lights Go Out: Conquering the Energy Crisis Before It Conquers Us. And starting this month, she’ll be contributing a regular column to the magazine that we’re calling Eureka. Her terrific first column is about the mind of a flip-flopper. Maggie will be writing frequently about the intersection of science and culture, about studies she finds to be especially revealing or provocative, about human behavior and technological innovation and natural phenomena. In short, she’ll be bringing us in closer, smarter, more exciting contact with the scientific world. We’re very happy to have her joining the magazine.

headline: Remember Iraq?
abstract: A new report should prod people to think more seriously about America’s role in the country we invaded.
lead_paragraph: Since troops withdrew at the end of 2011, Iraq has receded from the American public consciousness. Just consider the U.S. presidential campaign where the economy – understandably – predominates. President Obama and Mitt Romney rarely even mention the country we invaded.

headline: Energy Security vs. Environment in Alaska
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Animal Migration', 'Natural Gas', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Reserves (Natural Resources)']
abstract: In a balancing act, the Interior Department rules out drilling in some sections of the National Petroleum Reserve but green-lights it in others.
lead_paragraph: While the Marcellus Shale in New York and Pennsylvania and the Bakken Shale in North Dakota are trigger points in the world of fossil-fuel extraction these days, Alaska has been the lodestar for oil and gas development in the United States for the last half-century. And as befits a state dominated more by wild lands than humankind, it has been home to some of the fiercest political battles pitting energy interests against environmental concerns.

headline: The Get | Skagen Denmark and Hiromichi Konno Watch
abstract: Konno’s sleek timepiece is his first foray into the world of watch design.
lead_paragraph: It could be said that Hiromichi Konno has a thing for Danish design. Four years ago, he enjoyed a certain degree of acclaim when he created the futuristic-looking Rin chair for the venerable Danish furniture collective Fritz Hansen. More recently, Konno approached the watch company Skagen Denmark about a collaboration. “I was so impressed by their design philosophy,” Konno said, which he defines as “simple and beautiful.”

headline: Wall Street’s Race to the 48-Millisecond Trade
keywords: ['Inventions and Patents', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The recent trading debacle at Knight Capital has highlighted the issues associated with automated and high-speed trading. Yet today’s technological challenges are not unlike those faced by traders in the 19th century, whose jobs were revolutionized by the advent of ticker machines.
lead_paragraph: It took just 45 minutes this month for one of Wall Street’s top trading firms to lose $440 million, a loss that has focused attention on the potential problems associated with high-speed trading. Yet today’s technological challenges are not unlike those faced by traders in the 19th century, whose jobs were revolutionized by the advent of ticker machines.

abstract: No, by definition — the GOP’s definition.
lead_paragraph: Several commenters have asked that I provide examples of Republicans making reasonable economic arguments; some of them seem to be saying that I’m proving my bias if I don’t provide such examples.

headline: Forget Harvard; Real Economic Change Will Come From the Bottom
abstract: A look at how the second-tier business schools are challenging the Harvards and Whartons for relevance and outreach.
lead_paragraph: In Sunday’s magazine, Adam Davidson finds a reason to cheer for second-rate business schools. They may lack Nobel laureate professors and ivy-covered buildings, but they have managed to drive down the cost of a business degree. Some schools, like the University of California, Irvine, even offer online classes for free. ‘‘There are hundreds of millions of small farmers, shopkeepers and potential entrepreneurs,’’ Davidson writes, ‘‘for whom mass business-educational tools could be transformational in ways that make a handful of top schools seem utterly irrelevant.’’ According to Larry Cooperman, director of U.C. Irvine’s OpenCourseWare program, the transformation has already begun.

headline: Still Recovering From Knee Problems, Nadal Will Miss United States Open

lead_paragraph: We will soon be unveiling our forecast model for United States Senate races. But as a point of comparison and because there have been a number of important primaries for the Senate in recent weeks, I first wanted to give you my view of the contests.

headline: Introducing the Ocean Health Index
abstract: Comparing different parts of the world’s oceans, the index weighs whether the human activity there is sustainable or in need of better management.
lead_paragraph: In a potential milestone for ocean management, a team of collaborators has produced the first Ocean Health Index, a tool for appraising the state of the world’s oceans. The index takes into account the major factors that influence the quality of regional marine ecosystems like fisheries, biodiversity, tourism and carbon storage and then assigns a score from zero to 100 for each place.

headline: A New Delano, This Time in Moscow

headline: Equal (Voting) Consideration
abstract: Ohio doesn’t treat all voters the same. Will the secretary of state fix that?
lead_paragraph: As the board mentioned on the editorial page today, Ohio doesn’t treat all voters the same. Depending on where you live, your polling place may close promptly 5 p.m., or stay open in the evenings and on weekends. More specifically, if you live in a county likely to favor President Obama, you’ll have to get to the polls before the end of the traditional work day; if you live in a county likely to swing Republican, you can take your time.

abstract: Former special operations and C.I.A. officers accused President Obama of leaking information for political advantage, an attack Mr. Obama’s aides compared to the Swift Boat ads in 2004.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a direct attack on one of President Obama’s political strengths, a group of former special operations and C.I.A. officers started a campaign on Tuesday night accusing Mr. Obama of recklessly leaking information about the raid that killed Osama bin Laden and other security matters to gain political advantage.

headline: ‘Kinky Boots’ Sets April 4 Broadway Opening
abstract: The musical adaptation of the 2005 film will feature a score by Cyndi Lauper and star Billy Porter and Stark Sands.
lead_paragraph: “Kinky Boots,” one of the most anticipated musicals of the new Broadway season, with Cyndi Lauper making her debut as a songwriter for the stage, will begin performances on March 5, 2013, at the Al Hirschfeld Theater and open on April 4, the producers announced on Wednesday.

headline: Australia Restricts Company Logos on Cigarette Packs
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Labeling and Labels', 'Smoking and Tobacco', 'Trademarks and Trade Names']
abstract: Australia’s highest court upheld a law that restricts the use of tobacco company logos on cigarette packages.
lead_paragraph: Australia’s highest court upheld a law on Wednesday that prohibits tobacco companies from using their logos on cigarette packets, a decision that means smokers could see more of the graphic images associated with their habit: blistered, cancer-stricken mouths; children sick from secondhand smoke, and gangrenous limbs.

headline: At Ryan-Adelson Gathering, Budget Talk Trumps Israel
abstract: Details start to emerge of what went on during Paul D. Ryan’s private meeting with Sheldon Adelson and other donors in Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — At a private gathering with Representative Paul D. Ryan, Sheldon Adelson, the billionaire casino owner and Republican super-donor, offered no public remarks and, somewhat surprisingly, his pet cause of Israel was not part of the conversation, according to an attendee.

headline: Wells Fargo Offers E-Receipts to Branch Customers
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Wells Fargo online banking customers can now get electronic receipts when visiting branches.
lead_paragraph: Lots of retailers — the online kind and the brick-and-mortar version — have begun offering electronic receipts for purchases to help cut down on paper clutter in your wallet. So why shouldn’t banks get into the act, too?

headline: Long Island Man Is Charged With Insurance Fraud in Faked Drowning Case
abstract: Raymond Roth, 47, was arrested at a hospital with psychiatric services in Nassau County where he had admitted himself early this month.
lead_paragraph: A Long Island man suspected of faking his drowning to collect more than $400,000 in life insurance was arrested Wednesday and formally charged with insurance fraud, conspiracy and filing a false report.

headline: Romney on Regulation
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The man who wants to repeal Dodd-Frank said on Wednesday that “no one is talking about deregulating Wall Street.”
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney’s response to Joe Biden’s latest verbal fumble has been both totally predictable and totally baffling.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Mars on View, and Odes to Minecraft
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday’s selection includes a Curiosity Rover app and song parodies from fans of the game Minecraft.
lead_paragraph: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: ‘Now 43’ Compilation Tops Album Chart
abstract: The 43rd installment of “Now That’s What I Call Music!” tops the Billboard album chart.
lead_paragraph: After a nine-week run at No. 1, Carly Rae Jepsen’s song “Call Me Maybe” has finally been bumped from the top spot, by Flo Rida’s “Whistle.” But Ms. Jepsen’s song is now part of a different No. 1. It is the first track on the latest installment — Vol. 43 — of “Now That’s What I Call Music!” — the long-running pop compilation series, which opens atop Billboard’s album chart this week.

headline: Embracing the Right Fit
abstract: There is already a lot of amorous language for Paul Ryan, but his suits could use an adjustment.
lead_paragraph: SO far, the Mitt Romney-Paul Ryan ticket has been given the approval rating typically reserved for a Hollywood bromance in the dead of August. Two thumbs up for the cute Republican dudes!

headline: Illegal Immigrants Line Up by Thousands for Deportation Deferrals
abstract: People who arrived in the United States as children and wish to stay lined up for blocks in several cities on the first day to apply for deportation deferrals and work permits.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Tens of thousands of young illegal immigrants waited excitedly in lines as long as a mile and thronged to information sessions across the country on Wednesday, the first day that a federal immigration agency began accepting applications for deportation deferrals that include permits to work legally.

headline: In Store | French Tips
abstract: Seven years since opening her pioneering multibrand boutique on Avenue Montaigne, Liliane Jossua shows that her eye for finding sexy pieces that women want to wear is sharper than ever.
