headline: 9/11 Museum Asks for Dismissal of Suit Over Cross
abstract: Leaders of the National September 11 Memorial and Museum are asking a federal court to dismiss a lawsuit seeking to block them from displaying a cross-shaped beam salvaged from the World Trade Center ruins.
lead_paragraph: The National September 11 Memorial and Museum filed court papers this week seeking to dismiss a federal lawsuit brought by a group of atheists who oppose the museum’s decision to display the giant cross-shaped steel beam that became a site of daily prayer during the cleanup of ground zero.

headline: Inflation Deflation
abstract: Is the 12-month inflation rate 1.4 percent, or is it 2.3 percent, or something in between? All of the above.
lead_paragraph: The Bureau of Labor Statistics estimated on Wednesday that prices rose at an annual pace of 1.4 percent over the 12 months ending in July, and even more slowly during July itself. The Federal Reserve likes an annual rate of 2 percent. So it’s time for more stimulus, right? QE33333333333!

headline: Bridgewater to Spend $750 Million on New Offices
abstract: The hedge fund giant will be constructing a state-of-the-art headquarters along the waterfront of Stamford, Conn., as part of an economic and community development initiative.
lead_paragraph: There are hedge funds, and then there is Bridgewater Associates.

headline: Ratification of Union’s Deal With Caterpillar May Face Difficulties
abstract: The accord would end a three-and-a-half-month walkout in Joliet, Ill., but local union leaders called for its rejection.
lead_paragraph: Caterpillar and the International Association of Machinists said on Wednesday that they had reached a tentative six-year settlement that could end a 15-week strike at the company’s hydraulics parts plant in Joliet, Ill.

headline: On Our Radar: Wildfires in Washington State
abstract: Altogether the fires have burned some 500,000 acres across a parched Idaho, Washington, Oregon and California.
lead_paragraph: Firefighters battle more than a dozen wildfires across the West, including a massive out-of-control blaze that has burned over 28,000 acres between two national forests in Washington State. [Reuters]

headline: Scouting Report
abstract: Macy’s opened part of its new shoe area; Rent the Runway has a permanent showroom and Fashion’s Night Out has a new event site.
lead_paragraph: OPENINGS

headline: The Young Person’s Guide to the (Smartphone) Orchestra
abstract: Tablets and smartphones can be an easy way for children to learn the fun of playing musical instruments.
lead_paragraph: When I was a toddler, my parents introduced me to music-making through a cheap plastic recorder. Later came a secondhand violin and the tireless efforts of my school’s choir teacher. It was all fun, even if I found it so hard to learn violin the “traditional” way. All I could produce for ages was a horrid squeaking.

headline: The Joys and Hazards of Self-Publishing on the Web
keywords: ['E-Books and Readers', 'Books and Literature', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Most self-published books don’t sell a lot of copies. But it’s easier than ever to try one’s luck.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, an aspiring book writer rejected by traditional publishing houses had only one alternative: vanity publishing. For $5,000 or $10,000, or sometimes much more, he could have his manuscript edited and published, provided that he agreed to buy many copies himself, often a few thousand or more. They typically ended up in the garage.

headline: A Man’s Humdrum Life Suddenly Turns Potent
abstract: Jonathan Tropper’s sixth novel is about Drew Silver, a divorced part-time drummer in an over-the-hill rock band, supporting himself partly by selling specimens to a sperm bank.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Tropper’s slick, manipulative new novel is about a lovable sad sack named Drew Silver. “You’ve got that kind of cuddly bad-boy thing going on, like you’re dangerous, but only a little bit, you know?” his daughter tells him.

headline: Missed Chance to Reject Voting Barriers
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Editorials', 'Identification Devices']
abstract: A Pennsylvania ruling requiring a government-issued photo ID card to vote is a sign that Republicans have manipulated legislation for their own ends.
lead_paragraph: Judge Robert Simpson of the Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania seems to assume that legislators have a high-minded public purpose for the laws they pass. That’s why, on Wednesday morning, he refused to grant an injunction to halt a Republican-backed voter ID law that could disenfranchise hundreds of thousands of poor and minority state residents in November.

headline: A Beach Body Built in Wisconsin
keywords: ['Exercise', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: Forget Jane Fonda. Paul Ryan, the presumptive vice-presidential candidate, is the one to sell a fitness program.
lead_paragraph: WHEN it comes to free celebrity endorsements, they don’t get much better than a presumptive vice-presidential candidate who swears by your product.

headline: Despite Alarm by U.S., Europe Lets Hezbollah Operate Openly
abstract: Washington and Jerusalem insist Hezbollah is a resurgent terrorist group with Iranian backing, but the European Union treats it as a Lebanese social and political movement.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — As American officials sound the alarm over what they call a resurgent threat from the Shiite militant group Hezbollah, thousands of its members and supporters operate with few restrictions in Europe, raising money that is funneled to the group’s leadership in Lebanon.

headline: Cisco Revenue and Profit Exceed Forecasts as Orders in Asia Stay Strong
abstract: The computer networking giant overcame a challenging environment for corporate spending. Its stock rose 5 percent after hours.
lead_paragraph: Cisco Systems, the world’s largest maker of computer networking equipment, delivered quarterly results on Wednesday that slightly surpassed Wall Street’s expectations in a challenging environment for corporate technology spending.

headline: A Thorny Flower
abstract: When it comes to flamboyantly glamorous interiors, Rose Cumming — the dealer-decorator who opened for business in New York in 1921 and drew her last autocratic breath in 1968 — is still the one to beat.

headline: Casino Plan Runs Into Opposition in Spain
abstract: The legal troubles of the American casino mogul Sheldon G. Adelson in the United States and Macau are fueling opposition to his plans to build a casino and resort in Madrid or Barcelona.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Two struggling Spanish cities, Madrid and Barcelona, have been eagerly courting the billionaire casino magnate Sheldon G. Adelson for months, each of them trying to become the site of his planned casino and leisure resort.

headline: Scene City: A Book Sale, Hamptons Style
abstract: The East Hampton Library holds its annual Authors Night benefit with a book sale and private dinners.
lead_paragraph: The East Hampton Library holds its annual Authors Night benefit with a book sale and private dinners.

abstract: Less than two weeks of summer left in most parts. What will you pack into those last days?
lead_paragraph: Less than two weeks.

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The New York State attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, subpoenaed several banks last month, including JPMorgan Chase, Deutsche Bank and the Royal Bank of Scotland.
lead_paragraph: State regulators are widening their investigation into interest rate manipulation, pursuing wrongdoing at seven of the world’s biggest banks.

headline: Anybody Have a Book?
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Parties (Social)', 'Philanthropy', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: At the East Hampton library authors night, literary luminaries gather to help a good cause (and to sell some books).
lead_paragraph: ONCE you write a book, the work isn’t finished. You still have to get people to buy it.

headline: Another Trial Is Scheduled for Man Charged in 2008 Killing of Psychologist
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Defense lawyers said they would not challenge a finding that their client is mentally fit. In 2010, a mistrial was declared when he became psychotic during jury selection.
lead_paragraph: A man accused of murdering a psychologist in her Upper East Side office in 2008 is set to face trial next year, after his lawyers said Wednesday that they would not challenge a finding that he was mentally fit. A 2010 attempt to try the man, David Tarloff, ended in a mistrial after he became psychotic during jury selection.

headline: New Big East Commissioner Can Talk Ambitions but Not Details
abstract: Mike Aresco, the new commissioner of the Big East, does not take over until September, so he does not emphasize specifics when answering questions about the conference.
lead_paragraph: There was much that Mike Aresco couldn’t address Wednesday, when he was formally introduced as the Big East’s newest commissioner at the Manhattan New York Athletic Club. New to collegiate administration, he still looked as his contemporaries would, with shadows under his eyes, though his job has just begun.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Syria, Pakistan, India and South Africa.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Pakistan, India and South Africa.

headline: Van Persie Heads to Manchester United
abstract: Arsenal sold Robin van Persie to Manchester United days before the start of the Premier League season.
lead_paragraph: Robin van Persie’s escape from Arsenal needs only a doctor’s approval before it becomes final.

headline: Frankie Valli and the Four Seasons Will Play Broadway
abstract: The show will celebrate the group’s 50th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: Frankie Valli and the Four Seasons will perform in a weeklong engagement at the Broadway Theater in October to celebrate the vocal group’s 50th anniversary, the producers announced on Wednesday. The show will run from Oct. 19 through 27.

headline: A Novel Asks Seattle to Laugh at Itself
abstract: Maria Semple, the author of “Where’d You Go, Bernadette,” a sendup of privileged Seattle, tells what she really thinks of that city.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Maria Semple made an instant, jarring discovery when she moved with her boyfriend and daughter from Los Angeles to Seattle, a city whose Patagonia-clad inhabitants like to talk about bicycling, the environment and the eternally dull question (in her opinion) of whether it might rain.

headline: Fall Trends
abstract: No. 1: the decorated jacket. No. 2: the wrap. No. 3: the new suit.
lead_paragraph: No. 1: the decorated jacket. No. 2: the wrap. No. 3: the new suit.

headline: Syrian Conflict Imperils Historical Treasures
keywords: ['ARCHAEOLOGY', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Fighting in Aleppo, Syria’s commercial capital, threatens to damage irreparably the stunning architectural and cultural legacy left by 5,000 years of civilizations.
lead_paragraph: Preservationists and archaeologists are warning that fighting in Syria’s commercial capital, Aleppo — considered the world’s oldest continuously inhabited human settlement — threatens to damage irreparably the stunning architectural and cultural legacy left by 5,000 years of civilizations.

headline: Big Retailers Plan Effort for Mobile Purchases
abstract: A group of big retailers, including 7-Eleven, Best Buy, CVS and Wal-Mart, are forming a company that will offer a way for customers to buy things with their smartphones.
lead_paragraph: Cash, credit or debit? You may one day have far more choices to make at the checkout counter. A group of big retailers, including 7-Eleven, Best Buy, CVS and Wal-Mart, said on Wednesday that they were forming a company that would offer a way for customers to pay for purchases with their smartphones, joining a wide array of businesses seeking a piece of this market.

headline: Broadway, Broadway, Here We Are! (Clap!)
abstract: Five Broadway newcomers in the “Bring It On: The Musical” cast discuss their first roles, their fears and the roles they would love to play.
lead_paragraph: POSTERS from infamous Broadway flops loom behind the young performers gathered for lunch recently at Joe Allen, the theater district restaurant. But for these exuberant actors, all making their Broadway debuts in “Bring It On: The Musical,” the brutal realities of the business couldn’t seem further away.

headline: Giving Their Regards
abstract: Five Broadway newbies are performing in “Bring It On: the Musical.”
lead_paragraph: Five Broadway newbies are performing in “Bring It On: the Musical.”

headline: Dreaming of a Life as Vivid as Her Art
abstract: For nine years Inocente Izucar was homeless in San Diego, moving more than 30 times, but that didn’t stop this teenager from having her first art show, a process documented in the film “Inocente.”
lead_paragraph: Inocente Izucar wants to join the circus someday and learn sign language. She paints her face every morning with colors and designs as bold as those on her sprawling canvases. She sometimes orders dessert before dinner because she emphatically believes “you can never go wrong with a root-beer float.”

headline: On Univision’s Nightly News, a Plea for Presidential Debate on Latino Issues
abstract: The hosts of “Noticiero Univision,” Jorge Ramos and María Elena Salinas, will urge Mitt Romney and President Obama to participate in a debate or forum for its Hispanic viewers.
lead_paragraph: Univision will use its nightly news broadcast on Wednesday to plead with both presidential campaigns to accommodate an additional debate, on Univision, directed at the issues of concern to Latino viewers.

headline: Hip-Hop’s Loyal Mascot Now Cheers Himself On
abstract: Thanks to help from his friends, 2 Chainz is hip-hop’s rising star.
lead_paragraph: 2 Chainz is 35, tall and gangly, all awkward angles. A working-class-minded interloper into a hip-hop era that has largely shelved self-presentations that are less than 110 percent polished, he juts out, tough to miss. His luxury restaurant is Benihana, not Philippe. His luxury brand is Polo, not Margiela. He rapped for more than a decade with little to no acclaim. He is nobody’s sex symbol.

headline: The Perplexity of Youths in a Group
abstract: The Smuin Ballet presented Trey McIntyre’s “Oh, Inverted World” at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: The opening work of the Smuin Ballet’s triple bill at the Joyce Theater on Monday provides evidence of one of the most singular choreographic minds working in ballet today. Trey McIntyre’s “Oh, Inverted World” — set to songs by the Shins — is a pop ballet, reminiscent of some of the best pop ballets of Twyla Tharp. Its subject, though, is one that I don’t remember Ms. Tharp tackling: the perplexity of young individuals amid the group.

headline: Pianist Greets Beethoven Like an Old Friend in a Festival Debut
abstract: The Austrian pianist Rudolf Buchbinder, making his Mostly Mozart Festival debut, played Beethoven’s Piano Concerto No. 3 in C minor on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: The Austrian pianist Rudolf Buchbinder has had a lifelong fascination with Beethoven, performing and recording the complete concertos and sonatas on several occasions. Beethoven “haunted me 24 hours, day and night, he often drove me half-crazy,” Mr. Buchbinder wrote about his experience of performing the sonata cycle in 1982.

headline: In Search of New Subjects to Spoof
abstract: IFC’s new series “Bullet in the Face” spoofs a variety of things, including exploitation films, comic-book fantasies and Asian shoot-’em-ups.
lead_paragraph: One good thing about “Bullet in the Face,” a new series starting Thursday night on IFC, is the theme song, a jazzy, torchy spoof of a “Goldfinger”-era James Bond anthem. The chorus serves as a convenient plot summary:

headline: Russian Mayor at Center of Protests Resigns
keywords: ['Police Brutality and Misconduct', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: Officials said Vladimir Strelchenko’s resignation as mayor of a Moscow suburb was unrelated to attacks on critics, including a newspaper editor who was beaten nearly to death four years ago.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — It was a conflict that made clear the impunity granted to public officials by Russia’s criminal justice system: The editor of a local newspaper was beaten nearly to death in 2008 after criticizing the mayor of a Moscow suburb, and the police barely feigned an investigation.

headline: Bridge Play at the Second World Mind Sports Games
abstract: At the Second World Mind Sports Games at the Lille, France, all three United States teams qualified for the round of 16.
lead_paragraph: LILLE, France — At the Second World Mind Sports Games here all three United States teams qualified for the round of 16, which started on Wednesday and will end on Thursday at 1:20 p.m. Eastern time. The results are at worldbridge.org.

headline: Tunisian Women March to Defend Equality
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Muslims and Islam', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: Thousands of Tunisian women marched in the capital, Tunis, Monday night, to protest a provision in the new Islamist government’s draft constitution describing women as “complementary to men.”
lead_paragraph: As Reuters reported, thousands of Tunisian women marched in the capital, Tunis, on Monday night to protest a provision in the new Islamist government’s draft constitution describing women as “complementary to men.” The 6,000 protesters pledged to defend the equality under the law they have enjoyed since Tunisia adopted its Code of Personal Status on Aug. 13, 1956.

headline: A Product With Devotees Tries to Widen Its Niche
abstract: The Pelican brand of protective cases for electronics overhauled its marketing strategy to reach more consumers by adding a Web presence and print and television ads.
lead_paragraph: THE Pelican brand of protective cases for electronics is well known, but only among users in fields like the oil industry, the military and aerospace. For years, the company’s primary form of marketing consisted of expos and trade publications.

headline: Johnson & Johnson to Remove Formaldehyde From Products
keywords: ['Formaldehyde', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Shampoos and Hair Products']
abstract: The announcement extended the company’s program to remove certain ingredients from baby products to include adult products.
lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson, which makes a range of personal care products like baby shampoo, acne cream and antiwrinkle lotion, announced plans Wednesday to remove a host of potentially harmful chemicals, like formaldehyde, from its line of consumer products by the end of 2015, becoming the first major consumer products company to make such a widespread commitment.

headline: On Frogs, Fungi, Climate and the New News Process
abstract: Two researchers focused on fungi, frogs and climate change explain their work and the challenges in communicating complicated science in today’s online environment.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, the University of South Florida press office put out a release to draw attention to an important new study finding amplified disease risk in frogs when exposure to a dangerous fungus coincides with increasingly varied temperatures. The headline was “Frogs Getting Sick from Climate Change.”

headline: Boundary: Keeping Cloud Software in Shape
abstract: Cloud-based applications feed off new data, check into different machines and deal with servers around the world. A start-up, Boundary, hopes to make a Big Data play out of mapping all this near chaos, improving performance and eventually predicting where there might be trouble.
lead_paragraph: With thousands of different software applications flying around the cloud of a data center’s computer servers and storage devices, things can get complex. There might be a business in explaining the story of their travels to overtaxed system managers.

headline: Eternally Under Construction
abstract: When John Archer finds an interesting piece of architectural salvage, he often builds a new wing around it.
lead_paragraph: When John Archer finds an interesting piece of architectural salvage, he often builds a new wing around it.

keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Salvage', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'ANTIQUES', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A one-man preservation society expands his house to fit all his salvage treasures.
lead_paragraph: DANVERS, Mass.

headline: The Cherished Remainders of a Luxe Life
abstract: Sotheby’s will auction treasures from two of Brooke Astor’s homes.
lead_paragraph: IN her heyday as the bejeweled empress of New York philanthropy, Brooke Astor entertained presidents, first ladies and a potpourri of pooh-bahs and literati at her elegant 14-room duplex on Park Avenue. And when she died on Aug. 13, 2007, at Holly Hill, her estate in Westchester County, at 105, she left behind two households’ worth of cherished possessions, including Qing dynasty lacquer furniture, a jade-and-diamond Cartier clock and dozens of 19th-century dog portraits.

headline: Seeking an Edge, Then Falling Off the Cliff
abstract: Baseball has the power to amaze and inspire, but the cheats keep pulling the sport down. Melky Cabrera was barred for 50 games after testing positive for testosterone.
lead_paragraph: The fastball left Matt Harrison’s hand at 93 miles per hour, headed for the inner half of the plate, belt high. This was the All-Star Game, last month in Kansas City, and any hitter might have done what Melky Cabrera did to that pitch: lash it on a line into the left-field bullpen for a home run.

headline: After Cabrera Is Suspended, Surprise and Sadness From the Yankees
abstract: Those who knew Melky Cabrera best from when he played for the Yankees gave the impression that they were stunned by the news that he was suspended.
lead_paragraph: The news that San Francisco Giants outfielder Melky Cabrera was suspended 50 games Wednesday for testing positive for testosterone was met with surprise and sadness in the Yankees’ clubhouse.

headline: Helen Gurley Brown, as Others Saw Her
abstract: Helen Gurley Brown as remembered by her friends and associates.
lead_paragraph: YOU can debate for hours whether Helen Gurley Brown liberated women or held them back, with her salacious cover lines, big-haired scantily clad cover girls and relentless focus on improving sex lives (hers and his).

headline: Skinny-Dipping in the City
abstract: Neighbors may not see you in an outdoor shower, but there are those traffic copters.
lead_paragraph: URBANITES: Consider the real estate luxuries that have consumed your thoughts, occupied your daydreams, perhaps even encroached upon your bank accounts, from the relatively modest (your own washer and dryer) to the truly extravagant (your own pool on the roof).

headline: In Yucatán, a Home for Two Travel Writers

lead_paragraph: A couple renovates a house in the Mexican state of Yucatán.

headline: In Mexico, a Dateline Beckons
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Design', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: After spending a week on assignment in Mérida, the capital of Yucatán, two travel writers return to live there.
lead_paragraph: TRAVEL writing, like any profession, has its advantages, the most obvious being the job itself: exploring faraway places on someone else’s dime. One drawback, though, is that travel writers are rarely able to immerse themselves in any one place.

headline: U.N. Panel Blames Syrian Army and Militia for Houla Massacre
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: An independent panel appointed by the United Nations to investigate rights abuses in Syria said Wednesday that the government’s armed forces and loyalist militias were responsible for the worst known atrocity in the conflict, the Houla massacre.
lead_paragraph: An independent panel appointed by the United Nations to investigate rights abuses in Syria said Wednesday that the government’s armed forces and loyalist militias were responsible for the worst known atrocity in the conflict, a massacre of 108 villagers, nearly half of them women and children, in the western village of Houla on May 25.

headline: Chandeliers
abstract: Sara Story, an interior designer, searches for the right chandelier for each room’s temperament.
lead_paragraph: Sara Story, an interior designer, searches for the right chandelier for each room’s temperament.

headline: Master of Suspense
abstract: Sara Story, an interior designer, likens a chandelier to “a piece of sculpture or jewelry” for a room that also happens to provide illumination and ambience.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Sara Story is looking for light fixtures, her feeling is, the bolder, the better.

headline: The King of Pants Hopes for a Second Reign
abstract: Known for his signature pants last decade, the designer Alvin Valley steps back into the spotlight, this time online.
lead_paragraph: POOR pants. You never hear economists pegging a market forecast to their lengths, as they do with skirts, or magazines celebrating “It” pants, as they do with bags and shoes. In boom times, as in lean years, pants are just pants.

headline: Market Ready
abstract: Would a fully equipped outdoor kitchen with appliances increase the resale value of my house?
lead_paragraph: Q. Would a fully equipped outdoor kitchen with appliances increase the resale value of my house?

headline: New York Times Magazine Plays New York Magazine in Softball, Everyone Gets Confused About Who’s On Which Team
abstract: So, big whoop, it turns out that some iPad designer at New York Magazine hit a home run in the bottom of the ninth to beat The New York Times Magazine. Winning isn’t everything.
lead_paragraph: Where we left off, on the fertile lowlands of Central Park’s public softball fields, our heroes from The New York Times Magazine were celebrating their first softball victory of the season (and maybe the last few years) against their archrival, The New Yorker. The score was around 9-1, some said. If only that were the only score of the summer we had to recall.

headline: Warning Issued on Codeine for Children
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration issued a warning on Wednesday after three children died from respiratory arrest caused by regular doses of codeine after surgery to treat sleep apnea.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration issued a warning on Wednesday after three children died from respiratory arrest caused by regular doses of codeine after surgery to treat sleep apnea. The agency cautioned parents and health workers to watch for symptoms of overdose, like unusual sleepiness, difficulty being aroused or awakened, confusion or noisy and difficult breathing.

headline: The Giants’ Top Pick Shows Grit and Speed
abstract: Running back David Wilson, a 2012 first-round draft pick from Virginia Tech, expects to be a starter at some point, though he realizes it will take time.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — David Wilson jogged close to the sideline, his right hand gripping a ball. In that moment at Monday’s practice, Wilson could hear the fans just 10 feet away.

headline: Even Turtles Need a Nice Place to Call Home
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'Turtles and Tortoises', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: A turtle pond installed by the popular children’s book author Jan Brett has apparently attracted at least one resident, not to mention a giant bullfrog.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, the children’s-book author and illustrator Jan Brett and her husband, Joseph Hearne, a bassist with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, installed a turtle pond on the grounds of their two-acre home in Norwell, Mass. It was inspired by her plan to write a book about an Eastern box turtle with wildflowers and ferns sprouting from its shell. In “Mossy,” due out next month (G. P. Putnam’s Sons; $17.99), the turtle spends some unhappy months on display at a natural-history museum until a penitent biologist restores it to its habitat.

headline: Ecuador to Let Assange Stay in Its Embassy
abstract: The government of Ecuador is letting Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, to remain indefinitely in its embassy in London as he seeks asylum.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — The government of Ecuador is prepared to allow Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, to remain in its embassy in London indefinitely under a type of humanitarian protection, a government official said in Quito on Wednesday night. Mr. Assange has been holed up in the embassy for two months seeking asylum.

headline: No House Training Needed
abstract: A new seating collection, designed by Owen Chuang and Cloud Lu of BiAugust, takes the form of a menagerie.
lead_paragraph: Visitors to the New York International Gift Fair this weekend will be greeted by a menagerie at the MollaSpace booth — a buffalo, lamb, dog and horse, all prepared to support you. Designed by Owen Chuang and Cloud Lu of BiAugust, the Black Animal Chair collection is handmade in Taiwan, where the two are based.

headline: In Connecticut, a Convergence of Green Thumbs
abstract: Sponsored by Hollister House Garden and the Garden Conservancy, the event will bring together master landscape designers of the Northeast.
lead_paragraph: From Aug. 24 to 26, gardeners may be inspired by earth-friendly techniques while exploring the art historian George Schoellkopf’s Hollister House Garden in Washington, Conn., at the symposium “Gardening Anew: Fresh Perspectives on the Garden.” Sponsored by Hollister House Garden and the Garden Conservancy, it will convene master landscape designers and plant gurus of the Northeast. Speakers will include Edwina von Gal, a designer whose clients include Richard Serra and Calvin Klein; William Cullina, executive director of Coastal Maine Botanical Gardens, a 250-acre expanse of organically grown native plants; and Eric T. Fleisher, director of horticulture for Battery Park City Parks Conservancy, who will discuss composting, soil biology and water conservation. Late-season plants from New England’s best nurseries will be sold, and there will be tours of seven area gardens, including Mr. Schoellkopf’s 25-acre masterpiece, developed over three decades.

headline: Counting Stanzas and Couplets Instead of Sheep
abstract: At Comma Workshop in Colorado, quilts are embroidered with poetry.
lead_paragraph: It’s not easy to read Kerry Larkin’s poetry without feeling the tug of the natural world. Truth be told, it’s not easy to read Ms. Larkin’s poetry, period. Sometimes the words are embroidered in white on white, and the messages are more like texture. Or in A Perfect Moon, above left, which mentions “pines that resemble construction paper cut outs against the almost black sky,” the lines are alternating bands of autumnal color.

headline: On Madison Avenue, a New Vibe
abstract: Conspicuous consumption has made a resounding return to Madison Avenue, at least on that mile of glistening shops stretching north of Barneys New York at East 60th Street. But it isn’t quite the same Madison Avenue as what was there before.
lead_paragraph: Conspicuous consumption has made a resounding return to Madison Avenue, at least on that mile of glistening shops stretching north of Barneys New York at East 60th Street. But it isn’t quite the same Madison Avenue as what was there before.

headline: Industrial Ingenuity (Just Add Water)
abstract: The 30-piece R. W. Atlas Collection, designed by Roman & Williams for Waterworks, has a strong industrial sensibility.
lead_paragraph: Roman & Williams, the design firm founded by Robin Standefer and Stephen Alesch, won fame for its scene-setting interiors for Manhattan’s trendy Ace and Standard Hotels, as well as the restaurants, bars and cafes within them. Now it’s moved on to product design, with bath fittings for Waterworks. The R. W. Atlas collection, which was inspired in part by a 1930s Leica camera and by an old microscope displayed in the designers’ offices, has a strong industrial sensibility; it would look at home in any vintage factory setting.

headline: Though Tone Is Familiar, Scott Has His Eye on a Different Result
abstract: Coming off a tough season, linebacker Bart Scott likes the athleticism of the Jets’ defensive line, the physicality of the new safeties and the confidence of quarterback Mark Sanchez.
lead_paragraph: CORTLAND, N.Y. — Jets linebacker Bart Scott spoke off the field Wednesday, and he still sounded like the player whose outspokenness helped him earn the nickname the Mad Backer.

lead_paragraph: Baker furniture has introduced an Odds & Ends outlet Web site, updated weekly, with items up to 75 percent off (a Bill Sofield for Baker Cheval dining table, usually $10,124, is $2,531); (866) 222-3060, bakeroddsandends.com.

headline: California: Man Convicted of Murder in Five Deaths From 2003 Wildfire
keywords: ['ARSON', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Forest and Brush Fires', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Rickie Lee Fowler, 30, intentionally set a fire in Waterman Canyon in the foothills above San Bernardino which burned 91,000 acres and 1,000 homes.
lead_paragraph: Rickie Lee Fowler, 30, was convicted of murder on Wednesday in the deaths of five men caused by a fire he intentionally set in 2003 in Waterman Canyon in the foothills above San Bernardino. The wildfire burned 91,000 acres and 1,000 homes. Investigators said Mr. Fowler was high on methamphetamine and angry with a friend who had thrown him out of his home. Witnesses reported seeing Mr. Fowler and another man fling a lighted flare into dry brush, the authorities said. Prosecutors said they would seek the death penalty.

headline: In Albany, Hopes of Making New York State a Yogurt Empire

headline: Maryland: Casino Bill Goes to Voters
abstract: The legislation would allow for a casino to be built in Prince George’s County and permit table games in casinos.
lead_paragraph: Maryland will get another casino and expand table games statewide if voters approve a measure signed by Gov. Martin O’Malley on Wednesday. The legislation would allow for a casino to be built in Prince George’s County and permit table games in casinos. It also would enable the state’s casinos to stay open all day and lower taxes at some of them. Mr. O’Malley said it would create 2,300 jobs and generate $200 million for education.

headline: Stoudemire Putting New Spin on Career
abstract: Amar’e Stoudemire, the pick-and-rolling, power-dunking star, is now a student of the low post, and his teacher is the Hall of Famer Hakeem Olajuwon.
lead_paragraph: Over a 16-month span that ended in May, Amar’e Stoudemire lost, in no particular order: his health, his brother, his head coach, his primacy in the Knicks’ universe, his scoring touch and, in the end, a little of his dignity.

headline: Mexico: Confessions Are Reported in the Killing of 5 Journalists
keywords: ['Confessions', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: The Mexican authorities announced Wednesday that captured members of a criminal cell had confessed to the killing of five journalists in the state of Veracruz this year.
lead_paragraph: The Mexican authorities announced Wednesday that captured members of a criminal cell had confessed to the killing of five journalists in the state of Veracruz this year. According to the state attorney, the criminals, one of whom was detained last week carrying identification cards belonging to Irasema Becerra, a recently slain newspaper employee, admitted to a total of 36 crimes. Press freedom activists expressed dissatisfaction with the announcement, saying that it was unacceptable for the authorities to announce the resolution of these cases based on confessions rather than conducting full investigations. A 2012 report from Human Rights Watch attributed the country’s failing justice system in part to the “acceptance by some judges of confessions obtained through torture and other ill treatment.”

headline: Iran Group May Remain on U.S. Terror List
abstract: The Mujahedeen Khalq, also known as M.E.K., has been lobbying to be removed from the State Department’s terrorist list, but its refusal to leave a camp in Iraq has caused concern.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — State Department officials are preparing for a possible decision by Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton to redesignate an Iranian opposition group as a terrorist organization, in part because of the group’s resistance to abandoning its camp in Iraq, two American officials said Wednesday.

headline: Syrian Rebels Said to Be Holding Elite Fighters From Iran
abstract: American officials said they had evidence that hostages taken by Syrian rebels were members of Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps, not pilgrims as described by the government in Tehran.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American officials said Wednesday that they had obtained credible information that at least some of the 48 Iranians captured in Damascus this month by Syrian rebels were members of Iran’s elite Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps, not the pilgrims described by the government in Tehran.

headline: U.S. Wins in Mexico for the First Time
abstract: With the exhibition victory, the United States men’s soccer team ended a 24-match road winless streak against Mexico that spanned 75 years.
lead_paragraph: The United States men’s soccer team ended a 75-year drought Wednesday night, defeating Mexico, 1-0, in a friendly for its first win on Mexican soil.

headline: The NBC Sports Network Hopes Ratings Will Rise
abstract: With the Olympics gone, the channel is making changes to get more traction in the ratings.
lead_paragraph: In past lives, it was called the Outdoor Life Channel, OLN and Versus. But by any name, the NBC Sports Network has been a blip in a universe dominated by ESPN.

headline: Hernandez Latest to Achieve Perfection, to Fans’ Delight
abstract: In what has become the year of the perfect game, Felix Hernandez of the Mariners added his name to the list, marking the first time that three pitchers have pulled off the feat in the same season.
lead_paragraph: In what has become the year of the perfect game, Felix Hernandez of the Seattle Mariners added his name to the list Wednesday, marking the first time that three pitchers have pulled off the feat in the same season.

headline: Even in a Scrabble Match, ‘Cheat’ Is a 4-Letter Word
abstract: Scrabble’s national championship tournament was shaken by the disqualification of one young player for pocketing blank tiles in an attempt to cheat.
lead_paragraph: Bending the rules in sports and games may have just gotten its biggest global exposure at the Olympics, where we learned, among other things, that losing in badminton and soccer is an actual strategy (and one the International Olympic Committee officially frowns upon). But now cheating has moved into a more puzzling arena: competitive Scrabble.

lead_paragraph: NEW data released last month signaled a milestone for American energy: natural gas joined coal as the top source of electric power. Gas production has boomed on the back of abundant supplies. That has spurred debates over hydraulic fracturing, a method to extract gas from shale.

headline: A Chinese Murder Mystery, Far From Solved

lead_paragraph: LAST Thursday’s hastily orchestrated murder trial of Gu Kailai, the wife of the ousted Chinese Politburo member Bo Xilai, has raised several questions that cast serious doubt on the case.

headline: The View From Pyongyang
abstract: In North Korea, a change in the face of the leadership and of the capital city, but not of policy.
lead_paragraph: LIKE Havana, only more so, the North Korean capital, Pyongyang, is bereft of commercial billboards but covered with propaganda posters. In recent years, however, one company has been allowed to advertise its products: Pyonghwa Motors, a joint venture between the Rev. Sun Myung Moon’s South Korea-based Unification Church and North Korea’s state-run Ryonbong General Corporation. A few signs promoting the company’s Whistle sedan can be seen in Pyongyang and surrounding areas. Essentially a Hyundai, the Whistle is an increasingly common sight on Pyongyang streets, along with a growing number of BMW, Lexus, Mercedes, Nissan and other luxury and nonluxury vehicles, many privately owned.

headline: With Arena, Rapper Rewrites Celebrity Investors’ Playbook
abstract: Jay-Z, who owns one-fifteenth of a percent of the Brooklyn Nets, has put his mark on almost every facet of the enterprise, his partners say.
lead_paragraph: When the developer Bruce Ratner set out to buy the New Jersey Nets and build an arena for them in Brooklyn, he recruited Jay-Z, the hip-hop superstar who grew up in public housing a couple of miles from the site, to join his group of investors.

abstract: Statements by a former Israeli national security adviser seemed to buttress a theory that Israeli saber rattling is primarily an effort to push the United States to bolster sanctions.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A former Israeli national security adviser said Wednesday that the prime minister and the defense minister told him this week they had not yet decided to attack Iran’s nuclear facilities and could be dissuaded from a strike if President Obama approved stricter sanctions and publicly confirmed his willingness to use military force.

headline: Coalition Aims to Link School Group and Romney

lead_paragraph: Hoping that New Yorkers will think of “Romney” as a dirty word, a coalition of labor unions and liberal advocacy groups is beginning a campaign on Thursday to tie the presumptive Republican presidential nominee to defenders of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s education policies.

abstract: A 28-year-old gunman shot and wounded a security guard in the lobby of the Family Research Council, a conservative Christian organization, the F.B.I. said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A gunman trying to enter the downtown offices of a conservative policy organization on Wednesday morning shot and wounded a security guard before he was wrestled to the ground and arrested, a city police officer said.

headline: Middle-Age Blues
keywords: ['Elderly', 'Medicare', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid', 'Privatization']
abstract: We are learning so much about Paul Ryan, people! But what will this all mean to the American health care system?
lead_paragraph: Paul Ryan is everywhere! Nobody can talk about anything but the congressman from Wisconsin. We now know he is the intellectual, spiritual and moral center of the House of Representatives, who keeps his body fat below 8 percent and excels at a sport that involves sticking your hand inside a catfish, grabbing it by the tonsils and pulling it out of the water. Also, I believe he may have been the guy who ran the men’s relay race in the Olympics on a broken fibula.

headline: A Freebie Too Far
abstract: State Senator Tony Avella of Queens did the right thing when he concluded that free tickets from the United States Tennis Association exceeded the state’s gift ban.
lead_paragraph: Most tennis fans can only dream about receiving the kind of thick, cream-colored invitation that State Senator Tony Avella of Queens got recently in the mail. The United States Tennis Association was pleased to invite him and a guest to view this year’s tennis championships, which begin Aug. 27. They could sit in the President’s Suite. They could pick “one session of your choice” during the first week. This is tennis at its best, viewed from the best seats in Arthur Ashe Stadium.

headline: Risk Builds as Junk Bonds Boom
abstract: Demand for high-yield corporate debt is insatiable, even as analysts warn that the market has become overheated and is ripe for a fall.
lead_paragraph: Money market funds pay next to nothing. Interest rates on United States Treasuries are dismal. The volatile stock market has been dead money for more than a decade.

headline: Pink Pants, Trotters and an Entourage

lead_paragraph: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — Normally on the dark day here, Tom Durkin sleeps late and catches up on bills and errands. It’s the only day off for the voice of New York racing when the Saratoga meet is in session, and Durkin cherishes his alone time and silence.

headline: Muni Bonds Not as Safe as Thought
keywords: ['Municipal Bonds', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Government Bonds', 'Interest Rates', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Municipal bonds are widely seen as one of the safest investments, but this belief is based on records for a narrow slice of the market, according to new research.
lead_paragraph: Municipal bonds, widely seen as one of the safest investments, actually default more often than most people realize, according to research issued Wednesday by economists at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

abstract: Facing strident criticism, President Mohamed Morsi’s government has suspended a satellite television channel, confiscated copies of a newspaper and censored columnists in a state newspaper.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Several recent moves by government authorities against Egyptian journalists have drawn sharp criticism from the news media and led to accusations that the country’s new Islamist president is willing to tolerate — if not employ — the same heavy-handed tactics used by former President Hosni Mubarak to stifle dissent.

headline: Judge Urges Apple and Samsung to Settle Their Patent Dispute

lead_paragraph: The judge presiding over an intellectual property dispute between Apple and Samsung Electronics said on Wednesday that the chief executives of the two companies should talk again before the jury begins its deliberations.

lead_paragraph: Afghanistan can be a hard and cruel land, especially for women and girls. Many fear they will be even more vulnerable to harsh tribal customs and the men who impose them after American troops withdraw by the end of 2014.

headline: Keyed Up
abstract: Ethan Cooper shows us a few shortcuts.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — In solving this Thursday puzzle from Ethan Cooper, I found that many of my hunches and first guesses just wouldn’t fit. It started at 1 Across with “Swiss —”, when I felt a compulsion to fill in “cheese,” particularly because it started with a “ch.” That would have been too many letters, though, and the right answer was the much healthier Swiss CHARD.

lead_paragraph: A criminal investigation into the collapse of the brokerage firm MF Global and the disappearance of about $1 billion in customer money is now heading into its final stage without charges expected against any top executives.

lead_paragraph: The WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange on Thursday was granted political asylum by Ecuador, whose embassy in London is currently shielding him. headline: Paul Ryan and the Art of the Possible
abstract: A further look at Ryan’s recent record.
lead_paragraph: In my Campaign Stops column this week, I make the point that you have to look at Paul Ryan’s record over the last few years in the context of where his party stood after the 2008 election — moribund, deluded, and potentially self-destructive — and recognize 1) how much he’s done to move the Republicans in a more constructive direction and 2) that many of the problems with his famous/infamous House budgets reflect his party’s continuing deficiencies rather than his own. The absence of a replacement for Obamacare in the budget, for instance, doesn’t mean that Ryan hasn’t come out for such a replacement. (He has.) Likewise with the absence of Social Security reform and the implausible cuts to discretionary spending that this absence entails: Ryan’s original Roadmap deals with Social Security in a more serious and plausible way; he just hasn’t been able to get all of his House colleagues onside.

lead_paragraph: IN late May, a week after she graduated from Yale University, 22-year-old Marina Keegan headed to her family’s summer cottage on Cape Cod to begin revisions of “Independents,” a musical whose book she had written the summer before. The plan was for her to be joined there by the show’s director, lyricist and composer, but she never made it; the car in which she was riding crashed, killing her.

headline: What Does Your Fridge Door Say About Your Family?
abstract: What does it say about the degree to which “ephemera” has taken over our home that I have tried — and failed — to organize the front of our fridge?
lead_paragraph: Want to spend some time thinking about who your family is, and how the way you live reflects the way you really want to live, as opposed to the life that you’ve settled into, somehow, without much thought?

headline: On Our Radar: Appalachian Coal for India
abstract: Kentucky’s coal producers have been searching for foreign customers as the United States moves away from coal-fired generating plants.
lead_paragraph: The Booth Energy Group and the River Trading Company announce a $7 billion deal that could send nine million tons of coal a year to India from West Virginia and Kentucky. Such exports are rising as American demand for coal falls, as electric utilities burn more cheap natural gas. [The Associated Press]

headline: Finding George Orwell in Venezuela
abstract: Venezuela is almost free of illiteracy? True. That’s thanks to a drive by the Chávez government? False.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — In 2005, Venezuela became an official Territory Free of Illiteracy. A massively funded government literacy drive achieved, in just over a year, what decades of neoliberal neglect had failed to deliver: a country where every single person knows how to read.

headline: The Disunion of Myanmar
keywords: ['Buddhism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Rohingya (Ethnic Group)']
abstract: Rather than quell communal violence, the government of Myanmar is further stigmatizing the Rohingya Muslim minority to ingratiate itself with the majority.
lead_paragraph: MAUNGDAW, Myanmar — At the sight of several Rohingyas collecting firewood and bringing cattle to pasture, the driver who was taking me to Maungdaw, a small town near Myanmar’s border with Bangladesh, screamed out that they should all be kicked out of the country or the recent bout of sectarian violence opposing them to the Rakhines would never end.

headline: How Much Can Patients Learn in a 15-Minute Doctor Visit?
abstract: An increasing number of doctors, including many pediatricians, are scrambling to cover as many preventive recommendations as they can, piling on the dos and don’ts during office visits. Even so, patients and parents are often left confused and uninformed.
lead_paragraph: Built more like a former professional basketball player than an elementary schoolteacher nearing retirement, the patient dropped a bagful of prescription medications on the table in the examining room and fell back into a chair. He couldn’t remember what most of them were for.

headline: Two Deputies Are Shot and Killed in a Louisiana Ambush

lead_paragraph: LAPLACE, La. — Two sheriff’s deputies were shot and killed early Thursday morning and two others were wounded in ambushes at a parking lot and a trailer park in this town about 25 miles up the Mississippi River from New Orleans.

headline: Marketer of Student Debit Cards Settles Charges of Improper Fees
abstract: Higher One, a big issuer of campus debit cards, agreed to settle with the federal regulators and change the way it charges fees for non-sufficient funds.
lead_paragraph: Higher One, a big marketer of student debit cards, agreed to repay $11 million to 60,000 students to settle allegations that it had charged excessive fees to students who overdrew their accounts, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said.

headline: Justice Dept. Approves, With Changes, Verizon Wireless Spectrum Purchase
abstract: The deal to pay $3.6 billion for wireless airwaves owned by Time Warner Cable, Comcast, Cox Communications and Bright House Networks still needs F.C.C. approval.
lead_paragraph: The United States Justice Department approved a deal struck by Verizon Wireless to purchase spectrum from the country’s largest cable operators, but officials also required that the agreement be altered to protect against higher prices for consumers.

headline: The Get | Smythson’s Currency Case
abstract: A 1966 classic, updated in time for Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Back in the 1950s, Katherine Hepburn wouldn’t board a plane without her Smythson address book. In its pages, Hepburn logged meetings with friends like Laurence Olivier, Frank Sinatra and Vivien Leigh. On its cover, she’d stamped her initials K.H. and three places she frequented — London, California and New York — initiating a new way to personalize paper goods. (For memorabilia buffs, Hepburn’s book is currently on display in Smythson’s in-store museum at 4 West 57th Street.) Now, in honor of Hepburn’s brilliant idea, the London stationer is offering four-zipper currency cases embossed with Fashion Week’s four biggest cities — New York, London, Milan and Paris — and available with the option of monogramming, too. An update on the company’s original 1966 currency case, these new ones come in violet, olive and classic brown crocodile.

lead_paragraph: With the release of the bike messenger chase film “Premium Rush,” a look back at movie chase scenes.

abstract: Instagram, the popular photo-sharing application, released a new version of its service that will let users plot their archive of photographs on an interactive map of the world.
lead_paragraph: Instagram may be waiting for its billion-dollar sale to Facebook to be finalized, but the company is not resting on its laurels. The company, working out of offices in San Francisco, continues to crank out updates to its popular photo-sharing application.

headline: In Fuel Cells, Some Hope for Urban Sanitation
keywords: ['Chemicals', 'Engineering and Engineers', 'Microbiology', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Urban Areas', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: A team of engineers has developed fuel cells that harness a mix of microbes to clean wastewater while producing their own power
lead_paragraph: As more and more people around the world flock to cities, urban areas in developing nations are struggling to keep up with the human influx and the waste that people produce. In 2010 roughly 2.5 billion people lacked basic sanitation, according to the World Health Organization.

headline: Who Owns That House?
abstract: There’s money to be made in Precita Park, but there are also neighbors to be lost.

headline: Feverishly Pursuing a Nondigital Chase
abstract: David Koepp’s “Premium Rush,” starring Joseph Gordon-Levitt as a bike messenger in New York City, largely avoids computerized effects for its stunts in heavy traffic.
lead_paragraph: IT took a lot of nerve for the director David Koepp to include a chase under an elevated New York City train in “Premium Rush,” about a bike messenger’s frantic race to deliver a package from one end of Manhattan to the other.

headline: Update: Whither Eleanor’s Album?
abstract: A few weeks ago, we presented a minute mystery, hoping to identify the photographer who put together a small yet fascinating Christmas gift for an art teacher in 1915. How close did we come?
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, we published a piece about a modest yet fascinating photo album that had found its way to the displays of the University of New Mexico Art Museum. “Random Shots Compiled for the Edification of Eleanor T. Wragg” read its first page — it was a Christmas gift from 1915, made up of 25 photos. Its pictures varied from quiet silhouettes and commonplace scenes to divers, airplanes and Gov. Jim Ferguson at the Cotton Palace Parade in Waco, Tex.

headline: 5 Critics Who Deserve a Statue
abstract: That Brooklyn lacks an Alfred Kazin statue is almost enough to make a bookish type want to move to Oxford, England — or at least to Oxford, Miss.
lead_paragraph: In Sunday’s Riff, Dwight Garner, a literary critic for The New York Times, makes the case for critics who are actually critical. “Critics take a beating, especially in popular culture,” Garner writes. “Jean Sibelius’s observation — ‘No statue has ever been erected to a critic’ — seems to be cited somewhere weekly. As well-known quotations go, this one strikes me as especially banal. It implies something disheartening about our culture. . . . That Brooklyn lacks an Alfred Kazin statue is almost enough to make a bookish type want to move to Oxford, England — or at least to Oxford, Miss.”

headline: Those Julia Child Treasures
abstract: We asked for your favorite Julia Child recipes — the recipes that, unlike her storied boeuf bourguignon, are part of everyday kitchen life — and you delivered.
lead_paragraph: We asked for your favorite Julia Child recipes — the recipes that, unlike her storied boeuf bourguignon, are part of everyday kitchen life — and lo and behold, you more than delivered. The following is a list, selected from over 200 comments, that highlight your most treasured Child standbys. They also demonstrate that the lessons she taught us about food and cooking continue to resonate. (See all the suggested recipes, and add to the list, here.)

headline: Ira Glass: By the Book
abstract: The host of “This American Life” and co-writer of the coming film “Sleepwalk With Me” would like to meet Edgar Allan Poe. “I don’t have a question, but dude just seems like he could use a hug.”
lead_paragraph: The host of “This American Life” and co-writer of the coming film “Sleepwalk With Me” would like to meet Edgar Allan Poe. “I don’t have a question, but dude just seems like he could use a hug.”

headline: What’s Your Favorite Movie Chase Scene?
abstract: A new film about a bike messenger racing against time in New York City raises the question: What would you nominate for greatest movie chase scene ever?
lead_paragraph: For the coming film “Premium Rush,” about a bike messenger racing against time, a corrupt cop and a teeming city, David Koepp decided to include a chase under an elevated New York subway line even though he knew it would invite comparison with one of the greatest chase scenes of all time, the one in “The French Connection” with Gene Hackman in a car going after a bad guy in a train on the tracks overhead. As Mr. Koepp explained in this article about the difficulties of getting a pursuit right: “Shooting a chase scene in New York City, you’re standing on the shoulders of that giant. I almost didn’t do it, but I love the trestles.”

headline: Director Plans Pinter With a Twist, as Actresses Trade Off ‘Old Times’ Roles
abstract: In Ian Rickson’s forthcoming production, Kristin Scott Thomas and Lia Williams will alternate in the lead female roles, opposite Rufus Sewell.
lead_paragraph: Most actors have enough layers to explore with just one character in “Old Times,” an enigmatic 1971 play about identity and fractured memories by Harold Pinter, the Nobel Prize winner best known for psychological chillers like the “The Homecoming” and “The Caretaker.” But the theater director Ian Rickson has thrown down a challenge to leading ladies Kristin Scott Thomas and Lia Williams for an coming London revival of “Old Times” – they will alternate in the female roles of Kate and Anna, old friends who have not seen each other in 20 years.

headline: Lincoln’s Panama Plan
abstract: Even as he crafted the Emancipation Proclamation, the president was making plans to ship freed slaves to Central America.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 14 1862, Abraham Lincoln hosted a “Deputation of Free Negroes” at the White House, led by the Rev. Joseph Mitchell, commissioner of emigration for the Interior Department. It was the first time African Americans had been invited to the White House on a policy matter. The five men were there to discuss a scheme that even a contemporary described as a “simply absurd” piece of “charlatanism”: resettling emancipated slaves on a 10,000-acre parcel of land in present-day Panama.

headline: Wave of Attacks Kills Dozens in Iraq
abstract: A series of bombings and shootings wounded more than 100 people across Iraq, just as the Muslim holy month of Ramadan drew to a close.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A wave of attacks across Iraq killed more than 100 people on Thursday, including dozens of women and children at an amusement park, security and medical officials said.

abstract: Red Sox fans usually come out in droves when their team is in Baltimore, but with the Orioles playing well, that has changed.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The Hampton Inn on Washington Boulevard here is just a pop fly from Camden Yards. There is even a couch shaped like a baseball glove at the entrance.

headline: Few Voters Are Truly Up for Grabs, Research Suggests

abstract: Ridejoy, an online service that matches travelers who need rides with drivers who have space in their cars, is releasing an iPhone app.
lead_paragraph: Users of Ridejoy, the online ride-sharing service, can now take it on the road. The company released an iPhone app today to complement its Web site, which, like a motor version of CouchSurfing, matches travelers who need rides with drivers who have space in their cars.

headline: The Slightly Surprising Sex Lives of Teenagers
abstract: Fewer teenagers than one might have expected report having oral sex before intercourse.
lead_paragraph: New numbers show fewer teenagers than you might expect report having oral sex before vaginal sex. The myth of teenagers experimenting with oral sex, and not really considering it “sex,” has been around for a while, but this new data, from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s National Survey of Family Growth and reported in The Times’s Health section, shows that teenagers themselves tell researchers something different.

headline: As Diplomatic Efforts Stall in Syria, U.N. Says It Will End Its Observer Mission
abstract: The violent rebellion against President Bashar al-Assad’s government has left peacemaking efforts paralyzed.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations Security Council decided on Thursday to terminate the United Nations observer mission in Syria, where the increasingly violent rebellion against President Bashar al-Assad’s government has left diplomatic peacemaking efforts paralyzed. But the Security Council agreed to keep a much smaller United Nations office in the country, holding out hope that a political solution was still possible.

lead_paragraph: In March, Karl Rove wrote an Op-Ed for the Wall Street Journal in which he belittled the president’s decision to order the raid on Osama bin Laden. “Mr. Obama did what virtually any commander in chief would have done in the same situation,” Mr. Rove argued. “For this to be portrayed as the epic achievement of the first term tells you how bare the White House cupboards are.”

As Corky St. Clair might put it, a “beautifully wrapped, glossy, sweet-smelling show?” At the very least, Mr. Guest, a writer, director and star of comedies like “This Is Spinal Tap,” “Waiting for Guffman” and “A Mighty Wind,” has hit upon a project that will bring him back to series television.

headline: Garden of Notes by Author of ‘Animal Farm’
abstract: George Orwell’s diaries address his interests in politics but also his passion for nature and gardening.
lead_paragraph: My favorite biographical detail about George Orwell might be that, when he died from tuberculosis in 1950 at the age of 46, his favorite fishing poles were standing in the corner of his London hospital room. He hoped he’d be using them again, and soon.

headline: Postcards in an Artist’s Journey
abstract: Mr. Wegman’s refusal to take himself too seriously may explain why he has escaped the hero worship that is lavished on other Conceptual artists.
lead_paragraph: BRUNSWICK, Me. — Maine has loomed large in the work of numerous American painters, from Marsden Hartley, John Marin and Edward Hopper to Andrew Wyeth, Alex Katz and Lois Dodd. But William Wegman is probably the only Conceptual artist — if an erstwhile one — to have fallen hard for the state, as evidenced by “William Wegman: Hello Nature,” a beguiling exhibition at the Bowdoin College Museum of Art here.

headline: Russia Assigns Bodyguards to Judge Ahead of Verdict in Pussy Riot Trial
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Russian Orthodox Church', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Bodyguards have been assigned to protect the judge in Russia presiding over the trial of three members of the all-female protest band Pussy Riot after unspecified threats.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW – Russian authorities announced on Thursday that bodyguards have been assigned to protect the judge presiding over the trial of three members of the all-female protest band Pussy Riot, after unspecified threats. The authorities did not describe the threats to the judge, Marina Syrova, who is expected to announce a verdict and possible jail terms for the women on Friday.

headline: Study of Judges Finds Evidence From Brain Scans Led to Lighter Sentences
keywords: ['Brain', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Research']
abstract: Judges who were told that a defendant in a hypothetical case was genetically predisposed to violence imposed lighter sentences than they otherwise would have, researchers reported.
lead_paragraph: Judges who learned that a convicted assailant was genetically predisposed to violence imposed lighter sentences in a hypothetical case than they otherwise would have, researchers reported on Thursday, in the most rigorous study to date of how behavioral biology can sway judicial decisions.

headline: Making Art Out of November’s Election
abstract: Beginning early next month, the New York artist Jonathan Horowitz will exhibit “Your Land/My Land: Election ’12” — an installation designed to promote engagement with the issues raised by the coming election.
lead_paragraph: If you walked into almost any contemporary art museum in the country at the moment, you would have a hard time telling that a bitterly fought presidential election was entering its final months. And while it’s not exactly the job of such museums to be vigilantly topical, the New York artist Jonathan Horowitz thinks that contemporary art should be more engaged with the issues being raised by the election.
