headline: Fleur Show
abstract: The creative director of Dior fine jewelry is the latest to brilliantly re-imagine our signature initial.
lead_paragraph: T asked the Paris-based creative director of Dior fine jewelry, Victoire de Castellane, to redesign the magazine’s signature initial for the fall women’s issue knowing she’d create something wild and completely wonderful. Translating her elaborate three-dimensional jewels into a flat, two-dimensional illustration for our magazine was no easy task. To do so de Castellane looked to her home city, Paris, for inspiration. “I very much like to stroll around le jardin des Bagatelles, in particular the iris garden,” she explains. Below, de Castellane talks about the T that’s anything but your average garden variety.

headline: The Toucan and the Lion
abstract: Inside the Asian gastro pub in the East Village, where Southeast Asian flavors make gleeful riot.
lead_paragraph: Inside the Asian gastro pub in the East Village, where Southeast Asian flavors make gleeful riot.

headline: Video Shows South African Police Shooting Miners
keywords: ['Mines and Mining', 'Organized Labor', 'Police', 'Police Brutality and Misconduct']
abstract: A video shows South African police opening fire on striking miners, killing at least 18 people.
lead_paragraph: As our colleague Lydia Polgreen reports, at least 18 striking miners were shot dead on Thursday by South African police officers who opened fire as a crowd approached carrying machetes and sticks at a Lonmin platinum mine in Marikana.

headline: Mine Strike Mayhem Stuns South Africa as Police Open Fire
keywords: ['Strikes', 'Police Brutality and Misconduct', 'Mines and Mining', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Police']
abstract: The police fired on workers engaged in a strike at a platinum mine. The news agency SAPA reported that 18 people had been killed.
lead_paragraph: MARIKANA, South Africa — The police fired on machete-wielding workers engaged in a wildcat strike at a platinum mine here on Thursday, leaving a field strewed with bodies and a deepening fault line between the governing African National Congress and a nation that, 18 years after the end of apartheid, is increasingly impatient with deep poverty, rampant unemployment and yawning inequality.

headline: Bookstores for Gazers
abstract: Among the atypical gallerylike spaces hidden in New York are bookstores carrying hard-to-find art books or other rare publications.
lead_paragraph: Especially in the summer, when the sidewalks of the New York art world turn into barren, windswept places, I spend a lot of time visiting what I like to think of as a parallel art world, one that seems almost clandestine.

headline: Drop In, and by Appointment
abstract: Printed Matter, Specific Object and 6 Decades are among the smaller bookstores catering to the art world in New York.
lead_paragraph: PRINTED MATTER The grande dame of New York artist-book stores. Perpetually packed to the gills with stuff. It functions like a vast net for what seems to be every publication, great or small, being cranked out by artists. 195 10th Avenue, between 21st and 22nd Streets, Chelsea; (212) 925-0325, printedmatter.org.

headline: The Mediterranean On an Asian Plate
abstract: An Asian gastro pub in the East Village introduces Italian burratas, Filipino limes and Scotch eggs to one another. Will they all get along?
lead_paragraph: PEANUT BUTTER and cheese is a midnight blunder, a case of misguided nostalgia for the orange sandwich crackers in your “Super Friends” lunchbox. But at the Toucan and the Lion in the East Village, it makes for the most exciting dish on the menu.

headline: Lottery Lout
abstract: The title character of Martin Amis’s new novel is a thug who wins the lottery and becomes a tabloid darling.
lead_paragraph: Pity poor Lionel Asbo, a thug burdened by a vestigial conscience, his every ignoble thought and gesture determined by his maker, Martin Amis, a man not given to mercy. The antihero of Amis’s new novel, “Lionel Asbo: State of England,” Lionel takes the kind of drubbing only satire can sustain. The youngest of the seven mostly criminal and largely dysfunctional children his mother bore by the age of 19, Lionel works at “the very hairiest end of debt collection.” Like his literary progenitor, the jet-setting John Self of Amis’s 1984 novel, “Money: A Suicide Note,” Lionel is in hot — desperate, tormented and doomed — pursuit of whatever gratifications might be wrung from the free fall and decline of contemporary society.

headline: Indianapolis Museum of Art Names New Director
abstract: The museum chose Charles L. Venable, the director and chief executive of the Speed Art Museum in Louisville, Ky., for the post.
lead_paragraph: The Indianapolis Museum of Art has chosen a new director, the museum’s board announced Wednesday.

headline: After MF Global, a Need to Find New Ways to Protect Customers
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Commodities', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: In theory, customer property at a brokerage firm should be even more secure than money deposited in a bank. Somehow, it never quite seems to work out that way.
lead_paragraph: The MF Global story still lingers as an insolvency matter, but now we hear rumblings that there will be no criminal charges. It may well be that no crimes were committed, but if this is so, it is time to seriously rethink how broker-dealers handle customer property.

headline: Getting Rental Car Coverage for Luxury Vehicles
keywords: ['Automobile Insurance and Liability', 'Credit Cards', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Rental car insurance is available for luxury cars for an extra fee, under American Express’s premium option.
lead_paragraph: Bucks recently reported on the differences in rental car insurance that consumers get, depending on which credit card they use to pay for the rental. The report noted that for basic coverage, available to cardholders at no charge, the major card networks generally exclude luxury vehicles and that American Express also excludes some popular sport utility vehicles.

headline: At Conventions, Strip Clubs Are Eager for Business
abstract: Gentlemen’s clubs in Tampa, Fla., and Charlotte, N.C., are extending a friendly welcome to conventiongoers — even as officials in both parties warn against partaking.
lead_paragraph: The convention organizers say no, no, no. But the gentlemen’s clubs of Tampa, Fla., and Charlotte, N.C., are saying yes, yes, yes.

headline: Sole Sisters
abstract: Cole Haan’s first limited-edition women’s collaboration features shoes by Olivia Kim of Opening Ceremony and Jen Brill, a brand ambassador for Chanel.
lead_paragraph: Cole Haan’s recent collaborations — with the musician Theophilus London on a pair of blue suede bucks and with the recording artist and designer Hiroshi Fujiwara on neon-accented wingtips — have offered men of style a new view of the venerable footwear brand. This fall, the company is giving its women’s line a similar treatment. For the first limited-edition women’s collaboration, Olivia Kim, Opening Ceremony’s vice president of creative, and her pal Jen Brill, a brand ambassador for Chanel and creative consultant, have created a collection of shoes that can be worn from day to night. “Being able to run around the city comfortably and still look cute is always a challenge,” Brill says. “That was the starting point of the design process.” Both women grew up wearing Cole Haan shoes, and for inspiration they turned to looks from the company’s archive, like a leather fisherman sandal from the mid-1990s and a 1970s clog. The twist? “We wanted to use colors that were different from what you may expect traditionally from Cole Haan,” Kim says of their collection’s three styles: a strappy sandal ($528), an ankle-strap pump ($528) and an ankle boot ($548), all rendered in jewel-toned Italian suede. “We personally love rich, saturated colors,” added Kim, whose hair is sometimes frosted pink. (Brill’s signature is red lips.) The Chelsea collection will be available Sept. 10 at the Cole Haan SoHo store (128 Prince Street; 212-219-8240). Kim and Brill, meanwhile, are hard at work on their holiday line; they say to expect metallic pastels and plenty of flash.

headline: 36 Hours in Johannesburg
abstract: In a city that offers a window into South Africa’s past, Johannesburgers are working to create a vibrant future.
lead_paragraph: TOURISTS who bypass Johannesburg and head straight to Cape Town or out on safari are missing one of Africa’s most thrilling metropolises. This former gold-rush town suffered in the aftermath of apartheid, but the revitalization that came with South Africa’s hosting of the soccer World Cup in 2010 has blossomed. With a major face-lift of the city’s infrastructure — including the two-year-old mass transit rail system, the Gautrain, which was completed in June — Johannesburg is showing off its virtues and overcoming its vices. Although crime in some precincts remains stubbornly high and a bit of caution is recommended, downtown Johannesburg is in the midst of a revival. Nowadays, young Johannesburgers from different backgrounds are working together to remake their city for the next generation, tapping into a wellspring of creative energy and entrepreneurial spirit. Parts of Johannesburg’s once-decrepit inner city have turned into a vital gathering place, including an old parking garage that now houses a food and fashion market, and a one-time alcohol warehouse that is today stocked with galleries and restaurants. New enticements seem to pop up every few months in this fast-changing dynamo of a city.

headline: Views of Johannesburg
abstract: Hopeful tours, colorful dining and a lively art scene converge in the South African city.
lead_paragraph: Hopeful tours, colorful dining and a lively art scene converge in the South African city.

headline: City’s Unemployment Rate Remains at 10 Percent
abstract: A loss of about 17,000 jobs in July did not change the unemployment rate, which matches the highest rate of unemployment the city had throughout the recession.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s unemployment rate remained as high last month as it ever was during the long recession that officially ended more than three years ago: 10 percent.

headline: An Intellect Highly Developed, but Not Superman
abstract: “Mike Kelley: 1954-2012” at the Watermill Center in Water Mill, N.Y., looks at the project that Mr. Kelley was working on when he committed suicide this year.
lead_paragraph: WATER MILL, N.Y. — Mike Kelley, the celebrated Los Angeles artist who took his own life at 57 this year, was a hero to many. But partly because he so determinedly defied traditional laws of stylistic consistency and coherence, the number of people who fully grasped what he was about is probably small.

headline: Serious Artists Plan Whimsy in the Sand
abstract: A sand-castle competition on Rockaway Beach will include structures by the design team Snarkitecture and the performance artist Kenya Robinson.
lead_paragraph: THERE’S a sand castle competition happening on Friday at Rockaway Beach in Queens, but don’t expect the typical driftwood drawbridges and sand-bucket cupolas.

headline: A Filmmaker’s Impressions of the Bayou
abstract: Benh Zeitlin, director of “Beasts of the Southern Wild,” talks about the “totally different culture” and crayfish pies he found in Louisiana.
lead_paragraph: BENH ZEITLIN, 29, wanted to make a film about holdouts — people in Louisiana’s bayou country who refused to evacuate from their homes during Hurricanes Katrina, Gustav and Ike.

headline: ‘Her Stories’
abstract: Shared features of this show include a feminist perspective, an activist spirit and a resistance to melting pot assimilation.
lead_paragraph: Queens Museum of Art, New York City Building

headline: New York Film Festival Unveils Main Slate Selections
abstract: New works by Noah Baumbach, Brian De Palma, Michael Haneke, Sally Potter and Alan Berliner are among the 32 features that will be presented in the main slate of the New York Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: New works by Noah Baumbach, Brian De Palma, Michael Haneke, Sally Potter and Alan Berliner are among the 32 features that will be presented in the main slate of the New York Film Festival, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Thursday. Mr. Haneke’s film “Amour,” which won the Palme d’Or at the Cannes Film Festival, will make its New York debut. The festival will also present the world premiere of Mr. Berliner’s documentary “First Cousin Once Removed,” about the poet Edwin Honig’s slowly succumbing to Alzheimer’s disease. Mr. Baumbach will be represented at the festival by “Frances Ha,” a comedy written with the actress Greta Gerwig and starring Ms. Gerwig as a young woman trying to start a dance career in New York.

headline: ‘Détournement’
abstract: This invigorating show proves that it is pleasing to see artists talking back to the soul-insulting banality of conventional advertising.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan LeVine

headline: Alex Gingrow
abstract: Ms. Gingrow’s show, “All the money IS in the label,” depicts gallery labels on paintings, but with a witty twist: Many of the titles seem to be quoting inane conversations overheard at exhibition openings.

headline: Darpa to the People: You Think It Up, We Make Sure It Shoots
keywords: ['Crowdsourcing (Internet)', 'Military Vehicles', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The military reaches out into the civilian crowd for new ideas on combat vehicles.
lead_paragraph: Most of us know what the term “crowdsourcing” means. It’s been around for more than five years now, and it’s been used to tackle big, complex tasks ranging from finding many people (after natural disasters) to finding one (after a plane crash). It’s been used for everyday problems like traffic and to answer scientific research questions. Crowdsourcing has even been used to make things, from books to videos.

headline: Pakistani Taliban Kill 22 Shiites in Bus Attack
abstract: The victims were mostly young men returning to their villages for Id al-Fitr, the Islamic festival that marks the end of Ramadan.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistani Taliban militants pulled 22 Shiites off buses and gunned them down in a remote northern mountain pass on Thursday, in the latest iteration of a pattern of attacks targeting religious minorities.

headline: CBGB Joins Efforts to Support Russian Punk Band
abstract: The promoters of the CBGB music festival have joined with Amnesty International to raise funds for the members of Pussy Riot, who are on trial in Moscow.
lead_paragraph: The promoters of the CBGB music festival in New York say they plan to sell special T-shirts and other merchandise online to raise money for the jailed members of the Russian punk rock band Pussy Riot, who face a prison term for singing a protest song in a church. On Friday in Moscow a judge declared them guilty of hooliganism.

headline: Behind the Robots in ‘Robot & Frank’
abstract: Images and sketches of the robots in the film, with commentary from its director Jake Schrier.
lead_paragraph: Images and sketches of the robots in the film, with commentary from its director Jake Schrier.

headline: Samurai Shopper | Dream Creams
abstract: Are you on board with exorbitantly priced skincare products? That’s the $64,000 question. Plus tax.
lead_paragraph: The Samurai recently went to see the newish movie “The Queen of Versailles,” a documentary about people with beer tastes and Champagne pocketbooks. But for the Samurai Shopper, that’s backward; my luxurious taste is often adulterated by a Pabst Blue Ribbon budget. Through the tricky economic stratagem of robbing Peter to pay Paul, I can occasionally spring for super-expensive skin care products that lighten, brighten and tighten. Why would I do this? Superman had kryptonite; I have Cle de Peau’s La Creme ($775 for 1.7 ounces).

headline: Hammer Museum Awards Its Crowdsourced Art Prize
abstract: Meleko Mokgosi is the recipient of the inaugural Mohn Award, a prize given by the Hammer Museum in Los Angeles whose winner is chosen by museumgoers from a pool selected by art professionals.
lead_paragraph: The people have spoken, and the winner is: Meleko Mokgosi.

headline: An Artistic Relationship Set in Stoneware
abstract: The works of the Bauhaus-trained ceramists Frans and Marguerite Wildenhain have returned to the limelight.
lead_paragraph: Frans and Marguerite Wildenhain, ceramists who trained at the Bauhaus, were torn from each other during World War II.

headline: For Europe’s Economy, a Lost Decade Looms
keywords: ['Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Euro (Currency)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: With the exception of Germany, none of Europe’s biggest economies have returned to the level of economic output they had at the beginning of 2008.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The euro zone is hurtling back into recession, economists declared after official figures this week portrayed a shrinking economy. But by some measures the downturn has been under way for years.

lead_paragraph: From New York’s North Fork to the California coast, 12 wine selections $20 and under that are worth investigating, listed in no particular order.

abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Thursday’s selection includes a third online publishing tool from the founders of Twitter and Blogger and musings on the possible design of the iPad Mini.
lead_paragraph: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: 3 Are Injured When Horse Sheds Coach in Manhattan
abstract: The spooked animal bolted near Columbus Circle, dumped its driver and toppled its carriage containing passengers, running into two cars. The horse escaped serious injury.
lead_paragraph: A spooked carriage horse burst out of line near Central Park on Thursday, thundered into the busy traffic on Columbus Circle, dumped his driver and two passengers, struck two cars, shed the wreckage of his carriage and ran free for four blocks before being captured on Ninth Avenue, the authorities and witnesses said.

headline: Bargains From American Vines
abstract: In the United States, unlike in the Old World, the wine industry did not evolve to make intriguing, inexpensive wines. But they do exist for $20 or less.
lead_paragraph: A FEW weeks ago, I wrote about wines at the coveted intersection of high value and low price. I suggested that the greatest concentration of value, where you could find wines that were not merely palatable, but exciting, was in the $15 to $25 range. And I recommended 20 bottles at $20 that were the kinds of wines I would look forward to drinking any day of the week.

headline: For Buckyballs Toys, Child Safety Is a Growing Issue
keywords: ['Magnets and Magnetism', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Babies and Infants', 'Toys']
abstract: Regulators are cracking down on products like Buckyballs, saying they are too attractive and hazardous to young consumers.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, two pals from Brooklyn came up with the idea of creating a desktop toy out of powerful magnets. Their creation, Buckyballs, became an instant hit. And by this year, the two — Craig Zucker and Jake Bronstein — had expected annual sales to reach about $25 million.

headline: City Picks Philadelphia Firm to Reopen Tavern on the Green
abstract: Emerald Green Group, which runs the Philadelphia restaurant Beau Monde, plans to reopen the space as a smaller, more rustic spot in 2013.
lead_paragraph: Aug. 17, 1:34 p.m. | Updated

headline: Master of a Shrinking Universe
abstract: “Cosmopolis,” directed by David Cronenberg and based on a novel by Don DeLillo, follows a young man with plenty of money.
lead_paragraph: The first image in David Cronenberg’s “Cosmopolis,” a cold, funny number about the erotics of money and the seduction of death, is that of a chrome grille on a white stretch limousine. The shot is a close-up that’s so tightly framed that the grille, with its U shape and vertical bars, looks as if it were smiling. It also looks like a shark, a perfect starting point for a story about a master of the universe who, over one long day and night, lives, eats, evacuates and fornicates in the limo. A master who, like some kind of millennial Jonah, has taken up residence in the belly of a new beast.

headline: This Week’s Movies | August 17
abstract: The New York Times critics on “Cosmopolis,” “Compliance” and “Chicken With Plums.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times critics on “Cosmopolis,” “Compliance” and “Chicken With Plums.”

headline: It’s ‘Amore,’ Her Father’s Way
abstract: Deana Martin, a daughter of Dean Martin, brings her show “Deana Sings Dino” to Feinstein’s at Loews Regency.
lead_paragraph: Deana Martin, the 63-year-old daughter of Dean Martin, might be described as a brassy, tarnished “chip off the old block” dusted with glitter. With a mischievous gleam in her eye, she recycled some of her father’s more famous remarks at Tuesday’s opening-night performance of her show “Deana Sings Dino” at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency.

headline: Slums of New York Teem With Life and Death
abstract: “Copper,” BBC America’s new series, tells the story of a police officer patrolling the Five Points neighborhood in post-bellum New York.
lead_paragraph: TO film “Gangs of New York,” Martin Scorsese painstakingly replicated the 19th-century tenements, saloons and almshouses of Lower Manhattan’s infamous Five Points. On the sprawling back lot of a studio outside Rome, he recreated an incandescent vista of the pentagonal intersection that epitomized the world’s worst slum.

headline: Fighting Crime in an Older, Dirtier Manhattan
abstract: The new BBC America series “Copper” is a period police procedural set in the Five Points neighborhood in 19th-century Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: “Copper” is BBC America’s declaration of independence: the first original drama from a channel built on British imports. And unlike the science-fiction and reality fare (“Doctor Who,” “Top Gear”) that BBC America has focused on, “Copper” is a prestige product, a dark and serious show that’s being thrown into the deep end of the cable television pool on Sunday night, where its time-slot competitors include AMC’s “Breaking Bad,” HBO’s “Newsroom” and USA’s “Political Animals.”

headline: The Grotesque, Weird Beauty of Vice’s Photo Issue
abstract: Vice magazine’s annual photo issue, showcasing a selection of projects by some of the magazine’s favorite photographers, is equal parts weird, beautiful and grotesque.
lead_paragraph: Vice magazine’s annual photo issue, showcasing a selection of projects by some of the magazine’s favorite photographers, is equal parts weird, beautiful and grotesque. The issue was originally produced by photographer (and former Vice photo editor) Ryan McGinley in 2001, and has become something of an institution for new photography. This year’s selection of pictures, on display last week at Brooklyn’s Black and White Gallery, was as intriguing as always, featuring images from more established artists like the South African photographer Roger Ballen (who photographed the band Die Antwoord for the Times magazine earlier this year) and younger artists like Elizabeth Renstrom (who is straight out of photography school) and 17-year-old Olivia Bee (who took the photographs for the Times magazine’s story on teaching teens about sex).

abstract: Photos from South Africa, Malta, Syria and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from South Africa, Malta, Syria and India.

headline: In N.H.L. Negotiations, Union’s Good Ideas May Not Matter
abstract: The N.H.L. players’ union has some interesting proposals, but the owners have the upper hand in the labor dispute and their primary goal is cutting salaries.
lead_paragraph: 10:59 a.m. | Updated Commissioner Gary Bettman and the owners may be coming off as the villains in the eyes of the public in the N.H.L. labor negotiations, but that won’t matter to them one bit, not while they have the chance to save hundreds of millions of dollars each year with a new collective bargaining agreement, and certainly not while they have the upper hand in these negotiations.

headline: Obama and Romney to Suspend Ads on 9/11
abstract: Both President Obama and Mitt Romney have agreed to suspend their campaign commercials on Sept. 11, in honor of the 2001 terrorist attacks.
lead_paragraph: It is quite likely the only reprieve Americans will get from what is expected to be an especially heavy and sustained barrage of political advertising this fall. But on Sept. 11, President Obama and Mitt Romney have agreed to suspend their campaign commercials.

headline: Time and CNN Reinstate Journalist After Review
abstract: The magazine says it is “entirely satisfied that the language in question in his recent column was an unintentional error.” His column will return to the magazine on Sept. 7. CNN likewise announced Mr. Zakaria’s return from suspension.
lead_paragraph: Time magazine and CNN are reinstating the commentator Fareed Zakaria after a review of his work in light of his admission that he plagiarized parts of a New Yorker article in a recent column for Time.

headline: How Hollywood Films Are Killing Opera
abstract: The common American idea of opera — as the most solemn kind of date night — has profoundly damaged it in this country.
lead_paragraph: “The opera?” the main character of Kenneth Lonergan’s recent film, “Margaret,” sourly asks her mother. “Why are you going to the opera?”

headline: Trial Delayed in Plot to Kill Saudi Envoy
abstract: Mansour J. Arbabsiar, an Iranian-American, had been interrogated for 12 days before he spoke with a lawyer or appeared before a judge last year.
lead_paragraph: The trial of Mansour J. Arbabsiar, an Iranian-American man accused of plotting to kill a Saudi ambassador, has been delayed, a federal judge said on Thursday, adding that he was concerned that the case was moving too slowly.

headline: Cycling and Socializing in Central Park
abstract: Several groups make bicycling around the park a social experience as well as a workout.
lead_paragraph: IF you’re looking for a cycling workout in New York City without having to navigate much traffic, the six-mile loop in Central Park offers one of the world’s best urban cycling courses. But for a less solitary ride, a variety of groups do the loop at paces from high octane to moderate to downright leisurely.

headline: Up Front
abstract: Kathryn Harrison on why she’s drawn to Joan of Arc, the subject of her next book.
lead_paragraph: Reviewing Martin Amis’s new novel, “Lionel Asbo,” this week, Kathryn Harrison observes that it harks back to Dickens in its themes and characters. But Harrison’s own work has been casting back farther than that lately, as she writes her biography of Joan of Arc. Joan’s story resonates on so many levels — the religious, the military, the political, the feminist — that we wondered which speaks loudest to Harrison.

headline: Seeing Ghosts Wherever He Looks
abstract: Norman, the focus of this beautiful-looking 3-D stop-motion animation, is an 11-year-old who cannot only see dead people, but is happy to hang out with them.
lead_paragraph: “ParaNorman,” a beautiful-looking, charmingly heartfelt 3-D stop-motion animation about a boy and his ghouls, comes with an assortment of hair-raising frights. Some of these are just the flesh-and-blood people in Norman’s life, the bullies and teachers and even relatives who, with degrees of impatience and love, chastise the 11-year-old for his unusually morbid habits. Norman, a sprout whose black hair stands at attention as if he were in a state of perpetual alarm (he is voiced with vivid emotion by Kodi Smit-McPhee), can’t help but be a little creepy. After all, he doesn’t just see dead people, he also hangs out with them, sometimes while watching creature-features on the family TV.

headline: Strange Tales Casting Wide Nets
abstract: For “A Living Man Declared Dead and Other Chapters I-XVIII,” the artist spent years chasing down stories and people to photograph.
lead_paragraph: Along with everything else that’s been deflated, downsized or drained of its power in our millennial lives, the image, formerly worth 1,000 words is now worth about 200 — maybe 250 on a good day. Now we rely on captions to convey meaning. These texts were already becoming obligatory in the 1930s, according to Walter Benjamin, but are now virtually a medium of their own.

headline: Cold Feat
abstract: As his wedding day loomed, the actor Andrew McCarthy braved more than just the snows of Kilimanjaro.
lead_paragraph: My pack is by the door; I leave in the morning. I am standing with my fiancée, D, in the kitchen. The sight of my waiting backpack has triggered her anxiety. She’s a different person than she was just a few minutes ago. “You’re always coming and going, leaving and coming, you have no time to love me,” she blurts out. We have just returned from a long, romantic dinner, after having spent the afternoon together. And now the tears come.

headline: Schools Pass Debt to the Next Generation
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Education (K-12)', 'Municipal Bonds', 'Mortgages', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Districts stymied by residents’ opposition to new taxes are finding creative ways to meet their responsibilities — often at extremely high costs.
lead_paragraph: The deleveraging of America is well under way, as individuals and companies recover from the excess borrowing that helped to produce the boom and left many people vulnerable when the bust arrived. Household debt is down nearly $900 billion over the last four years, partly from repayments and partly from defaults.

headline: Strings Coming Loose for a Violinist in Tehran
abstract: In “Chicken With Plums,” from the artist behind “Persepolis,” a tormented violinist takes to his bed to await the end of his life.
lead_paragraph: Graphic novels, at their best, do whatever they want; movies, all too often, do what they think they are supposed to do. No artist is freer than one with a good story and a sufficient supply of paper and ink, and the graphic-novel form, as it has evolved over the last two decades — to encompass memoir, history and eyewitness journalism — is bracingly unconstrained by visual or narrative convention. It is not surprising that some of the most interesting films in recent years have tried to capture that freedom.

headline: The World of Noël Coward
abstract: At the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, an exhibition delving into the career of Noël Coward; and at Habana Outpost, an outdoor film series that runs well into October.
lead_paragraph: The Miser once whiled away many autodidactic hours around Lincoln Center, triangulating between the CD racks of Tower Records, the brimming bookshelves of Barnes & Noble — who knew that someday we’d miss the chains! — and the extensive media holdings of the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts.

headline: Ancient Havens of Reflection and Renewal
abstract: “Chinese Gardens: Pavilions, Studios, Retreats,” a new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, features 80 paintings and objects that evoke the garden’s role across more than 1,000 years of Chinese culture.
lead_paragraph: Daily I stroll contentedly in my garden

headline: Just Trust Me
abstract: When it comes to his tax returns, Mitt Romney expects the public to accept his word.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney deigned to answer questions about his tax returns today, assuring reporters at a news conference that he had never paid less than 13 percent of his income in taxes in the last decade. That’s considerably lower than the rate many middle-class families pay, but what’s really remarkable is that Mr. Romney now expects the public to accept his word and move on.

headline: When a New Best Friend Hits the Ground Whirring
abstract: In Jake Schreier’s “Robot & Frank,” Frank Langella plays an elderly parent living alone whose son gives him a robot minder.
lead_paragraph: In American movies, old people tend to be cute or crotchety, though sometimes they’re both. Ruth Gordon is cute in “Harold and Maude” and somewhat cute if also somehow menacing, at least at first, in “Rosemary’s Baby.” (Later, when the old lady comes out as a Satanist, she’s the ne plus ultra of crotchety: evil.) In “Robot & Frank,” an eager-to-please story set in the near future about an elderly gent, his robot and some awkwardly managed truths about old age, Frank Langella plays so many variations on cute and crotchety and with such suppleness — he’s by turns a charming codger, a silver fox and a wise graybeard — that his performance comes close to a saving grace.

headline: Upheaval in Iran, Brought to You Live by the Protesters
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Movies']
abstract: This documentary by Ali Samadi Ahadi bears witness to the exhilaration that preceded the presidential election of June 2009 and to the violence that followed.
lead_paragraph: By turns frustrating and moving, Ali Samadi Ahadi’s documentary “The Green Wave,” about the Green Revolution in Iran, gets a jolt from footage shot by the people for the people on the people’s cellphones. Shaky, blurry, sometimes hard to make sense of, these images bear witness to the exhilaration that preceded the presidential election of June 2009 and to the violence that followed. The film also has animated sequences and interviews with Iranian exiles, but nothing matches the effectiveness of that raw, you-are-there footage.

headline: Oregon, Sitting at the Border of Safe and In Play
abstract: Oregon seems to be just to the ideological left of where most political observers place the border between competitive and safely Democratic states.
lead_paragraph: Today we continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of the peculiarities that drive the politics in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Today’s stop: Oregon, the Beaver State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with William Lunch, a professor in political science at Oregon State University, and Jeff Mapes and Harry Esteve, both of whom report on politics for The Oregonian.

headline: Take Two Explosions and Call Me in the Morning
abstract: Prominent action stars and a preposterous amount of explosives join forces to enact a good-triumphs tale.
lead_paragraph: Just when you think the action-hero-filled “Expendables 2” has forgotten that this is at heart a comedy franchise, along comes a guy who has been out of the game for years to save the day.

headline: Galleries of the Page
abstract: New York has entered a kind of golden age of art-book establishments that transcend the bounds of the bookstore.
lead_paragraph: New York has entered a kind of golden age of art-book establishments that transcend the bounds of the bookstore.

headline: Love, Sex, Desire and Lyrics (Oh, and Stiletto Pumps) Across the Decades
abstract: The French director Christophe Honoré laces “Beloved,” a musical film starring Catherine Deneuve and Chiara Mastroianni, with whimsy and loss.
lead_paragraph: The characters in Christophe Honoré’s musical films — the new one, “Beloved” (“Les Bien-Aimés”), and its predecessor, “Love Songs” (2007) — do not burst into song so much as wander into it, giving voice to complicated thoughts about their feelings rather than to the feelings themselves. The musical numbers, which occur with minimal choreography on ordinary streets (and are written, for both movies, by Alex Beaupain), are less expressive than analytical, as if singing were above all a kind of philosophical reflection.

headline: An Addled Mother and Her Prodigy Son Need Drugs, and Fast
abstract: In “Why Stop Now?” the shenanigans begin when a cocaine addict, played by Melissa Leo, is badgered by her son, portrayed by Jesse Eisenberg, to enter rehab.
lead_paragraph: The domino that sets off a cascade of falling pieces in “Why Stop Now?” is a Catch-22 moment based on an incident witnessed by Ron Nyswaner, one of the movie’s creators, while working as a volunteer in a detox unit. When Penny Bloom (Melissa Leo), a cocaine addict, is badgered by her son, Eli (Jesse Eisenberg), to enter rehab, she is turned away for lack of insurance and because her urine sample shows no signs of drugs. Surreptitiously advised that she will be admitted if she comes back with “dirty” urine, Penny and Eli do as suggested and go directly to her dealer, Sprinkles (Tracy Morgan), whose supply has run dry.

headline: Bahrain Sentences Activist to 3 Years in Prison for ‘Inciting’ Protests
keywords: ['Freedom of Assembly', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Political Prisoners', 'Social Networking (Internet)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Bahrain sentenced a leading rights activist to three years in prison on Thursday for “inciting” anti-government protests in speeches and Twitter updates.
lead_paragraph: Bahrain sentenced a leading rights activist to three years in prison on Thursday for “inciting” antigovernment protests in speeches and Twitter updates, the state news agency reports.

headline: A Woman Who Knows the Music Industry, and a Few Who Don’t (Yet)
abstract: Jordin Sparks has the title role in “Sparkle,” a Cinderella tale out of Motown that features the last screen performance by Whitney Houston.
lead_paragraph: It is impossible to watch “Sparkle” and not relate its story to the life of Whitney Houston, one of its executive producers. She portrays Emma, a former entertainer turned prim, disapproving church lady in late-1960s Detroit. Emma forsook show business after nearly succumbing to the same excesses that caught up with Houston, who died in February, not long after “Sparkle” was completed. If the film is a sudsy show-business Cinderella story in which Emma’s youngest daughter, Sparkle (Jordin Sparks), ascends to glory, Houston’s presence makes it a cautionary tale.

headline: Ghosts and Memories Haunting a House
abstract: “The Awakening,” directed by Nick Murphy and starring Rebecca Hall and Dominic West, is a ghost story set in an England paralyzed with grief after the traumas of World War I.
lead_paragraph: Sherlock Holmes meets “The Others” in “The Awakening,” a supernatural thriller with a chilly “Masterpiece Theater” gloss and a pretentious, post-Freudian subtext. Ghosts are not merely the restless undead in this sleek first feature directed by Nick Murphy from a screenplay he wrote with Stephen Volk. They are also repressed memories in the subconscious of its luscious female Sherlock, Florence Cathcart (Rebecca Hall, from “Vicky Cristina Barcelona”). More broadly they are the unquiet spirits of the dead in a country paralyzed with grief after the traumas of World War I and the 1918 influenza pandemic.

headline: Real-Life Creepiness: Just Following Orders
abstract: In Craig Zobel’s “Compliance” a fast-food manager confines and searches an employee at the direction of a telephone caller identifying himself as a police officer.
lead_paragraph: Confining extremes of human behavior to a single, drab room, “Compliance,” the squirmy sophomore feature from the writer and director Craig Zobel, is a slow-motion punch to the groin. As such, it’s fitting that one of our first sights is a large “NO” stenciled in the parking lot of a fast-food joint in suburban Ohio: as the film progresses, the word becomes a silent mantra for viewers who can’t quite believe what they’re seeing.

headline: Off the Charts: Measuring Recoveries
abstract: Since June 2009, when major developed economies hit bottom after the credit crisis, Germany has seen the largest increase in gross domestic product. Even those euro countries that are now in recession have generally not fallen back to 2009 levels. But using another measure known as domestic demand, which reflects the level of final sales within a country, Italy and Spain have now fallen below where they were in 2009. Stock prices, another measure of the extent of economic recovery, have risen the most in the United States.

headline: N.F.L. Channels Available to Cablevision Subscribers
abstract: The NFL Network and NFL RedZone channels will be available for the first time this season to Cablevision customers.
lead_paragraph: Six years ago, Cablevision’s quid pro quo for carrying the NFL Network was articulated by its chief executive, James L. Dolan: We’ll take the network if we get NFL Sunday Ticket, the package of out-of-market games that is the exclusive property of the satellite operator DirecTV. That was a nonstarter.

headline: Analyzing History Before the Dust Settles
abstract: In “Brother, Can You Spare a Dollar?” Thom Hoffman makes the argument that comparisons between the current recession and the Great Depression have their limitations.
lead_paragraph: Thom Hoffman, the director of the amateurish “Brother, Can You Spare a Dollar?,” apparently attended the Scattershot School of Documentary Filmmaking. He has a moderately interesting point he wants to make — comparing the current state of the economy with the Great Depression — but his method of doing so is to blast away haphazardly, hitting the target only occasionally.

headline: Looking for Horse-Friendly Homes
abstract: The demand for homes or farms with equine facilities is rising as costs grow at horse-boarding centers.
lead_paragraph: SHARYN GUZZI, a broker-owner of Long Island Horse Properties, a niche agency, has 192 homes and farms with equine facilities listed on her Web sites, lihorseproperties.com and liequine.com.

headline: Love as Espionage, and Vice Versa
abstract: Kabir Khan’s “Ek Tha Tiger” follows Tiger, an agent in India’s Research and Analysis Wing, as he travels around the world on espionage missions and, unexpectedly, falls in love.
lead_paragraph: Kabir Khan’s “Ek Tha Tiger,” a Bollywood romance dressed in espionage clothes, seems most engaged during its glass-shattering, rooftop-hopping action sequences. Its superagent hero, Tiger (Salman Khan) — his 007 T-shirt is more descriptive than aspirational — can’t help making a mess fighting and chasing in foreign cities. Dublin, Istanbul and Havana are probably still sweeping up, rewiring and getting their trains back on track after Hurricane Tiger.

headline: A Fantasy Land Where Love and Betrayal Reign
abstract: “Painted Skin: The Resurrection,” directed by Wuershan, is a love story set in a fantasy land filled with demons and warriors.
lead_paragraph: Despite its obsession with a triumvirate of powerful women, “Painted Skin: The Resurrection,” Wuershan’s fantastical follow-up to Gordon Chan’s popular 2008 original, plays like the death knell of feminism. Not that this is likely to be of concern to the film’s target audience, whose appetite for ancient Chinese ghost stories is more vulnerable to a scarcity of special effects than to a surfeit of regressive sexual attitudes.

headline: New Operator Is Chosen for Tavern on the Green
abstract: The parks department selected the Emerald Green Group, which runs a bistro in Philadelphia and plans to open a smaller, more rustic Tavern in 2013.
lead_paragraph: More than two years after the legendary Central Park restaurant Tavern on the Green closed and its once-luxurious appointments were auctioned off, the parks department has selected a new, Philadelphia-based operator that plans to reopen the space as a smaller, more rustic restaurant in the fall of 2013.

headline: Cutler-Marshall Reunion Gives Bears’ Offense a Lift
abstract: Wide receiver Brandon Marshall and quarterback Jay Cutler, who both made the Pro Bowl in 2008 when they were with the Broncos, hope to have similar success in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: BOURBONNAIS, Ill. — During a seven-on-seven drill early in training camp, Bears quarterback Jay Cutler completed pass after pass to wide receiver Brandon Marshall. Thousands of fans cheered after each catch. Finally, defensive back Tim Jennings turned to the crowd and, smiling, shouted, “We’re on the team, too.”

headline: Twitter Makes New Rules for Developers
abstract: On Thursday, Twitter disclosed how it plans to tighten-up rules for developers who build applications on the company’s platform.
lead_paragraph: The relationship between Twitter and developers who build apps linked to Twitter has been a bit rocky for some time. A year ago, Twitter warned that stricter rules and regulations were coming to people who built apps on the company’s platform.

headline: Adopting a Beast as One of Their Own
abstract: “True Wolf,” a documentary by Rob Whitehair, documents the efforts of Bruce Weide and Pat Tucker as caretakers of a female wolf named Koani.
lead_paragraph: Crudely made and frustratingly vague, “True Wolf” documents the extreme efforts of Bruce Weide and Pat Tucker to lead “a wolf-centered life” as caretakers of a female wolf named Koani. Having raised the animal from a pup as part of a 1994 television project, the couple found themselves stuck with a beast that was unable to survive in the wild and that they could not bring themselves to euthanize. Things, you might say, were not thought through.

headline: Republican National Committee Takes In $37.7 Million in July
abstract: The committee has spent close to $21 million on attack advertisements against President Obama since the second week of July, according to Federal Election Commission disclosures.
lead_paragraph: Bolstered by strong fund-raising over the last year and a major influx of cash brought Mitt Romney in recent months, the Republican National Committee has spent close to $21 million on attack advertisements against President Obama since the second week in July, according to Federal Election Commission disclosures.

headline: Rural County Faces Housing Suit
keywords: ['Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Minorities', 'Discrimination', 'Affordable Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']

lead_paragraph: THE Washington law firm that helped secure a landmark desegregation settlement with Westchester County has now partnered with a Connecticut nonprofit group on a discrimination lawsuit taking aim at much of Litchfield County.

headline: Svetozar Gligoric, Who Pioneered Chess Moves, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Gligoric was considered one of the greatest players of the 20th century and pioneered several systems of moves, but he never won the chance to compete for the world championship.
lead_paragraph: Svetozar Gligoric, a chess grandmaster who was considered one of the greatest players of the 20th century but who never won the world championship — in one instance losing a chance to play for the title by executing a fatally impulsive move in response to critics who found his match boring — died on Tuesday in Belgrade, Serbia. He was 89.

headline: A Society’s Dizzying Changes Cast the Police in the Role of Relationship Counselor
abstract: As societal changes transform Bangalore, many young Indians are struggling to cope, and they take their problems to the only symbol of authority that is accessible around the clock: the police.
lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, India — The three stars and the red-and-blue ribbon on his shoulder strap indicate that M. L. Purushotham is a police inspector. But his unofficial job title might well be this: redeemer of relationships and savior of marriages.

headline: From Weeds and Bricks to Media Hub in Brooklyn
abstract: After decades of neglect, 20 acres of grassy hills and crumbling mansions in a corner of the Brooklyn Navy Yard that few New Yorkers have ever seen may get a new life.
lead_paragraph: Hidden behind weeds and broken bricks, amid the hum of traffic from the nearby Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, lie 20 acres of abandoned grassy hills, crumbling Greek Revival mansions and Second Empire structures that few New Yorkers have ever seen.

headline: Park Avenue, the ’Tween Years
abstract: Park Avenue in Midtown was a very different place in the early 20th century, before the switching yards of Grand Central were covered and the railroad electrified.
lead_paragraph: THE reconstruction of Park Avenue in Midtown is just getting under way, first with Harry Macklowe’s quarter-mile-high apartment house at 56th Street, then with similar projects waiting in the wings. But even at flood tide it will be nothing like the transformation of the same stretch in the early 20th century. That was when, over the course of a decade, a string of apartment houses like McKim, Mead & White’s giant 277 Park Avenue, rose up, in some cases out of thin air.

headline: Reality Is Flat. (Or Is It?)
abstract: Adopting the reductionism that equates humans with other animals or computers has a serious downside: it wipes out the meaning of your own life.
lead_paragraph: In a recent essay for The Stone, I claimed that humans are “something more than other animals, and essentially more than any computer.” Some readers found the claim importantly or trivially true; others found it partially or totally false; still others reacted as if I’d said that we’re not animals at all, or that there are no resemblances between our brains and computers. Some pointed out, rightly, that plenty of people do fine research in biology or computer science without reducing the human to the subhuman.

headline: At a War of Spoken Words’ End, a Prize
abstract: The documentary “Speak” chronicles the 2008 Toastmasters World Championship of Public Speaking and the emotional investments of its contestants.
lead_paragraph: Documentaries about competitions of various sorts — spelling bees, kiddie beauty pageants, even muskrat skinning — have become common, and many are somewhat formulaic: they focus on a few contestants to let viewers develop a rooting interest, then culminate in the crowning of the winner. “Speak,” about the Toastmasters World Championship of Public Speaking, follows that formula most of the way through, but in its final minutes, after the contest is over, it delivers an unexpected jolt.

headline: Murder Arrests in Mexico Met With Skepticism
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Confessions', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'News and News Media', 'Organized Crime']
abstract: The suspects in the killings of three photojournalists and a publicist were picked up on drug and weapons charges, and confessed to the murders.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The local authorities in Veracruz State declared the case closed. Members of a drug gang had confessed to one of the state’s most notorious crimes in recent months: the murders of three photojournalists and a newspaper publicist.

headline: Career and Apartment, Finally in Sync
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: With rents rising, Carlo Dellaverson bade his roommates goodbye and started looking for an apartment he could afford in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: FOR a few years, Carlo Dellaverson was more than happy living with friends in shared apartments. After his graduation from the University of Richmond, he lived in a series of “three frat-pad apartments with three guys,” he said. “We loved living in the city. Everyone was classic rent-poor but having a great time.”

headline: Yankees and Rangers: See You in October
abstract: With the the two best records in the American League, the Yankees and the Rangers seem destined to meet in a couple of months, and the players are not afraid to say it.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Red Sox straggle into New York on Friday, but the truth is that the show has left town. The uniforms of the Yankees and the Red Sox evoke a time gone by, when the teams were close in talent. The Red Sox are bickering and stale and going nowhere now. The real rivalry is the one we just saw.

headline: Don’t Waste the Drought
abstract: The drought represents an opportunity to reimagine how we manage, use and even think about water.
lead_paragraph: WE’RE in the worst drought in the United States since the 1950s, and we’re wasting it.

headline: Another Casualty of War: Soap Operas
keywords: ['Ramadan', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Soap Operas', 'Television']
abstract: In losing the soap opera, the Syrian government has lost one of its most powerful means of spreading ideas and political messages.
lead_paragraph: IN the Syrian town my family comes from, every afternoon during the holy month of Ramadan the streets were jammed with people. They were rushing home not only to escape the heat and to prepare the iftar, the evening meal that breaks the fast, but also to catch the latest episodes of their favorite soap operas — the musalsals.

headline: Hugo Bedau, Philosopher Who Opposed Death Penalty, Dies at 85
abstract: Professor Bedau’s half-century career encompassed several cycles in the national debate over capital punishment, which he opposed as immoral, unjust and ineffective.
lead_paragraph: Hugo Bedau, a philosopher who preferred to wrestle with the knottiest of public policy issues rather than reason from the remove of academia — most notably in confronting capital punishment, which he opposed as immoral, unjust and ineffective — died on Monday in Norwood, Mass. He was 85.

headline: Amid Unrest, Hope and Glimmers of Romance
abstract: Avi Nesher’s “Matchmaker” is a coming-of-age tale in which a teenager living in Haifa, Israel, in 1968 spends a summer doing background checks for a scarred matchmaker.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1968 in Haifa, Israel, a teenager named Arik (Tuval Shafir) finds his lazy vacation from school overtaken by an unexpected gig: doing background checks for a mysterious, scarred matchmaker who lives in a colorful, low-rent part of town. In “The Matchmaker,” written and directed by Avi Nesher, Arik’s coming-of-age story and the personalities he encounters along the way express the hopes and fears of a country awash in unsettling history.

headline: That Hot New Rifle From Russia

American sales of single-shot civilian versions of the Kalashnikov rose by 50 percent last year among buyers impressed with the automatic model’s lethal accuracy in the world’s trouble spots.

headline: Cherished Tradition or a Colossal Waste of Time?
abstract: Despite its almost sacred place in baseball, there is one little secret about batting practice: many players think it is a mind-numbing, flaw-producing, strategically empty exercise.
lead_paragraph: Baseball is a sport defined by routines and traditions, and there are few more entrenched than batting practice, a pregame ritual that is far older than most teams that engage in it. For two hours before almost every game, each team dutifully rolls out the batting cage and hits slowly pitched balls to outfields across North America.

No reporters were allowed, perhaps because the campaign didn’t want them asking uncomfortable questions about the multiple federal investigations into the company behind Mr. Adelson’s wealth.

headline: President Morsi’s Rebalancing Act
abstract: While much is obscure about Egyptian politics, the new president seems to be seeking a fine line between an Army accustomed to power and Islamists hungry for it.
lead_paragraph: The stunning events in Egypt over the past week have been at least as significant for what didn’t happen as what did. After President Mohamed Morsi replaced the country’s top two generals on Sunday, there were no street protests condemning his actions, no real alarms from Israel and no Army retaliation. In fact, the generals accepted medals of commendation from Mr. Morsi and will serve as his advisers.

headline: China: Protester Killed as Police Fire on Demonstration
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Police']
abstract: As many as 1,000 people demonstrated against mining operations in an environmentally fragile part of Tibet on Wednesday, Radio Free Asia reported.
lead_paragraph: The police shot and killed a protester on Wednesday after as many as 1,000 people demonstrated against mining operations in an environmentally fragile part of Tibet, Radio Free Asia reported Thursday. The broadcaster, which quoted an India-based Tibetan exile with contacts in the region, said security forces detained six people and used tear gas and live fire to disperse locals who were protesting against the mine. Government officials claim that the site, in Markham County in the Tibetan Autonomous Region, is being prepared for a power plant. In another matter, the Tibetan Center for Human Rights and Democracy said that two men who this week had set themselves on fire to protest Chinese rule had died of their injuries.

headline: On Eve of Sentencing, an Artistic Show of Solidarity for Russian Punk Band
abstract: A samizdat kind of crowd turned out in New York in support of a Russian punk group whose three young members have been jailed in Moscow since March.
lead_paragraph: Scant Russian was heard, but on Thursday night, a samizdat kind of crowd turned out in support of the Russian punk art group Pussy Riot. At 7:30 p.m., hundreds of people — mostly women, but some men, a few in homemade “Free Pussy Riot” T-shirts — lined up around the boutique Ace Hotel, stretching along 29th Street and down Broadway. The hotel’s subterranean Liberty Hall is normally the province of exclusive rock shows and fashion afterparties. But on this evening, a handful of performers stood before a bank of speakers there, reading heady statements related to the trial of Maria Alyokhina, Yekaterina Samutsevich and Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, the three young members of Pussy Riot who have been jailed in Moscow since March, and whose case has become a global cause célèbre.

headline: Jason Pierre-Paul, the Late-Blooming Defensive Wunderkind
abstract: The freakishly gifted 23-year-old was one of the best defensive ends in the league last year. And he’s still learning to play the game.
lead_paragraph: In 1999, a promising young director named Doug Liman was dispatched to Florida to work on a commercial with Tiger Woods, then still in his wunderkind phase. The shoot was scripted, and Liman, who would eventually direct “The Bourne Identity,” was part of a team that had only eight hours with the star. Liman noticed that during breaks, Woods, visibly bored, would juggle a golf ball with his club head. The ball never hit the ground. While the crew ate lunch, he grabbed a camera and asked the star to do the trick again. Woods juggled the ball more than 40 consecutive times — around his back, between his legs, sitting it on his club face, never dropping it — before thwacking it down the fairway in mid arc. The 30-second spot became the 1999 equivalent of a viral video, in large part because it laid bare Woods’s superhuman talent.

It survived the Sept. 11 attack and has stood for more than 10 years in Battery Park, damaged but instantly recognizable as a “memorial to those we lost,” in Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s words.

headline: The Graduate
abstract: After a decade of Harry Potter movies, Emma Watson traded Hogwarts for Oxford and Brown. Now the former child star is back on the big screen with a whole new bag of tricks.
lead_paragraph: Emma Watson, the onetime co-star of the most successful movie franchise ever, is a very grateful and a very lucky person. How do I know that? Because I sat down with the 22-year-old in a gastropub in a trendy neighborhood of North London, and in the course of an hour’s conversation she said “grateful” five times and “lucky” eight. True, of those five “grateful”s two were of the “ungrateful” form — yet these were embedded in clauses like “I felt guilty because I felt like that meant I was ungrateful. . . .” So, as you can see, Watson is a young woman who wants it put firmly on the record that she understands human lives are shaken up in the snow globe of uncertainty, and that simply because she’s ended up being covered in golden flakes, she doesn’t take it as her due, oh, no.

headline: A Champion of the Book Takes to the iPad
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: William H. Gass is celebrating the virtues of electronic publication, which is rather like Hunter Thompson extolling moderation or Hugh Hefner championing celibacy. How did one of the most eloquent defenders of the humble printed book decide to start issuing his new work on the iPad?
lead_paragraph: Devotees of the old-fashioned printed book who are distressed by the onrushing digital future — and there are more of them out there than you might think — cherish William H. Gass’s 1999 essay, “A Defense of the Book.” Personally, I own multiple copies, including its original appearance in Harper’s magazine, its reappearance in Mr. Gass’s collection “A Temple of Texts,” even a slightly strange limited edition done in cardboard. Nothing has ever summed up so well the book’s virtues as an object.

headline: Rare Survey of Late Raphael Masterpieces at the Prado
abstract: The great 16th-century painter Raphael (1483-1520) is being honored with a rare exhibition focusing on the last period of his life. “Late Raphael” is on display at the Prado through Sept. 16 and moves on to the Louvre from Oct. 8 through Jan. 14.
lead_paragraph: The great 16th-century painter Raphael (1483-1520) became one of the most influential Western artists during the last phase of his brief life. But though often celebrated, he has not been honored with a full-scale exhibition focusing on this period.

headline: Kerr Goes Kiwi
abstract: To cap off an extended stay in New Zealand with her family, Miranda Kerr gives Wellington a whirl in fall’s white shirts and strappy flats. And this time her movie-star husband is behind the camera.
lead_paragraph: Miranda Kerr was 18, just out of high school, a girl from the Australian countryside curious about what the rest of the world had to offer, when she first visited New Zealand. Along with a close friend from Gunnedah, the pastoral town where she grew up, Kerr set out to experience what for many is the draw of New Zealand: to escape and explore, to get a little lost and, in the process, get a little found. They slept in a tent. Swam in natural hot springs. Hiked terrain so raw and depopulated and expansive it felt as if they were the first humans to discover it. Kerr didn’t know it at the time, but her life would change significantly in the years that followed, thanks largely to her enviable genetic gifts: the long pale legs, the shimmering doe eyes and, most famously, the pert, dimpled cheeks that have made her one of the highest paid, most recognizable models in the world. Modeling, for Kerr, has been its own sort of adventure, one she will be the first to acknowledge as a stroke of good fortune not to be taken for granted. “Still, that backpacking trip, just having that freedom, was one of the best times in my life,” Kerr recently reflected. “Ever since, I’ve wanted to get back to New Zealand.”

headline: In the Sundarbans, Folk Homes for Modern Living
abstract: An artist renovates mud homes in Bali Island in West Bengal using clay, bamboo, dried hogla leaves, stones and cow dung.
lead_paragraph: Most of the residents in the Sundarbans in West Bengal live in mud homes, but only until they get the money needed to build concrete houses. Bidyut Roy, an artist and architect, is on a mission to persuade locals that mud and other natural materials can make for a modern home.

headline: Confessions of an Olympic Bid Writer
abstract: Would an Istanbul capable of staging the Games be a city in control of its future?
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — “Bah! Humbug!” When the subject of the Olympic Games comes up, I feel like Ebenezer Scrooge in his unreformed middle period, ready to douse the first signs of enthusiasm with a cold bucket of cynicism. The reason why my guard is still up a week after the London torch moved on to Rio de Janeiro is that I live in a city that’s trying to bring home yet more gold.

lead_paragraph: While AMC is perhaps best known for scripted dramas like “Mad Men” and “Breaking Bad,” that cable channel is continuing to add to its roster of unscripted series — you might also call them reality shows — for those hours when Don Draper and Walter White are taking it easy.

headline: The Fast and the Furious
abstract: Can’t British employers do more to accommodate Muslims during Ramadan?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — I stopped by my favorite fruit stall in Brixton earlier this week, only to find the seller fast asleep, with head propped against cart and face cupped in hand. I began sorting through various cartons of peaches, making just enough noise to wake Pervez Khan, a fellow Pakistani who has been based in south London for more than a decade. As I tossed the fruit into a basket, Khan awoke and began apologizing. “It’s terrible of me to sleep on the job,” he said, “but it’s so hard to stay awake when you’re fasting.”

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Guilty Verdicts in Pussy Riot Case, and China’s Media Strategy
abstract: Three members of the Russian feminist punk band Pussy Riot were found guilty on Friday over a stunt they staged in February, and China is following a Western template with the hope to bolster its image and influence around the world.
lead_paragraph: 10:59 a.m. | Updated Three members of the Russian feminist punk band Pussy Riot were found guilty on Friday over a stunt they staged in February against Vladimir V. Putin in the main Moscow Russian Orthodox cathedral, David Herszenhorn reports. The scene in hot, overcrowded courtroom with the three women behind bulletproof glass was being streamed live by Russia Today, fueling worldwide interest in the prosecution of the band members, who have received support from musicians around the world including Paul McCartney and Madonna. The judge sentenced each to a two-year prison sentence. The YouTube video of the incident is at nearly 450,000 views.

headline: Making a Child Stop Her Distracting Dance
abstract: What happens when friends and record-selling clash, etiquette for attending a funeral of an ex-spouse’s parent, and correcting your mother’s texting style.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I attended an outdoor jazz concert at Lincoln Center. When the music began, a little girl (about 7) began doing an interpretive dance in the aisle, and didn’t stop. We could not look at the stage without seeing her. After a while, my husband politely asked the parents to restrain the girl. The mother carried her away, kicking and screaming. She wagged her finger at us, saying: “See what you’ve done.” Another man told us we had broken the girl’s heart and owed her an apology. Were we out of line?

headline: Pok Pok Wing to Get a New Name and Dish: Phat Thai

lead_paragraph: The elephant on the plate, as far as Andy Ricker, the owner of the Pok Pok restaurants, is concerned, has always been the noodle dish called phat Thai, or pad Thai. It is about the most popular Thai dish among Americans, but Mr. Ricker has long made a point of not serving it. Until now.

lead_paragraph: In today’s episode, our critics offer their takes on three independent films: David Cronenberg’s “Cosmopolis,” Craig Zobel’s “Compliance” and the first live-action film from the French animators Marjane Satrapi and Vincent Paronnaud, “Chicken With Plums.” Full reviews of all of this week’s films can be found here.

headline: A World of Trouble
abstract: As cousins come of age, a killer stalks young girls in this first novel.
lead_paragraph: Why do teenagers make such ideal protagonists? Maybe it’s because they’re doing just what novels do: struggling to make sense of a troubling and imperfect world. And at first, Jim, called Biscuit, and L. A. (Lee Ann), the teenage cousins at the heart of Tom Wright’s feisty first novel, are ­exactly what you hope they’ll be: funny, frank, mouthy and more than a touch off kilter. Both are forced to live with their grandmother because their mothers aren’t up to the task of child rearing. Their homes are haunted by alcoholism and violence, but Gram takes a simple, affectionate, responsibility for them — though it’s almost inevitable that certain questions, if not the answers, will push their ugly way to the surface sooner or later.

headline: Working 9 to 12
abstract: A historian and his philosopher son make a case for the shorter hours Keynes predicted.
lead_paragraph: Robert Skidelsky is a historian best known for his definitive three-volume biography of John Maynard Keynes; his son Edward Skidelsky is a philosopher. They have collaborated on a book arguing that people in wealthy countries like Britain and the United States work too hard and by doing so miss out on the “good life” — an ethical concept of a life as “worthy of desire, not just one that is widely desired.”

headline: Silence, Exile and Cunning
abstract: A new biography of James Joyce records his struggles against censors and literary snobs.
lead_paragraph: If you walk in Dublin along Nassau Street and continue straight into South Leinster Street and then look up at the gable end of the red-brick building on the left, you can see the old sign that says “Finn’s Hotel.” The hotel is long gone, but an event that took place nearby in June 1904 gave an emotional context, a strange nourishing power, to James Joyce’s novel “Ulysses,” and the name of the hotel became one of the words he played with in the title of his novel “Finnegans Wake.”

headline: The Once and Future War
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The conflict between the United States and Iran, from 1979 to the present.
lead_paragraph: Revolutionary regimes, in the grip of a universalist faith, are often prepared to use violence to export their ideology. France did so after 1789, Russia after 1917 and Cuba after 1959. Only one revolutionary state currently poses a serious threat to world order: Iran. Like 18th-century France and 20th-century Russia, Iran has fused the expansionary impulse of an imperial power with an ideological attack on the status quo. But that only makes Iran harder to deal with, above all for the United States, the chief pillar of that status quo.

headline: The Case Against Purple
abstract: Tyler Brûlé, the editor in chief of Monocle, wouldn’t be caught dead in the ‘color of compromise.’
lead_paragraph: In the late ’90s, you described the typical reader of Wallpaper, the first magazine you founded, as “a copywriter for a hot advertising firm in Stockholm or a grunge kid working in an indie record shop that suddenly got a film deal, there’s a degree of affluence all of a sudden.” Do those people even exist anymore?  Those people are still out there. They might have landed at different gigs. I’m constantly amazed by people who still get extraordinary tech deals for concepts and businesses which don’t have any hope of returning anything to their investors.

headline: I Was Jeff Koons’s Studio Serf
abstract: How I painted and broke a masterpiece.
lead_paragraph: As a 21-year-old art student, I answered a help-wanted ad at the SoHo studio of Jeff Koons. During the interview, the studio manager set my slides on a light box and leaned over them with a loupe, inspecting each one like a jeweler with a tray of semiprecious stones. The head painter was consulted, a tall and taciturn man who eventually came over to shake my hand.

headline: Last Known Address
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Dating and Courtship', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Running']
abstract: The previous tenant; the ex-girlfriend; the front-runner.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after renting a house, I found out from neighbors that the previous tenant died of an overdose. This didn’t create any major inconveniences, although early on we did find a few remnants (like police tape). But it did feel unsettling and slightly disturbing. Did our landlord have any ethical obligation to tell us what had happened before we signed the lease? WILLIAM, NEW YORK

headline: Who Made That Tube Top?
abstract: Plus: Great moments in tube-top history.
lead_paragraph: Elie Tahari arrived in New York in 1971 with less than $100 in his pocket. “I slept in the parks on the benches,” recalls the fashion designer. The son of Iranian refugees who emigrated to Israel and placed him for a time in an orphanage, Tahari hoped to make his fortune at 19 in the United States, “the land of the movies.”

headline: When the Network Effect Goes Into Reverse

lead_paragraph: With battered Facebook shares closing Friday at just over half their offering price in May, no one’s talking anymore about a social media “bubble.”

headline: Eats, Shoots and Leaves
abstract: To celebrate The Selby’s new book on far-flung food culture, T makes the photographer the subject for a change.
lead_paragraph: On a recent summer afternoon, the photographer Todd Selby was standing in the kitchen of his minimalist apartment in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, stirring shell pasta in a stock pot. He was making Olga’s Shell Soup, a bouillon-and-tomato-paste number concocted by his childhood nanny, a Mexican native who was named after a Swedish character in a telenovela. “This is my favorite soup in the world, but I’ve never met anyone who’s really that into it,” Selby said. “So I’m kind of curious what the reaction is going to be.”

headline: Collateral Damage
abstract: Brian Castner realizes that his skills as a bomb technician can be a liability in peacetime.
lead_paragraph: London, 1940. Capt. Terence Stevenson of the Bomb Disposal Section arrives on the scene to defuse a delayed-­action bomb lodged in the rubble of a hospital. He reassures a boy lying only a few feet away, unable to be moved, that he’s just taking out the bomb’s tonsils “so he can’t talk.” Stevenson relays each step in his process through a microphone to his crew, positioned at a safe distance.

headline: Charles in Charge
abstract: A biography of Charles de Gaulle, an autocrat stuck in a democracy.
lead_paragraph: Dare I call a 707-page biography a page turner? For once, the fake enthusiasm of blurb prose rings true. I did “finish the book in one sitting,” as another chestnut has it, though the sitting was a very long flight of 16 hours. And why? Because Jonathan Fenby, a former editor of The Observer of London and a prolific author, knows how to turn breadth and depth into enthrallment. ­Academic historians tend to shy away from the grand sweep, while journalists like to stick to the chatty and topical. Fenby has blended the best of both crafts — the historian’s gravitas, the journalist’s feel for drama — into a magnificent book that will rank alongside a classic like Jean Lacouture’s multi­volume biography of Charles de Gaulle.

headline: California Dreams
abstract: The first volume of a biography of the British artist covers the years 1937 to 1975.
lead_paragraph: David Hockney is often described as England’s most popular artist, but in his youth he dreamed of Los Angeles. He moved there in 1963, at age 26, unable to drive and believing he would get around the city by bus. This did not prevent him from traveling in his imagination to another California, one that bore little resemblance to the surfer-girl paradise enshrined by the Beach Boys. Instead of sand and the frothy ocean, Hockney painted quiet, slightly vacant-looking scenes of turquoise swimming pools in private backyards. They’re landscapes waiting for people to arrive, even when the people are already there.

headline: Disturbing the Peace
abstract: In Karin Fossum’s novel “The Caller,” children are both victims and villains and far more dangerous than any adult.
lead_paragraph: Thrillers not so thrilling lately? Serial killers too silly? Police detectives too sensitive? Wondering where all the tough guys went? I give you the Norwegian author Karin Fossum, whose new novel, THE CALLER (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $25), is one of the darkest, most disturbing crime stories you’re likely to read this year.

headline: The Other America
abstract: A visit to the centers of this country’s poverty in the 21st century.
lead_paragraph: This book is a collaboration between Chris Hedges and Joe Sacco, showing us daily life in four centers of 21st-century American poverty. Hedges’ contribution — a combination of reportage and commentary — is in a long tradition of literary journalism. Sacco’s is the sort of graphic art popularized by Art Spiegelman in “Maus.” Both writers have decades of experience as correspondents in war zones, but in “Days of Destruction, Days of Revolt” they turn their attention to the bombed-out and collapsed areas of their own country.

headline: Under the Influence
abstract: Part memoir and part criticism, Maureen N. McLane’s book includes essays about poets, along with lineated poem-games.
lead_paragraph: Poetry changes nothing, W. H. Auden suggested. For once in his life he was wrong. Poetry changes ­everything, starting with the good behavior of anyone who reads a lot of it, as the poet-critic Maureen N. McLane discovers in her beguiling new book, “My ­Poets.” “I was good at school,” she writes. “The very things that made me good at school — a talent for aligning with authority, or for knowing what it wanted; a capacity for self-­estranging self-discipline; an ability to use anxiety as a fuel; an ­overidentification with established codes — were precisely the things that might render me not a writer, not a poet.”

headline: Back Forty to Serve Crabs on the Rockaway Boardwalk
abstract: Peter Hoffman’s downtown restaurants will be celebrating crabs with pop-ups in the Rockaways on Saturday, Aug. 18, and again on Aug. 25.
lead_paragraph: Back Forty and Back Forty West, Peter Hoffman’s downtown restaurants, will be celebrating crabs with pop-ups in the Rockaways, in Queens, on Saturday, Aug. 18, and again on Aug. 25, on the boardwalk at 96th Street. The crabs will be hot and spicy starting around 2 p.m. and will be served as long as the supply lasts, perhaps until early evening. For $25 you will get a bucket of six steamed crabs, some potatoes and two ears of corn. There is a bar nearby. No reservations, or even shoes, for this!

headline: Here if You Need Me
abstract: Alix Ohlin’s characters struggle to make personal connections.
lead_paragraph: There are two species of novelist: one writes as if the world is a known locale that requires dutiful reporting, the other as if the world has yet to be made. The former enjoys the complacency of the au courant and the lassitude of at-hand language, while the latter believes with Thoreau that “this world is but canvas to our imaginations,” that the only worthy assertion of imagination occurs by way of linguistic originality wed to intellect and emotional verity. You close “Don Quixote” and “Tristram Shandy,” “Middlemarch” and “Augie March,” and the cosmos takes on a coruscated import it rather lacked before, an “eternal and irrepressible freshness,” in Pound’s apt phrase. His definition of literature is among the best we have: “Language charged with meaning.” How charged was the last novel you read?

lead_paragraph: INTO THE DARKEST CORNER  By Elizabeth Haynes.  Harper/HarperCollins, $25.99.

abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
