headline: A Big Party for a Not-So-Big Film
abstract: Jake Gyllenhaal’s new movie, in which he plays a cop in South Los Angeles, has a private screening and celebrity-filled party in East Hampton.
lead_paragraph: IN the new movie “End of Watch,” Jake Gyllenhaal plays a cop in South Central Los Angeles, working the neighborhood patrol and battling some seriously scary thugs from a Mexican drug cartel.

headline: No Charges for Officer Accused by Judge
abstract: The Queens district attorney said his office determined there wasn’t enough evidence to show that the judge had been injured or that the officer intended to hurt him.
lead_paragraph: After a three-month investigation, the Queens district attorney has decided not to bring criminal charges against a police officer who was accused of assaulting a State Supreme Court justice on the street in what the judge contended was an unprovoked attack, officials said Wednesday.

headline: Limited Convention Broadcasts Shut Out Ann Romney
abstract: Believing that viewers are tired of politics, the networks will broadcast three hours of convention coverage, less than they showed in 2008.
lead_paragraph: At 10:30 on Monday night, Ann Romney is scheduled to take the stage at the Republican National Convention, in Act 1 of her husband’s four-day introduction to the nation. But tens of millions of people will not be able to watch.

headline: U.S. Oil and Mining Companies Must Disclose Payments to Foreign Governments
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Mines and Mining', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Metals and Minerals', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Conflict Minerals and Resources']
abstract: The rule, which would fulfill a section of the Dodd-Frank financial reform law, is aimed at curbing corruption, which is common in some major oil-producing nations.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Despite stiff industry lobbying against it, the Securities and Exchange Commission voted 2 to 1 on Wednesday to require American oil and mining companies to disclose taxes and other fees they pay to foreign governments. The disclosures are aimed at curbing corruption, which is common in some major oil-producing nations.

headline: Kenya Clashes Leave Dozens Dead
abstract: With estimates of the death toll varying, Kenyans were shocked by ethnic clashes in a coastal area that left around 50 people dead, mostly women and children.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — As many as 52 people, most of them women and children, were killed Wednesday in a coastal area of Kenya in attacks involving two rival communities, officials said.

headline: In Texas, Don’t Even Mention Abortion
abstract: A federal court clears denial of state money to Planned Parenthood-affiliated clinics in Texas despised by the Republican Party and Gov. Rick Perry.
lead_paragraph: The Republican-controlled State Legislature in Texas and Gov. Rick Perry are perfectly willing to endanger the general health and welfare of low-income women to further their agenda of eroding abortion rights. And, now, a federal appeals court has given them a green light to do that, at least temporarily.

headline: Book Will Describe Raid That Killed Bin Laden
abstract: The book, written under a pseudonym by a member of the Navy SEALs, will be published on Sept. 11 and offer a “blow-by-blow narrative” of the raid that ended in the death of the Qaeda leader.
lead_paragraph: A detailed first-person account of the raid that killed Osama bin Laden, written by a member of the Navy SEALs who participated in the mission and was present at Bin Laden’s death, will be released next month, the publisher said on Wednesday.

headline: David Champion, Director of Automotive Testing for Consumer Reports, Joins Nissan
abstract: Mr. Champion, formerly the senior director of Consumer Reports’ auto test center, will work to ensure Nissan’s competitiveness and build quality.
lead_paragraph: To fill the newly created position of adviser for competitive assessment and quality, Nissan North America has hired David Champion, formerly the senior director of Consumer Reports’ auto test center. The appointment takes effect on Sept. 10, Nissan noted in a media release on Wednesday.

headline: Father’s Age Is Linked to Risk of Autism and Schizophrenia
abstract: Random genetic mutations in children that become more numerous with advancing paternal age may account for as many as 30 percent of autism cases, researchers reported.
lead_paragraph: Older men are more likely than young ones to father a child who develops autism or schizophrenia, because of random mutations that become more numerous with advancing paternal age, scientists reported on Wednesday, in the first study to quantify the effect as it builds each year. The age of mothers had no bearing on the risk for these disorders, the study found.

headline: Ryan Pressed to Explain Position on Rape and Abortion
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Sex Crimes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The vice presidential candidate suggests that the policy of Mitt Romney is the policy of the ticket.
lead_paragraph: Representative Paul D. Ryan sought to distance himself from Todd Akin, his House colleague, on Wednesday by condemning his comments about rape, even while deflecting questions about the meaning of “forcible rape.”

headline: The Get | Chloé’s Boots
abstract: The brand is out with three pretty-close-to-perfect boots this fall.
lead_paragraph: A fall boot is like a winter coat — so critical it can easily turn into a must-have of mythic proportions. Thankfully, Chloé’s Clare Waight Keller has designed three similar and pretty-close-to-perfect boot styles — the toe shape is the same on all; the heel size and height varies from pair to pair — that help make the best-ever boot something one cannot only attain but wear everyday. Available in three seasonally-appropriate colors — mustard-yellow, brick-red and rich burgundy (very important this season, take note) — the glossed-leather gives the shoes’ equestrian silhouettes a polished feel. The only hard part now? Picking which one to wear.

headline: U.N. Visit Will Set Back a Push to Isolate Iran
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Despite American-led efforts to marginalize Iran, Ban Ki-moon, the secretary general of the United Nations, plans to attend the annual meeting of the Nonaligned Movement being held there.
lead_paragraph: Efforts led by the United States and Israel to isolate Iran suffered a setback on Wednesday when the United Nations announced that Ban Ki-moon, the secretary general, would join officials from 120 countries in Tehran next week for a summit meeting that Iran has trumpeted as a vindication of its defiance and enduring importance in world affairs.

headline: Struggling to Recover From a Cyberattack
abstract: When someone hacks into a company’s computer system and wreaks havoc, and a former employee is suspected, how does the business rebuild?
lead_paragraph: IN 2006, Peter Justen, a serial entrepreneur, founded MyBizHomepage, an online service that connected to companies’ QuickBooks accounting software to help business owners monitor their financial metrics. When the site went live in 2008, it attracted significant media attention. It was free to use and the company planned to make money through advertising, a recipe that appealed to Mr. Justen’s investors, who valued the company at $100 million based on the vast potential they perceived.

headline: Die Koelner Bierhalle
abstract: A cavernous, loud German-style beer garden with an unintimidating and older Park Slope crowd.
lead_paragraph: IN the spirit of barbarian tribes, beer gardens with no-frills décor and heavyweight glassware have invaded New York’s bar scene. The latest is Die Koelner Bierhalle, which opened in early August in Park Slope, a few blocks from the Barclays Center.

headline: Video: Primary Day in Connecticut
abstract: The Lieberman-Lamont race remains tight as the polls close in Connecticut. (Producer: Matthew Orr)
lead_paragraph: The Lieberman-Lamont race remains tight as the polls close in Connecticut. (Producer: Matthew Orr)

headline: A New Addition to Police Lingo: ‘Easy, Peasy, Lemon Squeezy’
abstract: It was something of a surprise to hear, from a suspect arrested on burglary charges, that an officer said “Easy, peasy, lemon squeezy” as he slapped on the handcuffs.
lead_paragraph: There are all sorts of things police officers are known to say when they arrest someone. “Freeze,” or “Police — don’t move!”

headline: University of Texas Compounds Conflict Question in Review of Gas Report
keywords: ['Conflicts of Interest', 'Drilling and Boring', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Natural Gas', 'Research']
abstract: A university adds fresh questions about conflicts of interest with its choice of a fracking-study reviewer.
lead_paragraph: As I wrote recently, the University of Texas, Austin, appropriately initiated an independent review of the report from its Energy Institute on gas drilling using hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, methods. The review was ordered after the Public Accountability Initiative, a nonprofit research group, pointed out previously undisclosed financial ties between a leader of the report, Charles Groat, and a drilling company.

headline: A Murder Sentence Underlines South African Inequality
abstract: The life sentence of a farmhand in the death of the white supremacist Eugène Terre’Blanche ended up being a symbol more of deepening inequality than of racial disharmony.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — When a leading white supremacist was found bludgeoned to death in his bed on his farm outside Johannesburg in April 2010, the Rainbow Nation shuddered.

headline: Stone Links: Paul Ryan, Pussy Riot and Philosophy
abstract: In this week’s links: philosophical influences on Paul Ryan and Pussy Riot, four types of philosopher, and more.
lead_paragraph: Over the past week, “philosophy” made the headlines of stories from opposite ends of the political spectrum.

headline: Whose Ryan Is It Anyway?
abstract: Brooks and Collins discuss Paul Ryan, the Ryan plan and whether good parents make good presidents.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: David, welcome back! You missed so much while you were on vacation. Tim Pawlenty is the Republican vice-presidential nominee, and Michele Bachmann is going to make the keynote speech at the convention, and Donald Trump will be leading the invocation.

headline: Most New Long-Term Care Claims Are Filed by Women
keywords: ["Alzheimer's Disease", 'Elderly', 'Home Health Care', 'Long-Term Care Insurance', 'Longevity', 'Nursing Homes']
abstract: Women filed two-thirds of new long-term care claims last year, an industry report says.
lead_paragraph: While deciding to purchase long-term care insurance is a complex decision, it is one that women, in particular, may want to spend some time considering. Nearly two-thirds of new claims under long-term care policies in 2011 were made by women, according to the latest data from an industry group.

headline: Akin Remarks Push Gender Issues to Center Stage
abstract: Todd Akin’s refusal to step aside in the Missouri Senate race has forced gender issues back into the political conversation, just as Mitt Romney was hoping to refocus it on his personal story and the nation’s struggling economy.
lead_paragraph: Just days before Mitt Romney formally assumes the leadership of his party, he and his Republican colleagues are once again confronting the party’s long-standing difficulty attracting the support of women — a demographic reality that could cost Mr. Romney the White House.

headline: In Google’s Inner Circle, a Falling Number of Women
abstract: The search giant’s efforts to recruit and promote more women have resulted in more hires, but not in the executive offices.
lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — At Google, data is king. Now the company is using data to figure out if it can anoint a few queens.

headline: The Kitchen Announces Its Fall Season
abstract: “Y? O! G…A” is an exhibit by Matt Keegan and Eileen Quinlan that employs yoga mats.
lead_paragraph: Yoga mats, Beethoven, stories from life in America and Mary Shelley’s “Frankenstein” all serve as fodder for offerings this season at The Kitchen performance and exhibition space, which released highlights of its program, which runs from Sept. 7 – Dec. 22.

headline: Reinventing Instant Film in an Age of Instant Imagery
abstract: The Impossible Project has resurrected large format instant film — dead since 2009 — and the results of the first experimental batch will be on display at the Impossible Project Space in New York.
lead_paragraph: In the world of photography, innovation has a shelf life. By 2008, some 60 years after Edwin Land’s invention of the Polaroid camera, analog photography had been usurped by the power of the digital age. The shuttering of instant film production left a community of Polaroid enthusiasts and professional photographers with uncertain futures: Would instant film ever be produced again? Could Polaroid be resurrected?

lead_paragraph: 9:30 p.m. | Updated  That’s a wrap! The live portion of our conversation is now concluded. But please still weigh in in the comments section below with any and all thoughts on Nora Ephron and her work. I’ll be checking in throughout the week. And stay tuned: we’ll announce our next book club selection soon.

headline: Older Fathers Linked to Risk of Autism and Schizophrenia
abstract: Older men are more likely to father a child with autism or schizophrenia.
lead_paragraph: A new study provides some of the first solid scientific evidence for a true increase in autism. In the Science section, Benedict Carey describes the research: “Older men are more likely than young ones to father a child who develops autism or schizophrenia, because of random mutations that become more numerous with advancing paternal age, scientists reported on Wednesday. The age of mothers had no bearing on the risk for these disorders.” Read more.

headline: Please Don’t Eat the Cheese Curls
abstract: What foods do your children bring into the house that you just can’t resist?
lead_paragraph: In the Dining Section, Matt Richtel writes about the ways having children has changed his diet — and not for the better. For him, it’s the main meals. He snatches the French fries and finishes the last bites of pasta.

headline: Another Player Receives 50-Game Ban
abstract: Bartolo Colon, enjoying a resurgent season, tested positive for testosterone and was banished for 50 games, a week after the Giants’ Melky Cabrera received the same penalty for the same substance.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in a week, Major League Baseball has suspended a prominent major leaguer for testing positive for an excessive level of testosterone, a clear indication that illegal performance enhancers continue to exist as a stubborn element of the sport despite intensified efforts to eliminate their use.

headline: Genome Detectives Solve a Hospital’s Deadly Outbreak
abstract: Real-time genome sequencing helped a federal research hospital understand and end an outbreak of a drug-resistant bacterium, Klebsiella pneumoniae, that killed six patients.
lead_paragraph: The ambulance sped up to the red brick federal research hospital on June 13, 2011, and paramedics rushed a gravely ill 43-year-old woman straight to intensive care. She had a rare lung disease and was gasping for breath. And, just hours before, the hospital learned she had been infected with a deadly strain of bacteria resistant to nearly all antibiotics.

headline: David Henry Hwang Wins $200,000 Prize for Playwriting

lead_paragraph: The $200,000 Steinberg award for playwriting, the most generous prize in theater, has been presented to Tony Award winner David Henry Hwang for 32 years of provocative satires and dramas (“Chinglish,” “M. Butterfly”) that brought more Asian and Asian-American characters to Broadway and other stages, the Harold and Mimi Steinberg Charitable Trust announced on Wednesday.

lead_paragraph: 4:42 p.m. | Updated Perhaps recalling the heady days when Bart Simpson T-shirts sold in the millions and a song like “Do the Bartman” had the power to become a cultural touchstone, the UnitedStates Postal Service produced 1 billion stamps featuring characters from “The Simpsons” in 2009 to commemorate the show’s 20th year on Fox.

headline: Notes From the Underground | Cerebral Ballzy
abstract: Having Cerebral Ballzy play at Santos Party House is like putting a tiger in a paper cage.
lead_paragraph: Having Cerebral Ballzy play at Santos Party House is like putting a tiger in a paper cage. Ballzy, one of New York’s loudest, most raucous fire starters, comes with a thick crowd — one of elbow-throwing, neck-snapping, mosh-pit-shoving ruffians that doesn’t exactly jibe with Santos’s thorough, and intimidating, fleet of security guards. At a recent performance, a prominently displayed sign forbade moshing, leaving the audience somewhat castrated in its enthusiasm, but it was clear that on any other night, the scene would be pure chaos. The singer Honor Titus — channeling a mixture of Jimi Hendrix, Tony Hawk and a punk prince — was apparently singing about getting black-out drunk, refusing to be told what to do and being a native New Yorker, but you’d have to be reading a karaoke screen to know that. For the raucous among you, Cerebral Ballzy will perform at the Afro Punk festival in Brooklyn this weekend.

headline: Can This Company Recover From a Cyberattack?
abstract: MyBizHomepage, a provider of business accounting software, was shut down by a wave of cyber attacks that apparently came from a disgruntled former employee.
lead_paragraph: A case study we’ve just published explains the challenges faced by Peter Justen, chief executive of MyBizHomepage, a Middleburg, Va., provider of business accounting software. The business was shut down by a wave of cyber attacks that apparently came from a disgruntled former employee.

headline: A Manic Collection of Orderly Designs
abstract: A look at the blog Amass, whose creator is devoted to collecting examples of typography.
lead_paragraph: As a design student with an inexplicable desire for accumulating all kinds of objects, I was filled with joy upon discovering Amass, the blog of James Phillips Williams, a former art director at Bergdorf Goodman. A successful graphic designer, Williams lives and works in New York with his wife, Allison Muench, where they run their own design studio, MW, whose clients have included the department store Takashimaya. I recently e-mailed Williams to find out more about his acquisitive nature and the blog.

headline: Taylor Swift Song Sets a Record for Digital Sales

lead_paragraph: This week on the music charts, Taylor Swift’s new song set a digital sales record, and the debut album by the rapper 2 Chainz opens at No. 1.

headline: The Dance Between Belize and Its Bondholders
abstract: The bondholders have no direct way of making Belize pay up, but the country probably has to worry more about long-term access to the financial markets than a country like Argentina or even Greece.
lead_paragraph: This is the dynamic at work in the negotiations between Belize and its bondholders. Really it’s the dynamic in most sovereign debt restructurings.

headline: A Web Site That Aims to Help Manage Student Loans
abstract: Loanlook.com aims to help students better manage their financial aid and student loans.
lead_paragraph: I don’t have student loans anymore (thank goodness). But I do recall that managing them was a challenge. How many loans did I have? How much was I paying in total? When would they all be paid off? Who is Sallie Mae, and why did I borrow so much money from her?

headline: Romney Returns to His Mainstay: The Economy
abstract: During a campaign stop in Iowa on Wednesday, Mitt Romney said President Obama had failed to deal with deficits and unemployment.
lead_paragraph: BETTENDORF, Iowa — With the unwanted distractions of Representative Todd Akin’s “legitimate rape” comments still swirling in the background on Wednesday, Mitt Romney returned to his political mainstay during a campaign stop at LeClaire Manufacturing here — hitting President Obama over the economy.

headline: In a Little-Known WWII Battle, a Father’s Experience Becomes a Daughter’s Journey
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Frank Parker charged the beach at Dieppe in 1942. Seventy years later, his daughter stepped onto the same hard sand for the first time.
lead_paragraph: DIEPPE, France — Going to the 70th anniversary commemoration of the Dieppe raid in Normandy this past weekend was part of a journey I began when I was very small. It gathered steam in college, when I first saw footage at the Canadian War Museum in Ottawa that was shot at Dieppe by the Germans. I stood in a gallery watching it, looking for my father, Francis Stanley Parker, a private in the Black Watch Regiment of Canada, in the columns marching past the camera — an American in the sea of Canadian captives.

headline: Work at Slaughterhouse Is Halted After Graphic Undercover Videos
abstract: A slaughterhouse in Hanford, Calif., was forced to stop operations after an animal rights charity secretly filmed inhumane treatment.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities have shut down a California slaughterhouse for investigation after an animal protection charity secretly filmed cows being electrically shocked, shot in the head, suffocated and undergoing other abuses.

lead_paragraph: The police arrested a New York City traffic enforcement agent on Tuesday night after a woman claimed he had raped her. headline: To Sketch, to Draw, to Create, With No Pencil in Sight
abstract: Put away the sketchbook and pencil. Sketching has gone digital, and several apps make it easy.
lead_paragraph: I used to have a habit of carrying around a red Moleskine notebook and, while sipping a beer or a coffee, I’d make little sketches. My drawings were just curiosities, sometimes of the scene or of an interesting person. They were more for fun, to let my creative juices flow, than an attempt at serious art. Often I’d have to borrow a pen from the bar or cafe because carrying a pencil in a jeans pocket wasn’t ideal.

The Prince of the title is Faith Prince and the Show Boy is Jason Graae, who, although hardly a boy, conveys the brashness of a mouthy hyperactive teenager. Both are vaudevillians to the bone.

headline: Diana Nyad’s Neverending Swim
abstract: The 60-something athlete ended her 43-hour swim from Cuba to Florida prematurely this week after she was stung by jellyfish and caught in a lightning storm.
lead_paragraph: Diana Nyad is in her early 60s and all she has wanted to do for the last 35 years is swim the 103 miles that separate Havana from Key West, Fla. She tried and failed three times, starting at age 28, before she jumped into the water on Saturday night to begin her latest attempt. Last December, Elizabeth Weil profiled Nyad in the magazine, capturing her obsessive determination to successfully cross the Straits of Florida, despite the pleading from some of those closest to her that she let this mania go.

lead_paragraph: Most performers who have been inclined to commemorate John Cage’s centenary this season have done so by performing Cage’s music. Kevin James, a trombonist and composer, decided instead to write a work using some of the same principles that animate Cage’s music, including randomness, humor and a mingling of music as it is traditionally understood and unalloyed noise. He presented the piece at the DiMenna Center on Tuesday evening, both as a tribute to Cage and as a way to introduce his new group, the [kaj] Ensemble, which clearly hopes to challenge counter)induction both as a new-music band and over its idiosyncratic orthography.

headline: A Classic Bookcase Comes to America
abstract: The Shelving System was created by the architect Mogens Koch, an unsung hero of Danish design.
lead_paragraph: The late Danish architect Mogens Koch, one of the lesser-known heroes of Scandinavian design, is perhaps best remembered for the shelving system he created in 1928 for his own home in Copenhagen. The system soon caught the interest of Rud. Rasmussen, a local company. Rasmussen put it into production in 1932 and has been making it ever since. Last year, Carl Hansen, another Danish manufacturer, acquired Rasmussen and is giving Mr. Koch’s design its American debut. The Shelving System (it features an extensive range of modular elements, including a CD/DVD unit) is exceptionally flexible. The sections for the basic six-piece unit can be installed horizontally or vertically, allowing lots of options. Made of solid oak with dovetail and rabbet joints to provide strength and stability, the basic unit measures about 30 by 30 by 10.6 inches and is $1,650. Information: (212) 242-6736 or carlhansen.com.

headline: The City That Always Twinkles
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: David Weeks’s Lonely City USB hub mimics the New York skyline.
lead_paragraph: Like so many other New Yorkers, David Weeks is a bit of a voyeur. His latest product, the Lonely City USB hub, is the result of “walking down the street late at night, looking up at a building and seeing that one window lit up,” he said. “Maybe it’s a lamp, maybe it’s the glow of a TV.” The hub illuminates when plugged into an outlet, regardless of whether a device is charging (there’s room for four to charge at any given time). The buildings are based on a Google map view of 16th Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, a block Mr. Weeks said he has frequented over the years, whether on the way to teaching at Parsons or shopping at Paul Smith. “Google maps shows the ghosted buildings at a 45-degree angle — we looked at that block, broke it into several parts and then elaborated on it,” he said. The Windows- and Mac-compatible hub is $25 on Mr. Weeks’s retail site, tweekstudio.com.

headline: Georgia: 2 Waffle House Plotters Are Sentenced
abstract: Two of the four men who federal officials said plotted terrorist activities from a booth at a North Georgia Waffle House were sentenced to five years in prison.
lead_paragraph: Two of the four men who federal officials said plotted terrorist activities from a booth at a North Georgia Waffle House were sentenced to five years in prison on Wednesday for conspiring to obtain an unregistered explosive device and silencer. Defense lawyers had argued that the men were egged on by an informant and that recordings of their plot showed nothing more than old men bragging. Prosecutors said the men were members of a loose-knit militia group that had scouted federal buildings in Atlanta to attack and had planned to kill people. Judge Richard W. Story of Federal District Court said that while people have the right to talk about what they want, “when they start buying bombs and silencers, I’m sorry, we have crossed the line.” Lawyers for the men, Frederick Thomas, 73, and Dan Roberts, 68, said the sentence was part of a plea deal that includes 100 hours of community service. The other men charged, Ray Adams and Samuel Crump, both in their 60s, plan to go to trial. They are charged with conspiracy and attempting to make the poison ricin from castor beans.

headline: Simon Says Don’t Use Flashcards

lead_paragraph: Parents who want to stimulate their children’s brain development often focus on things like early reading, flashcards and language tapes. But a growing body of research suggests that playing certain kinds of childhood games may be the best way to increase a child’s ability to do well in school. Variations on games like Freeze Tag and Simon Says require relatively high levels of executive function, testing a child’s ability to pay attention, remember rules and exhibit self-control — qualities that also predict academic success.

headline: Shuck and Awe
abstract: A dozen recipes for corn off the cob.
lead_paragraph: I don’t need to tell you that there are alternatives to eating corn straight from the cob: you’ve probably adored creamed corn for most of your life. (Possibly you’ve never made it from scratch, and if that’s the case, throw some kernels in a pan with some butter, and after a little while, add some cream along with seasoning. Heat. Eat.) But it’s equally probable that you haven’t done much else with corn kernels taken off the cob. This isn’t a revolutionary process (it’s as old as corn), nor is it difficult: Stand shucked corn upright in a bowl and use a paring knife to cut down along the kernels, as close to the cob as you can. Really dig that knife in — you want everything you can get from the cob. Corn kernels are a revelation, assuming, of course, that the corn is good to begin with. And right now, it should be (and it should be just fine raw, as it is in the first three of these ideas). So before corn costs $6 an ear next year, go for it.

headline: Venus and Serena Against the World
abstract: 15 years after the sisters’ first U.S. Open, theirs is still the most interesting story in sports.
lead_paragraph: There’s video that exists of Venus and Serena Williams playing tennis when they were kids — 8 and 7, respectively — in the late ’80s, on unshaded but otherwise decent-looking public courts in California. This is not one of the clips you’ve maybe seen, taken from various news segments, but an earlier, stranger video, made by their father and longtime coach, Richard Williams, as a kind of audition tape for the tennis-instructional guru Vic Braden, ostensibly requesting an invitation to Braden’s camp, although the real reason for it, you can’t help feel in watching, simply was to let Braden know that greatness had arrived in the world. Richard’s face in the film as he presents the girls to Braden seems, as it does so often, on the brink of laughter. This was in Compton, the low-income, gang-afflicted hub city outside Los Angeles, an area made infamous by many a rap song. Although they enjoyed about as stable an upbringing as you could have in Compton back then, its problems were no mere abstraction: they supposedly knew to lie down on the court when gunshots rang out in the park. And there’s a story that Richard, when asked what he would do if his daughters ever won a Grand Slam, said he would go back and try to help the Crips who sometimes looked out for the girls during their practice sessions. “Venus Williams Is Straight Outta Compton!” read an early promotional poster their father made, to post on telephone poles. He billed the two as celebrities before they were even famous. That was how you did it. Not fake it till you make it. You decided what you were. First you had the belief, and then you had the training. “Belief and training,” Venus told me a couple of weeks ago when I met with her in Cincinnati, where she and Serena were playing in a tournament just days after returning from the Olympics. “That was unconquerable.”

headline: Queens Was Burning, Too
abstract: It wasn’t quite the Yankees and the Bronx. But the last Open to be played in Forest Hills was a spectacle — and a turning point in the history of tennis.
lead_paragraph: On a Sunday night midway through the 1977 U.S. Open, nearly 7,000 people gathered in the stadium at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens, for a third-round match between the ninth-seeded Eddie Dibbs and an 18-year-old named John McEnroe, who was making his debut at the tournament that year. Two months earlier, McEnroe surprised the tennis world by reaching the semifinals of Wimbledon as a qualifier. His feathery touch dazzled the British fans while his combustive behavior led the British tabloids to nickname him Superbrat. Now McEnroe, who grew up in nearby Douglaston, looked poised to make a deep run at the Open. First, though, he had to get past Dibbs, a short, speedy player known as Fast Eddie.

headline: Eye Candy or Eyesore?
abstract: From Park Avenue to Brooklyn, the city is awash with outdoor art, some beautiful, some not.
lead_paragraph: Public art makes me think of what the Conceptualist Douglas Huebler once said: “The world is full of objects, more or less interesting; I do not wish to add any more.” That may be a funny thing for an artist to say, but if you live in a place as densely packed with objects of all kinds as New York City, you may appreciate its wisdom. Nevertheless, for better or worse, temporary public art displays pop up all over the city during the warm seasons in hopes of adding beauty and zest to the urban fabric.

abstract: Whether Americans call themselves middle class doesn’t necessarily have a lot to do with whether they earn close to the median income, a survey finds.

That they do so while weighing less than a cinder block is a nice perk, too.

headline: School of Hard Knocks
abstract: For success, character trumps cognitive skills, Paul Tough says.
lead_paragraph: Most readers of The New York Times probably subscribe to what Paul Tough calls “the cognitive hypothesis”: the belief “that success today depends primarily on cognitive skills — the kind of intelligence that gets measured on I.Q. tests, including the abilities to recognize letters and words, to calculate, to detect patterns — and that the best way to develop these skills is to practice them as much as possible, beginning as early as possible.” In his new book, “How Children Succeed,” Tough sets out to replace this assumption with what might be called the character hypothesis: the notion that noncognitive skills, like persistence, self-control, curiosity, conscientiousness, grit and self-confidence, are more crucial than sheer brainpower to achieving success.

headline: Grown-Up Angst
abstract: Molly Ringwald’s fiction debut centers on a couple in a troubled marriage.
lead_paragraph: Even when she was MOLLY RINGWALD, Molly Ringwald wasn’t content just being Molly Ringwald. In 1988 the teen idol reteamed with her “Pretty in Pink” co-star Andrew McCarthy for “Fresh Horses,” a talky drama about a tough, sullen Kentucky country girl who catches the eye of an engaged engineering student. For moviegoers who went in expecting the plucky high schooler she played in the earlier movie, or “Sixteen Candles,” “Fresh Horses” was a real downer. The group of much more popular friends to whom I recommended it abandoned me halfway through for “Ernest Saves Christmas” and never hung out with me again. I loved it, though — in part because you could see how hard Ringwald was working to be not just a teen-movie star but an actress. That she couldn’t yet pull it off made “Fresh Horses” poignant, and no less enjoyable — and as fans of the ABC Family series “The Secret Life of the American Teenager” know, in the end she has become an actress, and not a bad one at all.

headline: Buccaneers and Bullion
abstract: Andrew Motion’s sequel to Robert Louis Stevenson’s 19th-century adventure classic.
lead_paragraph: Alas for the unintended cruelty of a book-reviewing aunt! On the long ride to catch the sunset from the dunes above Lake Michigan, I handed my restless 7-year-old nephew a book from my beach bag: Robert Louis Stevenson’s “Treasure Island.” Instantly and intently, he began reading aloud, propelled by the excitement of discovery. Later, back at the cottage, he asked, “Can I have my book now?” Guiltily, I told him he’d have to wait: I needed it for a story I was writing about “Treasure Island” and its new sequel, “Silver,” by the British poet Andrew Motion. I felt like a blackhearted mutineer.

Abrams, the founding general editor, and Stephen Greenblatt, the current general editor, discuss the history of the anthology, the challenges facing English literature survey courses and the enduring question, Why study literature?

headline: Save the Date
abstract: In this series opener, history is broken, and it’s up to three young time travelers to fix it.
lead_paragraph: Admit it. You’ve fantasized about time travel. You’ve wondered what it would be like to visit your own past and slap some sense into your younger self. Perhaps you’ve imagined having dinner with Leonardo, or sitting in the emperor’s box in the Roman Colosseum.

headline: Drawn Out
abstract: Three picture books encourage children to become constructors of their worlds.
lead_paragraph: Why do we draw and write? Toddlers, protean in their creativity, exuberantly deploy any drawing implement within reach. “Only on paper!” I used to admonish nervously, reliving the maternal wrath I once incurred after “decorating” my childhood bedroom wall with wild-style wax crayons.

headline: Mutant Chronicles
abstract: Two novels allude to the feelings of alienation among middle-school boys.
lead_paragraph: The middle school years conspire to make all boys feel like mutants. This is a circumstance two middle-grade books acknowledge in a fashion that is mercifully more creepy-crawly than touchy-feely.

headline: Bookshelf: First Day
abstract: New picture books about heading off to school.
lead_paragraph: IT’S TIME FOR PRESCHOOL!  By Esmé Raji Codell.Illustrated by Sue Ramá.  40 pp. Greenwillow Books/HarperCollins Publishers. $15.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 5)

headline: An App for Cartoon Multitasking
abstract: The Cartoon Network has introduced an app that lets children watch Cartoon Network shows on the top half of an iPad screen while playing a video game on the bottom half.
lead_paragraph: You know how your children act when they are overstimulated? Well, here’s an app that pretty much guarantees that behavior.

headline: Identity Crises
abstract: For the high-spirited Olivia and others, the pressure to conform can sometimes seem overwhelming.
lead_paragraph: Individualism. Embracing differences. Following your dream. Being free to be you and me. These are among the great themes of American children’s literature. They’re among the great themes of American adult literature too — of America, period. Figures as diverse as Ron Paul and Barack Obama, Ayn Rand and Mark Twain, John Ford and Wes Anderson would, I think, agree. Each in his or her own special way!

headline: Bodies and Soul
abstract: In David Levithan’s novel, a teenage romance is put to the test.
lead_paragraph: As surely as a gardener plants flowers or a mason lays stone, a writer puts obstacles in the path of love. Your families hate each other. Your cultures clash. One of you is rich and one of you is poor, or one of you is naïf and one of you is whore. Maybe there’s a prickly vampirism issue, maybe a pesky time-travel quirk. It’s always something.

headline: Bookshelf: Numbers
abstract: New picture books offer creative approaches to counting.
lead_paragraph: ONE TWO THAT’S MY SHOE!  Written and illustrated by Alison Murray.  32 pp. Disney-Hyperion Books. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 6)

headline: Spellbound
abstract: In the Middle East, a sheltered girl befriends a shape-shifter.
lead_paragraph: Teenagers typically turn to fantasy as a means of escaping the rigors and disappointments of adolescence, and many authors specialize in creating universes entirely separate from our own. But in “The Girl With Borrowed Wings,” a frankly spellbinding love story, Rinsai Rossetti shows the power of fantasy when it coincides with, rather than opposes, what may be a grim reality.

headline: One Man’s Tale of Two Koreas, Changed Allegiances, Torture and Fear
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Torture']
abstract: Kim Young-hwan, who in the 1980s plotted against South Korea, today works to promote democracy in the North. But his capture in China in March has put his mission at risk.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The bizarre twists of fate and intrigue that have shadowed Kim Young-hwan, once one of South Korea’s best-known student activists, read like the plot of a Bond movie.

headline: Tell Me
abstract: Three very different books illuminate the urge to narrate.
lead_paragraph: Native American lore tells of animals so entranced by powerful tales they forget to gather winter provisions, a myth that makes vivid our innate hunger for storytelling. But sometimes what most satisfies our need for stories is telling the tale ourselves.

headline: Can You Keep a Secret?
abstract: Rebecca Stead’s hero contends with a bully and an eccentric new friend.
lead_paragraph: Unlike her Newbery Medal-­winning novel, “When You Reach Me,” in which time travel is the subtext to all the interwoven story lines, Rebecca Stead’s new book, “Liar & Spy,” is firmly grounded in the here and now. What the two do share is a mood of shimmery unrest. Part coming­-of-age tale, part mystery, “Liar & Spy” takes place in contemporary Brooklyn and revolves around a seventh-grade loner and misfit named Georges. Cast out of his own home after his father loses his job and the family sells their house to make ends meet — and cast off by his best friend in favor of the popular clique — Georges finds himself living in a new apartment building with a cast of eccentric neighbors. These include the similarly aged and oddly named Safer, the building’s resident dog walker as well as a budding spy; Safer’s candy-obsessed younger sister, Candy; and their bird-watching older brother, Pigeon.

headline: Hanging on Every Word
abstract: A story inspires an app, a short film and now a book.
lead_paragraph: It may be telling that “The Fantastic Flying Books of Mr. Morris Lessmore,” a kind of totem to the unmatched joys of reading, appeared in two different screen adaptations before making the transition into print. Winning an Oscar earlier this year for best animated short after appearing, last summer, as a lauded animated app, William Joyce’s story of a natty Southern loner was a feat of digital imagination, a dazzlingly polished animation and a wordless tribute to a fading literary age. Now, realized at last as a children’s book, his tale gains elegance but loses depth. The print-edition “Morris Lessmore” is a stylishly paced, vividly illustrated parable for young readers, yet it somehow lacks the dreamy creativity of its animated precursors. Ultimately, Joyce’s book tells us something we may already suspect: that storytelling these days has a broader canvas than the hallowed space within the ­library doors.

headline: Life Backstage
abstract: In this graphic novel an ambitious theater geek concentrates on friendship and creative fulfillment instead of boy craziness.
lead_paragraph: The parenting-book world is flooded with jeremiads about how tween culture breeds sociopaths and prostitots, ergo we should unplug the Internet. But this is a narrative belied by the thriving field of age-appropriate books epitomized by the nice-girls-finish-first graphic novels of Raina Telgemeier, poetic illustrator of middle-school life.

headline: Aftermath
abstract: In their new young adult novels, Joyce Carol Oates and James Preller examine the consequences of fatal events.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after the 2002 release of “Big Mouth & Ugly Girl,” her first novel for young adults, Joyce Carol Oates noted in an interview that young adult fiction is “just stripped-down adult fiction with more dialogue and less description. In adult fiction you do things with language — for example, you might repeat certain adjectives for an atmospheric effect. In young adult fiction, that isn’t done, and the chapters tend to be shorter.”

headline: Bookshelf: Funny Folk Tales
abstract: Variations on Goldilocks, the Three Little Pigs and more.
lead_paragraph: GOLDILOCKS AND THE THREE DINOSAURS  Written and illustrated by Mo Willems.  40 pp. Balzer & Bray/HarperCollins Publishers. $17.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 7)

headline: Fear and Self-Loathing
abstract: School, relationships, popularity. Navigating life’s uncertainties, the teenage girls in these novels are pushed to the brink.
lead_paragraph: When you’re a teenager, especially if you’re a girl, it’s deceptively easy to wreak havoc, if unintentionally, on your body. The pressure to appear flawless and to fit in without ever breaking a sweat requires putting your best poker face forward while shoving the messiness of adolescence under the bed. Skipping meals? Why not? Sticking two fingers down your throat after too many carbs? Easy as pie. Becoming a little fast and loose with alcohol and drugs, or negotiating a quick slice of the knife across your inner thigh? It happens all the time.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: LIONEL ASBO: State of England,  by Martin Amis. (Knopf, $25.95.) The Dickensian theme of Amis’s novel is the corrupting influence of money, as his antihero, a career criminal with a vestigial conscience, wins the lottery and is baffled by legitimate wealth.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: ROCK THE CASBAH: Rage and Rebellion Across the Islamic World,  by Robin Wright. (Simon & Schuster, $17.) Wright, a veteran foreign correspondent and the author of “Dreams and Shadows: The Future of the Middle East” (2008), examines the causes and repercussions of revolts against autocratic rule in countries like Tunisia, Egypt, Libya and Yemen. Traveling across the region, she profiles poets, playwrights, feminists, TV imams and others working toward a “counter-jihad” to reclaim Islam from militants who crave perpetual holy war.

headline: In the Shadow of War
abstract: Young girls learn about the limits of their parents in two new books about the strains produced by the Iraq war.
lead_paragraph: A convention of novels aimed at children in the middle-grade years holds that whatever problem a girl confronts, her parents will not be the ones to help. This often makes sense both psychologically and narratively. These are the years when children begin to differentiate themselves from their parents and learn to fight their own battles. And really, how exciting would a story be in which our heroine, say, is ganged up on by other girls, but then tells her mother, who steps in, does all the right things, and every­thing’s fine?

headline: Universal Struggles
abstract: Three new middle-grade novels feature girls from very different backgrounds dealing with the challenges of school.
lead_paragraph: Businesses are quick to lump together tweens and teenagers into one big marketing opportunity, but when it comes to books, younger readers are very different from their young adult counterparts. How do you define that shifting period of transitions between the ages of 8 and 10, or 7 and 10, when children read at very different rates, with different aptitudes and for different reasons?

headline: Batman’s New Perch Above Gotham: Your iPad
abstract: Hoping to bridge the gap between physical and digital toys, Mattel has created a line of enhanced iPad games called Apptivity. One of the first offerings in the line is Batman, inspired by the movie “The Dark Knight Rises.”
lead_paragraph: From the shadows, Batman swoops down and lands on your iPad to fight a gang of thugs. But fear not! He’ll throw a lot of punches, but he won’t scratch your screen.

headline: Up Front
abstract: Hanna Rosin on women’s success in college.
lead_paragraph: This week, Hanna Rosin reviews Nathan Harden’s “Sex and God at Yale,” an investigation into oversexualized college life — and its dangers to young women. A senior editor at The Atlantic and Slate, Rosin conducted her own campus research for her forthcoming book, “The End of Men” — although she came to markedly different conclusions. She maintains that the “hookup culture” Harden decries might be “integral” to women’s success in college. Why? Casual relationships “won’t derail future life plans.”

headline: Fantasy Football: Running Back Primer
abstract: Perhaps the most important position in fantasy football, running back will also be the toughest to get right this season.
lead_paragraph: Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice and analysis throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter @5thDownFantasy. Jason also blogs at blackfifty9razor.com.

abstract: New picture books about heading off to school.
lead_paragraph: New picture books about heading off to school.

headline: Republican Immigration Platform Backs ‘Self-Deportation’
keywords: ['Deportation', 'Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)', 'Foreign Students (in US)', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Illegal Immigrants', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: Republican delegates hammered out an immigration plank calling for tough border enforcement and opposing “any forms of amnesty” for illegal immigrants, instead endorsing “humane procedures to encourage illegal aliens to return home voluntarily,” a policy of self-deportation.
lead_paragraph: Republicans have adopted a party platform on immigration that would require employers nationwide to verify workers’ legal status and deny federal financing to universities that allow illegal immigrant students to enroll at lower in-state tuition rates.

headline: Undeterred by Drug Testing in Baseball
abstract: Bartolo Colon’s suspension tells writers that the Bay Area is the capital of steroids and makes them wonder whether the sport’s testing system works.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, the news that pitcher Bartolo Colon has tested positive for performance-enhancing drugs is about as surprising as the Cookie Monster testing positive for chocolate chips. He is 39, having resurrected his injury-plagued career with help from a fishy-sounding stem cell procedure last year and despite a physique that makes it clear his performance-enhancing drugs are hidden in double cheeseburgers.

lead_paragraph: New picture books offer creative approaches to counting.

lead_paragraph: Variations on Goldilocks, the Three Little Pigs and more.

headline: State Agency Web Sites May Work Business Hours
abstract: Be it to rest their algorithms or maybe just to ponder their purpose, some New York State government Web sites are available to the public less than 24/7.
lead_paragraph: In this day and age, when routine chores like paying bills and ordering groceries can be done online at anytime, day or night, some New York State agencies have Web sites that have yet to join the 24/7 world.

headline: Half of Homeowners Under 40 Are Still Underwater
abstract: The less time you’ve been in your home, the more likely you’ve accumulated little equity and seen the value of your property fall since 2005.
lead_paragraph: The country’s underwater homes are slowly resurfacing as the housing market improves. But younger borrowers are still more likely to be submerged, a new report from real estate site Zillow.com finds.

headline: Image of the Day: August 23
abstract: A procession marking the end of the Sindhi fasting festival of Jhulelal Chaliha in Ahmedabad, Gujarat.

headline: The Lowdown | Michael David Quattlebaum Jr. and Mykki Blanco
abstract: Hip-hop and homosexuality, rap and cross-dressing, and feminine fury and hustling masculinity have been thrust into one.
lead_paragraph: Hip-hop and homosexuality have been thrust into the same uncomfortably small room, most recently on the occasion of Frank Ocean’s much-discussed coming out and the stream of controversial shows of support or slander that followed. But the community is poised to have to swallow a much bigger bite of acceptance with the virtually unprecedented marriage of rap and cross-dressing embodied by the artist known as Mykki Blanco.

headline: Business Day Live | August 23, 2012
abstract: For the housing market, the beginning of a recovery. | Fed officials push for action to support the economy. | A derailed effort to change money market funds.
lead_paragraph: For the housing market, the beginning of a recovery. | Fed officials push for action to support the economy. | A derailed effort to change money market funds.

headline: With Multimedia Show, Ford Looks to Give Fusion an Edge
abstract: Ford’s redesigned midsize sedan anchored an ambitious gallery opening in New York.
lead_paragraph: Ford brought its redesigned Fusion sedan to meet some artists and artisans Tuesday night at Eyebeam in Chelsea. A multimedia exhibition, called “Wall to Wall: The Fusion Collective,” filled the event space with mirrors and fog, pulsating lights and towering speakers.

headline: Despite Good Intentions, a Fresco in Spain Is Ruined
abstract: A century-old fresco depicting Jesus crowned with thorns has been disfigured after an elderly parishioner took it upon herself to restore the artwork, damaged by moisture.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — A case of suspected vandalism in a church in a northeastern village in Spain has turned out to be probably the worst art restoration project of all time.

headline: Key Democratic State Parties Have Financial Edge
abstract: While President Obama and Mitt Romney crisscross the nation raising money for their campaigns, in battleground states Republican and Democratic organizations have been laying the groundwork for voter organization and turnout for the November election.
lead_paragraph: While President Obama and Mitt Romney crisscross the nation raising money for their campaigns, in the battleground states Republican and Democratic organizations have been laying the groundwork for voter organization and turnout for the November election. Much of the money for those efforts comes from the national party organizations — the Democratic and Republican National Committees, plus several Congressional party arms — that has been sent to the states from Washington.

headline: JPMorgan’s Former Leader Makes a Case for Big Banks
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Glass-Steagall Act (1933)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: William B. Harrison Jr., a primary architect of the modern-day JPMorgan Chase, writes in an op-ed in The Times that the breakup of big banks would not prevent risky behaviors.
lead_paragraph: More than a decade ago, William B. Harrison Jr. and Sanford I. Weill pioneered the model of the financial behemoth from their perches atop JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup. But today, the two Wall Street veterans hardly see eye to eye.

headline: Sonia Gandhi Ranked Sixth Most Powerful Woman in the World
abstract: Despite rising criticism at home, Mrs. Gandhi’s rank rises in Forbes’ annual list.
lead_paragraph: Sonia Gandhi, the Congress party president and chairwoman of the coalition government running the country, is India’s most powerful woman and the sixth most powerful woman in the world, according to Forbes magazine.

headline: Polls Highlight Senate Races in Swing States
abstract: New surveys show the ratings for governors in Florida, Ohio and Wisconsin as well as the state of play in key Senate contests.
lead_paragraph: Democratic incumbents have an edge over their challengers in the Florida and Ohio Senate races, while in Wisconsin, fresh from winning the Republican primary, former Gov. Tommy Thompson has a six-point advantage over Representative Tammy Baldwin.

headline: Drawbacks to Banking Accounts for Seniors
abstract: A new report finds that some checking accounts geared to older people provide few advantages.
lead_paragraph: Caveat check writer.

headline: Walking the Walk, Cane in Hand
abstract: Rob McClure, an actor with no Tony Award or major name recognition, nonetheless landed the title role in the musical “Chaplin” on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: THE sight of an actor lost in thought, murmuring lines en route to an audition, is hardly uncommon in a city’s theater district. But passengers on an Amtrak train from Philadelphia to New York one morning two years ago may have noticed something far rarer: a performer prepping a bit of silent-film high jinks.

headline: China Confronts Mounting Piles of Unsold Goods
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The severity of the country’s inventory surplus has been masked by the blocking or adjusting of economic data by the government.
lead_paragraph: GUANGZHOU, China — After three decades of torrid growth, China is encountering an unfamiliar problem with its newly struggling economy: a huge buildup of unsold goods that is cluttering shop floors, clogging car dealerships and filling factory warehouses.

headline: Lennon’s Killer Denied Parole a 7th Time
abstract: The state parole board, while noting Mark David Chapman’s good conduct record in prison, told him that paroling him “would greatly undermine respect for the law and tend to trivialize the tragic loss of life which you caused.”
lead_paragraph: Mark David Chapman has been denied parole, for the seventh time, in the murder ofJohn Lennon, the New York State corrections department said Thursday.

headline: California Dreams, Iranian Décor
abstract: How a mother built a home out of two suitcases.
lead_paragraph: In 1978, my mother packed two maroon, leatherette suitcases, and she, my father and I boarded a plane for the United States. Just about everyone who could leave Iran had done so already; friends and relatives had been selling off their houses for months. But “revolution” and “exile” were not words my family applied to our circumstances. We left our apartment on Pahlavi Avenue completely intact. The two suitcases suggested, if not a vacation, at most a temporary absence.

headline: General Notes Taliban Coercion in Some Attacks on Troops
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Assaults']
abstract: Gen. John R. Allen, the senior commander in Afghanistan, said that up to one-quarter of the attacks by Afghan security forces on Americans could be caused by Taliban infiltration or coercion.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The senior commander in Afghanistan made new allowances on Thursday that Taliban influence could play a large role in attacks by Afghan security forces on Americans, saying that up to one-quarter of the killings could be caused by Taliban infiltration or coercion. But he reiterated that most of such insider attacks have still been attributed to personal grievances and animosities.

headline: Indian Government Casts a Wide, Puzzling Net Over Internet
abstract: Twitter parodies of the Prime Minister, bloggers who exposed false rumors among government targets.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, the Indian government acknowledged that it had asked internet service providers to block about 250 web pages in an effort to contain ethnic tensions between Muslims and people from the northeast.

headline: Rowling to Make U.S Appearance to Promote Her First Novel for Adults
abstract: The author of the Harry Potter series will be interviewed by the author Ann Patchett at Jazz at Lincoln Center on Oct. 16.
lead_paragraph: J.K. Rowling is coming to America to promote her first novel for adults, “The Casual Vacancy,” her publisher has announced. Ms. Rowling will appear at one public event, an onstage interview at Jazz at Lincoln Center with the author Ann Patchett on Oct. 16. She will also take questions from the audience and sign copies of her book for audience members. Tickets go on sale Sept. 10, starting at $37, a price that includes a copy of the book.

headline: Levon Helm Tribute Is Planned for October
abstract: Proceeds from the “Love for Levon” concert will go to help his family retain ownership of his home and his famous studio, a converted barn in Woodstock, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: John Mayer, Gregg Allman, Joe Walsh and other prominent musicians plan to hold a large benefit concert to raise money for Levon Helm’s estate on Oct. 3 at the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J., Mr. Helm’s family announced.

headline: Lincoln’s Letter to the Editor
abstract: How the president used his famous response to Horace Greeley to explain his new policy on emancipation.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 19, 1862 Horace Greeley, the editor of The New York Tribune, published a long “open letter” to President Lincoln in his newspaper. Titled “The Prayer for Twenty Millions,” the letter demanded that Lincoln immediately move to end slavery, not only in the Confederacy, but also in the loyal slave states – Delaware, Maryland, Kentucky, and Missouri, as well as in those parts of Tennessee under control of the United States. The letter was noteworthy as a bold, widely read attack on the president by a major figure in his own party. Even more noteworthy, though, was Lincoln’s response.

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘Dogs’
abstract: Written by Ido Bernstein, the show explores the culture of aggressive masculinity in contemporary Israel.
lead_paragraph: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festival’s close on Aug. 26. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

headline: Based on Donations, N.H.L.’s American Owners Prefer Republican Candidates
keywords: ['Hockey, Ice', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Political donations made by the owners of the N.H.L.’s 23 United States-based clubs have gone largely to Republicans.
lead_paragraph: N.H.L. owners are very wealthy and engaged in battle with a union, so it would not be surprising to find that when it comes to American electoral politics, they lean strongly Republican.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Preventing Abortions…With Lethal Force
abstract: A Republican candidate for sheriff in New Hampshire says elective abortions need “to be stopped.”
lead_paragraph: Via Talking Points Memo

headline: Even if Akin Wanted to Quit Race, It Would Be Difficult
abstract: In Missouri, changing nominees in the middle of a campaign is complicated.
lead_paragraph: Despite the firestorm over his comments about rape and pregnancy, Representative Todd Akin says he has no plans to drop out as the Republican Senate nominee in Missouri.

headline: What the Sound and Fury Over Best Buy May Signify
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity']
abstract: Behind the squabbling between Best Buy and its founder and principal stockholder, Richard M. Schulze, there is a mystery. What exactly is Mr. Schulze’s strategy? And why are both parties fighting so publicly?
lead_paragraph: The squabbling between Best Buy and its founder and principal stockholder, Richard M. Schulze, appears about as mature as sibling teenagers fighting over the only car.

headline: F.T.C. Settles With Marketers of Ab Circle Pro
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission announced a settlement with Fitness Brands Inc. and its marketing partners on Thursday, over deceptive advertising claims for an abdominal exercise machine called the Ab Circle Pro.
lead_paragraph: There are few easy ways to lose weight quickly, but that has not stopped some marketers from making claims to the contrary, especially for products pitched on late-night infomercials.

headline: Facebook Speeds Up iPhone and iPad Apps
abstract: Facebook released major upgrades for its iPhone and iPad apps. Those who have suffered from the sluggishness of the current apps can breathe a collective sigh of relief: these new versions are much faster.
lead_paragraph: Facebook on Thursday released major upgrades to its iPhone and iPad apps. Those who have suffered from the sluggishness of the current apps can breathe a collective sigh of relief: these new versions are much faster.

headline: Pairs Well With Peanuts? Wine Tasting on Delta
abstract: The carrier will begin what it’s calling a “Winemaker Series” for business travelers.
lead_paragraph: In-flight food has gotten regular upgrades — this spring alone British Airways prepared a menu with the chef Simon Hulstone, and ANA enlisted the French pastry chef Pierre Hermé. Now, Delta has turned its attention to oenophiles, who know that a chewy wine doesn’t mean you’ll need a toothpick after a glass.

headline: Vain Glorious | Braid, Not Frayed!
abstract: The classic hairstyle has been morphing from a Nordic, tight style into chic, messier plaits.
lead_paragraph: Braids have been around forever, of course, but they are morphing from a Nordic, tight style into chic, messier plaits, thanks to modern-day heroines like Jennifer Lawrence (as Katniss Everdeen in “The Hunger Games”) and Emilia Clarke, who plays the warrior princess Daenerys Targaryen on “Game of Thrones.”

headline: Facebook Reorients Itself for a Small-Screen World
abstract: The company is trying to find ways to show lucrative ads to mobile users without cluttering up their hand-held screens and driving them away in frustration.
lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — At Facebook’s headquarters here, mobile devices are everywhere. The first thing visitors do is sign in on iPads at the front desk. Employees at the campus coffee shop use iPads as cash registers. Instead of sending e-mails, Facebook employees prefer to use the company’s messaging system, which pops up new messages on both mobile devices and PCs.

headline: Sony Pictures the Latest Studio to Make Broadway Push
abstract: Sony has purchased a 20 percent equity stake in Scott Sanders Theatrical Productions as it seeks to mount stage versions of the studio’s films, with their first project being a musical adaptation of the 1982 Dustin Hoffman comedy “Tootsie.”
lead_paragraph: Sony Pictures Entertainment has signed a five-year deal with the Broadway producer Scott Sanders (“Evita,” “The Color Purple”) to mount stage versions of the studio’s films, with their first project being a musical adaptation of the 1982 Dustin Hoffman comedy “Tootsie.” The deal, which was announced on Thursday, represents the latest move by several Hollywood film studios to capitalize on theatergoers’ appetite – particularly tourists visiting New York – for musicals based on movies or books; most Broadway musicals these days are adaptations, like the top-grossing shows “Wicked” and “The Lion King” and new hits like the Tony Award winner “Once” and the Disney musical “Newsies.”

headline: Author of Book on Bin Laden Raid Is Identified
abstract: The anonymous Navy SEAL member who wrote the book remained anonymous for less than 24 hours.
lead_paragraph: The anonymous Navy SEAL member who has written a book about the raid that killed Osama bin Laden remained anonymous for less than 24 hours.

headline: Report Finds Americans Wasteful of Food
abstract: A report from the Natural Resources Defense Council says that much of the food produced for Americans goes unused, wasting water and the other resources that go into producing it.
lead_paragraph: Forty percent of the food Americans have available to them goes uneaten, according to a report released this week by the Natural Resources Defense Council. Most of this nutrient-rich uneaten food ends up rotting in landfills.

headline: China Forces Ethnic Kachin Refugees Back to a Conflict Zone in Myanmar’s North
keywords: ['Civil War and Guerrilla Warfare', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Officials in southwest China are pushing ethnic refugees from neighboring Myanmar back into Kachin State, where a renewed civil war has forced 7,000 to 10,000 people to flee to China, according to Human Rights Watch.
lead_paragraph: KATMANDU, Nepal — The authorities in southwestern China are forcibly evicting thousands of encamped ethnic Kachin refugees who fled a renewed civil war in neighboring Myanmar, pushing them back into the conflict zone in Kachin State in northern Myanmar, according to foreign human rights researchers, political analysts and two people in Kachin State.

headline: Bulgaria Plots Return to Olympic Prominence
abstract: Plovdiv, Bulgaria’s second largest city, is expanding its Soviet-era rowing course, a part of an effort to overturn two decades of sporting disappointment since the glory days under communism.
lead_paragraph: PLOVDIV, Bulgaria — Svetla Otzetova, a grande dame of Bulgarian rowing, wore a perfectly pressed blouse, and her brow somehow managed to stay dry despite the stifling heat.

headline: Far, Maybe Too Far, Into the Yukon
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Camps and Camping', 'Rivers', 'Canoes and Canoeing']
abstract: On a canoe trip near the Arctic Circle, capsizing in swift current, backpaddling to avoid a bear and seeing what the world looks like more than 100 miles from the nearest road.
lead_paragraph: WE watched the pot closely, feeding the fire beneath it with whatever damp, gnarled sticks we could scavenge from the tree-starved tundra around us — but still it didn’t boil.

headline: Self-Deportation
abstract: The Republican Party thinks it’s possible, and desirable, to force 11 million undocumented immigrants to leave the country by making them miserable.
lead_paragraph: The Republican platform drafting committee has adopted the “self-deportation” immigration “solution” that Mitt Romney embraced during the primaries. This is the idea that it is not only possible to force 11 million undocumented immigrants to leave the country by making them miserable, but also desirable–presumably because Americans are itching to get back to farm labor, domestic and restaurant work, small-scale entrepreneurship and other backbreaking, minimal-wage jobs that illegal immigrants have stolen from them.

headline: They’re Not Making Any More (Well, Almost)
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'United States Economy']
abstract: There are fewer new homes on the market than at any time in decades, and some of those available are not exactly new.
lead_paragraph: Two facts stand out from Thursday’s report on new home sales in July.

headline: Craig Zadan and Neil Meron to Produce Academy Awards Show
abstract: Along with their credits as film producers, Mr. Zadan and Mr. Meron have worked in television.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The next Oscar show has found its producers, and they are a very musical pair. Craig Zadan and Neil Meron, whose films include the musicals “Chicago” and “Hairspray,” have agreed to produce the 85th Academy Awards ceremony, set for Feb. 24, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said on Thursday. Along with their credits as film producers, Mr. Zadan and Mr. Meron have worked in television, where their series include “Drop Dead Diva” and “Smash,” and on Broadway, where they were producers of the revived “How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying” and “Promises, Promises.” The recruiting of Mr. Zadan and Mr. Meron was the first major step by Hawk Koch, who was elected president of the Academy earlier this month.

headline: ‘The Exonerated’ to Be Revived at the Culture Project

lead_paragraph: “The Exonerated,” a critically acclaimed play about wrongfully convicted survivors of death row, which had star-filled casts for its Off Broadway run from 2002 to 2004, will return for a seven-week run starting Sept. 15 at the Culture Project, its artistic director announced on Thursday. The production will once again feature a rotating cast of stars – including Stockard Channing, Brian Dennehy and Brooke Shields – who will read accounts by former death row inmates.

headline: Edible Selby | The Big Morel Cookout With Connie Green

lead_paragraph: In this sequel to The Selby’s last film, which follows the mushroom huntress Connie Green and the chef Sean O’Toole on a search for edible fungus in California’s high Sierras, Green gathers her friends — “the tribal members of this mushroom hunting cult,” she calls them — for a four-course morel-focused meal. Joining her and O’Toole at the outside table: Chef Hiro Sone of Terra Restaurant in Napa, Calif., who prepares a tartine of foie gras-stuffed morels in a crayfish sauce; the pastry chef and restaurateur Lissa Doumani, also of Terra, and Ame in San Francisco, who makes morels stuffed with lamb kibbe; the Kitchen Door‘s chef, Todd Humphries, who serves morels stuffed with bratwurst; and Chef Staffan Terje of Perbacco and Barbacco, cooking porcinis and peaches. headline: Whole Wheat Tomato and Ricotta Tart
abstract: This tart has a whole-wheat pastry, to echo the wheat beers.
lead_paragraph: These American wheat beers in the hefeweizen style are bright refreshers designed to sip and enjoy on their own on a summer day, or to pour alongside food that is anything but serious. Beer and grilled hot dogs? Burgers? Pizza? Without question. The last time we trained our palates on this category of suds I devised a pizza paved with ripe tomatoes, Vidalia onions and Stilton. On this revisit I took a longer detour on the way to beer and pizza, making a tomato and ricotta tart for a warm-weather lunch, an early evening bite or a first course at dinner. The whole-wheat pastry pays homage to the beers.

lead_paragraph: IN the heat of a waning summer, when half the world seems to have taken off on vacation, a late-morning glass of wheat beer can be another sort of pleasurable departure. In Bavaria, home of the hefeweizen style of wheat beer, such refreshment is an essential component of the brotzeit, or second breakfast.

lead_paragraph: Despite C. P. Snow’s 1959 plaint about the gap between science and the humanities, there isn’t any — on one level at least. Artists happily take up whatever new technology falls into their hands. The mystery is why some inventions gain traction and others, like holograms, are met with a flurry of excitement, used for a short time and then abandoned.

headline: No Breaks for a Rider in a Hurry
abstract: “Premium Rush” stars Joseph Gordon-Levitt as a bicycle messenger racing around New York City.
lead_paragraph: Pushing pedal to the mettle and its breezily thin, goofy story to the breaking point, “Premium Rush” provides just about all the late summer air-conditioned relief you could hope for. It’s buoyant dumb-fun, a ticking-clock thriller about a New York bicycle messenger who has to get from here to there without being taken out. Stuffed with zingers and zippy stunts, it comes with pretty young things of all hues and hair types — few prettier than its lead, Joseph Gordon-Levitt — and start-to-finish clever special effects, none more clever or special than Michael Shannon. If you want to see a political undertow in its urban band of multicultural renegades, there’s that for the taking too.

In Gillian Flynn’s “Gone Girl” — at No. 1 in its 11th week on the hardcover fiction list — a young wife disappears from her home on the morning of her fifth anniversary. Paula Bomer’s “Nine Months,” published on Aug. 21, features a pregnant painter who abandons her family and takes off on a debauched cross-country trip. And new on the extended hardcover fiction list at No. 18 is Maria Semple’s “Where’d You Go, Bernadette,” in which a renowned, reclusive and very cranky architect vanishes, leaving her 15-year-old daughter to piece together the clues.

What do you think?

headline: Whimsy Teased From Molten Beginnings
abstract: Jean-Michel Othoniel’s midcareer survey at the Brooklyn Museum focuses mainly on the glass pieces he has created almost exclusively since 1993.
lead_paragraph: Some of the art in “Jean-Michel Othoniel: My Way,” a whimsical but cloying midcareer survey at the Brooklyn Museum, can strike you as the sculptural equivalent of haute couture. A bed framed by Murano glass beads is accompanied by veils of tulle, each one hand embroidered with gold thread in a workshop established by Louis XIV. Elsewhere, 4,200 yellow blown-glass bricks, shaped by artisans from Firozabad, India, form a shimmering rectangular solid.

lead_paragraph: The producers of the recent Off Broadway musical “Soul Doctor,” about the life and singing career of Rabbi Shlomo Carlebach, are in talks to move the show either to Broadway’s Circle in the Square Theater or to Off Broadway’s New World Stages, according to the lead producer of the show, Jeremy Chess. He said he is now seeking to expand his pool of investors to remount the show as he awaits word from Paul Libin of Circle in the Square while pursuing separate negotiations with executives at New World Stages.

headline: In a Tiny Nook, an Array of Treats
abstract: Atsushi Numata improvises with what surrounds him at a stall within the Essex Street Market.
lead_paragraph: FIRST you must find it, somewhere in the depths of the Essex Street Market on the Lower East Side, past the cheesemonger, the Latin grocer and the baklava shop. Ni Japanese Delicacies, which opened last September, is not a restaurant, just a cluttered stall (a nook, really) without tables or chairs. At a short counter along the back wall, the owner and chef, Atsushi Numata, labors alone over a cutting board wedged against an induction burner. Pots and scissors dangle. Unlidded Tupperware and jars of condiments inch toward the edge.

headline: Sarah Wong’s Portraits of Dutch Transgendered Children

The automaker said the redesigned compact car would offer revised exterior and interior styling, along with improved fuel economy, but provided no further details.

headline: The Leisure Class Bears Its Burden
abstract: “Neighboring Sounds” illuminates the present state of Brazilian society by exposing the complex relationships and simmering contradictions in its enclaves of privilege.
lead_paragraph: “Neighboring Sounds,” Kleber Mendonça Filho’s revelatory debut feature, takes place mostly on a wealthy block in the northeastern Brazilian city of Recife. Identical, gleaming white high-rises — some with fancy names like Vivaldi, Westminster and Camille Claudel — dominate the skyline, obscuring the nearby ocean and also the urban poverty that has been central to Brazil’s social and cinematic identity for decades.

headline: Worth Its Weight | Mannin’s New Insignia Collection
abstract: With Suzanne Donnegan’s new line, affordable bespoke jewelry is within reach.
lead_paragraph: With gold prices continuing to rise, jewelers are looking for new ways to execute their designs without compromising quality. Suzanne Donnegan is among them. “There was really a void in the market for affordable bespoke jewelry,” says Donnegan, who, four years ago, introduced the minimalistic fine jewelry line Mannin. It features 18-karat solid gold monogrammable pendants, rings and cuff links — exquisite but very expensive expressions of quiet luxury. (Jennifer Aniston, Jessica Biel and Halle Berry are customers.) Enter Donnegan’s new Insignia collection: necklaces, rings, bracelets, earrings, cuff links and money clips, in all-silver and silver with 22-karat gold overlay for a sheen and weight that mimics, uncannily, their 18-karat solid gold counterparts. “New luxury should be about both high quality and accessibility,” Donnegan says. In other words, same dash, less cash. “The Insignia shopper is interested in collecting jewelry. She appreciates understated design details and loves owning pieces that reflect her personal identity.”

headline: Restrained Chronicler of Tumultuous Times

lead_paragraph: Unknown computer hackers claim they forced the world’s largest oil company, Saudi Aramco, to quarantine its oil production systems from infected PCs inside the company last week. They threatened to attack the company again this Saturday.
