lead_paragraph: Guillaume Canet’s “Little White Lies” delivers a two-and-a-half-hour scolding to so-called “bobos,” the term in France for affluent people who embrace a fusion of bourgeois and bohemian values. Although the word “bobo” has been used by David Brooks, a columnist for The New York Times, to describe “members of the new information elite,” in France it refers to overgrown Parisian yuppies in their 30s and 40s, like the group of bickering friends in “Little White Lies” who take a communal vacation every summer in Cap Ferrat.

headline: Broken Hearts and Breaking News
abstract: “The Newsroom” has had some harsh reviews, but now, with its season finale on Sunday, Aaron Sorkin’s sharp repartee is more evident.
lead_paragraph: The most recent episode of “The Newsroom” opened with a let’s-put-on-a-show moment — literally — as the idealistic producer of the fictional cable-news program at the heart of the series rallied her troops. Hoping to exploit the chaos of a power blackout to regain control of the newscast, she delivered a stem winder, beginning with, “A miracle happens — we become a team again,” and as it built you couldn’t help thinking: Here he goes again.

headline: Beyond the Luster of Mahogany
abstract: The historian Jennifer L. Anderson’s “Mahogany: The Costs of Luxury in Early America” explores the origins of some 18th-century furniture.
lead_paragraph: Mahogany for 18th-century furniture was harvested under appalling conditions across the Caribbean. Slaves branded with owners’ monograms lived in thatched huts and scouted for trees. They had to drag and roll felled mahogany trunks to riverfronts and then float the logs, which were chained together, to ships waiting in bays full of sharks and coral reefs.

headline: The Dual Powers of Woman, in Muted Force or Frenzied Abandon
abstract: A single woman dances both Dido and the Sorceress in the Mostly Mozart revival of Mark Morris’s version of “Dido and Aeneas.”
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Mark Morris has staged nothing more tragic than his 1989 version of Henry Purcell’s hourlong opera “Dido and Aeneas,” and nothing more fixated on the nexus of love, sex, destruction and death. For many people it is the greatest work Mr. Morris has ever made. What matters more, though, is that Mr. Morris has created a dazzling interpretation of Purcell’s superlative work. The more closely you follow it, the more packed its movement is with meanings; even though I have seen the work a number of times over the years, it keeps surprising me.

headline: Mog, an Online Music Service, Sells Its Ad Network for $10 Million
abstract: The buyer is Townsquare Media, which already owns 244 radio stations in small markets and a collection of music Web sites.
lead_paragraph: Last month, half of the digital music company Mog was sold to Beats Electronics, the company behind the popular Beats by Dr. Dre headphones. Now the other half, an advertising network for music Web sites, has been sold as well.

lead_paragraph: Dance

headline: Eurofile | Loving Ljubljana
abstract: Slovenia’s winsome capital city is home to some of Europe’s best and most original restaurants and several new boutique hotels.
lead_paragraph: Long before I’d actually visited one, I thought I knew what the ideal European town should look like. On snowy school-vacation afternoons in Westchester, N.Y., my grandmother would pull down from the shelves a beautifully illustrated German or English storybook she’d grown up with and suggest we get “cozy.” (This meant hot chocolate for my brother and me and a tumbler of sherry with rattling ice cubes for her.) In these Victorian volumes, there was always a castle on a mountain in the middle of the city, which would be cut in half by a swan-dotted river, and ham- or mustard-colored houses. Cobbled streets led to squares with four-spout stone fountains. Off-duty soldiers would be flirting with buxom barmaids, clergymen would be patting children on their heads (and not elsewhere), and housewives would be pinning hand-scrubbed sheets to lines run between old lilac bushes.

lead_paragraph: AS college students prepare for fall classes, some of their parents or grandparents will be studying up on the real estate markets near campus.

lead_paragraph: The Miser is away this week, so he’s left it to us to scrounge up a couple of free and fabulous things to do this weekend. Bonus: They both have great beats that you can dance to.

lead_paragraph: The Eastman Kodak Company outlined a plan on Thursday to sell its legacy film units and focus on commercial printing services, as part of its plan to emerge from bankruptcy protection.

headline: Taking Dance to the Air
abstract: Heather Hammond, who runs the Heliummm Aerial Dance and Entertainment company, teaches classes on aerial dance for various skill levels at gyms in Manhattan and Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: AFTER dancing on land and in the water, I was naturally ready for the next element. So I tried it in the air, which turned out to be no easy feat. It called on all the strength I could muster to stay aloft and keep gravity in check.

headline: Where Chocolate Lovers Can Play Willy Wonka
abstract: A Manhattan mother and her daughter share their passion for high-quality chocolate by making their own treats with the chocolatier Aditi Malhotra at Christian Vautier Le Concept on the Lower East Side.
lead_paragraph: AS the mother of an energetic and curious 4-year-old daughter, I’m constantly searching for activities to fill our weekends that go beyond the usual Central Park visit or Staten Island Ferry ride. While the plans I make might entertain my daughter, Meenakshi, they tend to leave me counting the minutes until we’re done. After all, I’m usually sitting on the side and watching as she takes a cooking class or another turn on a kiddie ride.

abstract: GOP monetary madness.

headline: Guano and Maya Glyphs Just Might Save the World
abstract: In “12.21” a doctor and a Maya scholar join forces to save the world from a sudden collapse, one foreshadowed by the puzzling demise of ancient Maya civilizations.
lead_paragraph: Dustin Thomason begins “12.21” with a prologue in which a mysterious ancient figure pricks his arm, draws blood and then begins writing what may become “the most valuable artifact in the history of Mesoamerican studies.” In the genre to which this book belongs — thrillers Dan Brown could write with a reanimated Michael Crichton, which, given the emphasis on weird science, is not out of the question — this is just the author’s way of saying hello.

headline: Mayor Offers Ideas for Why Homeless Numbers Are Up
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg responded to a question about a sharp rise in the number of homeless people in the city’s shelter system.
lead_paragraph: Asked about a sharp rise in the number of homeless people in New York City’s shelter system, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg suggested Thursday that people were staying in shelters longer in part because the shelters were “much more pleasurable” than they used to be, making people less eager to leave.

headline: Singing for Siri, and Others, With Humor
abstract: Raissa Katona Bennett brings new songs and standards to Feinstein’s at Loews Regency for her show there, “Another Kind of Light.”
lead_paragraph: As the singer Raissa Katona Bennett peeled away the layer of perky, ingratiating sweetness that so many Broadway performers feel obliged to affect in nightclubs, a tart-tongued commentator on modern life with a dark sense of humor revealed itself on Wednesday evening at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency. Her show, “Another Kind of Light,” directed by Eric Michael Gillett, had its sticky inspirational moments. But in its best numbers, Ms. Katona Bennett, who played Christine in “The Phantom of the Opera,” dropped the official facade of graciousness and sentimentality to voice a cheerful sense of the absurd.

headline: Around the World in 99 Minutes and Zero Words
abstract: Filmed in 25 countries and using striking images but no narration or dialogue, “Samsara” examines the state of the modern world.
lead_paragraph: Susan Sontag concluded her book “On Photography” with a plea for “an ecology of images,” an approach to making and reproducing photographs that would protect both the meaning of particular pictures and the integrity of the reality they depict. Since the 1970s, when the essays in Sontag’s book were written, the global glut of images has grown almost beyond measure. In the age of Instagram and Google Earth it is easy to believe — it is sometimes hard not to believe — that every inch of the planet, every human face and patch of wilderness, has been snapped up and uploaded. We have seen it all.

headline: Turbine Plans Hit Headwind
abstract: The Bayshore Regional Sewerage Authority has been ordered to seek zoning clarification for a planned wind turbine that would be close to many homes.
lead_paragraph: Union Beach

headline: New Houses Shed Excess Feet
abstract: In some new construction in Westchester and Putnam Counties, megamansions are being displaced by more eco-conscious houses.
lead_paragraph: BUILDERS in parts of Westchester and counties farther afield are finally venturing forth into the market once again — but steering well clear of the megamansions that were popular before the real estate market tanked.

headline: For a Buyer Who Has Everything
abstract: A windmill, a barn, a stagecoach tavern and a boathouse are among one-of-a-kind homes on the market.
lead_paragraph: THIRTY years ago, desiring more space than their Manhasset Tudor provided, Steve and Helene Kosoff bought a stable, an unfinished carriage house and two outbuildings on five acres of a subdivided Gatsby-era 65-acre estate in Matinecock known as Farnsworth.

headline: Debates Denied, Univision Turns to Candidate Forums
abstract: The Spanish language network said Thursday that it will broadcast separate “Meet the Candidate” forums with President Obama and Gov. Mitt Romney.
lead_paragraph: Univision’s request for an official presidential debate may have been rejected, but the Spanish language network has succeeded in securing both candidates’ attendance at “Meet the Candidate” forums, the network said late Thursday afternoon.

headline: ‘The Clubbiest Club in New York’
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The Harvard Club on West 44th Street is a holdout on what was once a block of clubs.
lead_paragraph: IN July the prim neo-Georgian Harvard Club of 1894, on 44th Street between Fifth and the Avenue of the Americas, lifted its veil of construction netting. Newly spruced up, it’s the oldest club on what was once a block of such institutions, including New York Yacht and Yale. Most of the clubs are gone, but Harvard expanded twice, and in 2003 built a controversial third addition that has only recently lost its novelty.

headline: Stand-Up Comedian’s Surrealistic Nightmares
abstract: In “Sleepwalk With Me,” a movie that the comic performer and writer Mike Birbiglia adapted from his one-man show, a slightly schlubby comedian takes his act on the road.
lead_paragraph: It takes a kind of crazy tenacity for an aspiring stand-up comedian to endure the grubby humiliations of life on the bottom rung of the professional ladder. Watching Matt Pandamiglio, the jocular, slightly schlubby alter ego of the comic performer and writer Mike Birbiglia, take his act on the road in “Sleepwalk With Me” is like observing an out-of-shape military recruit stumbling through the first week of boot camp. Survival depends less on talent than on having a thick enough skin to recover after every setback and still maintain a facade of genial equanimity.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: One-App Millionaires and 700 Questions
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Thursday’s selection includes what nine jurors will have to do in the technology trial of the decade, Facebook talking about its new apps and Google’s privacy violation task force.
lead_paragraph: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Africa and Elsewhere
abstract: Photographs from South Africa, Lebanon, Israel and Ethiopia.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from South Africa, Lebanon, Israel and Ethiopia.

headline: Accommodating a Three-Dog Lifestyle
abstract: Bonnie John and Gary Pelton needed an apartment in a building that would take three large dogs.
lead_paragraph: IN Pittsburgh, where they lived for nearly 30 years, Bonnie John and Gary Pelton acquired their first mastiff because they wanted a dog with a predictable temperament. “Mastiffs are typically very laid-back and very tolerant,” Ms. John said.

headline: The True Culprits of College Data Fudging
abstract: The author writes that universities are not the only ones responsible for falsifying their admissions data.
lead_paragraph: For this week’s installment of The Choice on India Ink, we have an essay about the malpractice of United States colleges and universities that misreport data to climb the college rankings charts. The author, Ben Murray, is an intern for The Choice and a student at New York University. — Tanya Abrams

headline: Should We Cancel the Election? (A Socratic Dialog)
keywords: ['Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Philosophy', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Socrates pays a visit to the author to argues that presidential elections are no better than a coin toss.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes I dream that I’m talking to Socrates. I’ve tried to talk philosophy with him, but he’s not interested. My guess is that he’s either figured everything out or decided there are no answers. But he does, oddly, have quite an interest in current events in the United States. So I asked him about the presidential election coming up in November.

headline: A French Shift on Africa Strips a Dictator’s Son of His Treasures
abstract: The seizure of a multimillion-dollar property owned by the son of the president of Equatorial Guinea underscores how France is changing its relationship with Africa.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For years, Teodoro Nguema Obiang Mangue seemed to lead a charmed life, visiting his five-story pied-à-terre here on the chic Avenue Foch two or three times a year, choosing among 11 supercars, ordering bottles of Romanée-Conti Burgundies and watching movies in his home cinema.

headline: Vermont: Inn Settles Bias Suit Involving Lesbian Pair
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Homosexuality', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Discrimination', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: A resort in Lyndonville on Thursday settled a lawsuit accusing it of discriminating against a lesbian couple when its owners declined to host their wedding reception.
lead_paragraph: A resort in Lyndonville on Thursday settled a lawsuit accusing it of discriminating against a lesbian couple when its owners declined to host their wedding reception. The lawsuit, filed by the American Civil Liberties Union, claimed that the Wildflower Inn violated that state’s Fair Housing and Public Accommodations Act when a representative said the inn would not host the wedding reception of Kate and Ming Linsley because of the owners’ “personal feelings.” The resort will pay $10,000 to the Vermont Human Rights Commission, a co-plaintiff in the case, and $20,000 to a charitable trust that the couple will disburse.

headline: Colorado: Campus Had Barred Massacre Suspect
abstract: James E. Holmes, who has been charged with killing 12 people in a July 20 shooting spree, had been barred from the campus of the University of Colorado Denver after making threats.
lead_paragraph: James E. Holmes, the former graduate student charged with killing 12 people in a July 20 shooting spree inside a movie theater, had been barred from the campus of the University of Colorado Denver after making threats in June, prosecutors said Thursday in a court hearing. They did not give details about the threats during the hearing, in which they sparred with the defense over whether the prosecution should have access to Mr. Holmes’s school records. They confirmed published reports that university officials had reported concerns about Mr. Holmes to the police, and said that he had also performed poorly on oral exams that capped his first year at the university. Mr. Holmes was dropping out of the neuroscience program in the month before the shooting.

headline: A Fresh Look at the Difference Between Climate Trends and Variations
abstract: A fresh visual explainer reveals the weak spot in assertions that global warming has stopped.
lead_paragraph: For awhile I’ve been wanting to draw attention to this visual deconstruction of the “global warming has stopped” meme often used by people whose profession or worldview makes them apt to reject science pointing to a greenhouse-heated climate:

headline: From War Casualty to Zombie, and Happy to Be Undead
abstract: In “The Revenant” a good-hearted soldier dies, becomes a zombie, and realizes he needs infusions of human blood to remain undead.
lead_paragraph: A middling zombie movie elevated by clever writing and gooeylicious special effects, Kerry Prior’s “Revenant” toys with big themes but settles for uneasy laughs. Even so, when you consider that most American horror-comedies are about as funny as rotting flesh, this small sleeper delivers a surprising number of pleasingly putrid punch lines.

headline: Identities and Lives Rooted in Two Worlds
abstract: The documentary “Somewhere Between” examines the lives of four teenage girls adopted from China and the policies that allowed that personal and cultural journey.
lead_paragraph: Shining a relentlessly rosy light on international adoption and the policies that enable it, “Somewhere Between” presents an effortlessly moving but superficial profile of four bright Chinese girls and their adoptive American families.

headline: The Most Pampering, the Highest Fees
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: For those willing to put down millions to own an apartment in Manhattan, a high tolerance for some of the highest monthly charges in the world is almost a prerequisite.
lead_paragraph: AFTER paying $15.5 million last November for a 3,000-square-foot apartment at the Carlyle, you would think the Hollywood power broker Brad Grey could rest easy knowing he had bought into a hot Manhattan luxury market.

headline: Nepal: Protest Shuts an Airport
abstract: Residents of Pokhara, the most popular holiday resort town in Nepal, have forced an indefinite airport shutdown with a hunger strike that began Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Residents of Pokhara, the most popular holiday resort town in Nepal, forced an airport shutdown with a hunger strike on Thursday. The people carrying out the strike are demanding that officials start construction on a proposed international airport that would presumably increase tourism revenue, according to one person in the industry. The Himalayan, a news organization, said the hunger strikers had vowed to shut down the domestic airport indefinitely.

headline: The Caucus Click: Waiting for Akin
abstract: Rebecca Kiessling, an anti-abortion speaker, and the Rev. Robert A. Sirico, president of the Acton Institute, waited for an address by Representative Todd Akin in Tampa, Fla.

headline: China Pressed to Prevent  Abuse of Psychiatric Confinement
keywords: ['CHINA', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: While there is virtually no public debate in China on the fate of dissidents in the country’s psychiatric system, involuntary commitment of non-dissidents by family members and others has become a hot topic.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In February 2011, Chen Guoming, 45, a jewelry store owner in southern China’s Fujian Province, was drugged by his wife, tied up with tape and taken to a psychiatric hospital where he was committed as mentally ill.

headline: Casting Blame for Jobs That Vanish
abstract: “Death by China,” a documentary by Peter Navarro, says the admission of China to the World Trade Organization has been catastrophic for the American economy.
lead_paragraph: By the end of the alarming and alarmist “Death by China” you may be asking why candidates for public office in this election year are talking about anything other than how to stop the Chinese from wrecking our economy.

headline: Australia Increases Refugee Quota
abstract: Prime Minister Julia Gillard ordered an immediate increase on Thursday in the number of refugees that Australia accepts yearly.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Julia Gillard ordered an immediate increase on Thursday in the number of refugees that Australia accepts yearly, part of an immigration reform package aimed at encouraging migrants to use official channels for asylum rather than long and dangerous boat journeys. The increase in the annual refugee intake — to 20,000 from 13,700, the biggest increase in 30 years — capped two weeks of debate that led Ms. Gillard’s governing Labor Party to reverse its longstanding opposition to reopening remote offshore detention centers. Those were closed in 2007.

headline: Wayward Women, Menacing Men and a Cabin in the Woods
abstract: A good-time romp in the great outdoors goes very wrong in “The Victim.”
lead_paragraph: Whenever anyone in a movie announces a desire for a quiet life, we know what follows will be anything but. And so it proves for Kyle (Michael Biehn), the inscrutable hero of “The Victim,” who arrives at an isolated woodland cabin anticipating nothing more taxing than pep talks from his online spiritual adviser. Too bad he didn’t choose a location less plagued by half-dressed, imperiled strippers.

headline: Republican Voters Could Sit Out Missouri Senate Race
abstract: Two polls of the Missouri Senate race since Representative Todd Akin’s remarks about rape showed a large number of Republicans who were not willing to declare their support for him or Claire McCaskill.
lead_paragraph: So far, we’ve had two polls of the Missouri Senate race since Representative Todd Akin made his remarks about rape on Sunday. The first survey, conducted by Public Policy Polling on Monday night, had Mr. Akin holding onto a one-point advantage in the race. But a second poll, conducted Wednesday night by Rasmussen Reports, had his opponent, the Democratic incumbent Claire McCaskill, up by 10 percentage points instead.

headline: Novice Knights: Now, What Was That Quest?
abstract: In “Knight Knight” a pair of dim knights try to rescue an imprisoned princess, unfurling many droll anachronisms and comic observations on the medieval era in the process.
lead_paragraph: The castles look terrific in Christina Bucher’s “Knight Knight,” as do the costumes and the British sunlight. And certainly the actors deliver in this light satire of the Middle Ages, in which two dim knights of the post-Arthur period, Gilbert (David Wayman) and Edgar (Tom Eykelhof), attempt to rescue the hardheaded Princess Katrina (Ms. Bucher), a prisoner of the portly, blustery King Vince (Nick von Schlippe). The script, by Nicholas Horwood, is packed with droll anachronisms and comic observations on the medieval era, as well as amusing twists: Each hero successfully escapes the castle, only to have to return. When Edgar proposes to Rachael (Claira Watson Parr), half-sister of Katrina, she replies: “What? God, no. I mean, sorry, I’ve got a boyfriend.”

headline: Attacks on Afghan Troops by Colleagues Are Rising, Allies Say
abstract: Afghan soldiers or police officers have killed 53 of their comrades and wounded at least 22 others in 35 separate attacks this year, according to NATO data.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Even as attacks by Afghan security forces on NATO troops have become an increasing source of tension, new NATO data shows another sign of vulnerability for the training mission: even greater numbers of the Afghan police and military forces have killed each other this year.

headline: The Ampersand as Crate & Barrel’s Vital Link
abstract: The brand’s logo style is the anchor for its new advertising campaign.
lead_paragraph: COMMERCIALS that are the centerpiece of a coming campaign for a major retailer of home furnishings may raise eyebrows. They show neither homes nor furnishings, nor the people who live in homes or buy furnishings.

headline: Crate & Barrel Commercial
abstract: A campaign for the Crate & Barrel retail chain, scheduled to begin on Sept. 10, shows neither homes nor furnishings, nor the people who live in homes or buy furnishings.
lead_paragraph: A campaign for the Crate & Barrel retail chain, scheduled to begin on Sept. 10, shows neither homes nor furnishings, nor the people who live in homes or buy furnishings.

headline: City Sets Up a Corporation to Oversee Its Tech Projects
abstract: Embarrassed by previous efforts to computerize New York City’s services, the Bloomberg administration has decided to outsource such jobs to a quasi-governmental contractor.
lead_paragraph: Scalded by scandal, cost overruns and embarrassments in some of its most ambitious computerization efforts, the Bloomberg administration has hit upon on a new remedy: outsourcing such projects to a new quasi-governmental entity that will operate free of the usual city procurement rules, salary limits and legislative oversight.

headline: From the Slums to the Soccer Field, 2 Boys Grasp at Hope
abstract: In “Hermano” soccer represents a ticket out of the slums for two talented Venezuelan boys.
lead_paragraph: “Hermano,” the heartfelt first feature from the Venezuelan filmmaker Marcel Rasquin, follows two soccer-playing boys whose striking talents offer escape from the slums of Caracas.

headline: Latinos Who Invested Savings Claim Betrayal in Ponzi Scheme
abstract: A number of law enforcement agencies are investigating the complaints of some 400 investors who say they were taken in by Inversionistas Unidos and its two charismatic Latin American principals.
lead_paragraph: Before Ruben Loja decided to invest in the fruit and vegetable importing business that had Latinos in pockets of Queens buzzing over the sizable checks paid every month, he visited its warehouse in the Bronx.

headline: Abortion and Akin Were Off Limits During Romney Interview, Reporter Says
abstract: A television reporter in Denver said she was told she could not ask questions about abortion or Representative Todd Akin’s comments about rape and abortion during an interview with Mitt Romney.
lead_paragraph: It’s the sort of statement that leaves journalists slack-jawed: “The one stipulation to the interview was that I not ask him about abortion or Todd Akin.”

headline: Taming of the Steed
abstract: “Wild Horse Wild Ride” is a documentary about the Extreme Mustang Makeover, a competition that assigns 100 trainers 100 wild mustangs to tame in 100 days.
lead_paragraph: “If you’re a true horseman, this is as good as it gets,” a trainer says at the outset of “Wild Horse Wild Ride,” a documentary about the Extreme Mustang Makeover challenge. This annual competition assigns 100 trainers 100 mustangs that had been rounded up in federal sweeps of public lands. Each trainer has 100 days to tame it before a two-day event in Fort Worth showcases the horses’ abilities and obedience. After a champion team is chosen, the horses are auctioned the next day, presumably to head to better lives.

headline: Lessons in Life, Love and Tennis
abstract: In “General Education” a teenager has landed a college tennis scholarship, but first he needs to graduate from high school after flunking a course, without Mom and Dad finding out.
lead_paragraph: Among the problems with the humorless comedy “General Education” is that the lead character’s sister is more interesting than he is, and she spends much of her screen time as a mute mime.

headline: A Creative Fold
abstract: Taro’s Origami Studio in Park Slope, Brooklyn, guides the young and old through the Japanese craft of paper folding.
lead_paragraph: Taro’s Origami Studio in Park Slope, Brooklyn, guides the young and old through the Japanese craft of paper folding.

headline: Call to Stiffen Laws Worries Town Built by Guns
abstract: Two recent mass shootings have galvanized advocates of tougher gun laws in Albany, and Remington has made it clear that such laws could prompt it to leave New York for a more sympathetic state.
lead_paragraph: ILION, N.Y. — This is the town that Remington built.

headline: In Effort to Curb Money Market Funds, a Plan B Is Considered
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Money Market Accounts', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Government regulators are considering invoking powers that were granted by the Dodd-Frank law to improve oversight of the money market fund industry.
lead_paragraph: After the failure of one effort to overhaul a major part of the mutual fund industry, top government officials worked on Thursday to find alternative ways to rein in what they see as a systemic threat to the financial system.

headline: Why China Resents Japan, and Us
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Chinese rage is primarily aimed at Japan — but it is also directed at the United States.
lead_paragraph: Norman, Okla.

headline: Is Private School Not Expensive Enough?
abstract: Private schools need a new pricing model. Affluent families must donate, as much as they are able, to make up the difference between tuition and the school’s real, per-student cost of operation.
lead_paragraph: ANY parent of a private-school child will tell you that tuitions are painfully high — and getting worse every year. Many New York City schools are approaching the $40,000 mark. And it’s not just New York: charges at many private secondary boarding schools are now touching $50,000. Outrageous, many say.

headline: The Medieval Roots of Todd Akin’s Theories
abstract: The beliefs about pregnancy held by Representative Todd Akin are obviously at odds with modern science. However, they are in step with medieval science.
lead_paragraph: Middletown, Conn.

headline: Season Tickets for Knicks and Rangers Are Nearly Sold Out
abstract: More than 95 percent of Knicks season-ticket holders have renewed their plans during the off-season, while more than 90 percent of Rangers season-ticket holders have already done so, according to the teams.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks and the Rangers are on pace to sell out nearly all their available season tickets for this season after both teams qualified for the playoffs for the second straight year.

headline: Export Powerhouse Feels Pangs of Labor Strife
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Series', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: As Bangladesh garment workers have seen their meager earnings eroded by double-digit inflation, protests and violent clashes with the police have become increasingly common.
lead_paragraph: ISHWARDI, Bangladesh — The air thickened with tear gas as police and paramilitary officers jogged into the Ishwardi Export Processing Zone firing rubber bullets and swinging cane poles. lead_paragraph: My 13-year-old son Jonah and his new best friend, Sebastian, were in the pool the other day, armed with Styrofoam water guns, when things escalated. I wasn’t there, but my wife, Cynthia, told me the story later. It seems Jonah was getting the worst of the shootout and after a while Sebastian’s mother suggested her son go easy. He didn’t. I’m guessing the fact that Jonah found the whole thing hilarious played a part in his friend persisting. But Sebastian also had another, more big-hearted reason for drenching my son.

headline: Why Does Anyone Root for Incompetent, Failing Teams?

I was living 30 miles north of Foxboro Stadium, and I can still remember the color of the sky that morning, the dense gunmetal of a looming storm. By late afternoon, snow was falling at an almost comical rate. It blotted out the yard markers and hampered traction, which lent the game a surreal, slapstick air.

headline: Impatience Takes a Number
abstract: The line jumper; the phantom tollbooth.
lead_paragraph: Returning my cable box at the Time Warner store, I arrived to find 30 people ahead of me in line. Begrudgingly, I took a number (as you do at the deli counter) and waited. A woman turned around and told me she could no longer stay. She offered me her ticket, five numbers away from being called. At first I said no — it wouldn’t be fair to everyone else who was waiting — but she insisted. I took her ticket, returned my cable box and walked out of the store while everyone else kept waiting. Was it right to take the ticket? ALEXANDRA, NEW YORK CITY

But unlike most actresses Ms. McCarthy has a day job that involves keeping her peers united, inspired and working. She is the brains behind Gorgeous Ladies of Comedy, or GLOC. It began as a blog just under two years ago and, under Ms. McCarthy’s tireless hand, has bloomed into an informal society of New York’s brightest comediennes. Kristen Schaal, of “30 Rock” and “The Daily Show,” the actress Kristen Johnston and the stand-up star Tig Notaro have all performed at its events or lent advice on the blog.

headline: ‘The Road to Serfdom,’ the Graphic Version

Ryan has cited Hayek’s seminal work, “The Road to Serfdom,” which was published during World War II, as a major influence on his own thinking. (He also lists it, along with Ayn Rand’s “Atlas Shrugged,” as a favorite book on his Facebook page.)

A survey of the major markets of the world indicates that North America was the best place to be for investors who chose to ride out the credit crisis, while the euro zone was clearly the worst.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Color Me Better
abstract: The usual enticement for “deluxe” editions is behind-the-scenes features. In this area, the color edition of “Scott Pilgrim” does not disappoint.
lead_paragraph: At No. 2 on the hardcover list this week is Volume 1 of the color edition of “Scott Pilgrim,” by Bryan Lee O’Malley. The original softcover version of the series was a regular presence on our sales chart in 2010 as fans counted down the days until the release of the film version starring Michael Cera. (The movie criminally underperformed at the box office.) In August of that year, the six volumes were in the top seven of the paperback list.

headline: Scandinavia on $125 a Day
abstract: How to be frugal in a region where a fast-food meal for one goes for $23? Six lessons learned the hard way.
lead_paragraph: IT was my first full day in Oslo and I thought that I had found a rare bargain: a six-pack of Carlsberg beer for under $5 (or 27.40 Norwegian kroner) at the Kiwi Minipris supermarket! Even for a mass-produced pilsner, it was a surprising deal for Norway, where just about everything costs more than you’d expect. And by more, I don’t mean by increments of 10 or 15 percent, but by multiples of two or three or four.

headline: Herding Sheep in Basque Country (Idaho)
abstract: Once, there were hundreds, if not thousands of Basque sheepmen in the American West. Meet one of the few who remain.
lead_paragraph: SHEEP, you may be surprised to learn, are not as dumb as they look. Some people might even describe them as shrewdly calculating, remarkably crafty animals with fierce independent streaks. Given the slightest opening, for example, they will quit a herd, striking out in small, enterprising bands for the high-desert plains — ungulate fugitives in a promised land of sagebrush and cactus — sometimes never to be seen again.

lead_paragraph: WHEN making his rounds as a traveling salesman for a Chicago printing company, Duncan Hines would occasionally pull off the Dixie Highway in Corbin, Ky., and eat at Sanders Cafe. In the 1939 edition of “Adventures in Good Eating,” his pioneering restaurant guide, he recommended the cafe and its adjoining motor court as “very good place to stop en route to Cumberland Falls and the Great Smokies,” highlighting its “sizzling steaks, fried chicken, country ham, hot biscuits.”

headline: Uncovering the Secrets of Fukuoka
abstract: Its shopping earned it the nickname “Retail City.” Its ramen might be the best in Japan. And its food carts are a breed apart. So why haven’t more tourists discovered it?
lead_paragraph: THE crowd at Akatan, a narrow, standing bar in the southern Japanese city of Fukuoka, thickened as each glass of sake and shochu was poured. By midnight, strangers had swept my husband, Dave, and me — the only Western faces in the smoky bar — into alcohol-fueled conversations that, with the language barrier, often devolved into comical pantomime. Every time we explained that we were visiting Fukuoka as tourists, the same question arose: “But why?”

headline: Sleepwalk to Work
abstract: New York is a place of innumerable home businesses. Chances are there’s one in the next apartment.
lead_paragraph: IT took a while for Athanasios Biros to solve the mystery of his noisy upstairs neighbor. Mr. Biros, 35, who works for a bank, at first suspected a bartender with odd working hours lived above his studio in Greenwich Village. Then he heard a pounding noise at 7 in the morning. “I just snapped,” he said. He knocked on the door, and met his neighbors, an Eastern European family with a child. The mother promised to stop the child from crisscrossing the paper-thin floors.

headline: Creativity Sprouts on a St. Petersburg Island
abstract: Created by Peter the Great but closed to the public until last summer, New Holland now draws visitors for everything from art to table tennis to a novel library.
lead_paragraph: SHELTERED by a wall covered in colorful murals that depicted a horror-fairy tale with a happy ending, a Russian friend and I sat back in lawn chairs and sipped cappuccinos. To our left was a still pool once used for submarine testing. Behind it stood large, shuttered, morbidly charming brick warehouses. “It’s amazing!” said my friend as he pointed at the row of buildings across the canal, in the midst of St. Petersburg. “All those years, you couldn’t come in here. Now it’s open, and you have a completely new view of the city.”

headline: Miniseries Treatment in Works for ‘Wolf Hall’ and ‘Bring Up the Bodies’

lead_paragraph: A six-hour adaptation of two of Hilary Mantel’s novels, “Wolf Hall” and its sequel, “Bring Up the Bodies,” will come to television in late 2013, BBC Two has announced. “Wolf Hall,” a historical novel set during the reign of King Henry VIII, won the Man Booker Prize for Fiction in 2009. Peter Straughan, who wrote the screenplay for the 2011 movie version of “Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy,” will adapt the Mantel novels for television.

lead_paragraph: IN the spring of 1970 Rudolf Serkin announced that he would play the 32 Beethoven piano sonatas in a series of eight recitals at Carnegie Hall during the 1970-71 season to commemorate the 200th anniversary of Beethoven’s birth. Then nearly 67, Serkin was a pre-eminent Beethoven interpreter. Yet he had never played a complete Beethoven sonata cycle.

Mowbray in 1908, sold under the radar for $21 million, the biggest sale of the week according to city records.

headline: Aug. 26 — Sept. 1
abstract: A selection of events.
lead_paragraph: THE novelist Ian Fleming was not pleased when he learned that his greatest creation, James Bond, was played by Sean Connery in “Dr. No,” the first in the film series. “I’m looking for Cmdr. James Bond,” he said, “not an overgrown stuntman.” Moviegoers disagreed, and Fleming later came to his senses. Now, in honor of the franchise’s 50th anniversary, the complete Connery Bonds (including “Never Say Never Again,” from 1983), will be screened in IFC’s aptly named program JAMES BOND NO. 1: SEAN CONNERY’S 007, starting Friday (with an all-day, seven-film Bond-a-thon next Sunday.)

headline: Auto Insurance, Scaredy-Cats and the Rollers of the Dice
abstract: How do our feelings about risk affect our decisions about how much auto insurance to buy?
lead_paragraph: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I try to lay out the facts and odds that lay behind the question of whether any of us have enough auto insurance. Some people look at the long odds of a bad wreck and buy the minimum amount that their state requires. Others buy as much as they can, figuring that it’s better to be safe than to be sorry.

headline: In Euro Crisis, Fingers Can Point in All Directions

headline: Counter Intuitive | Chez Aline in Paris
abstract: A young chef serves up old-school Parisian fare in a former butcher shop.
lead_paragraph: It was happenstance that the young chef Delphine Zampetti came to open the tiny Parisian eatery Chez Aline. Last May, Zampetti, who has worked at Café Caché and Le Verre Volé, was walking down Rue de la Roquette in the 11th Arrondissement when she noticed a butcher shop with a charmingly retro vibe. The next week, she passed the shop again, only this time there was a “for sale” sign in the window. It was “une petite idée, just like that,” she muses. And then she went for it.

headline: Will Emissions Disclosure Mean Investor Pressure on Polluters?
abstract: A new financial tool is aimed at encouraging greater disclosure about greenhouse gas emissions from companies while, hopefully, also pushing investors to build more responsible portfolios.
lead_paragraph: A new financial tool developed by the investment firm South Pole Carbon, in partnership with the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, provides greenhouse gas emissions profiles of more than 40,000 publicly listed companies. This index is aimed at encouraging greater disclosure from companies while, hopefully, also pushing investors to build more responsible portfolios.

headline: ‘Quadrophenia,’ Still a Flash Point for the Mods
abstract: The Blu-ray and DVD reissue of “Quadrophenia,” the film based on the Who rock opera, is part of a continued interest in the Mod culture and fashions the film revealed.
lead_paragraph: MANY years after filming the climax to the 1979 film “Quadrophenia” in Brighton, England, the director Franc Roddam found himself back there for a screening. Though the town had long been famous as a beachfront resort, Mr. Roddam’s film adaptation of the Who’s rock opera has drawn fans there as well, particularly for its depiction of a 1964 gathering of the futurist Mods, which ended in a clash with their sworn enemies, the backward-gazing, leather-clad Rockers. Most notoriously, he denounced its cheap sentiment in an interview with Reader’s Digest and called the second season “atrocious,” preceded by an adverb that cannot be written here.

headline: France: Remarks Cost Designer Award
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Discrimination']
abstract: President François Hollande of France has stripped John Galliano, the fashion designer convicted last year of making anti-Semitic remarks, of the Légion d’Honneur that he was awarded in 2009.
lead_paragraph: President François Hollande of France has stripped John Galliano, the fashion designer convicted last year of making anti-Semitic remarks, of the Légion d’Honneur that he was awarded in 2009. Mr. Galliano, 51, who was made a chevalier of the Légion d’Honneur by former President Nicolas Sarkozy, was involved in two drunken episodes in a small Paris bar and restaurant. His anti-Semitic remarks, some of them caught on an amateur video, led to his conviction last year on charges of “public insults based on origin, religious affiliation, race or ethnicity.” In February 2011, Mr. Galliano harangued a museum curator about being Jewish and uttered racial insults at her friend, who is of South Asian origin. The court also saw a video of Mr. Galliano, the previous November, declaring his love for Adolf Hitler. Mr. Hollande, elected in May, has been outspoken in condemning anti-Semitism and crimes against Jews committed by the French police under Nazi occupation.

abstract: Talks between the two rental car leaders are expected to continue through the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Hertz Global Holdings is near a deal to acquire the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group for nearly $2.5 billion, according to a person briefed on the transaction, ending a fierce and protracted merger battle among the nation’s largest car rental companies.

headline: As Tough as His Task
abstract: Long before Bill O’Brien chose to lead the rebuilding of Penn State football, he had already been dealt a far greater challenge.
lead_paragraph: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — Every morning, Bill and Colleen O’Brien know their older son, 10-year-old Jack, will have a seizure when he wakes up. It could last 30 seconds or go on for 30 minutes, necessitating an ambulance trip to the hospital. There may be more seizures during the day, depending on disparate factors like weather patterns and Jack’s growth spurts. And when they happen, the O’Briens can do little except to turn their son on his side and wait for the seizure to end.

headline: Tennis, of Course, and Ladybugs
abstract: Patrick McEnroe, the former tennis pro, goes to church, plays with his three girls in the park and has become an avid collector of ladybugs.
lead_paragraph: Patrick McEnroe, 46, ESPN’s affably enlightening tennis commentator, will host and call matches at the United States Open, which starts Monday at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Flushing, Queens. He also works at the site year-round, as the general manager of player development for the United States Tennis Association. Mr. McEnroe retired from professional tennis in 1998, though he and his older brother John won the over-45 legends doubles tournament at the French Open this year. He and his wife, the actress-singer  Melissa Errico, live in SoHo with their three daughters, Victoria, 6, and the twins Diana and Juliette, 3 ½. Sundays are family time, either in the city or at the house they rent in Sag Harbor, N.Y., in summer.

headline: Wilson Shines for Giants’ Offense, but Amukamara Sustains Ankle Injury
abstract: David Wilson totaled 75 yards and showed explosiveness with the ball, and Prince Amukamara sustained a high-ankle sprain in the first quarter.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — With 12 days until the regular-season opener, the Giants entered their third preseason game with significant expectations for two young players. David Wilson, the first-round pick, is pushing to become a critical part of the running game, and Prince Amukamara, the first-round draft pick in 2011, had been trying to fit in as a de facto starting cornerback.

headline: Local Stop: Sutton Place
abstract: The quiet neighborhood of Sutton Place runs along the East River from 53rd to 59th Street.
lead_paragraph: The quiet neighborhood of Sutton Place runs along the East River from 53rd to 59th Street.

headline: Parks, Privacy and River Views
abstract: Sutton Place is a stately, if staid, enclave on the East Side, the sort of place where the butcher shop still delivers.
lead_paragraph: Sutton Place is both a grand old residential avenue (originally known as “Avenue A”), running alongside the East River from 53rd to 59th Street, and a serviceable neighborhood extending west to Second Avenue. At the river’s edge, the cross streets end in little vest-pocket parks with wide views of boats navigating the river’s treacherous currents, of Roosevelt Island’s Southpoint Park and of the monumental Queensboro and Williamsburg Bridges. Like many of its residents, Sutton Place is sedate and well maintained. Once here, people and businesses tend to stay put. “Whenever people talk about assisted living, I say, ‘No way, I’d rather live in Sutton Place!’ ” said Vera Mayer, who moved there from Riverdale, in the Bronx, 38 years ago. “There’s the privacy of Sutton Place, and then you walk over one block and you have everything you need.”

headline: Knicks’ Anthony Optimistic After Olympics
abstract: A successful off-season, including an Olympic gold medal, has the veteran Carmelo Anthony excited for the Knicks’ training camp.
lead_paragraph: This off-season has been a success for Carmelo Anthony. He won his second Olympic gold medal for the United States in London, where he averaged 16.3 points and set a single-game American Olympic scoring record with 37 points against Nigeria.

headline: Seeking Brooklyn’s Lost Mass Grave
keywords: ['Revolutionary War, American (1775-83)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Cemeteries']
abstract: A Revolutionary War historian says he believes that the mass grave of the First Maryland Regiment lies under a vacant lot in Gowanus, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: NOTHING is visible at the intersection of Third Avenue and Eighth Street in the Gowanus section of Brooklyn to indicate that anything extraordinary is there. The artisanal-pie place on one corner and the auto body shops across the way suggest it is merely another spot in the city where grit is giving way to gentrification. But if a small group of history enthusiasts are right, this particular corner of Kings County is hallowed ground.

headline: Calling All Refugee Kids
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Equal Educational Opportunities', 'Children and Childhood']

lead_paragraph: The Refugee Youth Summer Academy in Manhattan helps immigrant children and their families find their footing in the United States.

headline: At Colorado Race, Mixed Reaction on Armstrong
abstract: Cycling fans at the USA Pro Challenge did not allow the Lance Armstrong scandal to diminish their enthusiasm for a sport riddled for years by doping.
lead_paragraph: BRECKENRIDGE, Colo. — Cycling fans who gathered for the start of Friday’s Stage 5 of the USA Pro Challenge did not allow the Lance Armstrong scandal to diminish their enthusiasm for a sport riddled for years by doping controversy. But some were deeply worried for young competitive riders facing tough choices.

headline: Newest Young Immigrants Get a Head Start on School
abstract: The Refugee Youth Summer Academy program helps dozens of recently arrived children, many from families of refugees, prepare to enter the school system.
lead_paragraph: The Refugee Youth Summer Academy program helps dozens of recently arrived children, many from families of refugees, prepare to enter the school system.

headline: India’s Paralyzed Parliament
abstract: India’s lawmakers have never been considered industrious, but productivity has reached a new low.
lead_paragraph: These days, the Indian legislators have settled into a routine: At 11 a.m., members of the upper and lower houses gather at the Parliament House. Immediately, the opposition members walk to the well of the house, shouting, “Nahi chalegi, nahi chalegi” (“will not function, will not function”) and “Manmohan Singh gaddi choro!” (“Manmohan Singh, leave the chair”). The helpless speaker repeatedly tells the members, “Kripya baith jaieye” (“Please sit down”), but no one listens. After few minutes, the session is adjourned.

headline: In New York, With 6 Weeks to Adapt to America
keywords: ['Summer School', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: The Refugee Youth Summer Academy tries to help recently arrived children to find a footing in their new country and prepares them for school.
lead_paragraph: TWENTY-FOUR days after he arrived in the United States, Mamadou Fadja Diallo, 13, showed up for summer school in Manhattan looking wary and confused. The building itself was disorienting: big and imposing, with polished floors, nothing like his school back home in Guinea. He was surrounded by students from all over the world. He could not understand a word anyone was saying.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: Regional news from India.
lead_paragraph: Jammu and Kashmir: A mob set fire to a police vehicle and beat up three police officers in Srinagar after prayers on Monday during the Muslim celebration of Id al-Fitr, Kashmir Live  reported.

headline: Blunting Ideology With Biography
abstract: The ascension of Wendy Long, the Republican candidate for Senate, suggests a continuing interest among conservatives in cultivating candidates with attributes that could blunt the impact of unpalatable social ideologies.
lead_paragraph: Unless you’ve subjected yourself to an Internet blackout to better commune with the natural pleasures of summer, chances are you’ve heard something about Mindy Meyer, the 22-year-old New York State Senate contestant, who, when asked about Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo in an interview, said she was “not familiar with him in particular, like his issues, and you know, everything about him.” A Brooklynite who would appear to find her intellectual stimulation in caricatures of celebrity vapidity, she has sought the endorsement of Kim Kardashian.

headline: Wages in Bangladesh Far Below India
abstract: Low wages helped the country pull ahead of India in garment exports.
lead_paragraph: India’s neighbor Bangladesh has become the second-largest apparel exporter in the world, after China, Jim Yardley  reports, but labor unrest is growing as workers demand higher wages.

headline: Remembering Steve Van Buren,  Hall of Famer for Eagles
abstract: Running back Steve Van Buren led the Philadelphia Eagles to three straight Eastern Division titles and their first two N.F.L. championships.
lead_paragraph: Steve Van Buren led the Philadelphia Eagles to three straight Eastern Division titles and their first two N.F.L. championships, in 1948 and 1949. He retired as the leading rusher in league history. Van Buren died on Thursday in Lancaster, Pa., of pneumonia. He was 91. A few thoughts:

headline: The Weekend Word: Crisis Management
abstract: Political news from today’s Times and around the Web, plus a look at the president’s weekly address.
lead_paragraph: Today’s Times• A 1968 car crash in France and the 1998 diagnosis of Ann Romney’s multiple sclerosis were dark moments in what has otherwise seemed a charmed existence for Mitt Romney, Sheryl Gay Stolberg writes. Both offer clues into the Republican nominee’s character and the way he reacts to challenges.

headline: Working Out With the Women of Hong Kong
abstract: Each morning in Hong Kong, elderly residents spill into parks, beaches and mountain trails for predawn workouts. The fitness culture here is particularly impressive among women, who by some measures live longer than anywhere else in the world.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG—Hong Kong is muggy and mountainous, but that isn’t slowing down the city’s senior citizens.

headline: Las Vegas and the Prince Harry Effect
abstract: British media said Prince Harry was headed for a dressing-down from his father this weekend over his Las Vegas antics. The Nevada resort city was meanwhile looking forward to an unexpected boost.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As British newspapers continued to harrumph about Prince Harry’s naked antics in Las Vegas, the scandal surrounding the third-in-line to the throne appeared to have done little to chill their readers’ enthusiasm for visiting Sin City.

headline: The End of the Line
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2000', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Despite assumptions in the past that the Gore name would persist in politics, members of the family seem to have left that world behind to pursue very different lives.
lead_paragraph: AL GORE lives alone now, in a 10,000-square-foot colonial in Nashville, where magnolia trees shade the house and geothermal wells, buried beneath the driveway, cool and heat its 20 rooms.

headline: Pakistani Militant Leader Dies in Airstrike, NATO Says
abstract: The death of the Taliban commander, Mullah Dadullah, is expected to have an impact on the fighting in Bajaur, where the Pakistani Army has been battling the local Taliban since 2008.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — NATO forces said on Saturday that they had killed a senior Pakistani Taliban commander in an airstrike in Afghanistan, highlighting the increasingly complicated nature of the fight against Islamist militants along the border between Afghanistan and Pakistan.

headline: At Least 39 Killed in Blast at Refinery in Venezuela
abstract: Balls of fire rose over the Amuay refinery, one of the largest in the world, in video posted online. At least 53 were wounded in the explosion, which was blamed on a gas leak.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — At least 39 people were killed on Saturday and dozens more were injured in a giant explosion that set off a raging fire at Venezuela’s largest oil refinery, according to officials who rushed to the scene on the Paraguaná Peninsula.

headline: Eight Fantasy Football Sleepers in 2012
abstract: There really aren’t true sleepers anymore, but rather players who are simply undervalued by the general public.
lead_paragraph: The term sleeper in fantasy football has changed over the last decade. Years ago, you could find great value with a rookie running back that no one knew about. Now, that player is going in the eighth round and every fantasy owner in your league knows his 40-yard dash time, vertical leap, college yards-per-carry and mother’s maiden name.

headline: Inflation Lessons
abstract: And the politicians who reject them.
lead_paragraph: One of the themes I’ve hit on many times is the fact that the crisis and slump have been a testing ground for economic doctrines. People came into this mess with very different views about how the economy works, and the crisis in effect provided natural experiments that tested those views.

headline: College Football Preview: Overlooked, but They Shouldn’t Be
abstract: Players flying under the radar in college football.
lead_paragraph: STAR LOTULELEI, UTAH, DTLotulelei, a senior, demands double teams, collapses the pocket, clogs running lanes and tears up game plans.

headline: Union Leader Works On Despite Brain Tumor
abstract: Michael Weiner, the union’s executive director who recently began treatment for a brain tumor, is well known for his laid-back demeanor and a sensible, cooperative nature.
lead_paragraph: The player representatives for every major league team were summoned to a conference call with the union’s executive director, Michael Weiner, at 1 p.m. Eastern on Tuesday. The players did not know the subject but had no reason to suspect anything unusual. Weiner wasted no time in telling them the news: the day before, he had begun treatment for a brain tumor.

headline: Games Are Over; Battle Goes On
abstract: The decorated American sprinter Sanya Richards-Ross has taken on Rule 40, an I.O.C. regulation that limits how athletes can promote their sponsors during the Olympics.
lead_paragraph: The Olympic sprinter Sanya Richards-Ross was at BET’s Midtown studios last Wednesday for an appearance on the hip-hop show “106 & Park.” Before stepping in front of the raucous studio audience, she put on her makeup with expert precision and helped a hair stylist fashion her characteristic “S. R. R. braid.” Later she joked with the rapper Bow Wow about his stealing the two gold medals she won at the recent London Games.

headline: Romney Compares Protesters to a Greek Chorus
abstract: Mitt Romney said he had re-read Mr. Obama’s Denver acceptance speech. “He says marvelous things,” Mr. Romney said. “He just hasn’t done them.”
lead_paragraph: POWELL, Ohio — Mitt Romney had a message for the protesters who greeted him and Representative Paul D. Ryan, along with 5,000 supporters, here on Saturday morning: “This is kind of like the Greek chorus in the background,” he said, in a reference to President Obama’s speech four years ago at the Democratic convention in Denver, which he delivered in front of large Greek columns.

headline: The Rangers’ Renaissance Man
abstract: Don Raleigh was a finesse hockey player for the Rangers during his 10-year career, but quit when the N.H.L. game became more rugged and less skillful.
lead_paragraph: The death last week of the Rangers star Don Raleigh at 86 severed another of the last links to a long-vanished world of hockey where the ice was brown, chicken-wire fencing guarded the ends of the rink and a skinny player who developed a taste for opera could make it in the N.H.L.

headline: Storm Adds to Misery in Haiti’s Homeless Camps
abstract: Tropical Storm Isaac delivered strong winds and rain on Saturday, which caused flooding, mudslides and several deaths, according to preliminary reports, but not the kind of destruction feared.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Tropical Storm Isaac whirled across Haiti on Saturday, delivering strong winds and rain that caused flooding, mudslides and at least a few deaths, according to preliminary reports, but not the kind of widespread destruction feared in the earthquake-battered nation.

headline: Jets’ Pouha Says He Will Be Ready
abstract: After sitting out much of the preseason with physical problems, nose tackle Sione Pouha plans to play in the Jets’ first regular-season game.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Sione Pouha thought he knew pretty much everything there was to know about what it felt like to butt heads with offensive linemen. Pouha is a 325-pound nose tackle entering his eighth year with the Jets, and knocking helmets is just a part of the job.

keywords: ['Euro (Currency)', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: President François Hollande of France expressed his commitment Saturday to keep Greece in the euro zone, but he urged its new prime minister, Antonis Samaras, to go all out to solve the economic crisis.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President François Hollande of France gave the new Greek prime minister some reassurance in a meeting here on Saturday, expressing his commitment to keeping Greece in the euro zone.

headline: Ragtag Revolts in Parts of Afghanistan Repel Taliban
abstract: While distrusting the government, many villagers have also come to loathe the Taliban for their dictatorial cruelty and are fighting back.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — In small mountain villages on Taliban turf in eastern Afghanistan, Pashtun tribesmen took up arms to fight the insurgents this summer, fed up with their heavy-handed tactics of closing schools and threatening families whose sons had joined the Afghan Army.

headline: Another Alternative Inflation Measure
abstract: Inflation in the price of alternative inflation statistics .. or not.
lead_paragraph: A correspondent alerted me to an interesting alternative measure of inflation beyond the Billion Price Index. Those who claim that inflation is vastly understated often appeal to the authority of Shadowstats, a site that purports to provide true measures of many economic variables.

headline: No Crime, No Punishment
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Editorials']
abstract: The financial crisis is receding, without prosecutions to deter wrongdoing even as a fuller picture is emerging of the range of banks’ reckless and lawless activities.
lead_paragraph: When the Justice Department recently closed its criminal investigation of Goldman Sachs, it became all but certain that no major American banks or their top executives would ever face criminal charges for their role in the financial crisis.

headline: Apple-Samsung Case Shows Smartphone as Legal Magnet
abstract: The smartphone patent wars are unusually complex, and the courts, rather than the patent office, are pushing companies toward a truce. In the end, consumers may be the losers.
lead_paragraph: The smartphone in your hand is a marvel of innovation, packing sophisticated computing and communications technologies into a sleek digital device.

headline: A Glitch in Health Care Reform
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Editorials']
abstract: Confusing language in the health care reform law could mean that millions of middle-class Americans are left without affordable coverage.
lead_paragraph: Confusing language in the health care reform law has raised the possibility that millions of Americans living on modest incomes may be unable to afford their employers’ family policies and yet fail to qualify for government subsidies to buy their own insurance. This is a bizarre development that undercuts the basic goal of health care reform — to expand the number of insured people and make their coverage affordable.

headline: The Outbreak of West Nile Disease
abstract: The West Nile virus should not be shrugged off, but it is important to put it in perspective.
lead_paragraph: The nation is in the midst of an outbreak of West Nile disease that could become the worst ever recorded since the virus was first detected in New York in 1999. The number of cases has risen sharply in recent weeks.

headline: How Mr. Romney Would Force-Feed the Pentagon
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Budget Control Act (2011)', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Mitt Romney’s plan would add trillions of dollars to projected military spending, yet there is no sense that this money would lead to a more effective security strategy.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan are portraying themselves as lionhearted budget-cutters, ready to slice out profligate spending in all sorts of government programs and services and lead America to lower taxes and lower deficits. Many experts say their numbers don’t add up, even if they were to impose all the cuts they want.

headline: How Long Do You Want to Live?
abstract: New biomedical discoveries may bring a steeper increase in life span — but not everyone wants it.
lead_paragraph: SINCE 1900, the life expectancy of Americans has jumped to just shy of 80 from 47 years. This surge comes mostly from improved hygiene and nutrition, but also from new discoveries and interventions: everything from antibiotics and heart bypass surgery to cancer drugs that target and neutralize the impact of specific genetic mutations.

abstract: After two years on the inside of The New York Times, the departing public editor is still looking for transparency and humility.
lead_paragraph: “WHY on earth would you want this job?”

headline: After Bullets Hit Bystanders, Protocol Questions
abstract: Outside the Empire State Building on Friday, the police killed a gunman but wounded others. The police commissioner said the shooter did not fire again after killing a former co-worker.
lead_paragraph: The encounter was breathtakingly brief: a surveillance video showed a gunman outside the Empire State Building on Friday pulling a pistol, pointing it at two police officers, their firing at him and his falling to the sidewalk.

headline: Leave Me Alone!
abstract: A football fan continues watching games alone, a habit formed growing up when his family often disrupted his television-watching experience.
lead_paragraph: I watched Super Bowl XLVI in February by myself, the same way I watch most televised N.F.L. games. Sad? Hardly. Solo watching is a habit I adopted in high school. Although my friends and family were not overtly obnoxious, I often found them disruptive.

headline: Big Chem, Big Harm?
keywords: ['Endocrine Gland', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Chemicals', 'Bisphenol A (BPA)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Research']
abstract: Chemicals in everything from canned food to A.T.M. receipts could affect you, your children and your children’s children.
lead_paragraph: NEW research is demonstrating that some common chemicals all around us may be even more harmful than previously thought. It seems that they may damage us in ways that are transmitted generation after generation, imperiling not only us but also our descendants.

headline: U.S. Cup Qualifier: The View From Traffic in Brazil
abstract: Last week’s stunning announcement, at least to some in United States soccer circles, that the next two and possibly six away World Cup qualifying matches would be shown only on Al Jazeera’s new network, beIN Sport, was not so bewildering in at least one quarter.

headline: 30 Seconds With Anthony Davis: Unique Twist to Hoops Trifecta
abstract: This year, Anthony Davis has won an N.C.A.A. title, was the top pick in the N.B.A. draft and won an Olympic gold medal with the United States team in London.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Davis has had a spectacular year. After leading Kentucky to the N.C.A.A. championship in April, Davis, a 6-foot-10 power forward, was chosen in June by the New Orleans Hornets as the first pick of the N.B.A. draft. This month, Davis helped the United States men’s basketball team win the gold medal at the London Olympics.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Conversations Between Doctor and Patient
abstract: Readers discuss whether clinicians should be assertive or let the patient decide.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss whether clinicians should be assertive or let the patient decide.

headline: Randy Moody
abstract: A Republican who favors abortion rights discusses Willie Nelson and indie films.
lead_paragraph: Randy Moody is the co-chairman of Republicans for Planned Parenthood, which was founded in 1995 to give Republicans who favor abortion rights a voice. Despite his long-shot lobbying efforts and the continuing furor over Representative Todd Akin’s remarks about abortion and rape, the G.O.P. Platform Committee last week adopted a strict anti-abortion position with no exceptions for rape, incest or to save the life of the mother.

headline: Underwater, Feeling Our Ocean Origins
abstract: Exploring a beautiful, teeming underwater world that can’t be put into words.
lead_paragraph: I’ve always loved scuba diving and the cell-tickling feel of being underwater, though it poses unique frustrations. Alone, but with others, you may share the same sights and feelings, but you can’t communicate well.

headline: Dozens of Bodies Are Found in Town Outside Damascus
abstract: Daraya, a suburb of Damsacus, has been the focus of what activists described as a scorched-earth campaign by Syrian troops to wipe out rebels.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Dozens of bodies, possibly more than 200, were found Saturday in a town outside Damascus, raising the specter of a massacre by Syrian troops as bad as any atrocity committed since the Syrian uprising began nearly 18 months ago.

headline: The Democrats’ Abortion Moment
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'ABORTION']
abstract: Representative Todd Akin’s comments are a gift to liberals, but only if they don’t overreach.
lead_paragraph: IN 1971, two years before Roe v. Wade, the philosopher Judith Jarvis Thomson used an arresting thought experiment to make the case for legalized abortion.

headline: An Immune Disorder at the Root of Autism
abstract: Future doctors will need to correct the postmodern tendency toward immune dysregulation.
lead_paragraph: IN recent years, scientists have made extraordinary advances in understanding the causes of autism, now estimated to afflict 1 in 88 children. But remarkably little of this understanding has percolated into popular awareness, which often remains fixated on vaccines.

headline: Chinese Deny Forcing Refugees to Myanmar
abstract: The Chinese foreign ministry says fighting in Myanmar is subsiding, contradicting other reports.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese Foreign Ministry has denied human rights advocates’ reports that China is forcing ethnic Kachin refugees to return to a war zone in Myanmar, saying that the people are going home of their own accord.

headline: Ever Meek, Ever Malleable
keywords: ['Psychology and Psychologists', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Movies']
abstract: An unsettling movie and our political culture illuminate our readiness to obey.
lead_paragraph: I INSTANTLY bought the strip-search. The nude jumping jacks, too.

headline: What Would Jesus Do? Skinny-Dip
abstract: A look at the history of skinny-dipping in the Sea of Galilee.
lead_paragraph: KEVIN YODER, a congressman from Kansas, apologized last week for swimming nude in the Sea of Galilee last summer during a trip with his wife and other members of Congress, who apparently were clothed. Actually, he apologized for “any embarrassment I have caused for my colleagues and constituents.”

headline: Out of a Job, but Not Missing a Beat
abstract: Scott Radinsky has been introspective since the Indians fired him 111 games into the season, his first season as pitching coach.
lead_paragraph: Scott Radinsky pitched for four major league teams from 1990 to 2001. A left-handed reliever who appeared in 557 games, Radinsky compiled a 42-25 record, a 3.44 earned run average and 52 saves. In 2004, he began working his way up the coaching ranks for the Cleveland Indians, serving as a pitching coach for four of their minor league teams. In 2010, he became the Indians’ bullpen coach, and this year, he was put in charge of the pitchers. But six days after a reporter interviewed him in Cleveland, Radinsky was home in California, without a job and pondering his next move. And he was being Radinsky, which means being engagingly different, as this two-week account demonstrates.

headline: Shifting Conference Alignments
abstract: Nearly a quarter of the 124 programs in the Football Bowl Subdivision will change their conference affiliation between 2011-13. A look at the 2012 and 2013 changes.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a quarter of the 124 programs in the Football Bowl Subdivision will change their conference affiliation between 2011-13. A look at the 2012 and 2013 changes.

headline: Lee’s Losing Battle on the Mound
abstract: Cliff Lee has seven losses and two victories, the fewest wins for any pitcher with at least 20 starts this season.
lead_paragraph: Last Tuesday, in the seventh inning against Cincinnati at Citizens Bank Park, Cliff Lee of the Philadelphia Phillies walked Todd Frazier. It is the only walk Lee has issued in four starts this month, compared with 32 strikeouts. Alas, he has no victories in August.

headline: The Antisocial Contract
abstract: The very idea of a culture war over values clouds what’s really at stake: women’s economic freedom.
lead_paragraph: WHEN the Republican Party meets in Tampa, Fla., this week, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey will deliver the keynote address. He promises “hard truths.” Twenty years ago, the Democrat-turned-Republican Phil Gramm had that job. Warning to Governor Christie: no one remembers anything Mr. Gramm said. What we do remember from the 1992 convention in Houston is the jeremiad delivered by Patrick J. Buchanan, the former speechwriter for Richard M. Nixon who won nearly a quarter of Republican primary votes that year. With his invocation of a “cultural war” for the “soul of America,” Mr. Buchanan brought down the house.

headline: Drugs, Sweat and Fear
abstract: The sweat-drenched practice of Bikram yoga was my medicine for anxiety, but over time, it stopped working.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2007, I attended my first yoga class. For more than four years — ever since graduation had dumped me into adulthood — I’d been leveled by anxiety. My days were plagued with worry. Was I living correctly? What if I died? What if, like in that Twilight Zone episode, the rest of the world died and I lived? abstract: The roots of Assam violence, how the Mumbai police mishandled the Azad Maidan protests and a lost girl returns from the forest decades later.
lead_paragraph: In a well-researched piece in the Economic and Political Weekly, Jyoti Punwani analyzes the run-up to the Aug. 11 rally at Azad Maidan in Mumbai and the fallout from the violence that occurred. There were clear signs of upcoming trouble, which the Mumbai police should have noticed, she argues, including a weeklong promotion of the rally that involved the circulation of graphic video clips taken from the Internet and widespread discussion in the Urdu press. The Mumbai police suffer from a chronic lack of intelligence about the city’s Muslim community, she argues, caused by its lack of knowledge of Urdu, lack of Muslim recruits and biased attitude.

headline: Reader Comments on my Big Chem Column
abstract: Readers comment on my column about chemicals that are all around us and appear to be even more dangerous than previously thought.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column is about chemicals that are all around us and appear to be even more dangerous than previously thought. I’ve written before about these endocrine disruptors, so called because they wreak havoc with the body’s endocrine system governing hormones. Now new research indicates that their effects may be passed down from generation to generation in humans. Using doses of the chemical BPA similar to what humans encounter, the study shows that exposure to the chemical in pregnant mice can affect the sociability of their children and their children’s children. This should be devastating for Big Chem, which has so far been able to block any meaningful national curbs on endocrine disruptors. This obviously isn’t regular fodder for op-ed columns, but it seems an issue of public health and public policy that deserves more attention. I’d welcome your comments on what should be done.

headline: ‘Obama’s America’ Is a Box-Office Surprise

lead_paragraph: The movie capital didn’t see this coming: The political documentary “2016: Obama’s America,” a cinematic extension of the best-selling book “The Roots of Obama’s Rage,” beat two new Hollywood releases at the weekend box office and came close to passing a third. “Obama’s America,” released by Rocky Mountain Pictures, took in an estimated $6.2 million at North American theaters, for a total of $9.1 million since opening in limited release last month. Two new movies — “Hit & Run” (Open Road Films) and “The Apparition” (Warner Brothers) — flopped, taking in less than $4.7 million each.
