headline: Navigating Tangled Narratives
abstract: In her novel “NW,” Zadie Smith employs a stream-of-consciousness technique to trace her characters’ thoughts in a rapidly changing London.
lead_paragraph: “NW,” the title of Zadie Smith’s clunky new novel, refers to northwest London, where she grew up — a multicultural corner of the city that will be familiar to readers of her dazzling debut, “White Teeth.” In that earlier book Ms. Smith took a contemporary London mapped by writers like Martin Amis, Salman Rushdie and Hanif Kureishi and claimed it decisively as her own. There are glimpses, here and there in “NW,” of that cacophonous metropolis — a city in constant flux as waves of immigrants and fierce youth reinvent it year by year, day by day — but “NW” is a much smaller, more meager book than “White Teeth.”

headline: Inventor Challenges a Sweeping Revision in Patent Law
keywords: ['Inventions and Patents', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Law and Legislation', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: Mark Stadnyk is suing the United States government, aiming to block a patent law that he says is a triumph of corporate lobbying that will hurt lone inventors like him.
lead_paragraph: In Silicon Valley, Apple just won big against Samsung in the patent lawsuit of the year, after trading claims and counterclaims of pilfered product ideas. Across the country, in a federal court in Florida, an inventor named Mark Stadnyk is waging a different kind of patent warfare — an ambitious and perhaps quixotic legal foray.

headline: Cuomo Calls for Resignation of Brooklyn Assemblyman
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo became the most prominent official to call for the resignation of Vito J. Lopez, who was censured after allegations of sexual harassment.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Sunday became the latest Democratic official to call for the resignation of a powerful Brooklyn assemblyman who was censured on Friday after allegations of sexual harassment.

headline: Qualifying at a Location Near You
abstract: How about bringing the pop-up concept to Grand Slam tennis?
lead_paragraph: How about bringing the pop-up concept to Grand Slam tennis?

headline: All Things Equal: Let’s Play Five
abstract: The United States Open established equal prize money for women in 1973, maybe it is time to let the women join the men in playing best-of-five matches.
lead_paragraph: An expanded tennis center should equal more tennis. But that does not necessarily mean expanding the field. It should mean giving the world’s greatest tennis players more time on the sport’s largest stage.

headline: Get to the Point, in Fewer Sets
abstract: With the increased physicality of the sport, best-of-five matches too often turn into seemingly interminable wars of attrition rather than the displays of finesse more befitting tennis.
lead_paragraph: It is time to do away with the best-of-five format that is burdening the men’s game at Grand Slam events. With the increased physicality of the sport, best-of-five matches too often turn into seemingly interminable wars of attrition rather than the displays of finesse more befitting tennis. The men play best-of-five only at the majors and the Davis Cup, and there is little recent evidence that best-of-three makes for undeserving winners. Just as Roger Federer, Novak Djokovic, Rafael Nadal and Andy Murray have ruled the Grand Slams, they have also dominated the best-of-three Masters 1000 events, having swept the last 16 consecutive tournaments at that level.

headline: The Way Forward: Recalling Forest Hills
abstract: The United States Tennis Association has a grand opportunity to reclaim some of the dignity it squandered with luxury boxes at Arthur Ashe Stadium.
lead_paragraph: The National Tennis Center is about to get another face-lift. Who runs tennis, anyway — Con Edison and its old Dig-We-Must slogan?

headline: Viewers Don’t Want Conventional
abstract: If political convention organizers acknowledged that they were putting on reality shows, television networks and viewers might be more inclined to watch.
lead_paragraph: If the political conventions were managed like a typical television show that was losing audience, think of the meetings that would be held during the run-up.

headline: As Indians Honor John Glenn, He Honors Neil Armstrong
abstract: During the Indians’ ceremony to commemorate the 50th anniversary of his orbiting Earth, John Glenn remembered Neil Armstrong for his accomplishments and patriotism.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — An event that was planned weeks in advance was altered Sunday after the death of Neil Armstrong, the first man to walk on the moon. John Glenn, the first American astronaut to orbit Earth and a good friend of Armstrong’s, threw out the ceremonial first pitch before the Cleveland Indians’ game against the Yankees at Progressive Field.

headline: The Living Death of Solitary Confinement
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Torture']
abstract: Solitary confinement does more than deprive an inmate of freedom; it violates the very structure of a person’s being.
lead_paragraph: There are many ways to destroy a person, but the simplest and most devastating might be solitary confinement.  Deprived of meaningful human contact, otherwise healthy prisoners often come unhinged. They experience intense anxiety, paranoia, depression, memory loss, hallucinations and other perceptual distortions. Psychiatrists call this cluster of symptoms SHU syndrome, named after the Security Housing Units of many supermax prisons. Prisoners have more direct ways of naming their experience.  They call it “living death,” the “gray box,” or “living in a black hole.”

headline: A Conflicted Novice in the Shadow of the Guillotine
abstract: Poulenc’s tragic 1957 work, “Dialogues des Carmélites,” was presented by Dell’Arte Opera company in repertory with “Carmen.”
lead_paragraph: Poulenc’s solemn, shattering 1957 opera “Dialogues des Carmélites” is about a novice in an order of Carmelite nuns doomed by the anticlerical extremism of the French Revolution. The young woman, Blanche, struggles mightily with the rigors of the life to which she is committing herself before ultimately, joyously accepting them.

headline: Broadway Just Got More Dangerous
abstract: Gerard Alessandrini is once again feasting on theatrical spoils, shaping his latest spoof, “Forbidden Broadway: Alive & Kicking!,” which anticipates fodder from shows opening in the fall.
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon the four cast members of the satirical revue “Forbidden Broadway” were running through a number sending up the frenetic hard sell of the hit musical “Newsies.”

headline: In Digital World, Advertising Age Redesigns Print Publication
abstract: The trade publication will soon introduce the most significant redesign in years to its weekly print product, redirecting its editorial focus in a digital world from breaking news to analysis.
lead_paragraph: A WEEKLY trade publication covering Madison Avenue since the Hoover administration will soon introduce its most significant redesign in years, as part of efforts to further redirect its editorial focus in a digital world toward analysis from breaking news.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
abstract: Account assignments, executive appointments and miscellaneous news from advertising agencies.
lead_paragraph: Accounts

headline: Band With a Confrontational Tilt Brings the Crowd Along for the Ride
abstract: A sparse audience watched the Canadian band Duchess Says give an intense performance Thursday at Public Assembly in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: People who have seen the French-Canadian band Duchess Says — and in the United States there still aren’t that many — generally remember physical contact with its singer, Annie-Claude Deschênes. She steps off the stage, or gets down from it somehow, crouching and sitting and sliding and rolling. Then she engages.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Adventure as a Cure for Ailing Love Lives
abstract: “The Matchmaker,” Thornton Wilder’s 1954 farce, has been given a rare and loving revival at the Stratford Shakespeare Festival this year.
lead_paragraph: STRATFORD, Ontario — It may take a little while for audiences to stop waiting for the band to strike up during “The Matchmaker,” the 1954 farce by Thornton Wilder that has been given a rare and loving revival at the Stratford Shakespeare Festival. Wilder’s confectionary comedy was the most popular of his plays on Broadway, where the original production ran for more than a year. But the fame of “The Matchmaker” has since been eclipsed both by the enduring greatness of Wilder’s two masterworks, “Our Town” and “The Skin of Our Teeth” — each a Pulitzer Prize winner — and by the huge commercial success and undeniable charm of the musical version of the play, “Hello, Dolly!”

headline: Snooki Is a Mom
abstract: Nicole Polizzi, the star of MTV’s “Jersey Shore” who is better known as Snooki, gave birth to her first child.
lead_paragraph: Nicole Polizzi, below, the star of MTV’s “Jersey Shore” who is better known as Snooki, gave birth to her first child, Lorenzo Dominic, on Sunday at a hospital in Livingston, N.J., according to MTV. Ms. Polizzi and her fiancé, Jionni LaValle, announced their engagement and the pregnancy last March, and the development became a focal point in the first season of the “Jersey Shore” spinoff “Snooki & JWoww.” Cameras followed the couple and Jennifer Farley, known as Jwow, to an ultrasound, and Ms. Polizzi appeared to give up the hard-partying ways that made her one of the most popular personalities in reality programming. MTV said that the last few months of Ms. Polizzi’s pregnancy would be featured in the sixth season of “Jersey Shore,” which has its premiere in October.

headline: Bullpen Rescues Garcia to Seal Yankees’ Win
abstract: Relievers threw four and one-third scoreless innings after the starter Freddy Garcia struggled as the Yankees increased their lead over the idle Tampa Bay Rays to four games.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Danger lurked everywhere during the Yankees’ six-game Midwestern trip.

headline: Writer Finds Her Niche in Dark Themes
abstract: Tana French puts her career into perspective as her latest murder mystery, “ Broken Harbor,” sits on the best-seller list.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — The identity of the murderer in Tana French’s thriller “Broken Harbor” is concealed, of course, until the end. But in some ways the killer is there all along, in the form not of a person but of a house — a malevolent family house rotting in a half-empty development begun in the Irish boom in the 2000s and all but abandoned in the subsequent crash.

headline: Midnight Movies at New York Festival
abstract: For the first time in its 50-year history the New York Film Festival has created a Midnight Movies sidebar that will celebrate genre films.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in its 50-year history the New York Film Festival has created a Midnight Movies sidebar that will celebrate genre films, according to The Hollywood Reporter. The three chosen films to be screened during the festival, which starts on Sept. 28 and runs through Oct. 14 at Lincoln Center, are “The Bay” by Barry Levinson, about a deadly parasite outbreak; Takeshi Kitano’s yakuza action film “Outrage Beyond” (with Beat Takeshi, above); and Peter Strickland’s film within a film, “Berberian Sound Studio.” The center also said Friday that it would host a two-day conference, “NYFF Convergence,” with panels and workshops devoted to transmedia, a form of storytelling that uses multiple digital platforms. It is to be held Sept. 29 and 30 at the Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center.

headline: A Composition Fit for a Prince (and a Finale)
abstract: The Mostly Mozart Festival came to a close with Louis Langrée conducting Beethoven’s Mass in C and with Martin Fröst as soloist in Mozart’s Clarinet Concerto.
lead_paragraph: Summers seem to fly by faster than they used to, but if you are in denial about whether this one is about to end, you need only have stopped at Lincoln Center early on Saturday evening. The plaza was packed with listeners facing the Metropolitan Opera House, where “The Enchanted Island” — the opening installment of the Met’s summer-closing HD Festival — was about to be shown on a large, flat-screen monitor. And inside Avery Fisher Hall the musicians of the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra were filing onstage to play the festival’s closing concert — as sure a sign as any that the season’s days are numbered.

headline: CNN Looks for a Boost From HBO Shows
abstract: As Time Warner attempts to reinvigorate its 24-hour cable news channel, the company has pushed for CNN to incorporate HBO’s sports and documentaries into its lineup of news programs.
lead_paragraph: In a bit of corporate synergy, Time Warner is planning to dip into one of its strongest cable channels, HBO, to help revive the fortunes of one of its weakest, CNN.

headline: Where the Fringe, the Post-Fringe and the Anti-Fringe Gather
abstract: Fringe festival leaders from several countries exchanged notes in Edinburgh. One thing they learned: Even the Fringe has its fringe element.
lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH — Bring together a group of theater types who all run Fringe festivals — those hand-to-mouth celebrations of artistic experimentation and DIY scrappiness — and you’re bound to get differences of opinion. And so it went at the inaugural World Fringe Congress here, which drew 47 festival leaders from Amsterdam, Avignon, St. Louis, Taipei, New Delhi and other cities.

headline: Casting Developments for Spinoff of ‘The Office’
abstract: With last week’s news that NBC’s long-running sitcom “The Office” will end after the coming season.
lead_paragraph: With last week’s news that NBC’s long-running sitcom “The Office” will end after the coming season, the network has moved forward with casting choices for the pilot of a planned spinoff called “The Farm,” starring Rainn Wilson as Dwight Schrute. According to Entertainment Weekly’s Web site, Majandra Delfino (“Roswell”), Thomas Middleditch (“The Campaign”) and Matt Jones (“Breaking Bad”) have been tapped to portray members of the Schrute clan at the family’s beet farm and bed-and-breakfast. No premiere date has been set.

headline: While Front Office Addresses the Future, the Mets Enjoy an All-Too-Rare Moment
abstract: The rookie Jeremy Hefner shut out the Astros for eight innings and Ike Davis hit his second solo home run of the game in the ninth inning to give the Mets the victory.
lead_paragraph: Here was their chance to interrogate a few of the men responsible for the Mets’ latest collapse. The manager, Terry Collins, and general manager, Sandy Alderson, entertained questions from about 1,500 season-ticket holders for about an hour Sunday morning at Citi Field, as did Mike Baxter, Jon Niese and the third base coach Tim Teufel.

headline: Times Agrees to Sell About to Diller’s IAC
abstract: The Times bought the expert site in 2005 but announced its intention to sell earlier this month.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Company has agreed to sell the About Group, which includes the About.com network of topic sites, to Barry Diller’s IAC/InterActiveCorp for about $300 million in cash, the company said on Sunday.

headline: August in New York, Time to Honor an Eternal Spirit
abstract: The Charlie Parker Jazz Festival lineup included the drummer Roy Haynes, a former Parker associate; the bassist Derrick Hodge; and the singer Rene Marie at Marcus Garvey Park in Harlem.
lead_paragraph: There comes a moment during all the Charlie Parker Jazz Festivals I have seen in Marcus Garvey Park in Harlem when the crowd decides it is truly happy, and pockets of excitement form like chemical reactions onstage and in the audience. The crowd tends to be middle-aged or older — wise, skeptical, funny, good at staging an outburst.

keywords: ['Automobile Renting and Leasing', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Two giants of the rental car industry agreed to merge late on Sunday, as Hertz Global Holdings announced a $2.3 billion deal for the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group.

headline: English Women Win at World Mind Sports Games
abstract: In the Women’s Teams final at the Second World Mind Sports Games in Lille, France, last week, England defeated Russia by 69 international match points.
lead_paragraph: LILLE, France — In the Women’s Teams final at the Second World Mind Sports Games here last week, England defeated Russia by 69 international match points. England also won this event four years ago in Beijing with four of the same players: Sally Brock, Nicola Smith, Heather Dhondy and Nevena Senior. This time, the third pair was Fiona Brown and Susan Stockdale.

headline: Present at Birth
abstract: A Monday puzzle that shows that it really pays to know how to spell.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — This is Michael Farabaugh’s third time out in The New York Times, and he offers us a perfectly O.K. puzzle that is a twist on the vowel run theme: instead of the letters being vowel runs, Mr. Farabaugh shows us that we can have our cruciverbal cake and eat it too. This time the entire first words of each theme phrase make up the vowel run.

keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Families and Family Life', 'Parenting', 'Summer (Season)']

headline: 2 Band Members in Russia Said to Flee to Avoid Arrest
abstract: The conviction and jailing of three band members from the punk collective Pussy Riot earlier this month drew condemnation from many foreign governments and celebrities.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Two members of the punk collective Pussy Riot who had avoided being arrested for their anti-Kremlin demonstrations have fled Russia, the band announced in an online posting on Sunday.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel’s Move May Seal Fate of ‘Nightline’
abstract: The decision to shift “Jimmy Kimmel Live” into the time slot long held by “Nightline” is a hurtful and possibly fatal blow to the program, former members of the news show say.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Kimmel’s ascent to the main stage of late-night television — the hour directly after the 11 p.m. local news — was greeted last week with widespread congratulations for a performer who had paid his dues and for a network willing to shake up the late-night status quo and bet on a comedic challenger to David Letterman and Jay Leno.

headline: The Guardian Backtracks From a Bold Move in Hiring
abstract: The liberal-leaning Guardian hired the conservative Joshua Treviño to write for its United States Web site, but the relationship did not last long.
lead_paragraph: ON Thursday afternoon, the conservative commentator Joshua Treviño was in an expansive mood — he had just begun as a columnist for the United States Web site of the esteemed liberal newspaper The Guardian.

headline: U.S.T.A. Confirms Schedule Change and Reaffirms Commitment to Roof
abstract: Officials for the United States Open said more definitively than ever Sunday that their main venue, Arthur Ashe Stadium, will one day have a roof. But they have yet to find a material that is lightweight enough.
lead_paragraph: Officials for the United States Open said more definitively than ever Sunday that their main venue, Arthur Ashe Stadium, will one day have a roof.

headline: In Canada, the Impact of America’s New Patent Law Is Seen
abstract: The United States passed new patent legislation last fall and key provisions are scheduled to take effect early next year. New research analyzing the experience in Canada, after it made a similar legal change, suggests that small inventors will be hurt. Patents awarded to individual inventors dropped by 15 percent after the legislative change in Canada.
lead_paragraph: In an article published in Monday’s New York Times and available now online, I wrote about a lawsuit that challenges the constitutionality of the nation’s new patent law, the America Invents Act.

headline: Storm Gains Strength Moving Toward Coast
abstract: Tropical Storm Isaac was expected to gather strength, potentially making landfall as a hurricane somewhere along the Gulf Coast, late on Tuesday or early Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — As Tropical Storm Isaac churned into the Gulf of Mexico on Sunday, South Florida managed to dodge the worst of it. But the fast-moving storm appeared poised to swell into a hurricane and hit land on Wednesday between the Florida Panhandle and New Orleans.

headline: Intriguing Habitats, and Careful Discussions of Climate Change
abstract: Many zoos are fearful of alienating visitors with tours or wall labels that dwell bleakly on damaged coral reefs, melting ice caps or dying trees.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Sitting on an artificial mangrove island in the middle of the ray and shark “touch tank,” Lindsay Jordan, a staff member at the New England Aquarium, explained the rays’ eating habits as children and their parents trailed fingers through the water. “Does anyone know how we touch these animals when we are not at the aquarium?” she asked.

headline: Volunteers Keep Watch on Protests in Chile
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Police Brutality and Misconduct']
abstract: Groups of observers take notes and help people who have been injured or abused during student protests, but for the most part they do not intervene.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — They appear at the student demonstrations that are once again filling the streets and occupying the schools of Santiago, and at the hospitals and police stations where the fallout lands afterward: small troops of observers in blue or white helmets, armed with notebooks, cameras, voice recorders and gas masks.

headline: Egyptian Leader Adds Rivals of West to Syria Plan
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']

lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Staking out a new leadership role for Egypt in the shaken landscape of the Arab uprisings, President Mohamed Morsi is reaching out to Iran and other regional powers in an initiative to halt the escalating violence in Syria.

headline: New Arrivals Change the Bills’ Attitude
abstract: After making an uncharacteristic off-season splash, with the signings of Mario Williams and Mark Anderson, the Buffalo Bills will seek to end the N.F.L.’s longest postseason drought.
lead_paragraph: When the Buffalo Bills’ torrid start last season culminated in a victory over the New England Patriots in Week 3, General Manager Buddy Nix was conspicuous among the skeptics who correctly predicted his team was not yet good enough to end the N.F.L.’s longest playoff drought.

headline: 36 Killed in China When Bus Collides With Methanol Tanker
abstract: Two drivers of the tanker were detained for questioning after the accident in Yan’an in Shaanix Province.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A double-decker sleeper bus plowed into the back of a tanker carrying flammable methanol on an expressway in Yan’an in northwestern China’s Shaanxi Province on Sunday morning, setting off a fire that killed 36 people, including the bus driver, and injured three, the state-controlled media said.

headline: Rise in July Electric Bills Confuses Even Con Edison
abstract: The New York utility sent out estimated bills for July when the company locked out its workers in a labor dispute.
lead_paragraph: If some New Yorkers were baffled about why their Consolidated Edison bills were so high last month, they are not alone: Even the utility is confused.

headline: Her Opponent Stumbles, but a Candidate Still Watches Her Step
abstract: Few voters are unfamiliar with Representative Todd Akin’s reference to “legitimate rape,” so Senator Claire McCaskill has not seen the need to bring it up.
lead_paragraph: MARSHALL, Mo. — A political storm is swirling around Senator Claire McCaskill’s Republican challenger for one of the most coveted seats in the fight to control the United States Senate. But one would not have learned about that here this weekend at Bloomfield’s Family Restaurant, where Ms. McCaskill campaigned before military veterans and went right on talking about veterans’ benefits, improvements at Arlington National Cemetery and surveys at military health care facilities.

headline: At Summit Meeting, Iran Has a Message for the World
abstract: As Iran plays host to the Nonaligned Movement meeting, it wants to tell its side of the long standoff with the Western powers over its suspect nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — At the entrance to the convention hall where Iran is sponsoring an international summit meeting are the crumpled wreckage of three cars driven by Iranian nuclear scientists who have been killed or hurt in bomb attacks. Placards with the photos of the scientists and their children stand alongside.

headline: Seeking Sparkle, Gleam and a Clean Slate
abstract: The night shift at the Westside Highway Car Wash tends to patrons amid an opera of spray, scent and, especially after midnight, unusual requests.
lead_paragraph: The wayfarers come on wheels and on foot, pausing their evenings long enough to bring a little sparkle to their lives, before the city goes about sullying them again.

abstract: Myths used to be about ancient Greeks. When authors write about myths today, they mean something more prosaic: a statement that almost everyone thinks is true but really isn’t.

headline: Going Down With Heads Held High
abstract: Three divisions away from their normal home in the Scottish Premier League, the first weeks of the 2012-13 season at Rangers have been either depressing or humorous, or both, depending on one’s point of view.
lead_paragraph: GLASGOW — “Rangers then, Rangers now, Rangers forever,” shouted the Scottish soccer club’s new owner, Charles Green, in front of almost 50,000 fans on hand for the team’s home opener Aug. 18. “Today is just the start of the journey,” he went on defiantly.

headline: As Restaurants Cut Salt, Some See Reasons to Pass
abstract: Sodium reduction has lately become a culinary cause célèbre, but critics call such moves unnecessary.
lead_paragraph: It was a slightly curious gesture: last week, Boston Market, the national chain of rotisserie chicken restaurants, removed the salt shakers from its tables, replacing them with small placards — tucked next to the pepper shakers — promoting the company’s interest in reducing sodium.

headline: 140 Passengers Stranded Aboard Trains to J.F.K.
abstract: The service problem for the Kennedy International Airport trains began at 5:33 p.m. and service was finally restored at 10:18 p.m.
lead_paragraph: About 140 rail passengers heading to or from Kennedy International Airport were stranded for hours on Saturday evening and had to walk beside the tracks to the nearest station, after a computer malfunction caused the AirTrain system to shut down. The trains run on an elevated platform high over the Van Wyck Expressway in Queens.

headline: Apple Case Muddies the Future of Innovations
abstract: For companies that emphasize distinctive design, the Samsung patent verdict was a validation of their efforts.
lead_paragraph: Apple’s victory on Friday in a patent lawsuit against Samsung could, if upheld, give its rivals a kick in the pants to create more original products.

headline: Vande Velde Captures the USA Pro Challenge and Stalls a Youth Movement
abstract: Christian Vande Velde, 36, defeated Tejay van Garderen, 24, by nine seconds in an individual time trial for the overall victory.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — The young guns of American cycling will have to wait another year. The old guard is not quite ready to step aside just yet.

headline: Steep Climb to ‘Fahrenheit 9/11,’ but Anti-Obama Film Is a Hit
abstract: “2016: Obama’s America,” a documentary critique of Barack Obama’s policies and ideological roots, ranked No. 8 at the box office over the weekend as it expanded to about 1,100 theaters across the country.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Love it or loathe it, “2016: Obama’s America” — the director Dinesh D’Souza’s documentary critique of Barack Obama’s policies and ideological roots — has arrived as a box-office event.

headline: U.S. Open Preview: Andy Murray Managing the Olympic Aftermath
abstract: Andy Murray endured a heartbreaking loss in the Wimbledon final and then won the Olympic gold medal at the All England Club.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the United States Open, Andy Murray will be sharing his observations on his matches and his time in New York on Straight Sets. It has already been a memorable summer for Murray, who endured a heartbreaking loss in the Wimbledon final and then won the Olympic gold medal at the All England Club. Murray, the No. 3 seed, opens his United States Open on Monday against Alex Bogomolov Jr. in the second match at Arthur Ashe Stadium.

headline: The Last Bipartisan
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Medicare']
abstract: The story of Ron Wyden and Paul Ryan shows just how perilous lawmaking is in today’s Congress.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I first encountered Ron Wyden in 1974, he was setting up the Oregon outpost of the Gray Panthers, a lobby group founded by the liberal activist Maggie Kuhn with a broad agenda but an emphasis on empowering the elderly. Wyden, who was 25, seemed improbably boyish to be a champion of senior citizens. But he radiated a winning, wonky exuberance. He was clearly bound for a life in politics. He won an insurgent campaign for a House seat in 1980, graduated to the Senate in 1996 — and now, at age 63, has spent almost exactly half his life on Capitol Hill.

headline: The Comeback Skid
keywords: ['Republican National Convention', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Taxation', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie’s boasts about tough choices and fiscal responsibility turn out to be a lot like Paul Ryan’s.
lead_paragraph: There will be two big stars at the Republican National Convention, and neither of them will be Mitt Romney. One will, of course, be Paul Ryan, Mr. Romney’s running mate. The other will be Chris Christie, the governor of New Jersey, who will give the keynote address. And while the two men could hardly look or sound more different, they are brothers under the skin.

headline: Westside Highway Car Wash
abstract: A neon sign calls to all those seeking to free themselves from the grime of the city, even if it lasts only a few minutes.
lead_paragraph: A neon sign calls to all those seeking to free themselves from the grime of the city, even if it lasts only a few minutes.

headline: These Days, It’s Back to School, Then Shopping
abstract: In an effort to follow trends, students and their families are delaying back-to-school purchases, which could hurt an economy heavily dependent on consumer spending to stay afloat.
lead_paragraph: Samantha Paradise is starting eighth grade in Manhattan next week, but she won’t be decked out in all new gear on the first day.

headline: Rejuvenation at the Barclays, and Maybe a Ryder Cup Spot
abstract: Nick Watney closed with a two-under 69 at The Black Course at Bethpage for a 72-hole total of 10-under 274 and a three-stroke victory over Brandt Snedeker at the Barclays.
lead_paragraph: FARMINGDALE, N.Y. — Another week, another lost player found his way back to the winner’s circle. Welcome to golf’s great summer revival, a traveling exhibition of born-again careers. abstract: A compassionate Senate bill would address reproductive-health needs for disabled veterans, as well as their spouses and surrogates.
lead_paragraph: One of the unexpected and little-noted consequences of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan has been an increase in the number of service members whose battlefield wounds leave them unable to have children. One apparent reason is the type of combat: when troops on foot patrols are struck by improvised bombs, they are particularly vulnerable to pelvic injuries that damage their reproductive systems. Military records show that since 2003, more than 1,800 service members in those wars — the majority of them Army troops — have suffered such wounds.

headline: The Amtrak Option
abstract: As more travelers choose rail, Mitt Romney, Chris Christie and Republicans in Washington should be doing everything in their power to improve train service, not stand in the way.
lead_paragraph: Helped by the high cost of gasoline and airline tickets, Amtrak is doing very well. The railroad recently announced that when given a choice between air or rail, three-quarters of travelers between New York and Washington take the train. Between New York and Boston, more than half prefer the rails. One of the biggest impediments to further growth is the pair of 100-year-old tunnels under the Hudson River — one going in each direction between New Jersey and New York City. The tunnels operate at capacity, creating a bottleneck that will only grow worse as the metropolitan area’s population grows. It’s obviously time for a new tunnel complex.

headline: DC Comics Unveils New Power Couple
keywords: ['Comic Books and Strips', 'Superman (Fictional Character)', 'Wonder Woman (Fictional Character)']
abstract: Wonder Woman and Superman embrace and kiss in issue No. 12 of “Justice League,” published by DC Comics, which is to be available in comics stores on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: “Do you ever feel alone?” “Of course I ... do.” And with that exchange, Wonder Woman and Superman embrace and kiss in issue No. 12 of “Justice League,” published by DC Comics, which is to be available in comics stores on Wednesday. The cover of that issue — featuring the two heroes in flight canoodling — got comic book fans talking when it was released last week. Those strong reactions, good and bad, were exactly the goal of Geoff Johns, the writer of “Justice League,” and Jim Lee, the book’s artist. In 2011 Mr. Lee was named co-publisher at DC Comics along with Dan DiDio, and Mr. Johns was named chief creative officer of DC Entertainment. In an interview they said that the Superman-Wonder Woman romance had been one of the most exciting elements they had conceived of when DC’s heroes were given a reboot last fall. “When we thought about relaunching the entire DC universe, we considered not what we were going to remove, but what we could add to the mythology,” Mr. Lee said. Mr. Johns said the romance and how it affects the characters, their teammates and their supporting casts will affect the DC universe for years. Fans with longer memories will recall that in 1986, after a previous reboot, Superman and Wonder Woman had another flirtation but eventually decided they were not right for each other. That version of Superman eventually revealed his identity to Lois Lane. He proposed to her, and they were married. And that version of Wonder Woman later caught the eye of Aquaman and Batman.

headline: Summer Fruit Galettes
abstract: Rustic free-form pies with a nutty but delicate whole-wheat crust showcase the season’s sweet, juicy stone fruits.
lead_paragraph: As long as there are still peaches, plums, apricots, berries and nectarines to be had, I’m buying them up and making pies and galettes. A galette is a free-form pie, more rustic than a tart. Although they’re usually made with classic buttery pie dough or puff pastry, I’ve been working at developing a dough recipe that is delicate and tasty but not too rich. I decided that a yeasted dough could work, and came up with a formula that yields enough for two galettes but has only 60 grams of butter (about 4 tablespoons). The flavor is nutty and rich because of the whole-wheat flour, but the dough isn’t heavy. The trick is to roll it very thin, then freeze it right away so that it doesn’t continue to rise and become too bready, and also so that it’s easy to work with when you are ready to assemble the tart. The dough works beautifully for these free-form galettes.

headline: March on the R.N.C.
abstract: Today’s protest was about preservation, not radicalism.

Eisenhower’s exact words on the opportunity cost of defense spending were: “Every gun that is made, every warship launched, every rocket fired signifies, in the final sense, a theft from those who hunger and are not fed, those who are cold and are not clothed. This world in arms is not spending money alone.”

lead_paragraph: In his Op-Ed column today, Roger Cohen quoted a letter from John Kael Weston to President Obama.  Mr. Weston, who served for the State Department in the city of Fallujah in Iraq and in Afghanistan’s Helmand Province, suggested that Mr. Obama appear in person at Camp Lejeune, in North Carolina, next month to present the Presidential Unit Citation to soldiers who fought under the Marine Expeditionary Brigade-Afghanistan from May 29, 2009, to April 12, 2010.

headline: As Genes Learn Tricks, Animal Lifestyles Evolve
abstract: Recent studies on how some snakes and other animals detect infrared light provide striking examples of how new lifestyles can evolve when old genes learn new tricks.
lead_paragraph: Early one evening a few years ago, I took a short hike with my wife, Jamie, in the Cockscomb Basin Wildlife Sanctuary in Belize. The large, lush reserve is known for its healthy population of jaguars, so, following closely behind our guide, we kept our eyes peeled for the elusive cats. We saw a few tracks and some claw marks on trees, but elected to leave the jungle before nightfall.

headline: Many Bone Tests for Some, and Too Few for Others
abstract: Recent reports suggest that too many younger women are being evaluated and treated for bone loss when they should not be, while many at greater risk are overlooked.
lead_paragraph: Though Riva Schwartz, who manages a law office in Garden City, N.Y., has never broken a bone, she began receiving bone-density scans almost 10 years ago, when she turned 50. Eventually she was given a diagnosis of osteoporosis and started treatment. But every bone-building medication she took had side effects.

headline: Aspirin May Aid Cancer Recovery
abstract: Men treated for prostate cancer who took aspirin regularly for other medical conditions were less likely to die of their cancer than patients who weren’t taking aspirin, a new study shows.
lead_paragraph: Men treated for prostate cancer who took aspirin regularly for other medical conditions were less likely to die of their cancer than patients who weren’t taking aspirin, according to a new study published on Tuesday in The Journal of Clinical Oncology.

headline: Fuel Factory Explodes, Then Comedy Ensues
abstract: Dan O’Neil’s’s eco-comedy uses a 1918 Expressionist play as its base for a comedic look at the energy industry.
lead_paragraph: The country’s insatiable appetite for energy powers Dan O’Neil’s “Victor Frange Presents Gas,” a diffuse and fitfully insightful eco-comedy from the Incubator Arts Project. With one roaring engine.

headline: Dented Souls, on the Road to Redemption
abstract: The novel “The Revised Fundamentals of Caregiving” by Jonathan Evison sends a man who has lost everything on a road trip.
lead_paragraph: “Before I became Mr. Mom,” says Ben Benjamin Jr., the unlucky hero of “The Revised Fundamentals of Caregiving,” Jonathan Evison’s third and most stealthily powerful novel, “I had decent options. O.K., options.” Ben had a work history of painting parade floats and stacking scones in a bakery, then switched gears to become a doting father and husband. He gave his all to domesticity. He had no idea how evanescent his ordinary life would be.

lead_paragraph: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Boss Vetoes Your Upgrade. (It’s the Seat Next to Him.)
abstract: Will Dean is chief executive of Tough Mudder, a 10- to 12-mile obstacle course challenge designed by British Special Forces. He’s found that travel can also pose challenges.
lead_paragraph: I’VE been flying all of my life. When you start a business, it’s great to have to fly because that means your business is growing. But the process is infuriating. As a former counterterrorism agent in Britain, I can’t argue against safety. And at my company, Tough Mudder, we take safety very seriously. But there just needs to be a more efficient manner to conduct security at the airports.

lead_paragraph: 5:47 p.m. | Updated Does the snarkiness of a blog post translate for a mainstream, general audience? A cable company is hoping to find out.

abstract: At least eight video clips uploaded to opposition activist channels on YouTube appeared to show a Syrian government helicopter exploding in flames and plunging to the ground outside Damascus on Monday.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Steven Erlanger reports, Syrian rebels claimed responsibility for shooting down a government helicopter during fighting in the eastern suburbs of Damascus on Monday.

headline: American Roots Music, Earnestly Embraced Onstage

lead_paragraph: Normally it works like this: A band comes to town, does a soundcheck on its stage for the night, maybe grabs a quick meal of debatable quality, plays a show, then squeezes in some carousing before it is time for its car or van or bus to depart for the next carnival.

headline: Portman to Reprise Obama Role for Romney Debate Preparation
abstract: Senator Rob Portman, an Ohio Republican, has been tapped to reprise his role of playing President Obama to help Mitt Romney prepare for his debates.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. – It’s time for Senator Rob Portman to dust off those old Obama audiobooks again. He has been tapped to reprise his role of playing President Obama to help Mitt Romney prepare for his debates.

headline: A Cynical Portrait of Two Political Bases
abstract: A Romney campaign attack ad accuses the president of gutting the welfare-to-work requirement.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The Romney campaign isn’t going to admit that its outrageous welfare ad, falsely accusing President Obama of gutting the welfare-to-work requirement, is a nakedly racial appeal to white working-class voters. (Tom Edsall’s expert dissection this morning makes that clear.)

headline: New Book in Battle Over East vs. West
abstract: Pankaj Mishra’s new book, “From the Ruins of Empire: The Intellectuals Who Remade Asia,” is part of his tussle with Niall Ferguson and other writers over Western imperialism and capitalism.
lead_paragraph: In 1988 Pankaj Mishra was a recent university graduate in the northern Indian city of Benares with big literary ambitions he had little idea how to fulfill. But when he heard that a local library was going to be auctioning back issues of The New York Review of Books as waste paper, he knew exactly what to do.

headline: Far From Wall Street and Silicon Valley, a Focus on Family Ties
abstract: David Einhorn is the largest investor in a fund run by his brother and father. Their firm, Capital Midwest Fund, aims to tap the Midwestern work ethic and has ambitions of changing the way early stage investments are run.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — When the hedge fund manager David Einhorn was just another investment analyst in the mid-1990s, his family gave him $500,000 to get his fund, Greenlight Capital, off the ground. Now that he is a billionaire after a career of doing battle with large corporations, he has returned the favor.

headline: Protests Muted as Convention Gears Up
abstract: Protests get off to a slow start, just like the convention, in Tampa.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The storm that caused Republican officials to cancel the bulk of the first day of their convention is also dampening the protests, as fewer demonstrators than were expected turned out for the first day of rallies.

lead_paragraph: Mitchell Krueger of Aledo, Tex., has decided to skip college and turn professional after the United States Open junior tournament, which begins next weekend.

headline: Photo Released for Suspect in 13-Year-Old’s Killing

lead_paragraph: Three days after a 13-year-old boy was killed in Brownsville, Brooklyn, the police released a photo on Monday of a 17-year-old who they say they believe is the gunman.

headline: Willard C. Butcher, Former Chief of Chase Manhattan, Dies at 85
abstract: Mr. Butcher oversaw the bank’s international expansion and its merger with Chemical Banking after succeeding David Rockefeller Sr. as chairman.
lead_paragraph: Willard C. Butcher, the former chairman and chief executive of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, who led the bank during a period of international growth in the 1980s, died on Saturday at his home in Hobe Sound, Fla. He was 85.

headline: U.S. Military Disciplines 9 Over Video and Koran Burning
keywords: ['Koran', 'United States International Relations', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Nine American service members were disciplined on Monday for the burning of Korans and the posting of a video showing Marines urinating on dead insurgents, events that prompted outrage in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American military authorities disciplined nine service members on Monday for two episodes this year — the burning of Korans and the posting of a video showing Marines urinating on dead insurgents — that prompted nationwide outrage in Afghanistan. The punishments did not include criminal charges or jail time, and they fell short of what President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan had demanded.

headline: Assembly Paid $103,000 in Harassment Case

lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Sheldon Silver, the New York State Assembly speaker, authorized a secret payment of $103,080 to settle sexual harassment claims against Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez this year, according to records released by the Assembly on Monday night.

headline: Connecting the Dots After Cyberattack on Saudi Aramco

lead_paragraph: Publicly released details of a cyberattack on Saudi Aramco, the world’s largest oil producer, appear to confirm reports that critical data on three-quarters of the company’s PCs was replaced with the image of a burning American flag.

headline: Where Pirates Can Dock and Dine in New York
abstract: A loose archipelago of restaurants and bars faces the glistening bay, most from the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens, attracting locals and boaters alike.
lead_paragraph: ON a recent Sunday, as a guitar player did his best Tom Petty imitation, a pirate politely enjoyed brunch on the deck of the Wharf Bar and Restaurant, overlooking Jamaica Bay. In a knit cap with rhinestone skull and crossbones, a jacket with golden epaulets and a scruffy and ashen beard, he hoisted his Budweiser in a toast: “To the captain!”

headline: Founders of Diaspora, Intended as the Anti-Facebook, Move On
abstract: Two summers ago, a quartet of students at New York University started an ambitious project called Diaspora that was intended to be an open alternative to Facebook. But since then the project seems to have petered out. The founders said on Monday that they would be turning it over to its users.
lead_paragraph: Two summers ago, a quartet of students at New York University started an ambitious project called Diaspora that was intended to be an open alternative to Facebook, one that would give its users greater control over their data and personal information. They created a project on Kickstarter with the modest goal of raising $10,000, enough capital to support themselves for the time it would take to develop the software. The project caught fire around the Web, and the group ended up raising $200,000.

headline: Expect Fewer Seats, Even for Overseas Flights

headline: Somalia: Troops Seize Port From the Shabab
abstract: Somali and African Union troops seized the port of Marka, Somalia, on Monday from the Shabab as part of a campaign to secure Somalia, which is trying to establish its first effective national government since 1991.
lead_paragraph: Somali and African Union troops seized the port of Marka, Somalia, on Monday from the Shabab as part of a campaign to secure Somalia, which is trying to establish its first effective national government since 1991. African Union officials said its fighters met little resistance in the battle for Marka, which is about 68 miles south of Mogadishu. The Shabab earned income from taxes and port fees in Marka, according to a United Nations report.

headline: China: 2 Tibetan Teenagers Set Themselves on Fire
abstract: Two Tibetan teenagers set themselves on fire and burned to death on Monday in an anti-Chinese political protest in a Tibetan-populated area of western China’s Sichuan Province.
lead_paragraph: Two Tibetan teenagers set themselves on fire and burned to death on Monday in an anti-Chinese political protest in a restive Tibetan-populated area of western China’s Sichuan Province, the rights group Free Tibet reported. At least 50 people have set themselves on fire since March 2011. The latest victims were identified as Lobsang Kalsang, an 18-year-old monk, and Damchoek, 17, a former monk. Free Tibet, which has networks of contacts in Tibetan-populated areas of China, said the teenagers staged their protest outside the Kirti monastery in the town of Ngaba, known in Chinese as Aba, a center of anti-Chinese sentiment.

headline: City Revives a Lunch Program That Takes Chefs Into Schools

lead_paragraph: Reversing course, city education officials said on Monday that a well-regarded culinary organization that recruits professional chefs to prepare school lunches could continue doing so when the new year begins next week.

lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The witness’s testimony was beginning to show cracks. He grew visibly tense, his knuckles turning white as he gripped the table harder.

headline: Destroying Precious Land for Gas
abstract: Natural gas has been sold as clean energy, but the word “clean” is taking on a disturbingly Orwellian tone. Don’t be fooled.
lead_paragraph: ON the northern tip of Delaware County, N.Y., where the Catskill Mountains curl up into little kitten hills, and Ouleout Creek slithers north into the Susquehanna River, there is a farm my parents bought before I was born. My earliest memories there are of skipping stones with my father and drinking unpasteurized milk. There are bald eagles and majestic pines, honeybees and raspberries. My mother even planted a ring of white birch trees around the property for protection.

headline: For Putin, Report Says, State Perks Pile High

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin is rumored to be among the world’s wealthiest men, with an oil-fed fortune worth tens of billions of dollars. He denies that, vehemently, but a report to be published Tuesday suggests that the dispute may be beside the point.

headline: Gangs’ Truce Buys El Salvador a Tenuous Peace
abstract: A truce between two notoriously violent street gangs endures in El Salvador after five months, but some wonder whether the government has made a deal with the devil.
lead_paragraph: SAN SALVADOR — They had faced off many times before, on the streets, with guns in their hands. But when top leaders of two of the hemisphere’s most violent street gangs sat across from one another in the stifling air of a maximum security prison here this year, the encounter had a very different aim: peace.

headline: In a Post-9/11 City, a Person’s Language Can Be a Cause for Police Suspicion

lead_paragraph: Earlier this summer, Thomas P. Galati, commanding officer of the New York Police Department’s elite intelligence division, sat for an unusual legal interrogation, during which he talked of his keen interest in Urdu-speaking New Yorkers.

headline: Composer’s Unknown Political Oeuvre

lead_paragraph: Lin-Manuel Miranda has had a busy few years since his musical “In the Heights,” a hip-hop-infused celebration of the grit and dreams of Latino immigrants in Washington Heights, became a hit on Broadway and won a shelf full of Tony Awards.

headline: Obama, D’Souza and Anti-Colonialism
abstract: A new film about the president ultimately disappoints because it resorts to the rhetoric of demonization.
lead_paragraph: I’ve never before had the experience of seeing a movie based on the ideas of a friend who is also the film’s producer, writer, co-director and on-camera star. The friend is Dinesh D’Souza and the movie is “2016: Obama’s America.” It’s a bit less than 90 minutes long and for the most part it follows the path of D’Souza’s 2010 book “The Roots of Obama’s Rage.”

headline: Samsung Case Puts Apple Closer to Google Fight
abstract: By making its own hardware, Google could end up more squarely in Apple’s sights. The jury’s findings in the case could potentially force Google to adjust its software, too.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Steven P. Jobs minced no words when talking about Android, Google’s mobile operating system, which he saw as too similar to the iPhone’s. He told his biographer, Walter Isaacson, that Android was “a stolen product” and said, “I’m willing to go thermonuclear war on this.”

headline: Where the Clothes Are as Eclectic as the Music
abstract: Attendees at the Afro-Punk Festival in Brooklyn last weekend said they felt their clothes should match the festival’s vivacity.
lead_paragraph: Music flowed through the streets outside Commodore Barry Park in Brooklyn last weekend, luring more than 30,000 concertgoers (according to festival organizers) inside the park for the eighth annual Afro-Punk Festival. The diverse musical lineup, which included Erykah Badu, who is known for her sultry soul sound, and Das Racist, the New York hip-hop group, reflected the crowd that gathered.

lead_paragraph: TOYOYAMA, Japan — Proud parents often keep mementos from their children’s sports exploits. Nobuyuki and Yoshie Suzuki went several steps further.

headline: After Empire State Building Shooting, a Gunman’s Mother Asks Why
abstract: The mother of Jeffrey T. Johnson has been searching her memory for something that might help explain why her son coldly shot and killed a former co-worker.
lead_paragraph: From the moment she learned that her son had coldly and calculatingly shot and killed a former co-worker in Midtown, the mother of Jeffrey T. Johnson has replayed every reel of his life from birth to boyhood and beyond, searching her memory for something that might help explain why.

headline: Active in Cloud, Amazon Reshapes Computing
abstract: Amazon is quietly upending the world of business computing through its cloud operations, a vast resource that gives companies heavy computing power without the baseline costs.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Within a few years, Amazon.com’s creative destruction of both traditional book publishing and retailing may be footnotes to the company’s larger and more secretive goal: giving anyone on the planet access to an almost unimaginable amount of computing power.

headline: After Attacks, Israeli Schools Confront Hate
abstract: As some two million Israeli children started school on Monday, a national conversation also began over an attempted lynching on Aug. 16 that left an Arab teenager near death.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Tamer Jbarah, a 17-year-old Palestinian student who speaks accentless Hebrew after years in a bilingual school that is about half Jewish, said he was not at all surprised when a mob of Jewish teenagers beat an Arab teenager unconscious this month while hundreds watched and did nothing to help.

headline: The Yellow Test
abstract: How to write narrative nonfiction in blocks of scenes.
lead_paragraph: I went to see Carrie a week after her accident. Her shoulder had been broken, the bone shattered, and 24 stitches were needed to sew the cuts on her face. Her arm was in a sling. Her feet were propped on a pillow. A bottle of Vicodin was on a table within easy reach.

headline: Upstate Judge Is Censured for Accidentally Firing Gun in Chambers
abstract: After a revolver went off in the chambers of Judge Vincent A. Sgueglia, assigned to Tioga County Court in upstate New York, officials found he had approved his own concealed-carry permit.
lead_paragraph: On second thought, Judge Vincent A. Sgueglia admitted to state judicial officials, the landmark courthouse in Owego, N.Y., was probably not the best place to repair a revolver with a faulty firing mechanism.

headline: Latest Scandals From Albany
abstract: The cleanup has started in Albany, but as the Vito Lopez and Shirley Huntley cases prove, it is far from done.
lead_paragraph: It is time for Vito Lopez to resign after 28 years as a New York state assemblyman. On Friday, Speaker Sheldon Silver censured him after the Assembly’s bipartisan ethics committee found that Mr. Lopez had sexually harassed and groped two female employees. Mr. Lopez, who says the accusations are “unfair and untrue,” was stripped of his powerful position as Housing Committee chairman. A fixture on the political landscape since 1984, Mr. Lopez is also the Democratic Party boss in Brooklyn.

headline: Business and Political Experiences Pull Romney 2 Ways on Economy
abstract: As governor of Massachusetts, Mitt Romney supported a greater government role in the economy, but as a presidential candidate, he has moved closer to the Republican mainstream.

headline: Texas: Appeals Court Declines to Rule on Forced Shaving of Defendant
keywords: ['Muslim-Americans', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The highest military appeals court ruled on Monday that it was premature for them to decide whether Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan could have his beard forcibly shaved before the start of his trial.
lead_paragraph: The highest military appeals court ruled on Monday that it was premature for them to decide whether Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, the Army psychiatrist accused in a shooting rampage at an Army base in Texas in 2009, could have his beard forcibly shaved before the start of his trial. Major Hasan told his lawyers that he began growing a beard because of his Muslim faith. But the judge overseeing his pretrial hearings at Fort Hood said that Major Hasan was disrupting the proceedings and violating Army regulations, and that he would be forcibly shaved if he did not do so voluntarily. Major Hasan’s lawyers appealed, but on Monday the United States Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces said that since the judge had not issued a definitive order for a forcible shaving, it was too early for them to decide. The court said that if such an order were issued, Major Hasan could appeal to a lower Army appeals court. But the court appeared to agree with Major Hasan’s lawyers on elements of the case, asking the judge to address, if an order for shaving was given, why a forcible shaving was the “least restrictive means” of intruding on his religious liberties. With the court’s stay on the proceedings lifted, neither a hearing date nor a trial date had yet been scheduled.

headline: Is Ron Paul Winning the Future?
abstract: Or do his gains within the G.O.P. reflect partisan incentives rather than principled shifts?
lead_paragraph: With no actual convention to cover here in Tampa these last two days, the press has gravitated toward what you might call para-convention events: Newt Gingrich’s week-long “Newt University” tutorial in conservative ideas, for instance, and Ron Paul’s “We Are the Future” rally for his army of supporters, held Sunday at the University of South Florida. About Gingrich, at this point, there is little of interest to be said, but the boasting title of Paul’s rally has at least some claim to be the truth, given how well the libertarian congressman performed with younger voters in the primary season. Writing for the American Conservative, Jim Antle makes a plausible case that Paul has moved the Republican Party in his direction, and might move it further still: From the party-wide enthusiasm for critiques of the Federal Reserve to the reappearance of “bona-fide noninterventionists” in Republican House contests to the emergence of Kentucky Senator Rand Paul as a more mainstream advocate for his father’s ideas, Antle writes, “the rapid progress” of Paulism “in a short period of time is undeniable.”

lead_paragraph: When he set out to open a market, Kyle Wittels, an interior designer, knew his limitations. “I wasn’t a retailer,” he said. “I knew I had to get professionals.” So that’s just what he did. All Good Things is a no-frills, floor-through affair in the heart of TriBeCa with counters for different artisanal vendors, like a food court for provisioning. He has lured Orwasher’s for bread, Blue Marble Ice Cream and Nunu Chocolates from Brooklyn, Dickson’s Farmstand Meats from Chelsea Market, Blue Bottle Coffee, the florist Polux Fleuriste and, from Sag Harbor, Cavaniola’s cheeses, condiments and cured meats. The chef Ryan Tate, formerly at Savoy, will run the produce and seafood stands. Mr. Tate will also be the chef for the intimate downstairs restaurant, Le Restaurant, to open in mid-October with a $70 to $80 prix fixe menu with no choices that will change every day.

headline: Aperitifs From Oregon Vineyards
abstract: The company’s two offerings are called Bittersweet Vermouth and Petal and Thorn.
lead_paragraph: The business of making spirits in America is constantly finding new niches. The latest are aperitif concoctions, like vermouth, that are inspired by venerable European models. Imbue, a fledgling Oregon company owned by three entrepreneurs, all of whom have worked in wineries, breweries or restaurants, has introduced a vermouth it rightly calls bittersweet. Instead of the austere herbaceousness of a classic French dry vermouth, it has a mellower flavor, without being sweet. Though the company says it was designed to go with new American gins, it seems better suited for what is called a perfect manhattan, which is made with half sweet, half dry vermouth. It’s also elegant on its own, over ice. An aperitif wine called Petal and Thorn is pale rose, fragrant with orange blossom and mimosa up front, but grips with a bitter finish. Serve it on the rocks as you might Lillet. Both products are made from Oregon pinot gris wines that are distilled and blended with eau de vie and botanicals.

headline: Stone Links: Consider the Octopus
abstract: In this week’s links: spineless consciousness; disgusting art; rigorous deconstruction, and more.
lead_paragraph: Scientific American discusses the claim of a group of prominent researchers on consciousness recently convening at Cambridge: a neocortex is not a precondition of conscious experience. In fact, these researchers believe there are good reasons to suppose that the neural substrates of experiential states, and of emotive states as well, are present in creatures with brains structured very differently from our own. Most interestingly, even some invertebrates—specifically, octopuses—appear to show signs of being conscious. “That does not necessarily mean that you could have a distraught octopus or an elated cuttlefish on your hands,” Katherine Harmon writes. But it does mean we need to think of consciousness as being spread across a wide range of species, and being realizable by a number of different neurological structures.

headline: About Black and White and a Great City’s Blight
abstract: In Scott Lasser’s novel, a lawyer returns to his blighted hometown and decides that he can’t leave it.
lead_paragraph: In the classic Motown song “Dancing in the Street,” Martha and the Vandellas sang, “Can’t forget the Motor City.” That’s easy enough to say when the topic is music: the MC5, the White Stripes, Bob Seger, Diana Ross, Smokey Robinson and countless other influential musicians have their roots there. But when it comes to literature, forgetting Detroit can be regrettably easy to do. The city may be one of our great, if crumbling, metropolises, yet contemporary fiction set there is sparse.  Dean Bakopoulos and Charles Baxter have written memorably about Detroit’s suburbs and nearby Ann Arbor. But fiction about present-day Detroit itself? Not so much lately; it’s almost as if novels themselves had had to flee the post-1960s urban blight.

headline: What’s Left of the Big Tent
abstract: Pro-choice Republicans are struggling for inclusion.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla.– The word “abortion” first appeared in a Republican platform in 1976, when the Party hadn’t yet made up its mind on reproductive freedom. The platform acknowledged that “the question of abortion is one of the most difficult and controversial of our time.” The 1976 G.O.P. favored “a continuance of the public dialogue on abortion,” which it called a “moral and personal issue,” while expressing support for “those who seek enactment of a constitutional amendment to restore protection of the right to life for unborn children.”

lead_paragraph: Just months ago, she was studying the translucent flesh of squid bought at a fish market, in the hope of replicating their gleam in the giant, handcrafted model she was making for a special exhibit on bioluminescence at the American Museum of Natural History.

headline: When Chief Executives Share Company News on Facebook
abstract: Some chief executives are turning to Facebook to share news about their companies. In the latest example, the head of RealNetworks shared an e-mail message that he sent to employees earlier in the day announcing layoffs.
lead_paragraph: RealNetworks, an online media pioneer that is trying to turn itself around, told employees on Tuesday that it would lay off 14 percent of them, or about 160 people over the next seven months, starting with 80 right away. Instead of trying to keep his e-mail to the staff a secret, though, Rob Glaser, the founder of RealNetworks and its interim chief executive, cut and pasted it onto his Facebook page.

headline: Victims’ Sons in Tough Fight for Redress After China Rail Crash
abstract: Two Chinese-American brothers’ odyssey to retrieve their parents’ bodies and gain compensation for a deadly high-speed railroad crash highlighted the workings of an unbending government agency in China.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Henry Cao has stark memories of the moment the high-speed train he was riding rear-ended another last summer in the eastern city of Wenzhou: the pleasantly hypnotic rocking that gave way to a jolt he likened to an earthquake, followed by blackness and the sensation of falling as the car plummeted 100 feet off a viaduct.

headline: In French Baseball League, the Feel Is More Minor Than Major
abstract: Low-paid Americans and French amateurs keep coming back for seasons full of long bus rides and doubleheaders.
lead_paragraph: ROUEN, France — The best baseball in France was played on a recent Sunday afternoon in Rouen, on a spartan diamond beyond the soccer field at a municipal sports complex. Rouen’s team, the Huskies, swept a doubleheader against the Templiers of Sénart, outside Paris, on a cool, drizzly day when, at most, 35 spectators huddled under umbrellas on metal-and-plywood bleachers behind home plate.

headline: At 70, Perkins Returns to Coach at Junior College

lead_paragraph: ELLISVILLE, Miss. — Ray Perkins held two of the most high-profile jobs a football coach can occupy. From 1979 to 1982, he was the coach for the Giants, and in 1983, he was chosen to succeed Bear Bryant at Alabama.

headline: Malcolm W. Browne, Pulitzer-Prize Winning Reporter, Dies at 81
abstract: Mr. Browne, who took one of the most memorable photos of the Vietnam War, won a Pulitzer Prize in 1964 for his reporting.
lead_paragraph: Malcolm W. Browne, a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter whose four-decade career included covering the Vietnam War — and taking one of the most memorable photos of the conflict — and a lively second act as a science writer who explained chemical weapons and described the rise of synthetic body parts, died on Monday in Hanover, N.H. He was 81.

headline: Battling Themselves and Zombies
abstract: In Douglas Aarniokoski’s new film, “The Day,” post-apocalypse survivors are hunted, inefficiently, by zombies.
lead_paragraph: Like an animal warfare episode of “Wild Kingdom” but with less character motivation, “The Day” cycles through bursts of horrific violence only to end much as it begins: static, hollow and vague. An unspecified event a decade earlier — Luke Passmore’s barely-there screenplay is no help here — has left all of society more or less like “The Hunger Games.”

headline: A Banker Bets on Organic Farming
abstract: There is profit-potential as well as environmental wisdom in organic farming, according to one investment strategist.
lead_paragraph: It’s unlikely that large-scale changes in the so-called food system will happen without movement on the part of big investors. Sadly, most of these — like the corporations they support — take short-term, profit-maximizing views. (This, along with enthusiastic dabblers, is the basic reason we have bubbles.) But there are unconventional exceptions. Jeremy Grantham, the chief investment strategist for the unfortunately named G.M.O. (it stands for Grantham, Mayo, Van Otterloo & Co. LLC, and he is a company co-founder), is one of those.

headline: Taking Flight From Misery, Only to Court Peril

That salty, accidentally man-made body of water, with its shoals of calcified fish and bird bones under a relentless desert sun, supplies both a bleak atmosphere and some convenient metaphors for “Little Birds,” Elgin James’s Sundance-incubated debut feature, which follows Lily and Alison on a journey from boredom to danger.

headline: Morsi’s Wrong Turn
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The new president of Egypt should understand that his visit to Tehran is helping the Iranian regime.
lead_paragraph: I find it very disturbing that one of the first trips by Egypt’s newly elected president, Mohamed Morsi, will be to attend the Nonaligned Movement’s summit meeting in Tehran this week. Excuse me, President Morsi, but there is only one reason the Iranian regime wants to hold the meeting in Tehran and have heads of state like you attend, and that is to signal to Iran’s people that the world approves of their country’s clerical leadership and therefore they should never, ever, ever again think about launching a democracy movement — the exact same kind of democracy movement that brought you, Mr. Morsi, to power in Egypt.

headline: France Opens Homicide Inquiry in Arafat’s Death
abstract: A French court will open a homicide investigation into the 2004 death of the former Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, French news media reported Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: A French court will open a homicide investigation into the 2004 death of the former Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, left, French news media reported Tuesday. Mr. Arafat’s widow, Suha, petitioned French authorities to investigate last month after findings by a Swiss laboratory suggested that Mr. Arafat may have been exposed to polonium 210, the same radioactive isotope used to poison a dissident Russian former spy in London in 2006. Mr. Arafat died in a French military hospital on Nov. 11, 2004, after an infection that was never identified, according to medical records. There have long been suggestions, however unspecific, that he may have been the victim of foul play. The Palestinian Authority, which has agreed to exhume the body for analysis, welcomed the French decision, Saeb Erekat, an aide to the Palestinian Authority president Mahmoud Abbas, told Agence France-Presse.

No one was certain what happened while they were there or what they talked about or how it came together, though eventually some details would trickle out. headline: The Insider | Matteo Corvino
abstract: The event designer for the Venice Film Festival shares his favorite places with T.
lead_paragraph: Behind the scenes, the event designer Matteo Corvino sees to it that Venice’s high-society parties like the Venice Biennales and the annual Film Festival, which starts today, are tricked out with the most lavish decorations, props, cutlery, crystal and flowers within his reach. And his reach is vast. He is the man that Chanel calls to build runway designs for their cruise collection shows on Venice’s Lido. Private dinner parties for Jeff Koons fall under his order, and the biggest galas in town, like those at La Fenice Opera House or Save Venice Inc., seem all the better because of his creative flair. For this year’s Film Festival, Corvino is hosting a party for the V-A-C Foundation (guests will include François Pinault, the designer Pierre Cardin and Francesco Bonami, the head curator of the Whitney Biennial). Here the Venetian insider shares his favorite places with T.

headline: Behind the New View of Globalization
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Protectionism (Trade)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations traces the evolution in economic thinking about the relationship between global trade and economic stagnation in the United States.
lead_paragraph: After a recent Economix post (as part of the election-year project called The Agenda) explaining that many economists see globalization as a major cause of the income slowdown in this country, Edward Alden of the Council on Foreign Relations noted on Twitter that this view was a new one. For years, economists argued that increased global trade did not have a large effect on wages or employment in the United States. The editors invited Mr. Alden — the director of the Renewing America initiative at the council, who previously helped run a council task force on trade and investment policy – to send along a more detailed version of his point.

A lot of big guns decamped for market weeks in Europe a while ago, so Calvin Klein and Tom Ford usually show in Milan and Scott Sternberg of Band of Outsiders took his collection to Paris this summer. Now London is putting a bigger focus on men’s wear shows and Mr. Ford has said he will show there in January.

headline: He Skewered Politics and New York, Without Actually Existing
abstract: Mr. Dooley, a figment of the humorist Finley Peter Dunne’s imagination, is remembered 100 years later.
lead_paragraph: Henry James, Henry Adams and Theodore Roosevelt read him regularly. The historian Charles A. Beard said that given the toxic level of public controversies in the early 20th century, he “relaxed the tension of the ‘moral overstrain.’” The columnist Franklin P. Adams called his meditations “merely truth concealed in sugar-coated idiom and dialect” to conceal his loathing of injustice, sham and selfish stupidity. Through hundreds of columns beginning in 1893, he was a national sage and satirist laureate.

headline: Humor and Horror: Victor LaValle Talks About His Novel ‘The Devil in Silver’
abstract: In Mr. LaValle’s new book, residents of a Queens psychiatric hospital battle bureaucracy and a monster.
lead_paragraph: In Victor LaValle’s third novel, “The Devil in Silver,” a man called Pepper is taken to a psychiatric hospital in Queens by three cops who don’t want to be bothered with putting him in jail for assault. He’s told he will be there for 72 hours of observation, but the days stretch to months. Mr. LaValle is known for an approach that mixes various literary influences and tones, from humor to horror. While Pepper struggles to get decent treatment from an indifferent staff, he also forges alliances — some shakier than others — with his fellow patients and marshals them to fight a beast that has the withered body of an old man and the large head of a bison. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. LaValle discussed “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest,” the art of making a monster, van Gogh’s kinship with his characters and more.
