abstract: Who was James Reilly, and where is he today?
lead_paragraph: As Michael Steinberger wrote in his recent magazine article about the 1977 U.S. Open, one of most startling moments during the tournament was the shooting of a spectator in the stands. James Reilly, a 33-year-old Manhattanite, was shot in the leg by — as police would later come to believe — someone in an apartment building near the stadium in Forest Hills, Queens. Whoever fired the gun was never found.

headline: A Football Watch Party With a Few Thousand Guests
abstract: Paul Myerberg of The Times is back this year hosting the best college watch party in the country and offering up his own analysis and insights on all of the big games and a lot of the not so big ones.
lead_paragraph: The only thing better than watching college football on Saturday is watching the games with your friends on a college football Saturday. Paul Myerberg of The Times is back this year to host the best college watch party in the country and offer up his own analysis and insights on all of the big games and a lot of the not so big ones.

headline: We Built It: Flood-Control Edition
abstract: Thanks to tax-payer dollars and the Army Corps of Engineers, the flood-control pumps in New Orleans are working.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. – Someone from the Louisiana delegation ought to steal the “We Built It” sign from the convention hall and hang it on one of the giant flood-control pumps now protecting New Orleans, because that’s where it belongs.

headline: Drogba Provides Hope for Fans of Chinese Club
abstract: Didier Drogba’s first achievement since joining Shanghai Shenhua has been bringing the team together and providing hope for its fans.
lead_paragraph: The first sight that Didier Drogba encountered on a Chinese soccer field was a familiar one. As Shanghai Shenhua’s newly introduced substitute waited for the second half to start, he shared a smile and a word with Aiyegbeni Yakubu, Guangzhou Fuli’s recently acquired striker.

headline: Booksellers Group Partners With Canadian E-Book Company
abstract: The American Booksellers Association said Kobo, a Canadian e-book company, would join with independent bookstores to sell e-books, replacing a little-used Google service that ends in January.
lead_paragraph: Nearly five months after Google said it would end a little-used program that allowed independent bookstores to sell its e-books, a Canadian e-reading company named Kobo has stepped in as a replacement.

headline: Field Trip! The Magazine at the R.N.C.
abstract: Christoph Niemann and Mark Leibovich check in from Tampa.
lead_paragraph: Christoph Niemann has filed another dispatch from Tampa, where he is live-illustrating tweets from the Republican National Convention:

headline: Happy Birthday, Parks. Now Open Your Web Site.
keywords: ['National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The National Park Foundation created a Web site with mobile devices in mind so travelers can find the nearest park and share park stories, photos or video.
lead_paragraph: It is safe to say that in 1916, when the National Park Service was created, no one could have imagined how the institution would be marking its 96th birthday: a Web site created with mobile devices in mind.

headline: Finding Effective Advertising in Surprising Places
abstract: Entertaining advertising can create the impression of a retailer that has a sense of fun and that might have something unexpected in store for its customers.
lead_paragraph: Recently, I heard that riff of music that I always hear when confronted with a piece of fine advertising. At the time, oddly enough, I was paused at an intersection in Austin, Tex., staring at the back end of a delivery truck for a local hardware store, Zinger Hardware.

headline: The Peanut Gallery’s View of the Convention
abstract: Comedians following the Republican National Convention this week have taken to Twitter for what amounts to a running routine. Here’s a selection of the best (family-friendly) jokes.
lead_paragraph: If Chris Christie ever runs for president, America will continue to lead the world in fat jokes. That is abundantly clear to anyone who was paying close attention to the vast peanut gallery that is Twitter last night. Comedians, who have embraced the form as much as any other artist, were hard at work reacting to the Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla., especially the major speeches of Mr. Christie, the New Jersey governor, and Ann Romney, wife of the  party’s nominee, Mitt Romney. Relying on Witstream, a Web site that collects Twitter postings from the comedy world, as well as some searching, I hereby offer a few of the best jokes suitable for a family newspaper.

headline: Pre-Publication Disclosure of Dowd Column: A Breach of Two Boundaries
abstract: The public editor weighs in on a Times reporter’s decision to give a C.I.A. staffer an advance copy of Op-Ed Columnist Maureen Dowd’s print column.
lead_paragraph: My final column as public editor was published in print on Sunday. However, I remain on duty through Friday and want to offer my take on the controversy this week over the pre-publication disclosure of a Maureen Dowd column. I see this as a problem of boundaries – the failure to maintain them.

headline: Day 2: TimesCast Politics Schedule and Convention Day at a Glance

lead_paragraph: 5:26 p.m. | Updated Tuesday’s Republican National Convention schedule featured nominations, protests, keynotes and 3 Doors Down, and that was only the beginning. The Times’s political unit is back in action in Tampa, Fla., broadcasting live with the latest from the convention hall. The next broadcast will be at 7 p.m.

abstract: Twenty years after Patrick J. Buchanan spoke at the Republican convention of a “cultural war,” his views are more common than controversial.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Twenty years ago, Patrick J. Buchanan rocked the Republican convention in Houston by declaring there was a “cultural war” taking place for the soul of America, denouncing the Democratic Party as one that supported abortion, radical feminism and the “homosexual rights movement.”

headline: Google Plus Goes to the Office
abstract: Google’s social networking service, Google Plus, is integrating communication features like group video with Google Apps, its collaboration tools for business. The idea is to offer companies social tools that could enhance productivity. It may also be a way to raise the profile of Google Plus, which has over 100 million users, but little buzz.
lead_paragraph: Now Google Plus means business.

lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. – Representative Paul D. Ryan, framing the presidential election as the “clearest choice possible,” intends to use his prime-time moment at the Republican National Convention on Wednesday night to assure Americans that he and Mitt Romney can oversee a strong economic recovery.

headline: Citigroup in $590 Million Settlement of Subprime Lawsuit
abstract: Plaintiffs in the lawsuit, settled for $590 million, said the bank failed to disclose its huge holdings in collateralized debt obligations.
lead_paragraph: Citigroup said on Wednesday that it had agreed to pay $590 million to settle a class-action lawsuit brought by shareholders who contended that they had been misled about the bank’s exposure to subprime mortgage debt on the eve of the financial crisis.

headline: Ex-Senator Criticizes Republicans’ Tone on Immigration
keywords: ['Hispanic-Americans', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Republican National Convention', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Former Senator Mel Martinez, Republican of Florida, said the immigration debate during the presidential primary season “did a lot of damage” to the party, and urged Mitt Romney to reach out to Hispanics.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. – Mel Martinez is a former United States Senator from Florida, served as chairman of the Republican Party under President George W. Bush, and is one of the highest-level Hispanic Republicans in public life. So it was striking on Wednesday morning to hear him speak starkly about his party’s problems with Latino voters after a primary season in which all the candidates stressed measures that would severely curb immigration

headline: Yoko Ono and Sean Lennon Organize Artists Against Fracking
abstract: Artists Against Fracking, a new coalition organized by Yoko Ono and Sean Lennon, will spread its message through social media.
lead_paragraph: Yoko Ono said it was not hard to recruit more than 180 artists to help convince Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York not to allow natural gas drilling in the Marcellus Shale through the hydraulic fracturing process known as fracking.

headline: FX Orders 90 More Episodes of ‘Anger Management’
abstract: The network committed last year to show 90 additional episodes of the Charlie Sheen sitcom if the first 10 met ratings thresholds.
lead_paragraph: Here’s something no one has been able to say about Charlie Sheen for a while: now he knows what he’ll be working on for the next two years, or, at least, where he’s supposed to go when he’s working. On Wednesday, FX said that it had committed to an additional 90 episodes of “Anger Management,” the sitcom that has served as Mr. Sheen’s comeback vehicle after his — didn’t you hear? — tumultuous departure from “Two and a Half Men.”

headline: Georgia Frees Hostages Along Border With Russia
abstract: The Georgian authorities said they had engaged in a fierce gun battle to free five Georgian villagers being held by a band of militants who had crossed over the border from the Russian republic of Dagestan.
lead_paragraph: TBILISI, Georgia — The Georgian authorities said Wednesday that their forces had engaged in a fierce gun battle to free five Georgian villagers being held by a band of heavily armed militants who had crossed over the mountainous border from the Russian republic of Dagestan. Three Georgian officers and at least 10 militants were killed, officials said.

headline: French Banks Prepare to Pull Out of Greece
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Société Générale said Wednesday that it was in advanced discussions to sell its 99.1 percent stake in Geniki Bank, one of Greece’s biggest financial institutions, while Crédit Agricole is expected to sign a deal to offload Emporiki Bank.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France’s biggest banks are preparing to pull out of Greece in the coming weeks, the latest large international business to abandon the country as it grapples with a debilitating recession and nagging questions about its future in the euro zone.

headline: Two Views of This Summer’s Deal-Making
abstract: The dollar value of mergers announced this summer was the lowest amount since financial markets began trembling in the summer of 2007. But the number of transactions was the second highest, reflecting a time of plentiful but small deals.
lead_paragraph: Looked at in one way, this summer was a dire time for deal-making. But from another perspective, it’s been a great one.

headline: Severe Diet Doesn’t Prolong Life, at Least in Monkeys
abstract: In a long-running study, rhesus monkeys whose caloric intake was restricted by 30 percent didn’t live any longer than their normal-weight peers.
lead_paragraph: For 25 years, the rhesus monkeys were kept semi-starved, lean and hungry. The males’ weights were so low they were the equivalent of a 6-foot-tall man who tipped the scales at just 120 to 133 pounds. The hope was that if the monkeys lived longer, healthier lives by eating a lot less, then maybe people, their evolutionary cousins, would, too. Some scientists, anticipating such benefits, began severely restricting their own diets.

headline: Super PACs and Party Stalwarts Mix in Tampa
keywords: ['Political Action Committees', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Super PACs blend in easily with the Republican leadership in Tampa, raising questions about coordination.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Why did the “super PAC” go to Tampa? Because that is where the money is.

headline: An Online Retailer Gets Its Own Makeover
abstract: The Web site Shopbop gets ready to compete with more polished luxury players.
lead_paragraph: SHOPBOP, the online powerhouse of contemporary fashion, has never gone in for bells and whistles.

headline: Authenticity and Ethnicity
abstract: Why do Indian, African and Arab writers who are longtime legal citizens of Britain or the United States still identify themselves as Indian, African or Arab? And is there really such a thing as an authentic Indian, Arab or African novel?
lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH — Fifty writers from around the globe assembled in a large tent in Edinburgh in mid-August, and over five days they spoke about the relationship between literature and politics; about whether style and content are really opposites (as people who lack style often claim); and about censorship and the future of the novel.

headline: Chris Christie: But Enough About Mitt, Let’s Talk About Me
abstract: In his keynote, Mr. Christie mostly talked about himself.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie is getting rave reviews today for his performance at the National Republican Convention, and there’s no doubt in my mind that he did a huge amount of good for the three most important people in his life – he, himself, and him.

headline: A Day in Indianapolis, and a Night in Tampa
abstract: Mitt Romney left the Republican National Convention on Wednesday to address the American Legion in Indianapolis as Republicans tried to focus on national security.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — A day after being formally nominated for president, Mitt Romney left the Republican National Convention on Wednesday to address the American Legion in Indianapolis as Republicans tried to focus on national security.

headline: Gay Republicans Try to Join the Party
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'Republican National Convention', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: GOProud, which advocates for gay conservatives, says it is bringing unusual levels of gay support to Mitt Romney, but discordant notes rang through the dance music at a party near the Republican convention.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The go-go dancers at the party for gay Republicans on Tuesday night were, by go-go dancer standards, modestly dressed in T-shirts and jeans, baring only their midriffs and arms. Their choreography, set to dance remixes of “Call Me Maybe” and other Top 40 hits, conveyed enthusiasm more than sexual enticement.

headline: Mazda Enters the Midsize Fray With Sleeker Mazda 6 Sedan
abstract: Unveiled at the Moscow motor show this week, the 6 is an outgrowth of the Takeri sedan concept shown over the last year.
lead_paragraph: Mazda introduced its 2014 Mazda 6 at the Moscow motor show on Tuesday. The redesigned midsize sedan will mix it up with recently updated entries from Ford, Chevrolet, Nissan, Honda and Toyota. Judging by the details released by Mazda at the show, the 6 seems well equipped for the fight.

headline: Indians in Venezuelan Amazon Report Attack by Gold Miners
abstract: Amazon Indians claim gold miners committed a massacre in a remote part of the Venezuelan Amazon.
lead_paragraph: The human rights group Survival International says it has received reports, not yet independently verified, of a July massacre of a Yanomami Indian community by Brazilian gold miners in the Venezuelan portion of the Amazon rain forest along the border with Brazil. The details are in a news release posted by the nonprofit group.

headline: Forget Tequila, September Makes Me Crazy
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Families and Family Life', 'Parenting', 'Working Hours']
abstract: Quick, parents of school-age children: Raise your hands if you’re still trying to beat the after-school schedule into reasonable submission.
lead_paragraph: A shout-out to all the fellow parents on Facebook madly grappling with pulling together the fall schedule. It’s transition time again, and just like what happens every June, September is the time to shift from the schedule devil we know to the devil we don’t know. School (bless school!) has its lovely, predictable schedule, and kindly provides us with even the date for the holiday concert months in advance.

headline: In Parole Transcripts for Lennon’s Killer, a Familiar Account, and Decision
abstract: According to a transcript released Wednesday, Mark David Chapman told a parole board that killing John Lennon was “a very selfish act and I deeply regret it.”
lead_paragraph: Last week, Mark David Chapman was denied parole for the seventh time in the killing of John Lennon. On Wednesday, the New York State department of corrections released the transcript of his Aug. 22 parole board hearing.

headline: PEN American Center Announces Literary Awards
abstract: Vanessa Veselka, James Gleick, Christopher Hitchens, Dan Barry and Robert K. Massie are recipients of the annual prizes.
lead_paragraph: The PEN American Center has announced the winners of its annual literary awards, naming Susan Nussbaum, the author of “Good Kings Bad Kings,” the recipient of the $25,000 Bellwether Prize for Socially Engaged Fiction, an honor for the author of an unpublished novel. Vanessa Veselka, author of “Zazen,” was named the winner of the $25,000 Robert W. Bingham Prize.

headline: The U.S. Open Chronicles: Listen to the Music

lead_paragraph: Irina Falconi, who is playing at the United States Open this year, will write posts throughout the tournament for Straight Sets. She has her own tumblr page, and can be followed on Twitter. On Tuesday, she lost in three sets to Olga Puchkova in the first round of the women’s singles competition.

lead_paragraph: On the Arthur Ashe Stadium court Wednesday, John Isner was thrilling a big crowd and brushing away thoughts that he was under pressure to advance far in the United States Open. He professed, after a hard-fought, 6-3, 7-6 (5), 5-7, 7-6 (9) victory over Xavier Malisse, that he was just happy to finally be awarded the honor of opening his tournament on the Open’s feature court.

headline: Questioning Kristof on Chinese Education
abstract: Guest blogger Alex Lew questions Nicholas Kristof’s view of Chinese education, arguing that the system is too focused on a high-stakes test.
lead_paragraph: Nicholas Kristof last wrote about Chinese schools shortly after the release of some stunning news: on a comprehensive exam testing students in 65 countries, China had come in first – thirty spots ahead of the U.S. in math. Kristof praised the Chinese model and ended with a warning: “These latest test results should be our 21st-century Sputnik.”

headline: U.N. Leader Broaches Delicate Topics in Meetings With Top Iranian Officials
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, met with Iran’s leaders Wednesday to address his concerns about the country’s nuclear program, the Syria conflict and human rights issues.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Making his first visit to Iran as United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon met with four members of the country’s hierarchy on Wednesday, including the supreme leader, in sessions that Mr. Ban’s spokesman described as “very serious meetings” that addressed the disputed Iranian nuclear program, the Syria conflict, human rights problems and what he called the leadership’s objectionable comments about Israel.

headline: Optical Allusion
abstract: Tom Ford reimagines a classic pair of frames immortalized by Malcolm X.
lead_paragraph: Like so many trappings of midcentury manliness, brow line eyeglasses — the kind favored by Malcolm X — have landed in the hipster bargain bin. Leave it to Tom Ford to rescue them with this exquisite version made of gold-plated metal and water buffalo horn, the way they used to be in the 1960s. (The horn component even comes with a certificate of authenticity, along with a special cleansing cream.) The only thing that’s not midcentury about these limited-edition frames is the $2,950 price tag.

headline: U.S. Open Food of the Day: Shortrib Sandwich

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – Nickelodeon, under pressure to reverse sharp ratings declines, fired its president of animation and longtime head of preschool programming on Wednesday amid a broader management shake-up.

headline: Mayor Makes It Official: It Was a Big Year for Isabella and Jayden

lead_paragraph: Looking pink-skinned, diminutive and a little bit wrinkly, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appeared in City Hall’s Blue Room on Wednesday morning to deliver one of the year’s more adorable bundles of news: the way we name our babies now.

headline: Preparing for the ‘Day After’ President Assad
abstract: A group of Syrian intellectuals have just finished a report on how to build a post-Assad democracy.
lead_paragraph: If Syrians ever get a chance to build a democracy, they should have an advantage over their Arab Spring brethren. Forty-five Syrian intellectuals have just finished a 122-page, post-Assad plan for how to take the country to an open, more pluralistic future.

headline: Yankees Welcome Ugandan Little League Team

lead_paragraph: The Yankees had special guests visit them on Wednesday: the Ugandan Little League team, the first African team to advance to a Little League World Series, was given a tour of the clubhouse by Manager Joe Girardi.

headline: Chris Christie Channels Oprah
abstract: Was the New Jersey governor’s speech on love and respect a “brain-switching” moment?
lead_paragraph: Watching Gov. Chris Christie’s combative keynote speech last night reminded us of the cover piece I wrote about him last year. His mention of his mother teaching him the difference between love and respect, in particular, brought me back. “The greatest lesson Mom ever taught me,” Christie told the crowd in Tampa last night, “was this one: She told me there would be times in your life when you have to choose between being loved and being respected. She said to always pick being respected, that love without respect was always fleeting — but that respect could grow into real, lasting love.”

headline: Colorful Pigeons in St. Mark’s Square Stir Controversy

headline: On Chris Christie’s “Flop”
abstract: The strange trashing of a not-great but pretty good speech.
lead_paragraph: I wrote my Campaign Stops column today about Ann Romney’s convention speech, but I should say something about Chris Christie’s address, given how quickly it’s been branded as a solipsistic flop. There is, of course, no real way to disprove the conventional wisdom in a case like this: Nobody (to my knowledge) conducts insta-polls of the TV audience’s reaction to a keynote speech, so if the chattering and political classes agree that Christie laid an egg, then that’s how his remarks will be remembered. But it’s worth noting that the indictment against the New Jersey governor is … distinctly underwhelming. He stands accused of talking too much about himself and not enough about Mitt Romney (or maybe not enough about Barack Obama, depending on which critique you read), and generally of failing to deliver the kind of tour de force that reporters are accustomed to seeing in his YouTube clips. But as even the big Politico piece calling the speech a “flop” allows, the most famous keynotes — Mario Cuomo in 1984 and Barack Obama in 2004 — were less about touting the nominee than laying out a broader vision of what the party stood for, and that was pretty clearly what Christie was trying to do as well. And I don’t think he did it all that badly. He made conservatism seem attractive, caricatured liberalism effectively, recast Romney in his own truthtelling image without mentioning of the details that might complicate that recasting, and generally came across as what he is: A tough-talking, charismatic politician, and an effective spokesman for the G.O.P.

headline: In Kerala, Feasting, Splurging and Mollywood Usher in Onam

headline: Who Wears the Pants in This Economy?
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Books and Literature', 'Men and Boys', 'Women and Girls', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Welcome to the new middle-class matriarchy.
lead_paragraph: Patsy Prater’s office looks like something between an executive’s and a teacher’s, her large desk crowded with neat piles of grant applications and daily logs but also with dishes of candy and other freebies for the young and old who pass through. On the bulletin board behind her head are big, colorful signs designed to remind her public-housing clients of what they are eligible for: cellphones, computer classes or prescriptions that she makes sure they have even if she has to drive them to the pharmacy herself. At the front of her desk is a photo of her “grandbaby,” who lives in Madison, Ala., three hours away. She wishes she could be there, taking care of the infant now that her daughter is back at work. “I love this job,” she said. “I know it’s where I’m supposed to be. But I am not a women’s-rights-type person. My place is in the home, and I’m fine with that, so long as my husband is earning the bacon. ’Course, that hasn’t been happening so much lately.”

headline: Edible Selby | French Laundry
abstract: Pastries at Vergennes Laundry, the bakery located in a former laundromat in Vergennes, Vt., have gained a cult following.
lead_paragraph: “Everything starts out raw and goes straight on the tart,” says Julianne Jones, explaining why her pastries have gained a cult following. At Vergennes Laundry, the bakery Jones opened in 2010 with her French husband, Didier Murat, in a former laundromat in Vergennes, Vt., all tarts are made to order with the freshest seasonal ingredients. Summer brings berries or tomatoes; the spring months asparagus with goat cheese and mint. In fall and winter it’s Gilfeather turnips, potatoes, rosemary and crème fraîche. Jones won’t use glaze, and she insists on an open kitchen. “I prefer that somebody can see the tart as I’m making it,” she says. “They see the bag of potatoes or the crate of berries. They see the wheel of cheese.” Though Jones and Murat are also renowned for their slow-rise bread and nougat, a few locals have yet to register the boulangerie. “We still have people come in with their laundry bags from time to time,” Murat says. More…

headline: Saying It’s Time to Move On, Yale President Will Retire

lead_paragraph: Brooklyn comedy is bustling. The Brooklyn Academy of Music recently started a stand-up series. Spaces like Littlefield and the Knitting Factory in Williamsburg have become reliable homes for great comedy. And Louis C.K. has made a habit of working out early versions of his annual stand-up specials at the Bell House. But the anchor of the Brooklyn scene is probably Eugene Mirman, the comic who runs a weekly Sunday show at Union Hall (where much of Mike Birbiglia’s movie “Sleepwalk With Me” was set) and curates and hosts the Eugene Mirman Comedy Festival. This freewheeling, talent-packed event has none of the stuffy air of more established festivals. It takes place Sept. 13-16 at the Bell House and Union Hall. Veteran comedians like Jon Glaser, Todd Barry and Sarah Silverman will appear. So will young, emerging comics like Michael Che and Brent Sullivan. You can also expect some special guests. The events include a Saturday show titled “Uh Oh: Dangerous, Inappropriate Comedy for Teenagers” and a film festival of short films on Sunday.

headline: Deflating Inflation

abstract: Argentina’s official and grossly underestimated figures for inflation are a lie so big and so old, the government has to keep telling it.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Every month, when the official statistics agency INDEC releases estimates for inflation, the Argentine government lies to its people. Everyone knows the figures fall far short of reality, which is that Argentina has one of the world’s highest rates of inflation. INDEC’s July figure brought 12-month inflation to 9.9 percent, well below the 24.1 percent estimated by private analysts.

abstract: Robert Sullivan’s seventh book, “My American Revolution,” chronicles his quest through some of America’s chaotic birthplaces.

Sullivan’s seventh book, “My American Revolution” (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26), chronicles his quest through some of America’s chaotic birthplaces, parts of New Jersey and New York where forgotten battles still haunt the landscape. His journey begins at the top of the Empire State Building, where Sullivan looks into the distance and sees greater New York as a “palimpsest of the Revolution, a painted-over canvas of ancient routes walked smooth. . . . ”

headline: The Ryan Record and the Ryan Speech
abstract: Notes on Paul Ryan’s convention speech.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, I wrote a trio of posts analyzing Paul Ryan’s record as a policy entrepreneur in the Obama era. My overarching argument was that he deserves substantial credit for pushing his party toward substance and away from the pathologies of the post-Bush moment; that he deserves credit, as well, for putting forward his own ideas and proposals on issues where he hadn’t yet brought the entire party on board; and that he deserves particular credit for his willingness to offer up multiple iterations of his signature entitlement reform idea, tweaking and rewriting and partnering with Democrats in an effort to make his proposals more plausible and marketable.

headline: 36 Hours in Sofia, Bulgaria
abstract: This capital city, marbled by a complex past, is looking to the future, targeting the title of European Capital of Culture 2019.
lead_paragraph: FIRST came the Thracians, about 2,700 years ago, followed by the Romans, the Byzantine Empire, the Ottoman Turks and then the Communists. These days — more than two decades after the fall of the Iron Curtain, and five years after joining the European Union — the Bulgarian capital is finally coming into its own. In place of the old Lenin monument, a statue of Sofia’s patron saint now stands tall — a dark princess that somehow embodies the city’s East-meets-West, old-meets-new allure. Under her gaze, a youthful, creative energy displays itself as Sofia angles for the title of European Capital of Culture 2019.

headline: Send Us Your First-Day-of-School Photos
abstract: We want to see you at your most adorable — or, better, most awkward. We’ll start.
lead_paragraph: There is something amazing and painful about revisiting your first-day-of-school photos. It’s not just the parade of bad clothes and worse hairstyles. It’s the fact that those clothes and hairstyles were chosen so carefully, so deliberately, in an effort to make you look your absolute best for your first new-year impression. Like the engagement ring flashed ostentatiously at a college reunion, those loafers or baby-doll dresses or No Fear shirts were your way to signal to your classmates how far you’d come since they saw you last and how this year would be different. To see that striving and posturing laid bare with the curse of hindsight can be a trying exercise in humility.

headline: Inspectors Confirm New Work by Iran at Secure Nuclear Site

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Iran has installed three-quarters of the nuclear centrifuges it needs to complete a site deep underground for the production of nuclear fuel, international inspectors reported Thursday, a finding that led the White House to warn that “the window that is open now to resolve this diplomatically will not remain open indefinitely.”

headline: Telluride Film Festival Announces Lineup
abstract: The Telluride Film Festival, which begins Friday, unveils a lineup that includes “Amour” and “Midnight’s Children.”
lead_paragraph: The Telluride Film Festival, keeping with its practice, made a last-minute announcement of the program for its proceedings, which begin in Colorado on Friday and continue through Monday. The festival includes 25 documentary and narrative films, like the Cannes Palme d’Or winner “Amour,” from Michael Haneke; “Midnight’s Children,” based on the Salman Rushdie novel; and “The Act of Killing,” a nonfiction film in which former members of death squads in Indonesia re-enact their killings as if they were scenes from favorite films.

headline: The Honor of a Partner’s Presence
abstract: When your partner spurns your boss’s dinner invitation; what to do when your dog bites a handler; and restraining from pointing out a fake diamond ring.
lead_paragraph: I received a promotion at work, and my boss proposed a celebratory dinner with my partner and me. I feel obliged to accept, but my partner does not care for my boss and has refused to go. I told my boss that I would be delighted to dine with him, but my partner could not attend. He then became insistent that my partner join us. I honor my partner’s wishes first, and am put off by my boss’s determination. How do I decline again, firmly and politely, and maintain good relations with him? Or is there another solution? Nadine, Washington

headline: The Get | Bonpoint’s Hi Panda Baby Pajamas
abstract: A French company’s new pajama collection comes with a panda design – and a message.
lead_paragraph: “I really imagined this collection as a dash of humor to start the school year,” says Christine Inammorato, the artistic director of Bonpoint. For fall, she’s brought the “insolent” creatures of the contemporary Chinese artist Ji-Ji’s Hi Panda collection to an exclusive series of cotton tees for children and moms, plus these pajamas for infants (available Sept. 1). His now famous Evil Pandas are made even cuter — if that’s possible — for the young and stylish with the addition of glasses, a book (how studious) and, of course, the French company’s signature cherries. Lest we forget, though, the bespectacled icons, which the fashion world fell in love with at the artist’s 2010 Palais de Tokyo show, aren’t there to just look adorable. Innamorato explains, “Ji-Ji gave them a true meaning: they reflect the passion, narcissism and endless search of identity of the Chinese generation born after 1980.” Lesson learned.

It is,after all, a country that has nurtured numerous international art stars and has plenty of government support for the arts but has not had a coast-to-coast biennial since 1989.

headline: Vain Glorious | True Blood?
abstract: A new under-eye solution for dark circles and puffy or crepe-y skin.
lead_paragraph: “Everyone thought it was complete insanity,” admits Melanie Simon, the celebrity facialist, of her new Circ-Cell ABO Blood Serum, a somewhat eerily named eye gel said to mimic certain functions of human blood topically with the help of powerful perfluorocarbons. “As we get older, our blood vessels break down and become increasingly unable to deliver nutrients to our tissues and metabolize waste,” she says. ABO Blood is targeted to the under-eye area, specifically dark circles and puffy or crepe-y skin, but Simon slathers it over her entire face. “It’s especially great for city dwellers,” she says. “If you press it in after your skin-care regimen, it will lock in your products, protect your skin from the environment and feed it, all at the same time.” $118; circcell.com.

headline: You Sent Me Packing … to California
abstract: For the magazine’s Food & Drink issue, I’ve decided to travel to California’s San Joaquin Valley, the most important food center in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to all for your suggestions for where I should visit for the magazine’s Food & Drink issue. After much consideration and brain-racking, and reading through hundreds of your e-mails and comments, I’ve decided to travel to California’s San Joaquin Valley next week; I could think of no place more exotic — or at least foreign — to which I might do a little justice in the short time I have. Many of you asked that I stay in America rather than venture abroad. The valley is the most important food center in the United States (and among the most important in the world), and it gets short shrift, largely because we tend to see it as industrial, monolithic, ugly and uninteresting. Though it has elements of all of those things (except the uninteresting), it has the opposites as well. I’m hoping to take a look at both extremes as well as the middle, through people, the land, the crops and animals, and of course through cooking.

He’s talking with his son, Denardo, about the imperative of original artistic expression and how it survives both the barbs of ungenerous critics and the bile of envious peers.

headline: Still in Fashion, a Century Later
abstract: A century ago Columbia Heights was “the most fashionable street in Brooklyn,” and it remains highly desirable today.
lead_paragraph: THE soft sea breezes make the Brooklyn Heights Promenade, overlooking New York Harbor, a transcendent summer sunset stroll. But get there an hour early for a sultry saunter down the flanking street, Columbia Heights, especially the block between Clark and Pierrepont Streets. A century ago this dead end was “the most fashionable street in Brooklyn,” and houses with water views now trade for $10 million.

headline: With Spirit and Variety, A Festival Unfolds Anew
abstract: The Here and Now Labor Day Festival at Bargemusic includes composers and performers of many stripes.
lead_paragraph: Bargemusic’s Here and Now Labor Day Festival is a motley but spirited new-music celebration that brings together composers of all stripes and draws some of the biggest crowds the barge gets all season. Listeners don’t always know what they are in for. Though an overall schedule is published on the barge’s Web site, on each of the festival’s four nights — it runs through Sunday — the performers and works are juggled anew for each program.

headline: Staying Power

headline: Finding a Musical Crossroads Onstage

Dressed in a long black dress and a golden cape, standing before a hammered dulcimer, she was an emanation from earlier times, even though she was flanked by synthesizers.

abstract: De Hallen Haarlem museum, only 20 minutes from Amsterdam, is presenting a major show about the sea in Dutch art since 1850, through Sept. 2.
lead_paragraph: In the waning days of summer, thoughts often turn to the sea. For those near Amsterdam, the distinguished De Hallen Haarlem museum, only 20 minutes from the city, can get their last dose of the season by taking in a major show about the sea in Dutch art since 1850, through Sunday. Dutch artists have always been drawn to it as a subject, whether depicting sea battles, coastal scenes or shipwrecks, changing their styles and perspectives according to their period.

headline: Finding Drama in Newfangled Filmmaking
abstract: “Side by Side,” with Keanu Reeves, revels in the quickly changing technical side of filmmaking.
lead_paragraph: There are quarrels that are certain to be provoked by Chris Kenneally’s new documentary, “Side by Side,” which explores the impact of digital technology on 21st-century moviemaking, but one thing is beyond argument. For a film geek this movie is absolute heaven, a dream symposium in which directors, cinematographers, editors and a few actors gather to opine on the details of their craft. It is worth a year of film school and at least 1,000 hours of DVD bonus commentary.

headline: The Great Divide

lead_paragraph: I’m not going to lie; there are easier people to share a closet with. People who wouldn’t flinch at the idea of hanging more than one shirt on a coat hanger; people who could forgive an ad hoc filing system, one that, say, mixed colors with neutrals, formalwear with casual wear, or — heaven forbid — anything sequined next to anything silk. (The risk of snagging? Who does that?)

headline: After a Life of Exile, He’s Taking on an Unusual Line of Work
abstract: “Breathing,” the first film directed by Karl Markovics, follows a 19-year-old who takes a job in the Vienna city morgue.
lead_paragraph: For a teenager stuck in a juvenile detention center, diverted by swimming and subjected to strip searches, 19-year-old Roman does not exactly choose a low-impact job for his work-release program. We first see him freaking out at a welding task in the opening scene, and the reaction of his parole officer shows that Roman has willingly botched previous attempts at gainful employment. After all that, the sulky boy — as a ward of the state from an early age, he has a child’s blinkered life experience — decides to apprentice at the Vienna city morgue.

It seems to be having an argument with itself: the dazzling but often antiseptic immersiveness of the viewing experience is countered by storytelling suffused with nostalgia for a simpler, messier, livelier period in Chinese film.

headline: A Child and a Box. What Could Go Wrong?
abstract: In “The Possession,” a box that a child clings to is the source of all kinds of demonic mischief.
lead_paragraph: Malevolent boxes abound in horror movies (the Rubik’s Cube-like container of “Hellraiser” being one of the most memorable), their contents inevitably wreaking havoc on humankind. The ratty receptacle in “The Possession” is no different: scooped up at a yard sale by Emily (Natasha Calis), the younger of two daughters toughing out the tension between their divorced parents, this particular box wastes no time releasing its inhuman contents.

headline: A Small-Town Buzz About the Missing
abstract: The disappearance of children, and possibly a stranger’s role, is the talk of a depressed mining town in “The Tall Man.”
lead_paragraph: Strange and sneaky and driven by a fury that only slowly reveals itself, “The Tall Man” opens like a ghost story and closes with its feet firmly in the real world. Until then, Pascal Laugier’s chilly little thriller manhandles our sympathies and gladdens our eyes in almost equal measure.

Boston to rest for his Friday morning pairing with Tiger Woods and Nick Watney.

To find the culprit, two detectives are summoned: the wise, middle-aged and slightly eccentric Song Donglu (Lau Ching-wan), a forensic investigator and expert in criminal psychology; and the handsome Guo Zhui (Nicholas Tse), “the fastest gun in Tiancheng,” as he is called more than once.

A few tables over, Newt Gingrich and his wife, Callista, nibbled on bacon cheeseburgers and fries. By the front door, Mary Hart of “Entertainment Tonight” held court with Representative Darrell Issa of California, chairman of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform.

headline: An App for Couch Potatoes With Places to Go

headline: Party of Strivers
keywords: ['Republican National Convention', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: The Republican Party unabashedly celebrates individual responsibility en route to material success, but our destinies are shaped by other forces.
lead_paragraph: America was built by materialistic and sometimes superficial strivers. It was built by pioneers who voluntarily subjected themselves to stone-age conditions on the frontier fired by dreams of riches. It was built by immigrants who crammed themselves into hellish tenements because they thought it would lead, for their children, to big houses, big cars and big lives.

headline: Russia: Crime-Scene Message About Convicted Band
abstract: Two women were found stabbed to death in their apartment in Kazan, officials said Thursday, adding that a message written on an apartment wall, possibly in blood, said “Free Pussy Riot.”
lead_paragraph: A 76-year-old woman and her 38-year-old daughter were found stabbed to death in their apartment in Kazan, 500 miles east of Moscow, officials said Thursday, adding that a message written on an apartment wall, possibly in blood, said “Free Pussy Riot.” Officials offered no immediate explanation for the message, which expressed support for three members of the Pussy Riot band who were convicted of hooliganism charges and sentenced to two years in prison for a protest against the Russian leader Vladimir V. Putin at a Moscow cathedral. Investigators said that the two women had been stabbed many times and that the murders occurred several days before the bodies were found. Supporters of Pussy Riot expressed dismay over the message at the scene; the band members’ lawyer called it “a horrendous provocation” or the work of a psychopath, according to news reports.

headline: An Unlikely Welcome Wagon, Back in Suburbia
abstract: After a year in the Maine woods with her family, the author finds the re-entry experience in New Jersey somewhat jarring.
lead_paragraph: We returned from our year in the woods on Aug. 1 and are still in the thick of unpacking, resettling, registering the kids for public school, and catching up on doctor appointments. The big surprise was having to fix the myriad house problems that manifested in our absence, such as broken shower nozzles, a broken refrigerator shelf, a year’s worth of untrimmed hedges and mismatched touch-up paint unwittingly applied by our well-meaning tenants throughout the house. My shell of calm began to erode as I drove across the Piscataqua River Bridge — Maine’s southern border.

headline: A Conversation With: Constitution Expert Madhav Khosla
abstract: Mr. Khosla has written a guide to understanding India’s constitution, the lengthiest in the world
lead_paragraph: Madhav Khosla, a doctoral student of political theory at Harvard University, is the author of “The Indian Constitution,” a short introduction to the world’s longest political text, which consists of 395 articles and 12 schedules. The book is a fascinating tour through the life of India’s supreme law, analyzing its central features like federalism, fundamental rights and the separation of power. In an interview with India Ink, Mr. Khosla explained why he sees the Constitution as more than a political text and how his book isn’t just for lawyers.

headline: Reviewing the Review Story
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Computers and the Internet', 'E-Books and Readers']
abstract: The reaction to an article about writers’ buying five-star reviews suggests several things: this sort of fakery has been going on for a long time, it is pervasive with books as well as other items, and there are few remedies in sight. Caveat emptor.
lead_paragraph: There was a large and energetic reaction to last Sunday’s article about a service that allowed writers to commission five-star reviews of their books. Some readers were shocked that the world of online reviews was pervaded by fakery and insincerity. “Sure puts a damper on online shopping,” wrote one. Said another: “This practice is the review equivalent of doping.” But just as with sports doping, others were not surprised and said it would be impossible to eradicate.

headline: Bookshelf
abstract: Detective work in Paris. David Byrne and music. Vintage menswear. Just some of the subjects in books T is reading this fall.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1980s, the artist Sophie Calle found an address book on a Paris street and, after tracking down the people listed inside, composed a very controversial secondhand portrait of its owner, Pierre D. Her titillating detective work finally appears in English as “The Address Book” (Siglio, $30). In “How Music Works” (McSweeney’s, $32), David Byrne approaches his personal passion with the clear-minded intensity of a scholar. Antoine Wilson’s novel “Panorama City” (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $24) contains one of the season’s more endearing characters: a binoculars-wearing, soliloquizing doofus named Oppen Porter. And among the utilitarian rarities collected in “Vintage Menswear” (Laurence King, $50) are a fin de siècle firefighter jacket and a “walking suit” made specially for Alpine rambling.

headline: Bad Neighborhood
abstract: In Ruth Rendell’s novel “The St. Zita Society,” characters are undone by their own obsessions.
lead_paragraph: I’m well aware of her reputation as a good citizen and a responsible member of Parliament, but trust me — you don’t want to live in Ruth Rendell’s neighborhood. Like her other urban teardowns, “Portobello” and “Tigerlily’s Orchids,” THE ST. ZITA SOCIETY (Scribner, $26) takes up residence in a picturesque London street and ever so slowly and delicately eviscerates the pretentious upper-middle-class residents behind its pseudo-Georgian facades. And lest anyone accuse this most cynical of satirists of sentimentalizing the lower orders, she turns and takes a bite out of these minions for adopting their masters’ shabby values.

headline: The Burning Book
abstract: Required reading.
lead_paragraph: My mother died 10 years ago. Her sister (my aunt) had been taking care of her and found a diary she kept during the last months of her life. My aunt gave it to me (I am the oldest child in our family). The diary shows a side of my mother I’d never seen before — angry, fearful, self-recriminatory. It’s upsetting to read. I suspect that the steroidal medications she was taking may have influenced her feelings, because she was not an angry person. I have never told my four younger siblings of its existence, but now — 10 years later — I wonder if I made the right decision. Should I burn it? NAME WITHHELD PORTLAND, ORE.

headline: Who Made That Flip-Flop?
abstract: How a Japanese sandal got Westernized — and supersized.
lead_paragraph: “I do not know how you feel about the Japanese,” wrote a journalist named Elliott Chaze in 1952, “but I do like their feet.” Seven years after World War II, many Americans still regarded the Japanese as enemies — and distrusted anything to do with the country. Yet a rubber version of a Japanese sandal called the zori had become a popular item in U.S. drugstores. “Our women have commenced wearing thonged sandals,” Chaze announced, noting that “obscene picture-books” from Asia eroticized the feet. Japanese women, he believed, revealed themselves in the curl of their toes. And now, thanks to the rubber zoris, American women would too.

headline: ‘Thriller’ and the Lessons of the Mega-Super-Album
abstract: The best-selling album of all time may not have even been the best album of 1982.
lead_paragraph: Michael Jackson’s “Thriller” turns 30 this year. It is still the biggest-selling album ever, worldwide, by a lot. As is the case with most biggest-evers, actual or perceived (“I Love Lucy,” say, or “Star Wars”), it’s hard to imagine a world in which “Thriller” didn’t exist. And who would want to remember the pre-“Thriller” days anyway, at least the stretch of months right before it was released, which were nasty ones for the music business? To paraphrase Don McLean’s “American Pie,” the year that “Thriller” came out, 1982, was the year the music almost died.

This balanced, informative biography, by two Boston Globe journalists, traces the prominent role Romney’s ancestors have played in Mormon history, deconstructs his leadership style and assesses his changing views on an array of social issues.

headline: Patriotism and Poultry
abstract: George Orwell’s diaries covered everything from his strong feelings about World War II to his careful counting of eggs laid by Moroccan hens.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Hitchens’s introduction to George Orwell’s “Diaries,” among the last things he wrote before his death, is meant as a tribute to one of the writers he most admired, but it can also be taken as a warning. “Read with care, these diaries . . . can greatly enrich our understanding of how Orwell transmitted the raw material of everyday experience into some of his best-known novels and polemics.” Read with care? What is Hitchens trying to tell us with that phrase? A few sentences later we have: “This diary is not by any means a ‘straight’ guide or a trove of clues and cross-references.” About the creative process that went into constructing one of the novels, Hitchens says Orwell “gives us little or no insight.” Most tellingly, he refers to the entries as “meticulous and occasionally laborious jottings.” Read with care, Hitchens’s introduction alerts Orwell devotees that they should not expect the same pleasures from this book that they get from other of his writings.

headline: Taking Sides
abstract: Alice Mattison’s novel follows the friendship of two men through the greater part of a century.
lead_paragraph: “For crying out loud!” “For Christ’s sake.” “Don’t give me that.” “I’ve never heard anything so stupid in my life.” “What the hell did you do that for?” “Enough already.” “Crazy dame.” The barbed expressions scattered liberally throughout “When We Argued All Night,” Alice Mattison’s fine novel of a friendship that lasts more than half a century, were for a long time the sonic wallpaper of life in certain quarters of New York City. During the years in which the novel unfolds, from 1936 to the beginning of the new millennium, being a New Yorker meant something specific and unfakable, and Mattison captures that essence of city life, beginning with how New Yorkers talked and then moving on to the small details that speak volumes, like this one, which comes at the beginning of the description of a dinner party: “They had no hall closet.”

headline: Accidental Tourist
abstract: A young American woman’s experience in 1960s Saudi Arabia.
lead_paragraph: It takes guts to title a novel after a line from the Bible — “the Most High rules in the kingdom of men” — and then to begin Chapter 1 with possibly the most famous biblical reference available: “In the beginning.”

headline: Gone
abstract: Charles Cumming’s spy thriller links the past and the present.
lead_paragraph: A jumble of events across time and continents kicks off the new spy thriller “A Foreign Country,” by the Scottish writer Charles Cumming. Amelia, a young au pair, disappears in Tunisia in 1978, leaving behind a lovelorn seducer. Years later, an elderly French couple are murdered in Sharm el-Sheikh, Egypt. Soon after, a young man is abducted from a dark Paris street in a 20-second maneuver “as easy as lighting a cigarette.” And Amelia, now the new head of MI6, the British intelligence service, has gone missing during a sudden trip to the South of France.

headline: Edith Wharton’s Awakening
abstract: Jennie Fields reimagines Edith Wharton’s Gilded Age world, and the love affair that threatened her closest friendship.
lead_paragraph: It is impossible to libel the dead; legal protection of reputation stops at the grave. But is it possible to embarrass the dead?

headline: Castaway
abstract: Was the forgotten British seafarer Robert Knox the inspiration for “Robinson Crusoe”?
lead_paragraph: “Each historical era and every culture has appropriated ‘Crusoe’ for its own purposes,” Katherine Frank announces at the start of her ambitious new book about “Robinson Crusoe,” Daniel Defoe and the obscure Englishman who might have been a significant inspiration for one of literature’s most famous characters. Before setting out her case for an unexpected original behind the original, Frank catalogs Crusoe’s latter-day incarnations, which have included “a hero of Romantic individualism, of Victorian Empire or 20th-century capitalism, an explorer, an inventor, the embodiment of radical or conservative ideologies, an evangelist, a prophet of positive psychology and the gospel of prosperity, even an antihero.” Surveying this long and varied afterlife, she declares, “You name it and someone has probably thought and said Crusoe has been it. That’s his secret: Crusoe is Anyone and Everyone. He is you and he is me.”

headline: Making Arrangements
abstract: A war-scarred heroine finds solace in Japanese artistic traditions.
lead_paragraph: IF you’ve never seen one, it’s almost impossible to capture the mesmerizing allure of a classic Japanese garden — and even standing for the first time in front of a bed of raked gravel can be a challenge. No vivid colors. No sweeping borders. No topiary animals. No shooting fountains. No fun, it would seem. Still, the traditional Japanese garden, esoteric as it is, has an ancient and undeniable appeal. It’s about secrets, perspectives, initiation, memory and time. It may take ages for a Japanese garden to come to maturity, to say nothing of the gardener. And yet, for all its mystery, the Japanese garden reveals itself as a capacious symbol of the human soul, replete with exactly the kinds of “borrowed landscapes” we live with. But we call them our personal histories.

headline: Written Off
abstract: Enrique Vila-Matas’s publisher-hero is on a mission.
lead_paragraph: Lying ill in a hospital, an aging, once successful publisher has a vivid dream. He is in Dublin, a city he has never visited but in his dream knows intimately. After a long walk, he enters a pub and orders a drink. His wife catches him, and the two end up sitting on a sidewalk, sobbing. The dream haunts the publisher, and two years later, he decides to make a trip to Dublin — “to feel a little busier in his retirement.” He rounds up three of his former writers and whisks them off to the cemetery where Paddy Dignam was buried in “Ulysses,” to stage a half-serious funeral for “the age of print.” There, he discovers that he’s being shadowed by a dead ringer for the young Samuel Beckett.

headline: The Lonely Middle
abstract: In Bernhard Schlink’s stories, diffident men grapple with the small delusions and half-truths of the everyday.
lead_paragraph: Since the success of “The Reader,” Bernhard Schlink has been firmly established as the voice of German guilt and conscience. Not all of his characters are as complicit as Nazi prison guards or the people who unwittingly love them, but it’s difficult for this German writer to use his country as a neutral background for private lives. With his mournful, meditative new collection of stories, translated (like “The Reader”) by Carol Brown Janeway, Schlink comes closer than ever to putting the war behind him. His characters could live anywhere, and in fact many do — in Amsterdam, in New York. They’re still haunted by the past, but the failures they confront are smaller, quieter and adamantly personal.

headline: They’re Souvenirs, Not Stuff!
abstract: After years of resisting exotic bazaars and stands selling trinkets, the author is done holding back. Her finds aren’t things, but memories.
lead_paragraph: SOUVENIR. Even the word is beautiful. It has that gentle, whispery sound of memory brushing by. A wonderfully inclusive label, it can apply to anything, because anything can be a souvenir, any object whose real value lies in its association with a past journey — or, I suppose, a person. A souvenir of a city. A souvenir of a love affair. Something that may have started as an inconvenience (how will I find room in my suitcase?) but on arrival home makes its way onto the mantel as a keepsake of delight. If it is a souvenir, it can transcend kitsch, at least for your lifetime. You are the keeper of its value.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: The mystery writer William Kent Krueger, whose novel “Trickster’s Point” is at No. 12 on the hardcover list, once tried to emulate Ernest Hemingway by going without underwear.
lead_paragraph: STERNER STUFF: Like Hunter S. Thompson — who as a young man retyped all of “A Farewell to Arms” just to absorb its rhythm and technique — the mystery writer William Kent Krueger once dreamed of becoming Ernest Hemingway. “At 19,” he says on his Web site, “I read everything by him and about him. In the course of my reading, I stumbled onto a couple of pieces of information concerning Papa’s lifestyle that I tried to incorporate into my own way of being. First of all, Hemingway never wore underwear. Well hell, I thought, whatever was good enough for Papa was good enough for me. Right away I discovered that Hemingway must have been made of sterner stuff, and I went back to wearing my beloved Fruit of the Looms.”

headline: Romney’s Speech and Obama’s Opportunity
abstract: What Romney’s speech accomplished, and the opening it left the Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Watching Mitt Romney’s convention speech last night, I felt like I was watching the best possible execution of what’s been the Romney campaign’s strategy for most of this general-election season. That strategy sees a public sufficiently primed to vote against Barack Obama that all Romney needs to do is present a plausible, acceptable, non-threatening alternative and he can grab a narrow, 51-49 win. It sees the kind of steps required to potentially expand that 51 percent to, say, 53 percent as simply too risky – in a polarized country and with a restive base – for the Republican candidate to undertake. And if you accept those two premises, last night’s speech was well-conceived and well-delivered: It was a genuinely humanizing and even moving performance that addressed what’s been his biggest liability to date – his career at Bain Capital – head-on while otherwise supplying only the most general, non-threatening account of what a President Romney might actually do in office. If all Romney needs to do to win in November is be an acceptable alternative for a weary and disappointed electorate, then this performance helped him clear that bar.

headline: The Divided Capital
abstract: Washington was the Union capital, but some of its most famous families were divided between North and South.
lead_paragraph: Though Civil War Washington was the capital of the Union, its population was dangerously split between Northern and Southern sympathizers. Pro-South feelings ran strongest in the Georgetown section. Started as a tobacco port in 1751, Georgetown, long a separate city within the District of Columbia, was dominated by a few leading families, who ran their corner of Washington like royalty. The Peter family was one. Robert Peter had been first mayor of Georgetown; Martha Washington’s granddaughter had married his son. When the Civil War came, two of the Peter sons joined the Confederate Army. To the everlasting sorrow and resentment of the family, they were hanged as spies after being captured in civilian clothes by Union troops in Virginia.

headline: Wine Salt: Easier to Make Than to Imagine

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent articles in the Travel section.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Regarding “Can Travel Make the Child?” (Aug. 12): Families participating in service-abroad programs should be cautious of one of travel’s worst crimes: academic tourism. Sure, it’s tempting to expose your (upper-middle class) children to the “exotic,” but can such short programs with such hefty price tags adequately address a country’s pressing social issues? As a former participant on similar programs, I suspect not. Equipped with a tour guide and camera, travelers become poverty tourists, observing locals through an invisible but palpable barrier. Families who take such brief glimpses at “the other” are at risk of undermining these cultures or even perpetuating stereotypes against them, while giving themselves an ego or a college-application boost. JOSHUA PETIMAR Staten Island

headline: Venice Film Festival: Michael Cimino Revisits ‘Heaven’s Gate’
keywords: ['New York Film Festival', 'Venice International Film Festival']
abstract: At the Venice Film Festival, Michael Cimino discusses his painful history with “Heaven’s Gate.”
lead_paragraph: VENICE — Most box office flops rarely even attain the status of film-history footnote. But “Heaven’s Gate,” the 1980 epic by Michael Cimino, became a legend. Its notoriously troubled production and disastrous premiere turned it into a punch line, a cautionary tale, a symbol of all that was wrong with the Hollywood system and its excesses. In the popular telling at least, this sprawling western, which recounts the violent conflict between wealthy cattle barons and poor European settlers in 1890s Wyoming, is the film that derailed the career of its ambitious young director (who had won an Oscar for “The Deer Hunter”) and sank its studio, United Artists.

headline: Vintage Fashion
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Movies', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: When I saw a screening of “Diana Vreeland: The Eye Has to Travel,” an entertaining new documentary that will have its premiere during Fashion Week, I was struck by how much Vreeland’s voice pervades the film.
lead_paragraph: “I LOATHE nostalgia,” Diana Vreeland declared at the beginning of her 1984 memoir “D.V.” She meant nothing of the sort, as Christopher Lehmann-Haupt noted in his review in The Times, calling the book a “deceptively frothy meringue of a monologue.” Vreeland was an unconventional editor and an unconventional mother (though something of a traditional mate), and her slant on life was from an angle informed by beauty. She had, quite simply, an amazing eye. This was a very specialized story she was bound to tell.

headline: Expanding Her Efforts to Be a Role Model
abstract: At 23, Coco Rocha is already beginning to age out of the modeling business. But that’s fine with her (and her 400,000 Twitter followers).

They entered the Coffee Shop, a restaurant in Union Square, and descended to a dimly lighted subterranean lounge with leather banquettes and Champagne buckets filled with mini cartons of coconut water. The girls, most of them around 16 years old, wore shorts and tank tops along with chunky heels and too much eye makeup.

headline: ‘The Waltons’ Meets ‘Modern Family’
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Parenting', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: In August 2010, as my husband and I approached our 50th birthdays, we were suddenly forced to move into my parents’ home in Michigan with our three teenage children and dog.
lead_paragraph: I AM now a statistic. Earlier this summer, the United States Census Bureau reported that the number of adult children living in their parents’ households had increased by 1.2 million between 2007 and 2010. Shared households accounted for 18.7 percent of all American households in 2010, up from 17 percent in 2007. Most of those children were between age 25 and 34, but I had suddenly joined their ranks at a considerably older age.

headline: City Has Sudden Jump in West Nile Cases
abstract: In three days, six new cases were reported in city residents, bringing the number this year to 14, health officials report.
lead_paragraph: Six new cases of West Nile virus were reported in city residents in the last three days, almost as many as in the whole rest of the summer so far, according to the city health department’s Web site. There has been one death, a man in his 80s who had recently traveled outside the city, the department said. The new cases bring the total to 14, three more cases than there were last year.

headline: How Is H.P.’s WebOS Doing? Hundreds  No Longer Work on It
abstract: Hewlett-Packard says its WebOS mobile operating system is still alive and well, and it just released an open-source version of the software. But hundreds of employees who used to work on the project have either switched to new jobs at the company or left to work somewhere else, according to their online profiles.
lead_paragraph: Hewlett-Packard says its WebOS mobile operating system is still alive and well. On Friday it released an early open-source version of the software that will allow outside companies and programmers to use it however they want. But it’s not clear how much muscle H.P. itself is planning to put behind the WebOS effort. Hundreds of employees who used to work on the project have either switched to new jobs at the company or left to work somewhere else, according to their online profiles.

(Translation: a tightly packed situation in which elbows might be useful.) In the midst of the throng, a woman approached two children in the cavernous ground floor space. “I’m going to give you something,” she said. They looked mildly alarmed. Then she added, “Some Shakespeare.”

The delicate wash of blue behind them doesn’t really tell you; the one thing you can say for sure about the animals in Holly Sears’s painting “Hawks” is that they are on the move.

abstract: Alexei Ratmansky’s version of “Cinderella,” danced by Diana Vishneva and the Mariinsky Ballet at the Edinburgh International Festival, reflects the mordant qualities of the Prokofiev score.
lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH — It’s odd to think that in 2002, when Alexei Ratmansky created “Cinderella” for the Mariinsky Ballet in St. Petersburg, he was virtually unknown to Western audiences. A decade and a fast rise to choreographic fame later, Mr. Ratmansky, who is American Ballet Theater’s artist in residence, is frequently described as the most important ballet choreographer working today.

headline: Original Charm Survives a Year of Renovation
abstract: Those who knew the previous iteration of the Old Lyme Inn, which reopened in April, will find a brighter and airier interior, but with a familiar, cozy atmosphere.
lead_paragraph: THE OLD LYME INN reopened in April after a year’s renovation by the couple who now own it, Ken and Chris Kitchings, and it fairly gleams under a glossy coat of white paint. Those who knew the place in its previous incarnation will find the interior brighter, and airier, too. Walls in the three dining areas — the main dining room, the intimate Peterson Room and the bar — have been repainted in shades of white and cream, white oak flooring has replaced dark blue carpets, and a window cut between bar and reception allows additional light.

headline: President Obama Takes Action on Vets’ Mental Health
abstract: There is little doubt about the need to do something to halt the frightening suicide trend among war veterans.
lead_paragraph: Today President Obama signed an executive order to improve mental-health care for service members and veterans, who are killing themselves at alarming and baffling rates. The order affects the Departments of Veterans Affairs, Defense, Health and Human Services, Education and Homeland Security. It calls for things like  more hiring of mental-health professionals, a national suicide-prevention campaign, and a review of existing mental-health and addiction-treatment programs to identify and expand the programs that work well.

headline: An Unblinking Eye on the New West
abstract: A retrospective selection of photographs by Robert Adams is on exhibition at the Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven through Oct. 28.
lead_paragraph: What separates art from politics is that in art, one can simultaneously occupy several positions, sometimes successfully. Take Robert Adams: Artistically somewhat conservative, Mr. Adams is also an ardent environmentalist whose photographs, dating to the 1960s, feel amazingly prescient — often radical — today. You can see this tension running throughout “Robert Adams: The Place We Live, a Retrospective Selection of Photographs,” an exhibition of over 200 photographs at the Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven.

headline: Telluride Film Festival: A Sneak Peek at ‘Argo’
abstract: In keeping with the tradition of surprise screenings at the Telluride Film Festival, Ben Affleck brought his new film, “Argo,” to town unannounced.
lead_paragraph: TELLURIDE, Colo. — Telluride is not exactly a secret film festival— there are enough journalists and publicists here in the San Juan Mountains to get the word out to the masses below — but discretion is among the local traditions. According to custom, the lineup for the 39th edition of the festival was announced only Thursday, 24 hours before the first screenings, and as usual a number of spaces on the schedule were left mysterious, marked TBA. Some of those slots are reserved for “sneaks”—movies that pop into town like sudden thunderstorms — and rumors immediately began to fly about what special extras might be in store this year. Would Clint Eastwood (or at least his new movie, “Trouble With the Curve”) stop by on his way home from Tampa? Would we get a peek at “Cloud Atlas” or “The Master”?

headline: Arizona: Sheriff Will Not Face Criminal Charges
abstract: The state attorney general’s office declined to charge Sheriff Paul Babeu of Pinal County over accusations that he misused his authority to harass and intimidate an ex-boyfriend.
lead_paragraph: The state attorney general’s office declined on Friday to charge Sheriff Paul Babeu of Pinal County, a former co-chairman of Mitt Romney’s presidential campaign in Arizona, over accusations that he misused his authority to harass and intimidate an ex-boyfriend, whom Sheriff Babeu later accused of stealing his online identity. The ex-boyfriend, Jose Orozco, a Mexican immigrant hired by Sheriff Babeu to run the Twitter account and the Web site for his Congressional campaign, also will not face charges over accusations that he improperly manipulated them. Mr. Orozco had accused Sheriff Babeu of threatening to deport him if he made their relationship public, but the authorities said the allegations could not be proved. Mr. Babeu dropped his bid for Congress and is running for re-election instead. He won the primary on Tuesday.

headline: Wyoming: Federal Protections End For Gray Wolves
abstract: Concluding a long effort to take gray wolves in the Northern Rockies off the endangered species list, the federal Fish and Wildlife Service lifted protections for most Wyoming wolves.
lead_paragraph: Concluding a long effort to take the gray wolves in the Northern Rockies off the endangered species list, the federal Fish and Wildlife Service lifted protections for most Wyoming wolves on Friday. The move allows the increased hunting of wolves in Wyoming, where there are about 270 outside Yellowstone National Park. Protections have already been lifted in Montana and Idaho. Major environmental groups immediately protested the move and will most likely sue to block it. They have long maintained that without the protections, hunters and ranchers in the area will kill wolves indiscriminately and ruin one of conservation’s biggest success stories. Ranchers argue that even if the overall cost of wolf attacks on cattle may be small, it can mean the difference between profit and loss in marginal operations.
